Great, I fixed my version and downloaded the code from the 
posted one.  I haven't studied style sheets since I only 
took a 1 credit course on making web pages at PCC.
Thankfully, information from here in the last couple of 
days has added to that.

In C programming I learned to put the literal to the left of 
an equals symbol in a comparison so that if I accidentally 
typed the assignment symbol it wouldn't compile, this saves 
the costly trouble of tracking down a logic error.  A tight 
syntax language probably would have caught my missing tag, 
then again, if a hanging anchor is a valid case it wouldn't
get caught as a syntax error.

BTW:  Anyone checking out ITT tech's new computer forensics/
      network security Bachelor's degree offering?  I don't
      know if ITT tech is accredited where it's not the only
      place I want to check the ratings of considering that
      Sprint may hire me to work in Virginia offering a $5k
      education benefit for taking one or two classes during
      the period of employment.  I'd like to stay in Oregon
      as it's less risky and I avoid the car problem, but
      not knowing what's going on with the economy here
      I don't know how I can.  I'm a debt free college 
      Junior with a general studies degree, but I'm 
      basically broke too.

From root at loraksus.d2g.com  Mon Sep  1 04:42:02 2003
From: root at loraksus.d2g.com (Karl Kulaga)
Date: Mon Sep  1 04:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Seattle Wireless Field Day
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309010333560.11919@server1.kilowatt-radio.org>
Message-ID: <OBENLJCGLBNLOCJDNLOPGECNCHAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>

Well, went, had a lot of fun. - went flying twice - once in my car and once
in the airplane, but the first is a long story. . .

The ground to air to air to ground link never really made it - small
helicopter and no room for a battery for the laptop, so batteries died and
they headed home pretty quick. They had the poor guy in the heli strap all
his equipment to his body with twist ties (so nothing falls out and hits the
rotor) and he didn't have a door on his side. I believe some more pics are
coming, but afaik this is all of them at the moment.
http://students.washington.edu/dejann/karl/
http://www.andrewhitchcock.org/gallery/2003wirelessfieldday

The SW folks did manage to get a link from floor 67 of the Columbia Tower
(the big black building) to alki point relayed to magnolia. A pretty good
distance. I believe speeds dropped down to 2 mbps, but it was a couple miles
line of sight between each, and I don't think our Internet access was that
fast.
A 24db parabolic antenna was set up at the Columbia tower - and Alki
connected with a 15db yagi and was retransmitting through a 24db parabolic
to Magnolia. Pretty good range.
Some more pics here.
http://loraksus.d2g.com/galleries/General/08-31-03/Alki%20Setup.jpg
http://loraksus.d2g.com/galleries/General/08-31-03/Alki%20WFD%202003.jpg

The airborn netstumbler was enlightening. We found "a few" nodes. Over
3000ft agl, there wasn't much that we could receive.
http://seattlewireless.net/misc/war_flying.zip

Equipment for the stumble was a tiny 5 db omni mounted (via magnets and
electrical tape) upside down on the bottom of the plane fed into a 30 mw
Orinoco. We were getting roughly 5-6 ap's a second shortly after takeoff,
but this rate fell off pretty sharply once we achieved the
3-4 thousand foot range. Best part was when we got clearance to circle right
in Boing Field's takeoff path. ATC was diverting 737s, etc around us. t'was
great.
Have a great long weekend.

> enough space on "/" to upgrade. So I used "rpm -e" to erase packages until I had
> enough space.

> japanese translation programs that were somehow installed fell by the roadside
> this way.
>

> gnome, I just haven't. So I removed some gnome files. And apparently, I removed

> talk to evolution; I don't have the menu bar any more and keystrokes don't work
> any more.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Sep  1 14:03:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Sep  1 14:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Jobs to Canada OT (Way Off!)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0308301856040.8615-100000@tetzmedia.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0308301856040.8615-100000@tetzmedia.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011255230.8485@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 30 Aug 2003, Dane P Carver wrote:
> You cannot be charitable with other peoples money. Charity is something
> giving willingly.

You pay taxes willingly.  You assess the consequences and act according to
your will.

Oh, the threat of violence by the state is an act of coersion that removes
your free will?  No shit.

> I have not given the government PERMISSION to take my money and give it
> someone because they 'qualify'.

It's not your money.  The money is a means of exchange provided by the
people of this country (i.e. the government) to ease the trade of goods
and services.  The goods themselves also belong to the people as products
of the land merely converted by the efforts of people from one state to
another, however, for the sake of managing scarcity the people use a
coercive police state to enforce property relations.

> In fact, I would call it enslavement. I am enslaved to government for 5
> months a year and with the passage of state income tax surcharge that is
> a couple more days.

So you are also an anarchist?

I would probably call myself an anarchist, but I also agree with the
statement that in order to be an anarchist one must first be a socialist.
That is to say, in the same sense that we must be eternally vigilant to
retain our liberties in a society with coersion, we must be eternally
vigilant to retain our civilization in a society without a coercive state
(i.e. pull together to prevent the reign of the law of the jungle).

> Again I will state that tax credits to those who do not pay taxes is
> legalized theft or at least possession of stolen property!

Credits to the poor are the very least (literally) that we can do to help
offset the gross injustices of state-enforced property relations.

I highly recommend reading up on the Nixon (yes, THAT Nixon) Negative
Income Tax plan.  If you must retain capitalist ideals and a coercive
state (and you simply cannot have the former without the latter), a system
like that should be in place to help alleviate the suffering caused by the
necessary underemployment.

J.

PS. I'd've sent this privately, but reply-to munging prevents that.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Mon Sep  1 14:50:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon Sep  1 14:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] unable to mount ext3 file system
In-Reply-To: <3794.134.244.174.79.1062224943.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <1625.134.244.174.28.1062216881.squirrel@sautez.com> <1062222747.680.78.camel@farm-libranet> <3794.134.244.174.79.1062224943.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <200309011426.13232.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

On Friday 29 August 2003 23:29, Josh Orchard wrote:
> > Notice all my <device> have a partation # except for cdroms.
> >
> > I have never seen <device> as hdb......
> >
> > Just my $0.02
> >
> > HTH
>
> hmm.  I think I see the errors of my way.  I hate this.
>
> Ok.  For some reason I was able to write to a filesystem that had no
> partitions. So, now I'm starting over.  I have to create partitions then
> run mkfs.ext3 again.
>
> Correct me if I'm wrong.  but for some reason the partitions were never
> created and I have this feeling that will be a bad thing.  And I still have
> 360GB of data to move or so.
>
> Josh

Josh,

No reason to panic.  Drives don't have to have partitions and are perfectly 
happy without them, which means that you can make a filesystem on them and 
access the files without weird consequence.  I can't explain the 
inconsistency in the mount commands on the different systems with authority.  
But it just seems like a quirk of the particular hardware/software 
combination and not a reason for concern.  Maybe the IBM drive controller 
internally treats a drive without partitions as a drive with a single 
partition and the newer version of mount retrieves this information from the 
drive whereas the previous version didn't?

Don't worry,

Mark
-- 
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Mark A. Martin, Ph.D.
Applied Mathematics -- Software Development -- Systems Administration
Currently available for employment.
See http://www.amath.washington.edu/~mmartin/resume/ for details.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Sep  1 17:21:01 2003

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 1 Sep 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> It appears that someone (probably a spam generating virus) send a
> message to dduncan at hexi.com.
>
> His verifier didn't recognized the sending address, and so responded
> with the correct email.
>
> What's not working? Would this not stop most spam from getting to him?

Um, because it WASN'T spam.  It was a legitimate automated message.  And
it didn't get to him.

Forced verification doesn't work because it assumes that legitimate email
only ever comes from a human being who reads replies and responds
intelligently.

J.

seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''



From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Mon Sep  1 23:33:02 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Mon Sep  1 23:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Q: comparison of video formats
Message-ID: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>

I'm having difficulty finding the answers to my questions via the
standard channels.  Most of my Google searches give me sales
websites.  There isn't much on the PLUG archives, except for some
discussion of MPlayer about 6 months ago.

So what I'm trying to do is offload the contents of several DV tapes,
and make a combined video of probably about 45 minutes to an hour,
which would go on a CD-ROM to be copied and distributed to a few dozen
people.  There might be other material on the same CD (e.g., JPEGs
from still pictures, and text).

So what I'm trying to decide is the format I should use.

The DV camera uses IEEE 1394 ("Firewire"), so I was kind of limited on
choice of machines.  My lab has a Windows box with an IEEE 1394 port,
so I just plugged in the camera to see what would happen.  The PC
brought up Microsoft Windows Media Maker, and I was able to download
the movies.  The tool also looks fairly capable.  The biggest downside
is it only produces the proprietary Microsoft WMV format.

Then I installed a CD that came with the DV camera, with its own
tools.  Then I had the choice of producing either AVI or MPEG-1
files.  One annoying problem was that it saves the files in raw DV
format, which is about 25Mb/s, and once the file reaches 4GiB, Windows
(XP) thinks there's no more space, and the program stops downloading
and starts converting what it's got, the result being that my movie is
broken into 19-minute chunks.  Presumably I could merge them back once
they are converted into MPEGs.

So I produced both MPEG-1 and WMV files.  These were fairly low
quality settings.  Both had tons of Moire patterns, jaggies and other
artifacts, but I couldn't see a significant difference between them.
The WMV audio was noticeably worse -- crowd noises seemed to have
strange resonances which I associate with low-bitrate MP3s; maybe some
fiddling with quality settings could fix this.  But what is
significant is that the WMV file was about 20 times smaller!  A 12
minute clip was 9MB in WMV and around 200MB in MPEG-1.

I wouldn't even think about using WMV, as some of the intended
recipients are non-MS users (Linux, Mac or otherwise).  But then I
heard that MPlayer can play WMVs as well.

So my questions are:

1. Does anyone else have experience with WMVs as compared to other
video compression formats?  Is WMV really that much better (in terms
of compression ratio)?  Or am I missing something?  (Perhaps the
Windows Media Player converts the MPEG-1 into WMV before passing it to
the WMV render engine, so they look the same to me, but a native
MPEG-1 decoder would look better?)

2. Are there patent issues with WMV?  Would the Gnuistically-correct
thing to do be to avoid it altogether?

3. If I go with the WMV (for the better compression), how badly am I
screwing my non-MS friends?  Should I just tell them to get MPlayer?
(I've heard differing opinions on how hard it is to get running,
though it seems to have improved.)  Is WMV supported on Macs (or do
they play the same game and just support Quicktime)?

4. Does anyone have experience with Moviex?  I found a website that
mentioned this -- it is MPlayer combined with a minimal Linux setup
that you can use to make a bootable CD-ROM for about 8MB.  (Then
again, people are less likely to bother watching the video if they
need to reboot.)

5. If I stick with MPEG-1, is there a way to make a VCD with "extra
content" (the JPEGs and text files) so that someone can pop it into a
DVD player that understands VCDs, and see the video, but if they pop
it into a computer, they can access the other stuff?

Thanks for your help.

Kevin

(BTW, I'm new to the group -- I went to my first meeting last month.
I'll be speaking on LaTeX when there's a free spot.)



From root at loraksus.d2g.com  Tue Sep  2 00:22:02 2003
From: root at loraksus.d2g.com (Karl Kulaga)
Date: Tue Sep  2 00:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Q: comparison of video formats
In-Reply-To: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>
Message-ID: <OBENLJCGLBNLOCJDNLOPIEDFCHAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>

Ok, a couple of things.
.wmv blows, don't even consider using it if you want anything resembling
quality. PITA for macs too.

re: the 4gb limit - convert the drive to ntfs, that should get rid of that
problem. Of course if this is a dual boot. . .  file size limit is something
like 20,000 terrabytes or some insane amount that you will never be able to
fill (note, this WILL come back to haunt me in 15-20 years)

There is a great program called virtualdub - free and is painfully easy to
use. Runs on windows. Very small.
I'd say capture raw avi, then open the file in virtualdub and compress.
There are a bunch of effects you can do with virtusldub too - check their
website for more goodies. You can capture too, as long as you aren't running
an ati card (because their video in/out chipsets, much like their drivers,
lick the salt off of a harry camel's nutsack, but enough ranting for now. .
. .) You'll probably have to do some work with the sound to make it sync,
but whatever. Or just capture how you are now ;)
Something like xvid 2-pass / divx 5 2-pass will give you quite nice results.
Since you're going for the whole compatibility thing, xvid is probably what
you are going after. Certainly 2 pass. Quality is tons better - a bit more
work, but well worth it.

I'm not sure what resolution you are capturing at either. That info would be
helpful. Basically what I'm saying is that if you're capturing at a greater
resolution than what your output format supports

(i.e. svcd supports 480?480 @ 29.97 fps)
This site is pretty useful.
http://216.239.39.104/search?q=cache:G5Wd7Vn3Z9UJ:www.uwasa.fi/~f76998/video
/svcd/faq/+svcd+resolution&hl=en&ie=UTF-8

4. Does anyone have experience with Moviex?  I found a website that
mentioned this -- it is MPlayer combined with a minimal Linux setup
that you can use to make a bootable CD-ROM for about 8MB.  (Then
again, people are less likely to bother watching the video if they
need to reboot.)
	Sorry, sounds cool though, more info?

5. If I stick with MPEG-1, is there a way to make a VCD with "extra
content" (the JPEGs and text files) so that someone can pop it into a
DVD player that understands VCDs, and see the video, but if they pop
it into a computer, they can access the other stuff?

See the above site. Nero has a plugin.

http://www.divx-digest.com/ has a ton of info, but more related to divx
encoding, a bunch of stuff for burning to dvd via mpeg 2 though, might be
helpful.
The www.dvdrhelp.com forums are sort of helpful.




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep  2 00:52:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Sep  2 00:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Messed up Evolution :(
In-Reply-To: <1062439159.27028.2.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <E19tDbp-0001EW-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <1062437441.1512.15.camel@kat>
	 <1062439159.27028.2.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <1062488887.3662.13.camel@kat>

Heh :)

Try 
  evolution --force-shutdown (or killev if 1.2.X)
  mv ~/evolution ~/old_evolution
  evolution 

There are some debugging ideas, but the above will determine if its an
evolution setting.

mv the directory back when you are done.

You can do the same for .gnome* .gconf* .gtk*

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep  2 00:55:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)

	dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat>

On Mon, 2003-09-01 at 17:21, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Mon, 1 Sep 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > It appears that someone (probably a spam generating virus) send a
> > message to dduncan at hexi.com.
> >
> > His verifier didn't recognized the sending address, and so responded
> > with the correct email.
> >
> > What's not working? Would this not stop most spam from getting to him?
> 
> Um, because it WASN'T spam.  It was a legitimate automated message.  And
> it didn't get to him.
> 

A little more precisely.

Someone subbed to PLUG has a "verify only" spam filter on his account.

The filter will not allow people who have not verified send mail.

PLUG mail has not verified since it is sent from people, or plug-admin.

So PLUG will never be verified.

Of course the question is why did someone set this up and not white list
his mail lists....  But this is what happens.


> Forced verification doesn't work because it assumes that legitimate email
> only ever comes from a human being who reads replies and responds
> intelligently.
> 

It does not work for a bunch of other reasons too, like why should I
jump through *your* hoops.

For a private email address that gets mail from few, known people, who
have the stronger desire to talk to you, than to tell you to f' off, it
works.




> J.

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 12:52:06AM -0700, Zot O'Connor wrote:

Good riddance.  Another challenge-response idiot caught by his own
hubris.

> For a private email address that gets mail from few, known people, who
> have the stronger desire to talk to you, than to tell you to f' off, it
> works.

Most people just look at the verifications and go "but I just sent you
an email" or "Oh, god, another idiot that doesn't realise
using challenge-response makes you a willing part of the spam
problem."  I'm in the latter group:  It breaks reliable transmission
and actively prevents you from reporting spammers.  Seems like it
would be easier and just as effective to use the osirusoft RBL.

From freyley at gmx.net  Tue Sep  2 03:44:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Tue Sep  2 03:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Q: comparison of video formats
In-Reply-To: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>
References: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>
Message-ID: <1062486151.807.23.camel@localhost>

> 1. Does anyone else have experience with WMVs as compared to other
> video compression formats?  Is WMV really that much better (in terms
> of compression ratio)?  Or am I missing something?  (Perhaps the
> Windows Media Player converts the MPEG-1 into WMV before passing it to
> the WMV render engine, so they look the same to me, but a native
> MPEG-1 decoder would look better?)

Yes, sadly, if you're encoding on a windows box and your choice is
between wmv and mpeg1, wmv is going to be a lot smaller. I don't know
why, but wmv seems to be a pretty good codec. Small wmv files usually
look pretty good.

> 2. Are there patent issues with WMV?  Would the Gnuistically-correct
> thing to do be to avoid it altogether?

Yes. It's questionably legal for linux users to use the wmv codec since
it's either using dlls that we don't have a license for or using reverse
engineered codecs that may be illegal under the DMCA. But, this hasn't
been tested in court and isn't likely to be, I don't think.

The best thing to do would be to go looking for more tools on that
machine and try to encode to divx, which is at least cross platform. The
gnuistically correct thing would be to try to find a way to encode to
Ogg Theora, but then any friend but a true techie will be screwed.

Most codecs have patent issues.

> 3. If I go with the WMV (for the better compression), how badly am I
> screwing my non-MS friends?  Should I just tell them to get MPlayer?
> (I've heard differing opinions on how hard it is to get running,
> though it seems to have improved.)  Is WMV supported on Macs (or do
> they play the same game and just support Quicktime)?

I watch wmv files on linux with mplayer or xine, and mac has a windows
media player available for it. I have had wmv files that worked fine in
windows crash mplayer, but I've also had wmv (and others) that worked
well in mplayer crash windows media player. So it's unclear who's the
winner.

> 4. Does anyone have experience with Moviex?  I found a website that
> mentioned this -- it is MPlayer combined with a minimal Linux setup
> that you can use to make a bootable CD-ROM for about 8MB.  (Then
> again, people are less likely to bother watching the video if they
> need to reboot.)

blurp...okay. Or just give them Knoppix which comes with Xine if I'm not
mistaken...

> 5. If I stick with MPEG-1, is there a way to make a VCD with "extra
> content" (the JPEGs and text files) so that someone can pop it into a
> DVD player that understands VCDs, and see the video, but if they pop
> it into a computer, they can access the other stuff?

No idea.

My final thoughts: if the wmv doesn't work on mplayer, mencoder can
sometimes (often) cross-encode it to lavc. I don't know why that is. But
the quality doesn't usually decline, or at least not badly.

Jeff

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Sep  2 07:50:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Sep  2 07:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net> <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat>
Message-ID: <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Zot O'Connor <zot at whiteknighthackers.com> [2003-09-02 00:55]:
> Of course the question is why did someone set this up and not white list
> his mail lists....  But this is what happens.

So what it boils down to is misconfiguration on the part of the user. 

It's not that it "doesn't work"... It's that it has to be set up
correctly. Like every other piece of software on one's system. 

> It does not work for a bunch of other reasons too, like why should I
> jump through *your* hoops.

Um. I disagree with this. Just as I should have control over who calls
my telephone number, I should have control over who can send me email.
If you REALLY want to contact someone, and they require you to verify,
then you'll verify. 

The opposite end of this arguement is "why should I be forced to deal
with your inbound email?"

You are correct in that you don't have to jump through hoops, but then
it's up to YOU as to how important it is to contact said person. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Paul Johnson wrote:
> Email is called email because it equates better to the postal system.
> Anybody can send you mail, that's the whole point.

However, I PAY FOR THE INBOUND BANDWIDTH, so I reserve the right to 
block those I feel need blocking.

Do you employ any spam limiting software? Even rules in your MUA? Then 
what's the difference?

With the USPS, the junk mail senders pay for the postage. There's no 
direct cost to me, beyond sorting through a few (less than 50 a month) 
unwanted advertisements.

With spam, I am currently receiving over 200 per day. I am very nearly 
at my limit and am comptemplating installing a challenge/response filter 
myself.

Here's an idea.. would you mind if I have my MTA forward all spam to 
you? By your own rules, you should happily accept it...

I didn't think so...

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 09:08:59AM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Do you employ any spam limiting software? Even rules in your MUA? Then 
> what's the difference?

You're not making it a pain in the ass for the people you want to mail
you to do so.  That's the important part.  I *won't* subscribe to
someone else's inbox, end of story.  If they want my mail, they get to
operate in an open environment.

> With the USPS, the junk mail senders pay for the postage. 

You pay more to the garbage company to dispose of it than you do
bandwidth for email, yet you somehow find postal junk mail
defensable but legitimate email something to harrangue your
correspondents over.  Cute.  Sure got your priorities straight there.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Sep  2 09:38:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Sep  2 09:38:01 2003

In-Reply-To: <20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net> <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat> <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net> <20030902155000.GA2183@ursine.ca> <3F54C09B.8000408@dimstar.net> <20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net>

Paul Johnson wrote:

>>Do you employ any spam limiting software? Even rules in your MUA? Then 
>>what's the difference?
> 
> 
> You're not making it a pain in the ass for the people you want to mail
> you to do so.  That's the important part.  I *won't* subscribe to
> someone else's inbox, end of story.

Who said anything about you subscribing? I'll write a procmail rule to 
readdress it to you, and then it's your email.

You are the one who stated anyone should be able to send you email. I'm 
simply stating that is no longer a viable paradigm to operate under.

You didn't answer my question. Do you have any spam filtering rules in 
place? Do you use something like spamassassin, or something in your MUA 
to filter spam out of your email?

AND, it's not a pain in the ass to send ONE ADDITIONAL EMAIL to get 
added to the white list. Inconvienent... maybe. Hit reply and send. Two 
keystrokes/mouseclicks. Sounds pretty simple to me. You do this for 
nearly every mail list you subscribe to already.

But, if you can't be bothered to send ONE ADDITIONAL EMAIL, then I 
probably don't want your damned email anyway.

I filter my phone calls with caller id. If it says "Out of area" or 
"Unknown", then I left the answering machine get it. It's my line, and I 
can choose to accept or reject calls as I see fit. Email is exactly the 
same. USPS is the same too. When I sort out junk mail from my postal 
stream, I rarely open the mail that's obviously junk.

> If they want my mail, they get to operate in an open environment.

Maybe they don't want your email? Ever think of that? Either that, or 
it's just not important enough for you to contact that person. 
(Remember, that's ONE ADDITIONAL EMAIL.)

At this point, it's your call if it's important enough. They've already 
made a decision to require validation. That's their right, as they pay 
for the connection to the 'net.

> You pay more to the garbage company to dispose of it than you do
> bandwidth for email, yet you somehow find postal junk mail
> defensable but legitimate email something to harrangue your
> correspondents over.  Cute.  Sure got your priorities straight there.

Actually, no, I don't, recycling is free. I have to have garbage 
service, and the bins don't cost me extra. In fact, I can use a smaller 
waste can because I recycle. You sure thought out that one.

If I lived in Eugene, they DEDUCT from my garbage bill for recycling. 
Almost all junk mail is fully recyclable, and that's exactly where I put 
it.

From cmize at goiter.com  Tue Sep  2 10:32:01 2003
From: cmize at goiter.com (Chuck Mize)
Date: Tue Sep  2 10:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net> <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat> <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net> <20030902155000.GA2183@ursine.ca> <3F54C09B.8000408@dimstar.net> <20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca> <3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <3F54D3D0.4050200@goiter.com>

Russ Johnson wrote:

> AND, it's not a pain in the ass to send ONE ADDITIONAL EMAIL to get 
> added to the white list. Inconvienent... maybe. Hit reply and send. Two 
> keystrokes/mouseclicks. Sounds pretty simple to me. You do this for 
> nearly every mail list you subscribe to already.
> 
> But, if you can't be bothered to send ONE ADDITIONAL EMAIL, then I 
> probably don't want your damned email anyway.

If you are the only one using C/R then he only has to deal with one 
additional email but what if everybody he emails is using it? Also a lot 
of the C/R systems I've looked at have an option to wipe entries in the 
whitelist after a certain amount of time so that you'd have to reconfirm 
yourself.

Also, what do you think happens to the challenges when the spammer 
forges the From: address with a valid address belonging to an innocent 
bystander? All of a sudden they are getting challenge requests from 
people they have never heard from. Sounds abusive to me...

Finally, if enough people actually start using C/R the spammers will 
just alter their spamware to automatically respond to the challenges and 
you'll be in the same place you are now. Right now they are just using a 
forged From: address but all they have to do is open a Yahoo dropbox, 
send out their spam using that dropbox, reply to the challenge requests 
and be on their way to the next spam run.

On Fri, 2003-08-29 at 16:26, chaos at gnutech.com wrote:
> I tend to agree with Rob. I like the analogy, too. I dislike scans
> against my network. Granted, many of them are not directed at me, per
> se, but still. When the scanner has compiled a list of machines from
> an entire subnet for the person to return to, that leads me to believe
> that they have something less than honest in mind.

I don't disagree that getting port-scanned is disagreeable ;)  I simply
don't think it should be a crime.  Criminalizing things because of what
"might" happen or what someone's intent "might" be is extremely
dangerous territory.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Sep  2 11:01:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Sep  2 11:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <3F54D3D0.4050200@goiter.com>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net> <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat> <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net> <20030902155000.GA2183@ursine.ca> <3F54C09B.8000408@dimstar.net> <20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca> <3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net> <3F54D3D0.4050200@goiter.com>
Message-ID: <3F54DA72.9020400@dimstar.net>

Chuck Mize wrote:
> If you are the only one using C/R then he only has to deal with one 
> additional email but what if everybody he emails is using it? 

Then the sender makes a decision. Either it's worth it to contact that 
person, or it's not. If it's not worth it to reply to the challenge, 
then they hit delete, and off they go. No problem.

> Also a lot 
> of the C/R systems I've looked at have an option to wipe entries in the 
> whitelist after a certain amount of time so that you'd have to reconfirm 
> yourself.

And that too is the choice the owner of the mailbox makes. I believe 
these systems also keep track of the time since last email, not just an 
arbitrary time since added to the database. For folks who correspond on 
a regular basis, it's no problem.

> Also, what do you think happens to the challenges when the spammer 
> forges the From: address with a valid address belonging to an innocent 
> bystander? All of a sudden they are getting challenge requests from 
> people they have never heard from. Sounds abusive to me...

No more abusive than the hundreds of sobig.f mails I'm getting per day 
with forged headers, or the "failed clean attempts" I'm getting from NAV 
for mail gateways telling me my linux box tried to infect someone...

We deal with it, because the alternative is we are overrun with junk 
email. If I wasn't blocking mail, then my signal to noise ratio would be 
near 2:10. 2 legitimate emails for every 10 emails received. I kid you 
not. Fully 40% or better is rejected by postfix, and then 70% of what 
gets delivered to me is still junk. I had a personal best the other day 
of 77% of mail was rejected by postfix. That's BEFORE spamassassin got a 
hold of it. Spam sucks, and I'll do many things to reduce it to a 
managable level. That doesn't include a C/R system yet, but I'm close.. 
Real close.

> Finally, if enough people actually start using C/R the spammers will 
> just alter their spamware to automatically respond to the challenges and 
> you'll be in the same place you are now. Right now they are just using a 
> forged From: address but all they have to do is open a Yahoo dropbox, 
> send out their spam using that dropbox, reply to the challenge requests 
> and be on their way to the next spam run.

That is called an arms race. We come up with a solution, and they come 
up with a way around it. We'll come up with something else, and 
eventually, they'll figure out a way to get around that too.

It happens. We will continue down that road. Even laws limiting spam 
would not stop this from happening.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
Home:	http://www.dimstar.net
LDP:	http://ldp.dimstar.net

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep  2 12:28:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Sep  2 12:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for
	dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat>
	 <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1062530670.3546.62.camel@kat>

On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 07:49, Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Zot O'Connor <zot at whiteknighthackers.com> [2003-09-02 00:55]:
> > Of course the question is why did someone set this up and not white list
> > his mail lists....  But this is what happens.
> 
> So what it boils down to is

Snipped oddly on purpose

>  misconfiguration on the part of the user. 
> 
> It's not that it "doesn't work"... 

I would argue if it is so easy to misconfigure, it is broken to begin
with.  The person who misconfigured theirs (who is probably bouncing all
his mail) was [likely] more intelligent than 95% of all the users.

> It's that it has to be set up
> correctly. Like every other piece of software on one's system. 
> 

No, not every piece of software has the potential for blocking main
communications.  Average users cannot configure Word/Openoffice to fubar
email (easily).  Properly written software and systems

> > It does not work for a bunch of other reasons too, like why should I
> > jump through *your* hoops.
> 
> Um. I disagree with this. 

> Just as I should have control over who calls
> my telephone number, 

I am a bit shocked no one has called you out on this.  This is just flat
out false.  You have extraordinarily little control over who calls your 
phone.  You only have two choices, refuse to answer the line (as you
mentioned in a later email using an answering machine), or follow a
punitive path (sue based on the do not call list).
 
> I should have control over who can send me email.

Think about that statement more.  It is really dumb.  This is a complete
failure to understand the design criteria of communications systems.

You might say "I should have control over which mails I read" which is a
HUGE difference (I give an example below).


> If you REALLY want to contact someone, and they require you to verify,
> then you'll verify. 

Again you fail to understand communication design.  You are assume the
sender is the most active component in terms of desired communication. 
This is simply not true.  Its about 50/50 (sender/receiver) at best, and
more often than not the receiver wants the communication more than the
sender.  How can I make such a bold statement?  The receiver would not
be receiving messages (for any system) unless there was a desire for the
message.  If we did not like TV programs so much, we would not get
commercials.  We desire to watch more than the people who write the
shows desire to send.  When we detest the commercials so much (fairly
rare) we pay extra (HBO/Rental/Record and zap).


> 
> The opposite end of this arguement is "why should I be forced to deal
> with your inbound email?"
> 
> You are correct in that you don't have to jump through hoops, but then
> it's up to YOU as to how important it is to contact said person.

No, you have set up a bunch of false assumptions as I mentioned above. 
In this particular case, the sender(s) (the LIST) couldn't give a rat's
ass over the person receiving the mail.  Do not think that everyone who
emails you wants to desperately contact you.

Let's look at some simple examples:

A HOT GEEK GIRL, after just beating up Ed, sends you and email
expressing her agreement to meet you (you sent her a request).  Then
heads out.  Your email blocks her.  She goes out with Eric instead (hey
this is all made up).

You enter a contest at the local car dealership.  You give them your
email.  Later you win the prize.  They send an email, get a bounce, and
then pick the next name.

You email tech support for a company.  They reply with a no-response
email to you (common).  You never see the note.

You apply for a job.  An automated system sends a note that your resume
did not load properly, or you need to specify a field.  You never get
the note since the return address gets piled into a return box, or to
/dev/null.

Your friend writes a long email that you want to read and sends it from
a temporary account.  You never get the mail.

You bid on an auction item.  Ebay sends a note that you are now losing
and you must act in minutes to up your bid.  You never get the note.

--------

This are all real examples I can pull from recent emails (OK, like The
HOT GEEK GIRL would go out with Eric).

BTW I also picked things that may get filtered by SPAM filters as well.

The difference for spam filters and Challenge/Response seems to be
people expect SPAM filters to fail.  I would not mind Challenge/Response
that put un-authenticated messages into a bin and you whitelist as you
go.  But then why have Challenge/Response?  You have a spam filter with
a draconian whitelist filter.  The difference is *you* (the receiver) do
the hoop jumping, and now, you have complete control over *your main
INBOX.*

Another major difference is where does the mail sit when in limbo.  If
you have challenge/response and a MUA whitelist feature, how do they
work together.


>From a future email:

> I filter my phone calls with caller id. If it says "Out of area" or 
> "Unknown", then I left the answering machine get it. It's my line,
> and I can choose to accept or reject calls as I see fit.

The big difference is that you are accepting the call in full.  The
answering machine did not drop the call, you can still pick it up.

My brother does this, and it catches when I call him while I am roaming
on my cell phone, which then looks out of area.

> Actually, no, I don't, recycling is free. 

Umm, this is not related, but this is simply not true.  recycling may be
paid for by other means (trash fees, taxes, etc.).  But it is not
free.   Occasionally it breaks even or makes a profit somewhere down the
line, but it is not free for pickup costs, or processing costs.

Or if you truly believe that it is free,  I suppose, in your "send SPAM
to you vein" we could all send you our recycling, and then watch you
process it for free.

 
-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

> not. Fully 40% or better is rejected by postfix, and then 70% of what

> Real close.

You get no argument from me about the dire situation email is in due to 
the spam problem but don't use a solution that perpetuates abuse.




From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Sep  2 13:26:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Sep  2 13:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for	dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <1062530670.3546.62.camel@kat>
References: <1062436126.1512.13.camel@kat> <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net>	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net>	 <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat>	 <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1062530670.3546.62.camel@kat>
Message-ID: <3F54FC65.1000600@dimstar.net>

Zot O'Connor wrote:
> I would argue if it is so easy to misconfigure, it is broken to begin
> with.  

That's a judgement call, and one I don't share. Lots of software, easily 
misconfigured, can fubar something else.

> The person who misconfigured theirs (who is probably bouncing all
> his mail) was [likely] more intelligent than 95% of all the users.

You are assuming this, so it's a spurious argument.

> I am a bit shocked no one has called you out on this.  This is just flat
> out false.  You have extraordinarily little control over who calls your 
> phone.  You only have two choices, refuse to answer the line (as you
> mentioned in a later email using an answering machine), or follow a
> punitive path (sue based on the do not call list).

Now you are splitting hairs. I would argue that they haven't completed a 
phone call unless I picked up. If I don't pick up, they have attempted, 
nothing more.

If they hang up during the outbound message, then I count that as an 
incompleted phone call as well. My machine doesn't count it, since 
there's no message.

>>I should have control over who can send me email.
> 
> 
> Think about that statement more.  It is really dumb.  This is a complete
> failure to understand the design criteria of communications systems.

OK, I'll refrase. I should have control over who can DELIVER email to my 
system. They can try to send all they want. But I reserve the right to 
close the door and block them. In fact, I'm doing so, right now. Certain 
IP addresses are blocked from connecting on port 25 to my system.

> Again you fail to understand communication design.  You are assume the
> sender is the most active component in terms of desired communication. 
> This is simply not true.  Its about 50/50 (sender/receiver) at best, and
> more often than not the receiver wants the communication more than the
> sender.

Then the reciever will configure the software so the sender doesn't get 
a C/R.

In reality, what difference does all this make? Some folks will use C/R 
software. When they do, they have made a decision to block mail from 
unknown parties (similar to bouncing email from systems that don't 
reverse resolve). If you choose to not participate, then you BOTH lose.

> How can I make such a bold statement?  The receiver would not
> be receiving messages (for any system) unless there was a desire for the
> message.

This is more argument to install the software correctly, and to make 
sure you update it when you request mail from a source that can't 
respond to the C/R.

> No, you have set up a bunch of false assumptions as I mentioned above. 
> In this particular case, the sender(s) (the LIST) couldn't give a rat's
> ass over the person receiving the mail.  Do not think that everyone who
> emails you wants to desperately contact you.

I'm not. I'm assuming that when YOU write an email directly to me, YOU 
desire to send information to me. If I've never communicating with you 
previously, I have no stake in the matter. So at this point, the ratio 
is 100:0.

If we've previously communicated, then the ratio is different. Depending 
on how much I want to receive mail from you, I may add you to my white 
list. If I don't want to receive from you, or don't care one way or the 
other, then I'd probably leave it alone until YOU initiate contact. 
Until that time, the receiver doesn't care.

> This are all real examples I can pull from recent emails (OK, like The
> HOT GEEK GIRL would go out with Eric).

And they are possible. No one said that managing this would start out easy.

These are also things that can be tuned.

> Another major difference is where does the mail sit when in limbo.  If
> you have challenge/response and a MUA whitelist feature, how do they
> work together.

I don't know, and that's a good question. Either the mail is delivered 
anyway, and the response simply flags future messages to not be 
processed, or the program holds it, pending a response.

Personally, I still have spam delivered to a special folder on my 
system, because I do get false positives. I would probably impliment the 
former, so I could verify "bad messages".

>>I filter my phone calls with caller id. If it says "Out of area" or 
>>"Unknown", then I left the answering machine get it. It's my line,
>>and I can choose to accept or reject calls as I see fit.
> 
> 
> The big difference is that you are accepting the call in full.  The
> answering machine did not drop the call, you can still pick it up.
> 
> My brother does this, and it catches when I call him while I am roaming
> on my cell phone, which then looks out of area.

I figure if someone wants to talk to me without talking to my machine 
first, they'll let me know who they are during the ringing.

I haven't had an out of area call in the last month that didn't hang up 
before the machine spits out it's default message.

I don't even have a customized message. It's just, "Hello, please leave 
a message, after the beep.". Usually, they hang up after the word 
"message".


>>Actually, no, I don't, recycling is free. 
> 
> Umm, this is not related, but this is simply not true.  recycling may be
> paid for by other means (trash fees, taxes, etc.).  But it is not
> free.   Occasionally it breaks even or makes a profit somewhere down the
> line, but it is not free for pickup costs, or processing costs.

OK, here's the deal. I *HAVE* to have garbage service. The recycle bins 
do not cost any extra. SO, when it comes to MY WALLET, and how much I 
SPEND, it's free.

In fact, I can make an arguement that it SAVES ME MONEY, since I can use 
and pay less for a smaller garbage can because I recycle.

So, in reality, recycling isn't free. It pays me.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
Home:	http://www.dimstar.net
LDP:	http://ldp.dimstar.net




From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Sep  2 13:46:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Tue Sep  2 13:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for
 dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <3F54FC65.1000600@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0309021331570.13883-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

Ok, guys, let it rest. It's not an issue of understanding the "nature of
communications", it's an issue of personal approach to communicating.
People fall into two cathegories.
If I belong to the first type, when I get an unknown message, I think
"Hey, someone wants to talk to me, cool. Odds are they have something
interesting to say".
If I belong to the second type, then when I get an unexpected message I
think "What a bother. Odds are I don't want to talk to you anyway" (and
before someone asks why does such person even join the 'net, they do have
people they know and want to communicate with, they just don't want to get
to know anyone else).
Well, there is also the third type, wackos who believe that communicating
with them is the path to salvation for the rest of the world, but I'll
neglect that group for now.

Zot and Russ seem to belong to two different types, at least as far as
their electronic communication stype is concerned. Neither is wrong. Some
people go an extra mile to TALK to others, other do the same to AVOID
TALKING to others. When the opposing types meet, they don't understand why
in the world would the other guy choose to live the way he does,
conclude that it must be because he has't considered the alternative
(since it's obviously wrong to do things the other way, and nobody does
wrong willingly) and try to explain him the error of his ways.

BTW, if you missed the heavy dose of saracsm and exaggeration in the last
paragraph, the indignant comments you are about to send my way fall into
the cathegory of things I don't want to read.

Fedor

From dduncan at hexi.com  Tue Sep  2 14:49:02 2003
From: dduncan at hexi.com (David Duncan)
Date: Tue Sep  2 14:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Bad 'Whitelist' Event (was Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0309021331570.13883-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.04.10309021346590.18351-100000@aqua.hexi.com>

I regret that problems on my system set off the wave of people calling
each other names, though it did raise some interesting points and exposed
some rather unexpected world-views.

As the contrite fire-starter, I'll refrain from direct retorts and just
report what happened.  I hope it has some educational value, or at least
gives some closure to those who became upset.

I've been using a procmail-based white-listing system for over a year,
since my spam-rate hit 4 per hour.  

I've been subscribed to this mailing list for a couple of years.

In just the 3 hours since I fixed my mail problem (described below), the
system blocked spam from 82 distinct 'from' addresses, i.e. 27 new
spammers per hour.  Ugh.

The whitelist system: Nic Wolff's 'procmail accept list' as posted at
http://angel.net/~nic/spam-x/


This system keeps 4 lists...  

 * An 'accept' list of OK senders (people who answered the 
   auto-generated message for previously unknown senders).

 * A 'deny' list of senders whose mail is to be quietly 
   discarded (manually updated, basically only effective 
   against non-pro spammers who actually use their real address)

 * An 'OK mailing lists' (manually updated, inside procmail script itself)

 * An 'OK domain' (manually updated, inside procmail script itself)


How it works normally works when email comes in:

 * The script determines the sender's email address by using 
   'formail' to create a reply header and extracting the 'To:'
   address that formail comes up with.

 * If the sender is on the 'deny' list, the mail is quietly
   discarded. Done.

 * If the subject line is 'Accept [sender's email address] for 
   [my email address]' then all prior email from this sender is
   delivered, the sender is added to the 'accept' list, and the
   challenge response itself, having served it's purpose, is
   discarded. Done.

 * If the sender's email is on the accept list, or is part of 
   an OK domain, or if the mail is addressed to an OK mailing list,
   then it is delivered to the user's inbox. Done.

 * If the mail hasn't been delt with by this point, then it 
   must be from a new address.  Check if any messages are 
   already cached from that address in a pending_messages 
   directory: if not, then send out the 'challenge' message.
   In any case, cache the current message.

The final part of the system is a cron job that deletes any cache files
more than 6 days old.


Here's why PLUG suddenly got a white-list challenge:

The rate and average size of spam email had increased so much that even a
6 day supply of spam was enough to fill up the entire /home partition...
Ouch.  

I'll be reviewing the 'spam' issue again and deciding if I need to tune my
rules or try a new system.  Suggestions on practical alternatives to the
challenge-response system would be appreciated.


- David






From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Tue Sep  2 15:17:02 2003

-Russ



From dpool at hevanet.com  Tue Sep  2 15:34:02 2003

David Duncan wrote:

> This system keeps 4 lists...  

I think we need to get away from filtering at the end user level. I 
don't mind doing challenge and response a couple of times. But I don't 
see it as a cure all.

I'd rather have a white list that is run collaboratively with a 
community I trust, like the PLUG. I mean, for the most part, if someone 
on this list is willing to put someone on an OK list I'm willing to 
accept that, at least provisionally.

david

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Sep  2 16:22:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Sep  2 16:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>
References: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309021617470.11506@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 2 Sep 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:

> Is there a database system similar to MS Access on Linux?

Holgar,

  Gag! Gak! NO! Access is a flat-file database. Very limited.

> Or, better, something that runs on Linux and Windows?

  Two that I can recommend: PostgreSQL and SQLite. The former is a standard
that approaches (or meets) the power of Oracle -- without the marketing hype
or cost. The latter is a SQL library that can be used for your own
applications, particularly embedded ones. Both GPL; both run on cygwin on
Microsoft. SQLite may have a native Winduhs port, but since I pay no
attention to such things I may be wrong.

Rich

                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Sep  2 16:24:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Sep  2 16:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>
References: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>
Message-ID: <1062544261.642.28.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 16:20, Holger Stephan wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> Is there a database system similar to MS Access on Linux? Or, better, 
> something that runs on Linux and Windows?

OpenOffice.org can use ODBC backends and design forms and such like
Access.  I haven't any idea of how it compares, since I've never really
used Access and just got it set up enough to see that it worked.

PgAccess is something kinda like that for Postgresql.

Slightly lower-level, GNUe has Forms database components.

I've also heard that you can connect Access as a front-end through ODBC
to SQL servers, which will at least get your data out of a closed
format.

Wil

From v_yau2 at hotmail.com  Tue Sep  2 17:38:01 2003
From: v_yau2 at hotmail.com (Vincent Yau)

Subject: [PLUG] Video card with TV Out
Message-ID: <Sea2-F69nXg3A8c04gA0002bca4@hotmail.com>

Dear All:

from my Linux box directly to my TV.  Most likely, I will be using Xine or

that has has good Linux support from the vendor?  I am not up with all the 
latest

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Sep  2 18:54:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue Sep  2 18:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Q: comparison of video formats
In-Reply-To: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>
References: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>
Message-ID: <1062553974.3672.10.camel@localhost>

On Mon, 2003-09-01 at 23:41, Kevin Theobald wrote:
> I'm having difficulty finding the answers to my questions via the
> standard channels.  Most of my Google searches give me sales
> websites.  There isn't much on the PLUG archives, except for some
> discussion of MPlayer about 6 months ago.

Mid-March?  Might be the thread where I was trying to figure out how to
nicely encode TV shows to fit two hours on a CD.  :-)

> So what I'm trying to do is offload the contents of several DV tapes,
> and make a combined video of probably about 45 minutes to an hour,
> which would go on a CD-ROM to be copied and distributed to a few dozen
> people.  There might be other material on the same CD (e.g., JPEGs
> from still pictures, and text).

That sounds cool.  You can get some very high quality stuff when you go
to about 600MB/hour.

> So what I'm trying to decide is the format I should use.

divx.

> The DV camera uses IEEE 1394 ("Firewire"), so I was kind of limited on
> choice of machines.  My lab has a Windows box with an IEEE 1394 port,
> so I just plugged in the camera to see what would happen.  The PC
> brought up Microsoft Windows Media Maker, and I was able to download
> the movies.  The tool also looks fairly capable.  The biggest downside
> is it only produces the proprietary Microsoft WMV format.

WMV... in my experience, it is easy to view in Linux, but it sucks in
the quality department.  If you're going for very small files (ie;
500KB/minute) it seems to be top-dog in the quality department.  If you
want medium sized files, it sucks compared to divx, et al.

> Then I installed a CD that came with the DV camera, with its own
> tools.  Then I had the choice of producing either AVI or MPEG-1
> files.  One annoying problem was that it saves the files in raw DV
> format, which is about 25Mb/s, and once the file reaches 4GiB, Windows
> (XP) thinks there's no more space, and the program stops downloading
> and starts converting what it's got, the result being that my movie is
> broken into 19-minute chunks.  Presumably I could merge them back once
> they are converted into MPEGs.

Ok... is there a Linux alternative to grabbing the video?  Or if you can
deal with storing 60 minutes at 25Mb/sec (I assume you mean megabyte,
not bit)... that's about 67GB/hour... I *think* you can just 
cat file2.avi >> file1.avi then encode that with mencoder to a nice divx
format.

> 1. Does anyone else have experience with WMVs as compared to other
> video compression formats?  Is WMV really that much better (in terms
> of compression ratio)?  Or am I missing something?  (Perhaps the
> Windows Media Player converts the MPEG-1 into WMV before passing it to
> the WMV render engine, so they look the same to me, but a native
> MPEG-1 decoder would look better?)

At super-low quality settings, WMV wins.  Otherwise, it loses.

> 2. Are there patent issues with WMV?  Would the Gnuistically-correct
> thing to do be to avoid it altogether?

As somebody else said, there are probably patent issues with *all* the
video formats... except that Ogg one he mentioned (and I haven't tried
yet).

> 3. If I go with the WMV (for the better compression), how badly am I
> screwing my non-MS friends?  Should I just tell them to get MPlayer?
> (I've heard differing opinions on how hard it is to get running,
> though it seems to have improved.)  Is WMV supported on Macs (or do
> they play the same game and just support Quicktime)?

mplayer is really pretty easy to get.  If they're in a binary distro,
they should find binary packages available... if not, it is a fairly
easy compile.  If they're in a source-based distro, they can get some
cool mplayer-ness... or build it their own, regardless.

> 4. Does anyone have experience with Moviex?  I found a website that
> mentioned this -- it is MPlayer combined with a minimal Linux setup
> that you can use to make a bootable CD-ROM for about 8MB.  (Then
> again, people are less likely to bother watching the video if they
> need to reboot.)

Never heard of it...

> 5. If I stick with MPEG-1, is there a way to make a VCD with "extra
> content" (the JPEGs and text files) so that someone can pop it into a
> DVD player that understands VCDs, and see the video, but if they pop
> it into a computer, they can access the other stuff?

I dunno... never played with VCD itself.  In my experience (a few years
old) VCDs are hard to play in computers... finding a reader in Linux was
a PITA.

If you decide you want to go the mencoder route, from Linux... I can
help you fine-tune some 2 pass encoding parameters for decent quality. 
I spent quite a bit of time fine-tuning my TV recording scripts to give
me the quality/size ratio I was looking for.

I use 2-pass divx encoding to encode TV shows... after they're encoded
and all done (with about 3 hours of CPU time put in for one hour of TV)
they're about 300MB an hour with about the same level of quality you'll
get out of an antenna and a VCR, I think.

Rob




From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Tue Sep  2 19:47:01 2003
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Tue Sep  2 19:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
Message-ID: <3F5555E7.30309@adnap.no-ip.com>

Hello.

I am in the process of configuring CVS on my server. I am not using CVS 
for any reason other than it's the only thing I had heard of in the open 
source area. Here are my requirements for the source control system:

1. It must have a simple interface. WinCVS works fine, but command line 
tools won't suffice (it will be used by other people that do not have 
(or want to have) any linux experience).

2. Users must be able to access it over the internet, and they must be 
able to access it *securely*. I want both the passwords and data 
exchanged over the network AND my system as a whole to be secure.  I'd 
like to give the users as little capability on the system as possible 
(i.e. no command line).

3. I must be able to install it on my RedHat 7.3 without disrupting too 
much existing stuff. The most important things are apache, sendmail, 
gnu-pop3d, and ssh (SFTP in particular).

I have set up CVS on my system, using SSH as the access protocol. If I 
stay with this setup, I will need some sort of shell to allow only CVS 
and SFTP access. I have been so far unsuccessful in finding such a program.

Assuming I stick with CVS, I have the following question:

How can I add a module to the list of modules? I can import modules just 
fine, and I can checkout a module if I know the name of it. But if I 
don't know the name of it, the command 'cvs checkout -c' produces no 
output and the only way I can get a list of modules is to look at the 
repository directory.

Thanks!
Evan






From holger at selover.net  Tue Sep  2 19:54:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue Sep  2 19:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <1062544261.642.28.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net> <1062544261.642.28.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <3F555917.9020206@selover.net>

Thanks Wil and Rich!

I'll look into the stuff you suggested.

BTW, it is true that you can connect Access to a SQL back-end. Either 
through ODBC or ADO. The Access back-end is not far from being SQL 
conform and the export is pretty straight-forward. Not too much of a 
closed format there really.

It just so that you can develop little db aware business applications 
blazingly fast with Access. My business partner is on Windows and I am 
on Linux.

Holger

Wil Cooley wrote:

>On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 16:20, Holger Stephan wrote:
>  
>
>>Hi,
>>
>>Is there a database system similar to MS Access on Linux? Or, better, 
>>something that runs on Linux and Windows?
>>    
>>
>
>OpenOffice.org can use ODBC backends and design forms and such like
>Access.  I haven't any idea of how it compares, since I've never really
>used Access and just got it set up enough to see that it worked.
>
>PgAccess is something kinda like that for Postgresql.
>
>Slightly lower-level, GNUe has Forms database components.
>
>I've also heard that you can connect Access as a front-end through ODBC
>to SQL servers, which will at least get your data out of a closed
>format.
>
>Wil
>  
>




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Sep  2 20:19:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Sep  2 20:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
In-Reply-To: <3F5555E7.30309@adnap.no-ip.com>
References: <3F5555E7.30309@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <3F555D68.3060603@pacifier.com>

Evan Heidtmann wrote:

> I am in the process of configuring CVS on my server. I am not using CVS 
> for any reason other than it's the only thing I had heard of in the open 
> source area. Here are my requirements for the source control system:
> 
> 1. It must have a simple interface. WinCVS works fine, but command line 
> tools won't suffice (it will be used by other people that do not have 
> (or want to have) any linux experience).

TkCVS works great on win and Linux, you need to install tk on the windows 
machines.  Should already have tk on Linux.
http://www.twobarleycorns.net/tkcvs.html


> 
> 2. Users must be able to access it over the internet, and they must be 
> able to access it *securely*. I want both the passwords and data 
> exchanged over the network AND my system as a whole to be secure.  I'd 
> like to give the users as little capability on the system as possible 
> (i.e. no command line).

$ grep cvs /etc/services
you should see that cvspserver is setup on port 2401

> 
> 3. I must be able to install it on my RedHat 7.3 without disrupting too 
> much existing stuff. The most important things are apache, sendmail, 
> gnu-pop3d, and ssh (SFTP in particular).

cvs is very non-intrusive, it won't be a problem.  Just make sure you give 
the repository plenty of space.  /usr/local/cvs is a common location.


> I have set up CVS on my system, using SSH as the access protocol. If I 
> stay with this setup, I will need some sort of shell to allow only CVS 
> and SFTP access. I have been so far unsuccessful in finding such a program.

create a new group 'cvsusers' and set the default shell to /bin/false

> Assuming I stick with CVS, I have the following question:
> 
> How can I add a module to the list of modules? I can import modules just 
> fine, and I can checkout a module if I know the name of it. But if I 
> don't know the name of it, the command 'cvs checkout -c' produces no 
> output and the only way I can get a list of modules is to look at the 
> repository directory.

TkCVS makes it much easier to work with modules.  Last time I used it you 
had to co CVSROOT and edit 'modules' to add an alias though.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)

			Software RAID on Linux

				  by

			     Fedor Pikus
		      <fedor_pikus at mentorg.com>

      Fedor will give a talk about Software RAID under Linux,
      with practical demonstration of different types of raid
      and their reaction to failing disks, reconstruction, etc.

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Tue Sep  2 21:02:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Tue Sep  2 21:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Bad 'Whitelist' Event (was Verify
	plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org)
In-Reply-To: <3F551AB3.4090700@hevanet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.04.10309021346590.18351-100000@aqua.hexi.com> 
	<3F551AB3.4090700@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <1062561638.9468.169.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 15:33, david pool wrote:
> David Duncan wrote:
> 
> > This system keeps 4 lists...  
> 
> I think we need to get away from filtering at the end user level. I 
> don't mind doing challenge and response a couple of times. But I don't 
> see it as a cure all.
> 
> I'd rather have a white list that is run collaboratively with a 
> community I trust, like the PLUG. I mean, for the most part, if someone 
> on this list is willing to put someone on an OK list I'm willing to 
> accept that, at least provisionally.
> 
> david
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug


Isn't the secret to rate mail based
on volume it is being sent out at so 
that it can be trapped at the ISP 
level if it exceeds what is likely 
legitimate?  

The other thing I'd like to see are 
ISP's catching worms and viruses.  
Without violating people's privacy, 
it should be possible to scan email 
data and other data for obvious 
viruses and worms at the 
intermediary routers affecting 
slowing certain types of attacks.

Probably the largest problem is that 
Winduhs does not protect software 
programs from Trojans and other 
malicious data.  I think the easy
hijacking of computers is the most 
integral part of the denial of service 
problem.

There has been some news that software
liability will become more important
after related court actions.  If it
means that Microsoft and others become
liable for selling any software that 
is easily cracked or has glaring 
security holes, that's probably 
a good thing.

An interesting history note is that
mail used to cost the receiver and
not the sender.  The latter is why
Thomas Jefferson wanted to receive 
less mail in his later years.

     --  Michael

Even if it was running, the lack of encryption of both passwords and 
data does not fit my needs.  I have heard of sserver, and I'm willing to 
try it if ssh falls through.

>> I have set up CVS on my system, using SSH as the access protocol. If 
>> I stay with this setup, I will need some sort of shell to allow only

allow SFTP connections.  I already have rssh, which does the job just 
great but doesn't allow anything other than SFTP (including CVS).

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Tue Sep  2 22:15:02 2003
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Tue Sep  2 22:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Logging STDOUT to file
Message-ID: <3F557880.4070600@adnap.no-ip.com>

Hello everyone,

I am looking for a way to have everything I see on the screen sent to a 
file at the same time that it is displayed. In other words, I want to 
log all screen output to a file.

I was alerted to the possiblity of such functionality by a very old 
Tektronix document describing how to do it on their UNIX system:

Sends screen output to printer

1. Login to your account
2. Assign *filename* sys$output
3. Type out your commands
4. Deassign sys$output
5. Print *filename*

The assign and deassign commands were ass and deass and had something to 
do with tape drives.  They do not exist on my system.

If the above system worked, all I would need would be steps 1-4.

Thanks,
Evan




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Sep  2 22:20:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Sep  2 22:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
In-Reply-To: <3F556A14.3020907@adnap.no-ip.com>

Message-ID: <3F5579D8.50604@pacifier.com>

Evan Heidtmann wrote:

> cvspserver is indeed listed in /etc/services. It is, however, not running.
> Even if it was running, the lack of encryption of both passwords and 
> data does not fit my needs.  I have heard of sserver, and I'm willing to 
> try it if ssh falls through.


You should be able to tunnel through ssh--not my speciality, but this looks 
good,
http://www.idealx.org/prj/idx-chrooted-ssh-cvs/dist/chrooted-ssh-cvs-server.html
and
http://hpcf.nersc.gov/software/tools/cvs.html


> I'm not sure of the best way to deal with groups and /bin/false does not 
> allow SFTP connections.  I already have rssh, which does the job just 
> great but doesn't allow anything other than SFTP (including CVS).


An ssh tunnel should help here too.


Looks like lots of folks have done similiar things so it should be doable, 
google 'cvs tunneled ssh'

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From boro at borosenclave.com  Tue Sep  2 22:21:02 2003
From: boro at borosenclave.com (borodimer)
Date: Tue Sep  2 22:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
References: <3F5555E7.30309@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <001401c371da$f2dd3b60$0d000d0a@borolan>

Hey,

This is just a plug for a very simple CVS utility called TortoiseCVS
(http://www.tortoisecvs.org/).  I have used it quite extensively both at
home and the office, and have found it to be the simplest way to work with
data in CVS.  If you are going to use CVS in an environment where the
simpler the better, give Tortoise a look.

  - Phil

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Tue Sep  2 22:41:02 2003
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue Sep  2 22:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
In-Reply-To: <3F5555E7.30309@adnap.no-ip.com>
References: <3F5555E7.30309@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <200309022240.19889.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Tuesday 02 September 2003 19:45 pm, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> Hello.
>
> I am in the process of configuring CVS on my server. I am not using
> CVS for any reason other than it's the only thing I had heard of in
> the open source area. Here are my requirements for the source control
> system:
>
> 1. It must have a simple interface. WinCVS works fine, but command
> line tools won't suffice (it will be used by other people that do not
> have (or want to have) any linux experience).
>

For Linux I use the "gcvs" client which is a GTK+ interface written by 
the same group that does WinCVS. We use use WinCVS on Windows clients 
and either "gcvs" or command-line "cvs" on our Linux systems. "gcvs" 
isn't quite the same as WinCVS but it's similar enough. I mainly use 
"gcvs" for browing code snapshots on my system and then use emacs as my 
real CVS client when I'm actively cutting code and commiting changes to 
the repository.

> 2. Users must be able to access it over the internet, and they must
> be able to access it *securely*. I want both the passwords and data
> exchanged over the network AND my system as a whole to be secure. 
> I'd like to give the users as little capability on the system as
> possible (i.e. no command line).
>

> 3. I must be able to install it on my RedHat 7.3 without disrupting
> too much existing stuff. The most important things are apache,
> sendmail, gnu-pop3d, and ssh (SFTP in particular).
>
> I have set up CVS on my system, using SSH as the access protocol. If
> I stay with this setup, I will need some sort of shell to allow only
> CVS and SFTP access. I have been so far unsuccessful in finding such
> a program.
>
> Assuming I stick with CVS, I have the following question:
>
> How can I add a module to the list of modules? I can import modules
> just fine, and I can checkout a module if I know the name of it. But
> if I don't know the name of it, the command 'cvs checkout -c'
> produces no output and the only way I can get a list of modules is to
> look at the repository directory.
>
> Thanks!
> Evan
>
>
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net




From jorgens at coho.net  Tue Sep  2 22:47:01 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Tue Sep  2 22:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
Message-ID: <01C371A4.859A6810.jorgens@coho.net>

On Tuesday, September 02, 2003 4:21 PM, Rich Shepard 
[SMTP:rshepard at appl-ecosys.com] wrote:
> On Tue, 2 Sep 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:
>
> > Is there a database system similar to MS Access on Linux?
>
> Holgar,
>
>   Gag! Gak! NO! Access is a flat-file database. Very limited.
>
> > Or, better, something that runs on Linux and Windows?
>
>   Two that I can recommend: PostgreSQL and SQLite. The former is a 
standard
> that approaches (or meets) the power of Oracle -- without the marketing 
hype
> or cost. The latter is a SQL library that can be used for your own
> applications, particularly embedded ones. Both GPL; both run on cygwin on
> Microsoft. SQLite may have a native Winduhs port, but since I pay no
> attention to such things I may be wrong.

As an Access developer (yes, I know, MS is evil, but Access what I've 
become good at, and it's catually a good product), I must beg to differ. 
 Access/JET is certainly a relational database, not a flat file database. 
 Access enforces relational integrity, supports transactions, rollbacks, 
etc.  What Access is not is a Database server, though it makes a perfectly 
good front-end for a database server.  Not only do I think Access is great, 
I was, for a while, heavily involved in an attempt to create a GPL, 
multi-platform replacement system.

The closest things to Access I have found in my wanderings appear to be 
Meargent (part of the GNOME office project) and pgSQL, though the latter 
works only with a PostgreSQL back-end.

Now, regarding whether a database server is superior to a client-based 
database engine with file shareing, there are cases where the file sharing 
system is superior.  Those are the cases where you need a database, but you 
don't need the hassle of installing a server or hiring a DBA.  You can copy 
your database file onto a CD, take it home, and open it up.  You don't have 
to create a backup, go home, log into your server as an administrator, 
create a database instance, decide where to put your log files, etc., then 
restore from the backup, ...




From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Tue Sep  2 22:52:02 2003

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep  2 23:39:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Sep  2 23:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>
References: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>
Message-ID: <1062569686.4422.34.camel@kat>

On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 16:20, Holger Stephan wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> Is there a database system similar to MS Access on Linux? Or, better, 
> something that runs on Linux and Windows?
> 

You want to state your requirements a bit better.

MS Access is many things to many people.

It is a forms/UI/DB application thingy.  It can be used to make a pretty
darn good app to interact with a DB (any ODBC connection).  It is not
stateless like the web, so it can do some real interaction with the DB. 
It is quick and easy.  It ports fairly well to VB and Visual C.  It is
hard to beat for non-DB programmers for creating quick and dirty DB
thingies.  So this part has a few parts:  Forms, Reports, DB Setup

It is also a database itself.  Anyone with DB experience will tell you
how crappy it is, but that is how people use it.

So if you need a DB, use *Anything* else.

If you need a portable DB UI thingie you have a few choices:

1)  Web based.  PHP/Perl/ASP/Cold Fusion will handle most DB real well. 
There are a number of script based interfaces that do the DB setup
(pgAdmin, myAdmin, etc.).

2)  runtime app based.  pgAcess is not bad.  I have not done forms with
it though.

3) Programmed.  There are a ton of environments that you can make killer
apps that work on many OSes.  [Perl|Tcl]/TK , Python, and Kylix are two
I have seen.

4)  Office Suite Based.  Open Office is supposed to do this.  I have not
tried.  I think there are Koffice tools.  There are several that fit
here or in #2.

So decide what you want and what you need.  If web based, pick a Linux
server drop Apache, PHP and Postgres, and phpPgAdmin on the server and
design away.

The others will require people to answer with more experience.


> Thanks
> 
> Holger
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com
