In-Reply-To: <3F54DA72.9020400@dimstar.net>
References: <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitmine.net> <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat> <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dimstar.net> <20030902155000.GA2183@ursine.ca> <3F54C09B.8000408@dimstar.net> <20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca> <3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net> <3F54D3D0.4050200@goiter.com> <3F54DA72.9020400@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20030903083603.GA21157@wirex.net>

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 10:59:14AM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Chuck Mize wrote:
> >If you are the only one using C/R then he only has to deal with one 
> >additional email but what if everybody he emails is using it? 
> 
> Then the sender makes a decision. Either it's worth it to contact that 
> person, or it's not. If it's not worth it to reply to the challenge, 
> then they hit delete, and off they go. No problem.

And if all 50,000 subscribers of bugtraq decide to install C/R systems?
That's 50,000 deletes or replies to do. I really wouldn't want to handle
just the 400 or so responses from the subscribers of PLUG.

At least with byugtraq, if you forward to the list admins the automatic
response a subscriber sent to your post, be it a challenge as part of a
C/R, an out-of-office notification, or an anti-virus program deciding a
gpg signature is really a virus, they'll unsub the offender. Even with
that policy, you can expect about 30 automatic responses to each bugtraq
post, if you gpg sign your message.

As usual, someon ehas written a "Considered Harmful" document about C/R
systems, in response to a debian-user thread:

  http://kmself.home.netcom.com/Rants/challenge-response.html

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 10:30:56AM -0700, Chuck Mize wrote:
> Finally, if enough people actually start using C/R the spammers will 
> just alter their spamware to automatically respond to the challenges and 
> you'll be in the same place you are now.

Meaning then C/R is basically a pissing contest that wastes even more
bandwidth and still does nothing to actually combat the problem.
Report your spam.  After a while, your spam volume goes *way* down.
Using spamassassin to sort my spam off someplace handy until I report
it, I'm averaging 0.0098% spam since I started keeping archives of
everything back in March (~54,000 ham, 528 spam, I went through my
archive last weekend after I accidentally toasted ~/.spamassassin and
retrained it).

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 10:59:14AM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> We deal with it, because the alternative is we are overrun with junk 
> email. If I wasn't blocking mail, then my signal to noise ratio would be

> not. Fully 40% or better is rejected by postfix, and then 70% of what 
> gets delivered to me is still junk. I had a personal best the other day

> Real close.

spammers.  I got my users to report spam themselves (and if they're
lazy, forwarding me their spam), my site is a pretty hostile target.

> I am thinking about replacing my existing video card with a new one that
> has TV out option so that I can broadcast some movies/videos from my
> Linux box directly to my TV.  Most likely, I will be using Xine or
> RealPlayer on Linux.
>
> My question is, what are some of the better video cards with TV out

> with all the latest happenings in the video card area.  The last time I
> bought a new video card, I bought one made by Matrox which I am still

My card isn't NEW, exactly, but I like it heaps and it does a stellar job
of TVOut.

It's a Matrox G400 DualHead card with a TVOut dongle.

The only annoying thing is that there is no Back End Scaler on the second
head, so you can't just say "mplayer -fs" on the second head and get
scaled video full-screen without other performance hits.

Oh, yeah, I use mplayer for TVOut.

On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 22:49, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> On Tuesday, September 02, 2003 4:21 PM, Rich Shepard 
> [SMTP:rshepard at appl-ecosys.com] wrote:
> > On Tue, 2 Sep 2003, Holger Stephan wrote:
> >
> > > Is there a database system similar to MS Access on Linux?
> >
> > Holgar,
> >
> >   Gag! Gak! NO! Access is a flat-file database. Very limited.
> >
> > > Or, better, something that runs on Linux and Windows?
> >
> >   Two that I can recommend: PostgreSQL and SQLite. The former is a 
> standard
> > that approaches (or meets) the power of Oracle -- without the marketing 
> hype
> > or cost. The latter is a SQL library that can be used for your own
> > applications, particularly embedded ones. Both GPL; both run on cygwin on
> > Microsoft. SQLite may have a native Winduhs port, but since I pay no
> > attention to such things I may be wrong.
> 
> As an Access developer (yes, I know, MS is evil, but Access what I've 
> become good at, and it's catually a good product), I must beg to differ. 
>  Access/JET is certainly a relational database, not a flat file database. 
>  Access enforces relational integrity, supports transactions, rollbacks, 
> etc.  What Access is not is a Database server, though it makes a perfectly 
> good front-end for a database server.  Not only do I think Access is great, 
> I was, for a while, heavily involved in an attempt to create a GPL, 
> multi-platform replacement system.
> 
> The closest things to Access I have found in my wanderings appear to be 
> Meargent (part of the GNOME office project) and pgSQL, though the latter 
> works only with a PostgreSQL back-end.
> 
> Now, regarding whether a database server is superior to a client-based 
> database engine with file shareing, there are cases where the file sharing 
> system is superior.  Those are the cases where you need a database, but you 
> don't need the hassle of installing a server or hiring a DBA.  You can copy 
> your database file onto a CD, take it home, and open it up.  You don't have 
> to create a backup, go home, log into your server as an administrator, 
> create a database instance, decide where to put your log files, etc., then 
> restore from the backup, ...
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

>

On Wed, 2003-09-03 at 04:14, Paul Johnson wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
> 
> On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 10:59:14AM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > We deal with it, because the alternative is we are overrun with junk 
> > email. If I wasn't blocking mail, then my signal to noise ratio would be 
> > near 2:10. 2 legitimate emails for every 10 emails received. I kid you 
> > not. Fully 40% or better is rejected by postfix, and then 70% of what 
> > gets delivered to me is still junk. I had a personal best the other day 
> > of 77% of mail was rejected by postfix. That's BEFORE spamassassin got a 
> > hold of it. Spam sucks, and I'll do many things to reduce it to a 
> > managable level. That doesn't include a C/R system yet, but I'm close.. 
> > Real close.
> 
> I was there once.  Make yourself a hostile target and report
> spammers.  I got my users to report spam themselves (and if they're
> lazy, forwarding me their spam), my site is a pretty hostile target.
> Spammers learn, though slowly.

You know, I vaguely remember there being a law against sending spam in
Oregon or Washington, not sure which, but I thought it was Oregon, and
there being stories of people successfully getting checks for $300-$500
out of spamming companies by sending them letters threatening to sue in
small claims court. Anyone know anything about this? I have the time, i
could go after spammers...

Jeff




From icepirate at comcast.net  Wed Sep  3 08:20:02 2003
From: icepirate at comcast.net (lemming)
Date: Wed Sep  3 08:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Gentoo Auto Update
In-Reply-To: <1062581931.7526.11.camel@sparticus>
References: <1062581931.7526.11.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <3F560367.6050902@comcast.net>

Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> All,
> 
> I would like to have my machines auto-update by running a weekly crontab
> like so:
> 
>   emerge rsync
>   emerge update portage
>   emerge -u world
> 
> May one rely on this not breaking things?

Though it's rare, it sometimes needs a personal touch if something 
breaks during updates.  As long as you read your output to keep your 
config files updated, it should work.

Myself I just run

emerge sync
emerge -pu world

Then decide when I want to update.  Sometimes I'll just update a few 
parts for now and update the rest later.

-Mark

It's Washington. I tried this once. The spammer claimed
that I had subscribed to a mailing list, which I didn't.
It was clear that he would fight me by claiming that I
had agreed to receive his spam but forgot. I didn't have
the time for this, so I blocked all his IP addresses and
the IP addresses of his uncooperative ISP.

From jkeroes at eli.net  Wed Sep  3 08:49:02 2003
From: jkeroes at eli.net (Joshua Keroes)
Date: Wed Sep  3 08:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Logging STDOUT to file
In-Reply-To: <20030903070602.7274.24302.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20030903070602.7274.24302.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20030903154809.GC9082@eli.net>

Evan Heidtmann <clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com> wrote:
> I am looking for a way to have everything I see on the screen sent to
> a file at the same time that it is displayed. In other words, I want
> to log all screen output to a file.

Perhaps script(1) would work for you? By default it writes *all* output
- STDIN, STDOUT, STDERR, escape sequences; everything - to a file called
'typescript'. Ex:

sandbox: ~ $ script
Script started, file is typescript
sh-2.05a$ touch foo
sh-2.05a$ ls foo
foo
sh-2.05a$ exit
exit
Script done, file is typescript
sandbox: ~ $ cat typescript
Script started on Wed Sep 03 08:44:04 2003
sh-2.05a$ touch foo
sh-2.05a$ ls foo
foo
sh-2.05a$ exit
exit
 
script done on Wed Sep 03 08:44:33 2003

Subject: [PLUG] PMVision on Linux
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309030923300.17655-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

Or ... running java programs on a linux system.

I'm having a _not well documented_ problem running the last version of 
PMVision (by Lucent?).  I realize this is rather vague but I'm away from 
the system I'm trying to get this running on.

I've searched for but found very little (nothing is more like it) on
installing the java runtime environment (JRE) and getting 'troublesome'
programs working.  Anyone have some pointers/links to getting the JRE
setup so it is easy to use and/or trouble-shooting it.  Btw, I have got
several other java programs to work but just not PMVision.

For those that don't know PMVision is a program for controlling 
Portmasters.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Sep  3 10:01:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Sep  3 10:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PMVision on Linux
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309030923300.17655-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309030923300.17655-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1062607446.642.136.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2003-09-03 at 09:34, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> Or ... running java programs on a linux system.
> 
> I'm having a _not well documented_ problem running the last version of 
> PMVision (by Lucent?).  I realize this is rather vague but I'm away from 
> the system I'm trying to get this running on.
> 
> I've searched for but found very little (nothing is more like it) on
> installing the java runtime environment (JRE) and getting 'troublesome'
> programs working.  Anyone have some pointers/links to getting the JRE
> setup so it is easy to use and/or trouble-shooting it.  Btw, I have got
> several other java programs to work but just not PMVision.
> 
> For those that don't know PMVision is a program for controlling 
> Portmasters.

PMVision can be a bear to run.  First of all, it requires a JDK 1.1,
which is kinda old, but can be installed alongside other versions fairly
easily.  Here's what my script to start it looks like; it's a slightly
modified version of the script that shipped with it:

====
#!/bin/sh
 
unset CLASSPATH
JAVA_HOME=/usr/local/jre117_v3
PATH=$PATH:$JAVA_HOME/bin
 
#CLASSPATH=/usr/local/jre117_v3/lib/rt.jar:.
if [ -s ../helpsys.jar ]
then
        help_loc=../helpsys.jar
else
        help_loc=./helpsys.jar
fi
if [ -s ../oromatcher.jar ]
then
        oro_loc=../oromatcher.jar
else
        oro_loc=./oromatcher.jar
fi
 
jre -cp pmvision.jar -cp pmvhelp.jar -cp $help_loc -cp $oro_loc PMVision $*
====

And yeah, sometimes they can be difficult to get running.  I had
FilterEditor running once (which is a good deal easier to use than the
editor built into PMVision), but now it won't connect at all.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * * * * Good, fast and cheap: Pick all 3! * * * * * * *
*   Naked Ape Consulting                http://nakedape.cc  *

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep  3 11:00:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Sep  3 11:00:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <001401c371da$f2dd3b60$0d000d0a@borolan>
Message-ID: <6307-98239@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 2 Sep 2003, borodimer boro-at-borosenclave.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> This is just a plug for a very simple CVS utility called TortoiseCVS
> (http://www.tortoisecvs.org/).  I have used it quite extensively both
> at home and the office, and have found it to be the simplest way to
> work with data in CVS.  If you are going to use CVS in an environment
> where the simpler the better, give Tortoise a look.

I've also used this in an environment where WinCVS was deemed to be too
complicated and it worked well.  Getting it set up over SSH was the
hardest part, and if you don't care about security or strong
authentication that step can be skipped.

  -- Steve





From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Sep  3 11:00:07 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Sep  3 11:00:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Gentoo Auto Update
In-Reply-To: <1062581931.7526.11.camel@sparticus>
References: <1062581931.7526.11.camel@sparticus>
Message-ID: <1062611906.3296.10.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2003-09-03 at 02:38, Cooper Stevenson wrote:

> I would like to have my machines auto-update by running a weekly crontab
> like so:
> 
>   emerge rsync
>   emerge update portage
>   emerge -u world
> 
> May one rely on this not breaking things?

I was thinking about doing the first line of that in a nightly
crontab...  but nothing quite so severe as emerge -u world in it.  But
then, I have several ~x86 packages here.

In all honesty, I really would expect it to break things.  If not at
first, eventually.  I *always* look to see what emerge -u world is going
to do (and actually use -U world) with an emerge -Up world first.

You may well be able to get along without it breaking anything... but I
sure wouldn't want to trust it like that.....

Rob

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep  3 11:18:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Sep  3 11:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Massive buffer cache yet still swapping
Message-ID: <5095-54250@sneakemail.com>

I've recently run into a performance problem on my desktop where the
system swaps out things that I'd rather stay in memory (i.e. the Mozilla
session I was using 10 minutes ago, desktops I haven't visited for a
while, etc.)  All the while, I see a massive buffer cache taking up space
that could be used for the programs I'm about to use again.

A search of the Usual Spots (google) hasn't turned up much:

http://www.google.com/search?q=linux+buffer+cache+limits

This guy seems to have the same problem I do:
  + http://mail.nl.linux.org/linux-mm/2001-04/msg00010.html

but I never saw any solution posted.

Even in 1999 it looked like the documented /proc/sys/vm values didn't
work:
  + http://mail.nl.linux.org/linux-mm-www/1999-12/msg00000.html

Here's what /proc/meminfo shows me:

-----
        total:    used:    free:  shared: buffers:  cached:
Mem:  517677056 510160896  7516160        0 35762176 363266048
Swap: 534634496 131747840 402886656
MemTotal:       505544 kB
MemFree:          7340 kB
MemShared:           0 kB
Buffers:         34924 kB
Cached:         327292 kB
SwapCached:      27460 kB
Active:         378056 kB
ActiveAnon:     171064 kB
ActiveCache:    206992 kB
Inact_dirty:      6064 kB
Inact_laundry:   67784 kB
Inact_clean:      8820 kB
Inact_target:    92144 kB
HighTotal:           0 kB
HighFree:            0 kB
LowTotal:       505544 kB
LowFree:          7340 kB
SwapTotal:      522104 kB
SwapFree:       393444 kB
-----

The problem is the Cached: line seems very high.  The next step is some
kernel-diving, but it would be great if one of you knows of a good way to
tune this.

  -- Steve





From cmize at goiter.com  Wed Sep  3 11:23:01 2003
From: cmize at goiter.com (Chuck Mize)
Date: Wed Sep  3 11:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org	for	dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <1062612490.13899.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net>	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitm		ine.net>	<1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat>	<20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dim	 star.net>	<20030902155000.GA2183@ursine.ca>	<3F54C09B.8000408@dimstar.net>	<20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca>	<3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net>	<3F54D3D0.4050200@goiter.com>	<3F54DA72.9020400@dimstar.net> 	<20030903111439.GD9025@ursine.ca>	<1062600526.856.19.camel@kokopelli>  <3F56077D.8000807@goiter.com> <1062612490.13899.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F563166.5060809@goiter.com>

Michael C. Robinson wrote:


> How do you tell the difference between a fake received line verses a
> real one?  It says that you need to look for a progression or something,
> but I'm not following.  An email is sent to someone, what can be faked
> in the headers and what can't be?

A lot of times the only line you can trust completely is the top line 
where your server received a message from another machine. The Received: 
headers start from the bottom up and a lot of times will be forged or 
from an open relay or open proxy. When I report spammers I always report 
the machine that connected to my mail server, the ISP of the website 
advertised in the spam and any dropboxes in the spam that the spammer is 
using to collect replies.

Lately spammers have been heavily abusing open proxies from China and 
Korea so reporting the origin of the mail is pretty useless. The best 
way to hurt a spammer where it'll do the most damage is to get his 
website and/or dropboxes shut down so that he can't actually profit from 
his spam run.

You can also try running the spam through spamcop.net to trace headers 
but their parsing isn't always that great so if you just concentrate on 
tracking down who is hosting the spammer's website and dropbox you will 
be doing enough.




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep  3 11:26:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Sep  3 11:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
In-Reply-To: <1062612197.13900.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <12879-62622@sneakemail.com>

On 3 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson michael-at-goose.robinson-west.com |PDX
Linux| wrote:

> Can sftp be disabled be disabled by removing a line from sshd.config?
> I believe the line is subsystem=/usr/include/sftp-server.

Yes.

> If I'm not mistaken, there's a way with CVS to indicate who can commit
> and who can just read the archive.

Unfortunately, the CVS pserver method is not encrypted, so it's generally
pretty simple to grab someone's password and impersonate them.

On our CVS system we use SSH and public key authentication with the
command that the key can run limited to "cvs server".  We use file
permissions to manage access.

The CygWin SSH client is pretty easy to install, but was definately the
hardest part of the Tortoise setup.

  -- Steve




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep  3 11:29:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Sep  3 11:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Verify plug-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org for
 dduncan@hexi.com]
In-Reply-To: <1062612490.13899.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <3F53DD2C.7040901@dimstar.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309011720130.11862@shaft.bitm
  ine.net> <1062489126.3662.18.camel@kat> <20030902144930.GA30937@sthelens.dim
  star.net> <20030902155000.GA2183@ursine.ca> <3F54C09B.8000408@dimstar.net>
 <20030902161728.GA6016@ursine.ca> <3F54C706.4040601@dimstar.net>
 <3F54D3D0.4050200@goiter.com> <3F54DA72.9020400@dimstar.net> 
 <20030903111439.GD9025@ursine.ca> <1062600526.856.19.camel@kokopelli> 
 <3F56077D.8000807@goiter.com> <1062612490.13899.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309031121450.14487@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> How do you tell the difference between a fake received line verses a real
> one?  It says that you need to look for a progression or something, but
> I'm not following.  An email is sent to someone, what can be faked in the
> headers and what can't be?

  Spammers almost always spoof the "From: " line, the "Reply-to: " line and
the domain name. However, the IP address is valid. Consider the header of
this message:

Return-Path: <plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org>
X-Original-To: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
Delivered-To: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com
Received: from drizzle.pdxlinux.org (unknown [198.107.38.238])
        by salmo.appl-ecosys.com (Postfix) with ESMTP id 9FE25177D2
        for <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>; Wed,  3 Sep 2003 11:09:11 -0700
(PDT)
Received: from localhost
        ([127.0.0.1] helo=drizzle.pdxlinux.org ident=list)
        by drizzle.pdxlinux.org with esmtp (Exim 3.35 #1 (Debian))
        id 19uc41-0004qE-00; Wed, 03 Sep 2003 11:09:05 -0700
Received: from web.robinson-west.com ([209.210.202.170]
helo=goose.robinson-west.com)
        by drizzle.pdxlinux.org with esmtp (Exim 3.35 #1 (Debian))
        id 19uc3o-0004oD-00
        for <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>; Wed, 03 Sep 2003 11:08:53 -0700
Received: from goose.robinson-west.com (goose.robinson-west.com [127.0.0.1])
        by goose.robinson-west.com (8.12.9/8.12.9) with ESMTP id
h83I8Aid014002
        for <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>; Wed, 3 Sep 2003 11:08:10 -0700
Received: (from michael at localhost)
        by goose.robinson-west.com (8.12.9/8.12.9/Submit) id h83I8Agi014001;
        Wed, 3 Sep 2003 11:08:10 -0700

  Working from the bottom up, we see the IP address 127.0.0.1 which we know
is the localhost, then we see 209.210.202.170 and, at the top,
198.107.38.238. The latter traces to verio.net and the former to:

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ whois 209.210.202.170 at whois.arin.net
[whois.arin.net]
Electric Lightwave Inc ELI-NETBLK98 (NET-209-210-0-0-1)
                                  209.210.0.0 - 209.210.255.255
Opus Interactive ELI-D1-D2-C8-00-22 (NET-209-210-200-0-1)
                                  209.210.200.0 - 209.210.203.255

  So, if this was spam, I'd report it to both abuse at verio.net and
abuse at eli.net and let them determine just which customer is abusing their
acceptable use policies.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, Chuck Mize wrote:

> Lately spammers have been heavily abusing open proxies from China and
> Korea so reporting the origin of the mail is pretty useless.

  ... and Japan, and Taiwan, and Malaysia and so on and so forth. That's why
many of us have extensive lists of IP addresses that are open relays or
otherwise tolerant of spammers. Unfortunately, we all pay for the bandwidth
and server capacity the spammers use to ship out their stuff and we use
rejecting it.

            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Wed Sep  3 12:20:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Sep  3 12:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Protecting bandwidth...
Message-ID: <1062616728.14143.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

What would it take to avoid the bandwidth losses from spam?
Do the ISPs have to stop it?

Is email going to have to be graded by ISP's at some point
based on a spam scale, 1 being definitely spam whereas 10
would definitely not be spam?  How could such a system be
implemented without creating zero privacy or large scale
false positives?

I'm thinking a lot of these worms that generate tons of 
messages  and send them at volumes intended to crash
systems should be easy to catch, unless the spam stream
looks like valid email or contains valid messages.

What percentage of email is spam and what is it's
average affect on bandwidth in our area?

Another question is, how can sendmail be programmed
to deal with overload gracefully?  I figure the most 
affective policy is to go offline and let all the 
senders bounce to reduce the volume.  Trouble is, 
will you get hit by as many retries when you come 
back?  The less extreme answer is to go to a list 
of allowed senders that shortens based on their 
level of importance and increasing overload up 
to thrashing.  This latter policy could be 
abandoned when the load is lighter.  What level 
of saturation should it be triggered at and how 
can such an approach be implemented with sendmail?  
Essentially, I'm thinking sendmail should close off 
mail service in cases of thrashing.  I've never 
overloaded to my knowledge, but I do wonder about 
this issue.

Should a primary server not accept retransmitted
email?  If you have a backup I would guess anything
being retransmitted should be dealt with by it.
Which brings up another question, how can I implement
a filter that checks if a message matches contents
wise exactly to one I've received already?  If
someone tries to send the same message multiple
times, it'd be nice to have that filtered out.

Clearly challenge response won't work because spammers
will just program their generators to respond and it's
the wrong answer for mailing lists like this one.  How
long will E-Bay's type in this box what these symbols
are work?

     --  Michael

From cmize at goiter.com  Wed Sep  3 13:09:02 2003
From: cmize at goiter.com (Chuck Mize)
Date: Wed Sep  3 13:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Protecting bandwidth...
In-Reply-To: <1062616728.14143.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1062616728.14143.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F564A1B.2020200@goiter.com>

Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> What would it take to avoid the bandwidth losses from spam?
> Do the ISPs have to stop it?
> 
> Is email going to have to be graded by ISP's at some point
> based on a spam scale, 1 being definitely spam whereas 10
> would definitely not be spam?  How could such a system be
> implemented without creating zero privacy or large scale
> false positives?

For a system like that to work I would think that you would have to 
first accept the mail, proccess it to determine the scale and then 
decided what to do with it. By then the spammer has already used your 
bandwidth and you've used your resources to process the message.
> 
> I'm thinking a lot of these worms that generate tons of 
> messages  and send them at volumes intended to crash
> systems should be easy to catch, unless the spam stream
> looks like valid email or contains valid messages.
> 
> What percentage of email is spam and what is it's
> average affect on bandwidth in our area?

Postini has a cool thing on their webpage if you have a shockwave 
capable browser that shows current spam statistics. For the last several 
weeks it's been hovering in the 70% range meaning that for the 84 
million inboxes they protect 70% of the mail has been identified as 
spam. AOL has released statistics that say they are reject over 50% of 
all incoming email and their users are still screaming about the number 
of spam in their inboxes.
> 
> Another question is, how can sendmail be programmed
> to deal with overload gracefully?  I figure the most 
> affective policy is to go offline and let all the 
> senders bounce to reduce the volume.  Trouble is, 
> will you get hit by as many retries when you come 
> back?  The less extreme answer is to go to a list 
> of allowed senders that shortens based on their 
> level of importance and increasing overload up 
> to thrashing.  This latter policy could be 
> abandoned when the load is lighter.  What level 
> of saturation should it be triggered at and how 
> can such an approach be implemented with sendmail?  
> Essentially, I'm thinking sendmail should close off 
> mail service in cases of thrashing.  I've never 
> overloaded to my knowledge, but I do wonder about 
> this issue.
> 
> Should a primary server not accept retransmitted
> email?  If you have a backup I would guess anything
> being retransmitted should be dealt with by it.
> Which brings up another question, how can I implement
> a filter that checks if a message matches contents
> wise exactly to one I've received already?  If
> someone tries to send the same message multiple
> times, it'd be nice to have that filtered out.

I think this is sort of what Vipul's razor, pyzor and the DCC all do. 
People submit their spams to these systems and then you can check 
incoming mail against their database.

There is a new system of "greylisting" that some people are playing 
around with where any email attempts from non white-listed people are 
given a 4xx error. If the message is being sent from a real, dedicated 
mail server the mail will be retransmited again and accepted by the 
receiving server. Since a lot of spammers are using direct-to-mx 
spamware that just sends everything once and shuts down their messages 
aren't making it through these greylisting systems. In that situation 
the message must be retransmited more than once.
> 
> Clearly challenge response won't work because spammers
> will just program their generators to respond and it's
> the wrong answer for mailing lists like this one.  How
> long will E-Bay's type in this box what these symbols
> are work?




From boro at borosenclave.com  Wed Sep  3 13:21:02 2003
From: boro at borosenclave.com (borodimer)

Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
In-Reply-To: <12879-62622@sneakemail.com>

I don't even mess with Cygwin's ssh environment.  Instead, get Pageant,
putty, and puttygen to use as needed.

  - Phil

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Steve Bonds
Sent: Wednesday, September 03, 2003 11:26 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Many CVS questions


On 3 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson michael-at-goose.robinson-west.com |PDX
Linux| wrote:

> Can sftp be disabled be disabled by removing a line from sshd.config?
> I believe the line is subsystem=/usr/include/sftp-server.

Yes.

> If I'm not mistaken, there's a way with CVS to indicate who can commit
> and who can just read the archive.

Unfortunately, the CVS pserver method is not encrypted, so it's generally
pretty simple to grab someone's password and impersonate them.

On our CVS system we use SSH and public key authentication with the
command that the key can run limited to "cvs server".  We use file
permissions to manage access.

The CygWin SSH client is pretty easy to install, but was definately the
hardest part of the Tortoise setup.

  -- Steve

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep  3 14:06:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Sep  3 14:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Massive buffer cache yet still swapping
In-Reply-To: <20030903195157.GA29773@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <20157-39721@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, Terry Griffin griffint-at-pobox.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> What kernel version is this? And is it a stock kernel from kernel.org or
> a patched kernel from a distributor?

This is on a RedHat kernel 2.4.20-20.7, but the problem does not seem to
be RedHat or 2.4 sub-version specific.

Interestingly, the kernel source documentation reads:

----- /usr/src/linux-2.4.20-20.7/Documentation/sysctl/vm.txt -----
buffermem:

The three values in this file correspond to the values in
the struct buffer_mem. It controls how much memory should
be used for buffer memory. The percentage is calculated
as a percentage of total system memory.

The values are:
min_percent	-- this is the minimum percentage of memory
		   that should be spent on buffer memory
borrow_percent  -- UNUSED
max_percent     -- UNUSED
-----

I was unable to locate the struct buffer_mem in the kernel source.  My
guess is that this capability was either never implemented or was removed
without updating the documentation.  (Gee, I never do that...  ;-)

  -- Steve

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep  3 14:27:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Sep  3 14:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Many CVS questions
In-Reply-To: <3F565943.2070603@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <21002-12072@sneakemail.com>

> borodimer wrote:
> > I don't even mess with Cygwin's ssh environment.  Instead, get Pageant,
> > putty, and puttygen to use as needed.

I've never been able to use Putty as an ssh tunnel.  It makes a fine
terminal with SSH capabilities, but for CVS over SSH you'll need something
else.  I've had good luck with the *recent* Cygwin SSH.  Some of the older
versions were terrible to get working.

> Steve Bonds wrote:

> > On our CVS system we use SSH and public key authentication with the
> > command that the key can run limited to "cvs server".  We use file
> > permissions to manage access.

> Evan asked:
> How exactly does one limit the access to just one command?

The first step would be "man sshd".  ;-)

(http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/man.cgi?query=sshd)

In the section "AUTHORIZED_KEYS FILE FORMAT":

----- 
command="command"

Specifies that the command is executed whenever this key is used for
authentication.  The command supplied by the user (if any) is ignored.  
The command is run on a pty if the client requests a pty; otherwise it is
run without a tty.  If an 8-bit clean channel is required, one must not
request a pty or should specify nopty. A quote may be included in the
command by quoting it with a backslash.  This option might be useful to
restrict certain public keys to perform just a specific operation.  An
example might be a key that permits remote backups but nothing else.  
Note that the client may specify TCP/IP and/or X11 forwarding unless they
are explicitly prohibited.  Note that this option applies to shell,
command or subsystem execution.
-----

An example from my configuration:

----- authorized_keys (all one line)  -----
no-port-forwarding,no-X11-forwarding,no-agent-forwarding,
command="/usr/local/bin/cvs server" ssh-dss <big-ass string O'characters>
<user>@<host>
-----

  -- Steve




From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Sep  3 14:34:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Sep  3 14:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Massive buffer cache yet still swapping
In-Reply-To: <20157-39721@sneakemail.com>
References: <20157-39721@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309031421180.30216@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, Steve Bonds wrote:

> I was unable to locate the struct buffer_mem in the kernel source.
> My guess is that this capability was either never implemented or was
> removed without updating the documentation.  (Gee, I never do
> that...  ;-)

Odd: vm.txt ("dated" 2.4.19) seems fairly out of date, unless Red
Hat's kernel has a *really* patched vm subsystem. Here's a comparison
of /proc/sys/vm/*:

  /proc file         2.4.20-20.9  vm.txt
  -----------------  -----------  ------
  bdflush            yes          yes
  buffermem          no           yes
  freepages          no           yes
  kswapd             yes          yes
  max-readahead      yes          no
  max_map_count      yes          yes
  min-readahead      yes          no
  overcommit_memory  yes          yes
  page-cluster       yes          yes
  pagecache          no           yes
  pagetable_cache    yes          yes

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Wed Sep  3 15:09:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Wed Sep  3 15:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Protecting bandwidth...
In-Reply-To: <1062616728.14143.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309031452190.23042-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On 3 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> What would it take to avoid the bandwidth losses from spam?
> Do the ISPs have to stop it?

Yup.  But filtering on your end can at least avoid the time losses.

> Is email going to have to be graded by ISP's at some point
> based on a spam scale, 1 being definitely spam whereas 10
> would definitely not be spam?

That's what SpamAssassin and many other antispam systems do.

> How could such a system be implemented without creating zero privacy or
> large scale false positives?

Privacy?  Email is as private as a postcard.  Avoiding false positives?
That's the very soul of the art of spam filtering.

I'm glad you're curious about this stuff, and you're obviously putting a
lot of thought into it.  It's the sort of thing system administrators
think about and research and discuss, and they've been doing it for a
while.  A bit of Googling and reading will sate your curiosity far better
than anyone here can.


Please try to be considerate of other people's time,
  Aaron

From logiplex at qwest.net  Wed Sep  3 15:35:02 2003

> something that runs on Linux and Windows?

The smallest MS Access equivalent I'm aware of is this shell script:


#!/bin/bash

while true; do
    dd if=/dev/random of=yourdata.mdb bs=1024k count=100
    echo "Your database seems corrupt. Try running Repair on it."
done


Sorry, couldn't resist ;)

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Sep  3 15:50:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Sep  3 15:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Massive buffer cache yet still swapping
In-Reply-To: <5095-54250@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <5787-70610@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, Steve Bonds 1s7k8uhcd001-at-sneakemail.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I've recently run into a performance problem on my desktop where the
> system swaps out things that I'd rather stay in memory (i.e. the Mozilla
> session I was using 10 minutes ago, desktops I haven't visited for a
> while, etc.)  All the while, I see a massive buffer cache taking up space
> that could be used for the programs I'm about to use again.

I found an excellent thread on this problem on the linux kernel mailing
list.  It took some time to find the correct search terms.

http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=linux-kernel&m=106126815206709&w=2

(BTW, the magic search term was "cache maximum".  Leaving off
"buffer" turned out to be a big help.)

The consensus seemed to be that for large memory systems running 2.4
kernels, that "swapoff -a" was the best way to eliminate the problem.  A
bit drastic, perhaps, but I bet it's quite effective.

The 2.6 kernels are reportedly a bit more effective at not swapping out
user programs to make room for file cache.

  -- Steve




From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Wed Sep  3 16:16:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Sep  3 16:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Saving bandwidth...
Message-ID: <1062630870.14708.95.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

If you scan email for spam at an ISP of other ISP's you save bandwidth
from that ISP to the target(s).  I'm figuring the messages have to clear
text for an ISP to scan them, hence the privacy questions.  The only
obvoius magic bullet I can think of is to throw anything out that has
any forged address in it.  The sooner an email is discarded on route
to a destination, the more bandwidth there is, hence where scanning it
can be part of saving bandwidth even though that means it has been
transmitted somewhere.  

    --  Michael



From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Sep  3 16:16:06 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Sep  3 16:16:06 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Massive buffer cache yet still swapping
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C72A@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Steve Bonds:
> I've recently run into a performance problem on my desktop where the
> system swaps out things that I'd rather stay in memory (i.e. 
> the Mozilla

<SNIP>

  Unfortunately, the VM system has been changing a lot recently.  The
/proc/meminfo file hasn't been very well documented since around 2.2.x.

  I was fighting with memory leaks in a kernel module last year and wrote
this little script.  It reads /proc/meminfo and stores the data in a daily
CSV file.  Run the script from cron every X minutes, depending on the
resolution you want to see.  

  Then, It's a simple matter to load the CSV into your spreadsheet of choice
and make charts from the data.  I found the trend data much more useful than
random numbers in a file.  

  The linux kernel will normally use all the memory available.  It will only
savage free cache memory as needed.  The VM shouldn't start swapping until
it runs out of free cache.  The Buffers and Cache are two different memory
pools.  If you're going into depletion because Buffer memory is depleting
real storage... then you have a kernel problem.  Buffer memory is all kernel
space.

  I have some very cool charts I can show you that have that exact same
condition. ;-)  I had a leaky kernel module blowing up memory every few
days.  First comes depletion, then comes swap, then comes thrash, then comes
crash!  The developer and I pulled our hair out for a month finding (and
fixing) all the leaks.  

Steve D...

<BEGIN SCRIPT>
#!/bin/bash

############################################################################
##
dt=`date +%m%d`
memfile="$HOME/mem_"$dt".csv"
tmpfile="$HOME/.mem_temp.txt"
dts=`date +%m/%d/%y,%H:%M:00`          # get the date/time stamp

# copy /proc/meminfo to a working file, strip whitespace
touch $tmpfile
cat /proc/meminfo | sed -e "s/   / /g; s/   / /g; s/  / /g; s/  / /g" >
$tmpfile

############################################################################
##
# Cut the meminfo data into CSV format
# dis the bytes, only record the kbytes
############################################################################
##
# tot_byte=`  grep "Mem:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
# used_byte=` grep "Mem:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f3`
# free_byte=` grep "Mem:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f4`
# share_byte=`grep "Mem:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f5`
# buff_byte=` grep "Mem:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f6`
# cashe_byte=`grep "Mem:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f7`
# swap_tot_byte=` grep "Swap:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
# swap_used_byte=`grep "Swap:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f3`
# swap_free_byte=`grep "Swap:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f4`

tot_Kb=`grep "MemTotal:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
free_Kb=`grep "MemFree:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
share_byte=`grep "MemShared:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`

buff_Kb=`grep "Buffers:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
cashe_Kb=`grep "^Cached:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
swapcashe_Kb=`grep "SwapCached:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`

active_Kb=`grep "Active:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
inactive_Kb=`grep "Inactive:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`

hi_tot_Kb=`grep "HighTotal:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
hi_free_Kb=`grep "HighFree:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
lo_tot_Kb=`grep "LowTotal:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
lo_free_Kb=`grep "LowFree:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
swap_tot_Kb=`grep "SwapTotal:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`
swap_free_Kb=`grep "SwapFree:" $tmpfile | cut -d" " -f2`

############################################################################
##
# Create the file and write the header line if the file has been (re)moved. 
# dis the bytes, only record the kbytes
############################################################################
##
if [ ! -f $memfile ]; then
#  echo -n
"Date,Time,MemTotByte,MemUsedByte,MemFreeByte,MemShareByte,MemBuffByte," >>
$memfile
#  echo -n
"MemCasheByte,SwapTotByte,SwapUsedByte,SwapFreeByte,MemTotalKb,MemFreeKb,"
>> $memfile
  echo -n "Date,Time,MemTotalKb,MemFreeKb," >> $memfile
  echo -n
"MemSharedKb,BuffersKb,CachedKb,SwapCachedKb,ActiveKb,InactiveKb,HighTotalKb
," >> $memfile
  echo "HighFreeKb,LowTotalKb,LowFreeKb,SwapTotalKb,SwapFreeKb" >> $memfile
fi 

############################################################################
##
# Write out the Memory data in CSV format
# dis the bytes, only record the kbytes
############################################################################
##
# echo -n
$dts","$tot_byte","$used_byte","$free_byte","$share_byte","$buff_byte"," >>
$memfile
# echo -n
$cashe_byte","$swap_tot_byte","$swap_used_byte","$swap_free_byte","$tot_Kb",
"$free_Kb"," >> $memfile
echo -n $dts","$tot_Kb","$free_Kb"," >> $memfile
echo -n
$share_byte","$buff_Kb","$cashe_Kb","$swapcashe_Kb","$active_Kb","$inactive_
Kb","$hi_tot_Kb"," >> $memfile
echo $hi_free_Kb","$lo_tot_Kb","$lo_free_Kb","$swap_tot_Kb","$swap_free_Kb
>> $memfile

############################################################################
##
exit 0
<END SCRIPT>

From freyley at gmx.net  Wed Sep  3 16:58:06 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Sep  3 16:58:06 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Saving bandwidth...
In-Reply-To: <1062630870.14708.95.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1062630870.14708.95.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1062633412.5302.18.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2003-09-03 at 16:14, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> If you scan email for spam at an ISP of other ISP's you save bandwidth
> from that ISP to the target(s).  I'm figuring the messages have to clear
> text for an ISP to scan them, hence the privacy questions.  The only
> obvoius magic bullet I can think of is to throw anything out that has
> any forged address in it.  The sooner an email is discarded on route
> to a destination, the more bandwidth there is, hence where scanning it
> can be part of saving bandwidth even though that means it has been
> transmitted somewhere.  
> 
>     --  Michael

problems:

1) how do you define a forged header? I have email accounts that do not
have SMTP servers, and I send email from those addresses using other
SMTP servers...is that a forged header? A computer is likely going to
think so.

2) if you discard the email, you are violating the rule of
non-interference which is critical because false positives mean that
email becomes an untrustworthy medium (not untrustworthy in that it's
insecure, cause we know it is, but untrustworthy in that you cannot
trust an email will be delivered. Right now you mostly can.) Or do you
send back a response to the originator? Cause that cancels out the
bandwidth savings.

Yet if you log and block the email and let the administrator look at it,
you create metric tons more work for the administrator.

The only thing I can see working for this idea relies on large hard
drive space and ignores privacy: store copies of email for 3 hours as
they go through. If you see more than 5 duplicates of an email, start
dropping it, because it's clearly spam. But then, the spammers will just
write code which puts some random text into their spam.

So I'm not sure you can win with this one. At least not with the way
you're thinking.

Jeff




From freyley at gmx.net  Wed Sep  3 17:19:02 2003

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep  3 20:58:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Sep  3 20:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] lsof
In-Reply-To: <1062646224.1503.37.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1062646224.1503.37.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309032055510.15893@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> When trying to find a file that I think may be open, and instead of
> searching through every screen of #/usr/sbin/lsof, can I use grep to do a
> more refined, and quicker search?

Dirk,

  Have you tried piping the output of lsof through grep? I do this all the
time to find a stuck soffice.bin. In that case, the syntax is 'ps ax | grep
soffice.bin'. Use the same approach with lsof.

Rich

From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Thu Sep  4 00:23:02 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Thu Sep  4 00:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The Beginning of the End
Message-ID: <E19uocf-0000DK-00@rooster>

> This would explain why SCO is so eager to challenge the GPL (it doesn't
> want to have to release the source code for Unixware)

This seems to be a perennial fantasy among OSS fans: that some GPL'ed
code is discovered in someone's code (oh, let it be Microsoft, please!),
and they are thus forced to open-source ALL of their code.

But all the GPL says is what the conditions for COMPLIANCE are.  So if,
say, MS were discovered with GPL code in Windows, the GPL would
effectively say: IF you want to keep this in Windows, THEN you must
release the rest of Windows (or at least the connected part) under the
GPL.

If it ever came to a courtroom, a sympathetic judge might rule that they
are out of compliance with the GPL.  But that wouldn't automatically
lead to a ruling to GPL everything else.  Most likely, the judge would
simply rule that they had to remove the GPL code.  If we were lucky, the
judge might award monetary damages. especially if it could be shown that
it was a deliberate violation, as opposed to, say, Sun getting it from
SCO.

Kevin




From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Thu Sep  4 00:46:01 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)

Subject: [PLUG] Q: comparison of video formats

AthlonRob writes:

 > Mid-March?  Might be the thread where I was trying to figure out how to
 > nicely encode TV shows to fit two hours on a CD.  :-)

Oh, well, that's easy -- just edit out the commercials!

 > > So what I'm trying to decide is the format I should use.
 > 
 > divx.

I've heard a couple of recommendations for divx.  How does it compare
to MPEG-1?

I figure if I use VCD or SVCD, then it can always be viewed in a
standard DVD player (in most cases) and wouldn't require a computer.
Also, can divx be viewed under Windows (without, say, expecting the
Windows (l)users among the recipients to go download some tool?

 > WMV... in my experience, it is easy to view in Linux, but it sucks in
 > the quality department.  If you're going for very small files (ie;
 > 500KB/minute) it seems to be top-dog in the quality department.  If you
 > want medium sized files, it sucks compared to divx, et al.

What sort of compression rate could I expect with divx, and how would
it compare to MPEG-{1,2,4}?

 > Ok... is there a Linux alternative to grabbing the video?  Or if you can
 > deal with storing 60 minutes at 25Mb/sec (I assume you mean megabyte,
 > not bit)...

No -- standard convention is b=bit, B=byte.

 > > 5. If I stick with MPEG-1, is there a way to make a VCD with "extra
 > > content" (the JPEGs and text files) so that someone can pop it into a
 > > DVD player that understands VCDs, and see the video, but if they pop
 > > it into a computer, they can access the other stuff?
 > 
 > I dunno... never played with VCD itself.  In my experience (a few years
 > old) VCDs are hard to play in computers... finding a reader in Linux was
 > a PITA.

Never a problem for me.  When I did "apt-get install xine" the first
thing I ran it on was my wife's VCDs.  (They're popular in Asia for
recording TV series.  For TV source, you only really notice the low
frame rate when they have, like, a sword fight.)  VCDs always worked
-- DVDs were harder because of having to install the decss stuff
manually.

 > I use 2-pass divx encoding to encode TV shows... after they're encoded
 > and all done (with about 3 hours of CPU time put in for one hour of TV)
 > they're about 300MB an hour with about the same level of quality you'll
 > get out of an antenna and a VCR, I think.

It sounds like divx does a much better job than MPEG-1, though
"antenna" kind of makes me worry (from my experience living in
Cambridge, Mass., which was about the last place in the US to get
cable because of endless negotiations with the cable company
wannabes).

Kevin

On Wed, Sep 03, 2003 at 08:11:16AM -0700, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> You know, I vaguely remember there being a law against sending spam in
> Oregon or Washington, not sure which, but I thought it was Oregon, and
> there being stories of people successfully getting checks for $300-$500
> out of spamming companies by sending them letters threatening to sue in
> small claims court.

Washington.  IANAL, but if you have a printer directly connected to
your machine, you might successfully be able to argue that they
violated fax anti-spam laws from the 1980s, since the laws describe a
fax machine as anything "capable of transcribing to paper."

This might be easier to argue if you use a keyboard and line printer for
your console (linux does actually support this).

From baloo at ursine.ca  Thu Sep  4 01:45:02 2003
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)
Date: Thu Sep  4 01:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Saner alternatives to challenge-response
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.04.10309021346590.18351-100000@aqua.hexi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0309021331570.13883-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com> <Pine.LNX.4.04.10309021346590.18351-100000@aqua.hexi.com>
Message-ID: <20030904084535.GD3105@ursine.ca>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 02:21:23PM -0700, David Duncan wrote:
> I'll be reviewing the 'spam' issue again and deciding if I need to tune my
> rules or try a new system.  Suggestions on practical alternatives to the
> challenge-response system would be appreciated.

First off, like most of the HOWTOs I've seen on tldp, I assume Debian
because it's what I use[1].  If this doesn't match up with your RPM based
distro, that's a personal problem, switch to Xandros, Knoppix
installed to a hard drive, Debian, or another similarly sane distro.
8:o)

Here's what I have done to get my site down to ~0.009% spam.  All
packages are in sid, so if you're using woody, don't be stupid, use
backports and DO NOT USE APT-PINNING.  If you need to know why, google
for apt pin harmful site:lists.debian.org.

Get exim-daemon-heavy and sa-exim (it'll pull in the necissary
depends, like spamassassin).  Out of the box, you'll have an automatic
teergrube (anything that scores higher than 30 gets teergubed instead
of delivered, watch the headers sa-exim puts in
/var/log/exim4/reject.log to make sure this is a sane number, though
the default is high enough that I've yet to see any ham get nailed by
it).

Then, go dig around through
/etc/exim4/conf.d/acl/30_exim4-config_check_rcpt and add this to the
(empty) blacklist section.  Please note: When you use RBLs, please do
the RBL maintainers a *huge* favor by *not* mentioning them in your
reject messages (do not use the defaults).  It only appears to serve
to confuse users and anger some, the angry ones then turn around and
harass the RBL maintainers for blocking their email, something that
the maintainers had zero to do with.  Also, spammers that use
dropboxes in their From: will get the bounces, see who is giving them
the most grief, and DDOS them (witness osirusoft).

<example>

  # Currently spamming

  deny  message         = Your mail server is currently spamming.  You can either wait it out or find an ethical ISP.
        log_message     = $sender_host_address is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = bl.spamcop.net

  # Broken sites that refuse bounce messages, God only knows if
  # they'll get this.

  deny  message         = Your domain refuses bounce messages, despite breaking RFCs 821, 2821, 2505 and 1123.  Contact your mail provider to have this fixed.
        log_message     = $sender_address_domain is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = dsn.rfc-ignorant.org/$sender_address_domain

# There are a *lot* of ignorant/retarded sites that fail to have a
# postmaster.  This would probably make a better spamassassin +1.000 rule.

#  deny message         = Your domain refuses mail to postmaster, despite breaking RFC 2821.  Contact your mail provider to have this fixed.
#       log_message     = $sender_address_domain is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
#       dnslists        = postmaster.rfc-ignorant.org/$sender_address_domain


# Sites with bad whois data are almost always spammers, except in the
# UK.  The UK, for reasons beyond my comprehension, has no whois.  The
# British seem to put the fear of God into people trying to spam
# through them, hence the exception for *.uk in the rule below.

  deny  message         = Your domain has bad whois information, despite breaking RFC 954.  Please contact your mail provider to have this problem fixed.
        log_message     = $sender_address_domain is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        sender_domains  = !*.uk
        dnslists        = whois.rfc-ignorant.org/$sender_address_domain

# Fortunately, it doesn't appear anybody legitimate has a broken
# ipwhois (or if I'm wrong, I haven't been burned by it yet).

  deny  message         = Your domain has bad ipwhois information, despite breaking RFC 954.  Please contact your mail provider to have this problem fixed.
        log_message     = $sender_host_address is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = ipwhois.rfc-ignorant.org

# Known spam havens.

  deny  message         = All mail from China, South Korea, Hong Kong, Brazil, Nigeria and Taiwan is rejected.  Please clean up your collective act and kill your spammers.
        log_message     = $sender_host_address is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = brazil.blackholes.us : cn-kr.blackholes.us : nigeria.blackholes.us : taiwan.blackholes.us

</example>

This combinations of RBLs turns up about one false positive every four
months or so for my site.



[1] I feel the whole United Linux and LSB issues are solutions looking
for problems Debian solved years ago...

b bit
B byte
kb kilobit

MB megabyte
Gb gigabit

Tb terabit

semi-DivX movies, using DivX for the video and Ogg for the audio;
these files usually end with .ogm.

From baloo at ursine.ca  Thu Sep  4 03:37:07 2003
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)
Date: Thu Sep  4 03:37:07 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Protecting bandwidth...
In-Reply-To: <1062616728.14143.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1062616728.14143.51.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Wed, Sep 03, 2003 at 12:18:48PM -0700, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> What would it take to avoid the bandwidth losses from spam?
> Do the ISPs have to stop it?

They don't have to but they should.

> Is email going to have to be graded by ISP's at some point
> based on a spam scale, 1 being definitely spam whereas 10
> would definitely not be spam?  How could such a system be
> implemented without creating zero privacy or large scale
> false positives?

Easy.  Messages start with a score of zero (neutral) and go above (is
spam) or below (isn't spam) points based on content.  User adjusts
thresholds to a score that is sane for the conditions they're in.
This is spamassassin's default behaviour.  Use exim4 with sa-exim and
*bam*, spammers past a score of 30 (you very, very rarely see ham with
a score higher than 4, so nothing actually not spam gets scored that
high) get teergrubed for 5 minutes (locking up a socket for them, thus
slowing them down, thus less spam sent to the rest of the world), and
rejects the spam.

> What percentage of email is spam and what is it's
> average affect on bandwidth in our area?

Vastly depends person to person, not region to region.  Some people do
things to invite spammers (like post their site on FFA pages, or use
AOL, etc.  Up until a couple years ago, Yahoo reserved the right to
sell your email address to whoever they damn well pleased, and did;
having a valid email address has always been a condition of membership
there, too).

> Another question is, how can sendmail be programmed
> to deal with overload gracefully?  

dpkg --purge sendmail && apt-get install exim4

> Should a primary server not accept retransmitted
> email?

That would mean anybody using their ISP's mail server wouldn't be able
to mail you.

> Clearly challenge response won't work because spammers
> will just program their generators to respond and it's
> the wrong answer for mailing lists like this one.  How
> long will E-Bay's type in this box what these symbols
> are work?

eBay got the idea from Yahoo, which as been doing it since I was in
middle school.  I'm now 21.

- --

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Sep  4 05:31:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Sep  4 05:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Q: comparison of video formats
In-Reply-To: <OFEC74928D.FE99A6B6-ON88256D96.0054E244-88256D96.0055432A@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>
Message-ID: <10588-05997@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 3 Sep 2003, lbrigman-at-fcpa.fujitsu.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> a great web site to answer most of your questions and more is
> 
> http://www.dvdrhelp.com/
> 
> It used to be vcdhelp.com and you can still get there by using that url.

I'll second this.  This is an excellent, excellent site for someome just
getting started with digital video.  I particularly like all the info they
have on VCD/SVCD/miniDVD for those of us who are too cheap to buy a DVD-R
burner and prefer to use cheap CD-R media.  (But still want the discs to
play in our DVD players...)

I've just started playing with dvd::rip, a perl-based DVD rip-and-convert
suite for linux.  The best way to try this out is to get "apt" from
http://www.freshrpms.net, install it, and then use apt to download
"perl-Video-DVDRip" from the same site.  The dependencies are a nightmare,
even with apt.

I've used dvd::rip in conjunction with "ffmpeg" (one of the dependencies)
to produce some very high quality MPEG-4 Divx-compatible video.  (I've had
some problems getting the "burn" portion of dvd::rip working, but I can
manually burn the images it creates without any problems.)

In the Windows world, I've found a combination of DVD2AVI, TMPGEnc, and
VCDEasy to work well.  This quick guide shows how:

http://www.dvdrhelp.com/mpeg2tovcd.htm

The quality with these tools seems somewhat lower than with ffmpeg.  Also,
VCDEasy recently went to nagware from freeware, so look for the pure
freeware version (http://www.google.com/search?q=vcdeasy+1.1.5.2).

  -- Steve




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Sep  4 05:53:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Sep  4 05:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] lsof
In-Reply-To: <1062646224.1503.37.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <27049-39648@sneakemail.com>

On 3 Sep 2003, Dirk Ouellette hapibeli-at-comcast.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> When trying to find a file that I think may be open, and instead of
> searching through every screen of #/usr/sbin/lsof, can I use grep to
> do a more refined, and quicker search?

If you already know the file you want to check, just:

lsof <filename>

You could also use:

fuser -u <filename>

(I think this works on Linux, but don't have a box handy to check with.)

One of the most common uses I have for lsof is to see what process is
listening on a given TCP port:

lsof -i tcp:80

Shows all processes that have TCP port 80 open.

  -- Steve

From jorgens at coho.net  Thu Sep  4 07:24:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Thu Sep  4 07:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
Message-ID: <01C372B5.FA35E930.jorgens@coho.net>

On Thursday, September 04, 2003 2:36 AM, Paul Johnson 
[SMTP:baloo at ursine.ca] wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
>
> On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 10:49:46PM -0700, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> > Now, regarding whether a database server is superior to a client-based
> > database engine with file shareing, there are cases where the file 
sharing
> > system is superior.
>
> Until you discover that the file-sharing system doesn't handle
> simultaneous transactions cleanly and it's a great way to corrupt data
> over time.  Database servers are easier to set up, too, so it's best
> just do it the Right Way.

Well, MS bashing is fun, but Access has managed to pretty much wipe DBase, 
Paradox, et al. right off the map for a reason.  It works pretty well. 
 Also, JET is the file-based database.  Access is a database front-end that 
includes JET if that's what you want to use.  And for all the disadvantages 
of a file-based system, it has plenty of advantages.
Some databases need relational and weak ACID capabilities, but they are 
used more in the context of documents than in the context of repositories. 
 You want to be able to make copies and open them on the fly like 
documents, etc.  If server daemons are such a great idea, why doesn't 
Gnumeric install a spreadsheet server?  Regarding the file corruption 
issue, most Access database corruption (in the back-end data files) arises 
from faulty NICs on an unswitched LAN and rarely occurs on a 
well-maintained LAN.  I've supported systems in production for years that 
demonstrate this.
I'm not saying Access is perfect - I bitch about it every day, and 
Microsoft's new licensing, only a Mother could love.  Every time I look for 
something else with the advantages Access has for my clients, though, I 
don't find it.  I'm hoping Meargent or Open Office reaches a point where it 
can work as a viable replacement soon, but as yet, they're not there.

From logiplex at qwest.net  Thu Sep  4 09:20:03 2003
From: logiplex at qwest.net (Cliff Wells)
Date: Thu Sep  4 09:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <01C371A4.859A6810.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C371A4.859A6810.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1062692369.28388.159.camel@software1.logiplex.internal>

On Tue, 2003-09-02 at 22:49, Steve Jorgensen wrote:

> As an Access developer (yes, I know, MS is evil, but Access what I've 
> become good at, and it's catually a good product), I must beg to differ. 
>  Access/JET is certainly a relational database, not a flat file database.

Agreed.

>  Access enforces relational integrity, supports transactions, rollbacks, 
> etc.  What Access is not is a Database server, though it makes a perfectly 
> good front-end for a database server.  

Agreed.

> Not only do I think Access is great, I was, for a while, heavily
> involved in an attempt to create a GPL, multi-platform replacement
> system.

Access *is* good at several things, mapping relations and creating
simple interfaces being a couple of them (although I find some of the
graphical tools more cumbersome than cli tools, that's probably just
me).

> The closest things to Access I have found in my wanderings appear to be 
> Meargent (part of the GNOME office project) and pgSQL, though the latter 
> works only with a PostgreSQL back-end.
> 
> Now, regarding whether a database server is superior to a client-based 
> database engine with file shareing, there are cases where the file sharing 
> system is superior.  

Ugh.  Strongly disagree.  I've corrupted enough Access databases trying
to have two or three users access them simultaneously that I can assure
you that file-sharing is a horrific approach.  If you need more than a
single user system, use a database server.

> Those are the cases where you need a database, but you 
> don't need the hassle of installing a server or hiring a DBA.  You can copy 
> your database file onto a CD, take it home, and open it up.  You don't have 
> to create a backup, go home, log into your server as an administrator, 
> create a database instance, decide where to put your log files, etc., then 
> restore from the backup, ...

Certainly simplicity is one of Access' strong points.  As long as you
don't try to use it as a replacement for a server, I'd have to concede
that it is fine (although having to install 150MB worth of software to
access a 15K database seems rather odd to me).   However, there is one
thing to consider (and this is true of any software tool):  if what
you've developed (be it with Access or anything else) is actually
useful, others will want to use it as well.  Of course, to avoid data
replication, you'll want to share the database, rather than give each
person their own copy.  Next thing you know you've got a real
maintenance problem because you've taken Access out of its niche.  From
my experience, if you're taking the time to develop a program, no matter
how seemingly trivial, you should always be prepared to have that
program become part of a larger system, as this seems to be the rule
rather than the exception.  Sometimes this leads to over-engineering a
simple program, but more often than not, it saves you from having to
start from scratch.


Regards,

-- 
Cliff Wells, Software Engineer
Logiplex Corporation (www.logiplex.net)
(503) 978-6726  (800) 735-0555




From holger at selover.net  Thu Sep  4 09:37:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Thu Sep  4 09:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <20030904093145.GI3105@ursine.ca>
References: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net>  <20030904093145.GI3105@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1062693389.2673.55.camel@halo>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 02:31, Paul Johnson wrote:
> Access hardly counts as a database in reality, there's not anything
> really equivilent to Access in Linux.
> 
> Just move up to some form of SQL.  apt-cache search sql to find
> available packages (debian based distros only, you're on your own in
> RPM land).

That ignores reality.

I'm on a contract to analyze my client's ERP system and look for
replacements. They have a bunch of supplementary Access databases they
use for reporting and data mining. Just two users on it to dig up the
data for others. Works like a charm and costs next to nothing. Should I
tell them to scrap it because Access doesn't count in db reality? 

Or my own situation: my partner can create the Access reports for our
material lists in matter of hours. With any other system I know it takes
days or weeks.

There are a lot of database situations with less than 5 users. And there
are and thousands of Access applications out there that help
coordinating the economy. Years ago I built an ERP/sales tool with
Access and sold it to companies with 2~15 users. I moved away and on,
don't support it any more but they still use it as the main tool for
bidding, ordering and invoicing, warehouse management and stuff. 

If we want to compete against an established monopoly it doesn't help to
ignore its strengths. 

Holger

PS Access does talk SQL. Not too far from ANSI either. 




From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Sep  4 09:38:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu Sep  4 09:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hostile Targets (was Verify plug-admin@...)
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C72B@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Jeff Schwaber:

> > I was there once.  Make yourself a hostile target and report
> > spammers.  I got my users to report spam themselves (and if they're
> > lazy, forwarding me their spam), my site is a pretty hostile target.
> > Spammers learn, though slowly.
> 
> You know, I vaguely remember there being a law against sending spam in
> Oregon or Washington, not sure which, but I thought it was Oregon, and
> there being stories of people successfully getting checks for 
> $300-$500
> out of spamming companies by sending them letters threatening 
> to sue in
> small claims court. Anyone know anything about this? I have 
> the time, i could go after spammers...

  I got this link from another mail list.  Make yourself a *really* hostile
target, *and* find a rewarding, well paying, socially active hobby.  Sue the
spammers!

Zen and the art of small claims

  "This guide is written for those who want to better the world and the self
through lawsuits. It focuses on filing small claims against telemarketers
who use recorded calls, junk faxers and a large percentage of spammers."

http://www.smallclaim.info/


Steve D...

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 00:57, Kevin Theobald wrote:
> AthlonRob writes:
> 
>  > Mid-March?  Might be the thread where I was trying to figure out how to
>  > nicely encode TV shows to fit two hours on a CD.  :-)
> 
> Oh, well, that's easy -- just edit out the commercials!

I was looking for something automated... and I haven't found an
automated way to edit out commercials yet.  :-\

> I've heard a couple of recommendations for divx.  How does it compare
> to MPEG-1?

A much higher compression rate... and just better?

> I figure if I use VCD or SVCD, then it can always be viewed in a
> standard DVD player (in most cases) and wouldn't require a computer.
> Also, can divx be viewed under Windows (without, say, expecting the
> Windows (l)users among the recipients to go download some tool?

Some newer DVD players support divx files, now.  As for viewing under
Windows... virtually all AVI files out there these days seem to be
encoded with DivX or as .mov files with Quicktime.  So if they've
downloaded TV episodes, game trailers, some movie trailers (which, in my
experience, tend to be .mov's)... etc... odds are they got and installed
the divx codec.  If not, you can grab it at divx.com.  I *think* Windows
XP will automagically grab the divx codec, but am not totally sure.   I
know Win9x doesn't like to do it automagically.


>  > Ok... is there a Linux alternative to grabbing the video?  Or if you can
>  > deal with storing 60 minutes at 25Mb/sec (I assume you mean megabyte,
>  > not bit)...
> 
> No -- standard convention is b=bit, B=byte.

So many people these days type Mb meaning megabyte and KB meaning
kilobit I had to check.  :-)

>  > I dunno... never played with VCD itself.  In my experience (a few years
>  > old) VCDs are hard to play in computers... finding a reader in Linux was
>  > a PITA.

**Brain freeze** ... I meant to type Windows 9x where I typed Linux.

> Never a problem for me.  When I did "apt-get install xine" the first
> thing I ran it on was my wife's VCDs.  (They're popular in Asia for
> recording TV series.  For TV source, you only really notice the low
> frame rate when they have, like, a sword fight.)  VCDs always worked
> -- DVDs were harder because of having to install the decss stuff
> manually.

CSS is a PITA.

>  > I use 2-pass divx encoding to encode TV shows... after they're encoded
>  > and all done (with about 3 hours of CPU time put in for one hour of TV)
>  > they're about 300MB an hour with about the same level of quality you'll
>  > get out of an antenna and a VCR, I think.
> 
> It sounds like divx does a much better job than MPEG-1, though
> "antenna" kind of makes me worry (from my experience living in
> Cambridge, Mass., which was about the last place in the US to get
> cable because of endless negotiations with the cable company
> wannabes).

If you want, I can record a few minutes of random TV, get it encoded,
and send it to you so you can better see the quality....  :-)

From logiplex at qwest.net  Thu Sep  4 10:29:01 2003
From: logiplex at qwest.net (Cliff Wells)
Date: Thu Sep  4 10:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The Beginning of the End
In-Reply-To: <E19uocf-0000DK-00@rooster>
References: <E19uocf-0000DK-00@rooster>
Message-ID: <1062692953.28388.177.camel@software1.logiplex.internal>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 00:33, Kevin Theobald wrote:
> > This would explain why SCO is so eager to challenge the GPL (it doesn't
> > want to have to release the source code for Unixware)
> 
> This seems to be a perennial fantasy among OSS fans: that some GPL'ed
> code is discovered in someone's code (oh, let it be Microsoft, please!),
> and they are thus forced to open-source ALL of their code.
> 
> But all the GPL says is what the conditions for COMPLIANCE are.  So if,
> say, MS were discovered with GPL code in Windows, the GPL would
> effectively say: IF you want to keep this in Windows, THEN you must
> release the rest of Windows (or at least the connected part) under the
> GPL.
> 
> If it ever came to a courtroom, a sympathetic judge might rule that they
> are out of compliance with the GPL.  But that wouldn't automatically
> lead to a ruling to GPL everything else.  Most likely, the judge would
> simply rule that they had to remove the GPL code.  If we were lucky, the
> judge might award monetary damages. especially if it could be shown that
> it was a deliberate violation, as opposed to, say, Sun getting it from
> SCO.

You're probably right.  Typically, even if the judge agreed that
requiring the company to GPL their software would be a legal/correct
judgement, he would also consider the impact doing so would have on the
company in question and temper his ruling based on that.  I suspect
almost any company could successfully argue that being forced to GPL
their code would mean the demise of the company and few judges are going
to intentionally dismantle a company over some copyright infringements
(unless it's Napster ;)

Still, as a fantasy, it's up there with my favorite featuring Bill Gates
being spanked with a flaming cat by Herve Villechaize, so try not to
rain on it, okay?

-- 
Cliff Wells, Software Engineer
Logiplex Corporation (www.logiplex.net)
(503) 978-6726  (800) 735-0555
