On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 09:36, Holger Stephan wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 02:31, Paul Johnson wrote:
> > Access hardly counts as a database in reality, there's not anything
> > really equivilent to Access in Linux.
> > 
> > Just move up to some form of SQL.  apt-cache search sql to find
> > available packages (debian based distros only, you're on your own in
> > RPM land).
> 
> That ignores reality.

[1]

> I'm on a contract to analyze my client's ERP system and look for
> replacements. They have a bunch of supplementary Access databases they
> use for reporting and data mining. Just two users on it to dig up the
> data for others. Works like a charm and costs next to nothing. Should I
> tell them to scrap it because Access doesn't count in db reality? 

Not at all.  But that isn't what you said.  You said you wanted an
*equivalent* to Access on Linux, not Access itself on Linux.  Besides,
if it works so well, why are you looking elsewhere?

> Or my own situation: my partner can create the Access reports for our
> material lists in matter of hours. With any other system I know it takes
> days or weeks.

That sounds more like "systems you *don't* know".  If other systems take
you that much longer, it's most likely because you aren't familiar with
those systems.

> There are a lot of database situations with less than 5 users.

True.  And more than 1 user is a problem for Access (using JET).

>  And there are and thousands of Access applications out there that help
> coordinating the economy. 

Are you referring to the US economy?  That would explain a lot ;)

> Years ago I built an ERP/sales tool with
> Access and sold it to companies with 2~15 users. I moved away and on,
> don't support it any more but they still use it as the main tool for
> bidding, ordering and invoicing, warehouse management and stuff. 

And have you actually followed up to see these user's experiences?  I'm
aware of plenty of systems where users have simply become used to the
flaws and don't complain about having to restore data, getting locked
out, crashes, having to avoid certain features, etc, etc.  They consider
it a basic cost of using computers.  It doesn't mean that there's
nothing wrong with the application, just that the users have figured out
how to live with it.

> If we want to compete against an established monopoly it doesn't help to
> ignore its strengths. 

Not competing.  Simply using the best tools.


1. Gleefully ignoring reality since 1994.

From logiplex at qwest.net  Thu Sep  4 11:05:02 2003
From: logiplex at qwest.net (Cliff Wells)
Date: Thu Sep  4 11:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <01C372B5.FA35E930.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C372B5.FA35E930.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1062695402.28388.260.camel@software1.logiplex.internal>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 07:27, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> On Thursday, September 04, 2003 2:36 AM, Paul Johnson 
> [SMTP:baloo at ursine.ca] wrote:
> > -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> > Hash: SHA1
> >
> > On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 10:49:46PM -0700, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> > > Now, regarding whether a database server is superior to a client-based
> > > database engine with file shareing, there are cases where the file 
> sharing
> > > system is superior.
> >
> > Until you discover that the file-sharing system doesn't handle
> > simultaneous transactions cleanly and it's a great way to corrupt data
> > over time.  Database servers are easier to set up, too, so it's best
> > just do it the Right Way.
> 
> Well, MS bashing is fun, but Access has managed to pretty much wipe DBase, 
> Paradox, et al. right off the map for a reason.  It works pretty well.

So Access sits at the top of the heap of toy databases.  Not much of an
accolade, IMO.

>  Also, JET is the file-based database.  Access is a database front-end that 
> includes JET if that's what you want to use. 

True.  And Access is fine for painting simple GUI's.

>  And for all the disadvantages 
> of a file-based system, it has plenty of advantages.
> Some databases need relational and weak ACID capabilities, but they are 
> used more in the context of documents than in the context of repositories. 
>  You want to be able to make copies and open them on the fly like 
> documents, etc.  If server daemons are such a great idea, why doesn't 
> Gnumeric install a spreadsheet server?

Because spreadsheets aren't typically used in a multi-user application
setting.  The basic paradigms don't fit.  How would an application
handle one user editing cell A1 while another tried to calculate the sum
of a range that included that cell?  I don't think you thought this out
very well.

> Regarding the file corruption issue, most Access database corruption
> (in the back-end data files) arises from faulty NICs on an unswitched
> LAN and rarely occurs on a well-maintained LAN.  

This is pure hooey ;)  I've never even used Access on an unswitched
LAN.  Whether there were faulty NICs that somehow only corrupted Access
data, I can't be certain, but any software this intolerant to a
networked environment shouldn't be used in one.

> I've supported systems in production for years that 
> demonstrate this.

Well, I consider you very lucky ;)

> I'm not saying Access is perfect - I bitch about it every day

Hm... I bitch about PostgreSQL every... well, let's see, um, I can't
recall...

> Microsoft's new licensing, only a Mother could love.  Every time I look for 
> something else with the advantages Access has for my clients, though, I 
> don't find it.  I'm hoping Meargent or Open Office reaches a point where it 
> can work as a viable replacement soon, but as yet, they're not there.

What is it you are looking for?  Is it simply the GUI builder?  Frankly,
that's the only thing I can see where Access has any clear advantage
over anything else.  And that advantage is strongly mitigated by the
requirement to use VB.  Not to mention that the GUI builder, while
convenient, is hardly viable for building complex GUIs.

If you are simply looking for a good toolbox for developing database
applications, I'd suggest the following:

PostgreSQL (or MySQL, if your database requirements are simple)
Python
wxPython (see also Boa Constructor, for building GUI's)


Granted, you don't get the "all-in-one" development system Access
provides.  You also don't get the lack of scalability, the data
corruption, VB, the licensing fees, VB, VB, the vendor lock-in, etc.

What you do get is a robust and powerful database, a simple yet powerful
programming language and a very flexible GUI toolkit.  And it's all
cross-platform and open source.

Regards,

-- 
Cliff Wells, Software Engineer
Logiplex Corporation (www.logiplex.net)
(503) 978-6726  (800) 735-0555

> > material lists in matter of hours. With any other system I know it takes

is close to as easy and quick to handle as Access. With my partner's
basic knowledge of databases and experience with Access he would be OK
with learning a new system if it is not much more tedious to get things
done with it.

installation that may never really get done and drains the budget to an

> > don't support it any more but they still use it as the main tool for
> > bidding, ordering and invoicing, warehouse management and stuff. 
> 
> And have you actually followed up to see these user's experiences?  I'm

Yes. They love the system and preserve boxes just to make sure it does
not get killed by updates. That's one of the big drawbacks of Access. It
is an Office component and so much integration can cause plenty of
problems. 


> > If we want to compete against an established monopoly it doesn't help to
> > ignore its strengths. 
> 
> Not competing.  Simply using the best tools.

With competing I mean trying to create or support other tools to break
the monopoly and keep the market moving. Aren't we all on this group
deliberately using less advanced tools for that purpose?


> 1. Gleefully ignoring reality since 1994.

It's a big world out there with lots of cracks and spots for those who
create their own reality and still survive. Not talking about you, but
after seeing software developers taking years to develop something for
their clients that is obviously not up for the task. Nobody checks the
market and compares and so it becomes the accepted standard in this
crack.

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 12:23, Holger Stephan wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 10:28, Cliff Wells wrote:
> > > I'm on a contract to analyze my client's ERP system and look for
> > > replacements. They have a bunch of supplementary Access databases they
> > > use for reporting and data mining. Just two users on it to dig up the
> > > data for others. Works like a charm and costs next to nothing. Should I
> > > tell them to scrap it because Access doesn't count in db reality? 
> > 
> > Not at all.  But that isn't what you said.  You said you wanted an
> > *equivalent* to Access on Linux, not Access itself on Linux.  Besides,
> > if it works so well, why are you looking elsewhere?
> 
> That was just an example of where Access works well. I was asking for a
> different application (that of my partner in a different venture). 

Okay, then let's stick with what you're trying to accomplish and argue
the merits of Access *there* rather than in hypothetical or unrelated
ventures.

> > > Or my own situation: my partner can create the Access reports for our
> > > material lists in matter of hours. With any other system I know it takes
> > > days or weeks.
> > 
> > That sounds more like "systems you *don't* know".  If other systems take
> > you that much longer, it's most likely because you aren't familiar with
> > those systems.
> 
> That's not only because of familiarity. I was looking for a system that
> is close to as easy and quick to handle as Access. With my partner's
> basic knowledge of databases and experience with Access he would be OK
> with learning a new system if it is not much more tedious to get things
> done with it. 

What is it about Access that makes it easy to use?  Honestly I found
MySQL to be far simpler than Access from a database perspective and
Python far simpler than VB (and more powerful as well) from a
programming POV.  So when you ask for something "like" Access, you
really should decide which features it provides that simplify life for
you (or your partner).  If it's the GUI-painter, then look for IDE's
that provide such a feature, if it's the administrative tools, then look
for those.  If it's the whole integration thing, then you probably won't
find it (yet).

> > > There are a lot of database situations with less than 5 users.
> > 
> > True.  And more than 1 user is a problem for Access (using JET).
> 
> Not true since Access 97. 

It was 97 I used.  It sucked.  Constantly corrupting data.  It sucked
differently when I tried using ODBC to access MySQL to avoid the
corruption (constant claims that the database was "locked").  In the end
I saved time by just skipping the whole Access thing and writing a
front-end in Python for the MySQL database.

> > >  And there are and thousands of Access applications out there that help
> > > coordinating the economy. 
> > 
> > Are you referring to the US economy?  That would explain a lot ;)
> 
> World wide. And it's very often a better thing than a $1mil SAP
> installation that may never really get done and drains the budget to an
> extend that a healthy upgrade path can't be followed. 

Er, who mentioned SAP or $1mil?  I thought we were talking open source
solutions (specifically database servers) versus MS Access.

> > > Years ago I built an ERP/sales tool with
> > > Access and sold it to companies with 2~15 users. I moved away and on,
> > > don't support it any more but they still use it as the main tool for
> > > bidding, ordering and invoicing, warehouse management and stuff. 
> > 
> > And have you actually followed up to see these user's experiences?  I'm
> 
> Yes. They love the system and preserve boxes just to make sure it does
> not get killed by updates. That's one of the big drawbacks of Access. It
> is an Office component and so much integration can cause plenty of
> problems. 

Undoubtledly.  However, in all fairness, updates and headaches aren't
exclusive to Microsoft.

> > > If we want to compete against an established monopoly it doesn't help to
> > > ignore its strengths. 
> > 
> > Not competing.  Simply using the best tools.
> 
> With competing I mean trying to create or support other tools to break
> the monopoly and keep the market moving. Aren't we all on this group
> deliberately using less advanced tools for that purpose?

It depends on what you mean.  It's true that some of the tools I use
don't have all the bells and whistles of a MS product.  However, I've
found that all the flashy stuff means jack when it comes time to debug
an obscure problem.  OSS tools typically provide less obscure problems
than do proprietary products.  The development time saved by using a
fancy GUI builder will never outweigh the time saved by not having to
debug a bizarre interaction between DCOM, Access and a mouse driver from
3000 miles away ;)

> > 1. Gleefully ignoring reality since 1994.
> 
> It's a big world out there with lots of cracks and spots for those who
> create their own reality and still survive. 

I was referring to the date I started using Linux (against all the
realists advice to the contrary).  There is a fine line between being a
crackpot and being an early adopter. The simple fact was, it worked for
what I needed it to do.  There were no fancy GUIs or tools, but those
are just fluff for the most part anyway.  I think if you gave some other
tools a try, you might find the same thing about Access.  In most cases,
the GUI just makes it *appear* easy, it doesn't *really* make it any
easier.

> Not talking about you, but
> after seeing software developers taking years to develop something for
> their clients that is obviously not up for the task. Nobody checks the
> market and compares and so it becomes the accepted standard in this
> crack.

I guess my point is that Access does nothing that I can't do by hand in
about the same amount of time (and better).  If you are a programmer, I
would think you could do the same.  If you aren't then perhaps that's a
different story.  


Regards,

From mikedela at ipns.com  Thu Sep  4 13:59:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu Sep  4 13:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
Message-ID: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

I've got a remote server that I visited today. It was running very badly
and I couldn't figure it out. After an hour, I went for a reboot.

On reboot, I discovered that it did not think it still had a /dev/hda6
swap partition. dmseg shows:

Partition check:
 hda: hda1 hda2 < hda5 >
 hdb: [PTBL] [1247/255/63] hdb1 hdb2 < hdb5 hdb6 hdb7 hdb8 hdb9 >

and

EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended



The system has been up for a year or so, maybe two. I ran:
# fsck /dev/hda6
fsck 1.26 (3-Feb-2002)
fsck: fsck.swap: not found
fsck: Error 2 while executing fsck.swap for /dev/hda6

What do I do next? I have current backups, but I don't want to trash the
partition table. 

I'm looking to see how to find fsck.swap, it seems to be missing
somehow...



-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com





From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu Sep  4 14:06:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Sep  4 14:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
In-Reply-To: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1062709509.31532.2.camel@localhost>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 13:58, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I've got a remote server that I visited today. It was running very badly
> and I couldn't figure it out. After an hour, I went for a reboot.
> 
> On reboot, I discovered that it did not think it still had a /dev/hda6
> swap partition. dmseg shows:
> 
> Partition check:
>  hda: hda1 hda2 < hda5 >
>  hdb: [PTBL] [1247/255/63] hdb1 hdb2 < hdb5 hdb6 hdb7 hdb8 hdb9 >
> 
> and
> 
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> 
> 
> 
> The system has been up for a year or so, maybe two. I ran:
> # fsck /dev/hda6
> fsck 1.26 (3-Feb-2002)
> fsck: fsck.swap: not found
> fsck: Error 2 while executing fsck.swap for /dev/hda6
> 
> What do I do next? I have current backups, but I don't want to trash the
> partition table. 
> 
> I'm looking to see how to find fsck.swap, it seems to be missing
> somehow...

When you run fsck /some/partition it seems to check that partition type
and call fsck.thatpartitiontype.  In this case, it seems /dev/hda6 is a
swap partition, so it goes looking for fsck.swap, which it isn't finding
(and for good reason).

So, it seems /dev/hda6 is a swap partition.  You don't fsck those.

Check /etc/fstab and see what you have there that might need to be
fsck'd.  :-)

Rob




From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Thu Sep  4 14:09:02 2003

From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Thu Sep  4 14:11:01 2003
From: garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com (Grigsby, Garl)
Date: Thu Sep  4 14:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
Message-ID: <FDEF90F7203F4F46BDE4151DE7A0752D2C8A06@cvgexsrv1.sdrc.com>

I was thinking you could just replace the fsck.swap from another running machine, but in the mean time you can just reformat the swap partition (mkswap /dev/hda6) and then turn the swap partition on (swapon -a). 

Garl

From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Thu Sep  4 14:18:03 2003
From: garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com (Grigsby, Garl)
Date: Thu Sep  4 14:18:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
Message-ID: <FDEF90F7203F4F46BDE4151DE7A0752D2C8A07@cvgexsrv1.sdrc.com>

Doh! I guess I should read the message more carefully (and turn my brain on). You won't have a fsck.swap because you don't fsck swap partitions. Try fdisking the drive to see what is really in the partition table. Does hda6 exist? If not, then it maybe something old that is left over in you fstab file. If it does exist, you might still try reformatting it. 

Garl

From logiplex at qwest.net  Thu Sep  4 14:20:02 2003
From: logiplex at qwest.net (Cliff Wells)
Date: Thu Sep  4 14:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
In-Reply-To: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1062710359.28388.617.camel@software1.logiplex.internal>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 13:58, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I've got a remote server that I visited today. It was running very badly
> and I couldn't figure it out. After an hour, I went for a reboot.
> 
> On reboot, I discovered that it did not think it still had a /dev/hda6
> swap partition. dmseg shows:
> 
> Partition check:
>  hda: hda1 hda2 < hda5 >
>  hdb: [PTBL] [1247/255/63] hdb1 hdb2 < hdb5 hdb6 hdb7 hdb8 hdb9 >
> 
> and
> 
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> 
> 
> 
> The system has been up for a year or so, maybe two. I ran:
> # fsck /dev/hda6
> fsck 1.26 (3-Feb-2002)
> fsck: fsck.swap: not found
> fsck: Error 2 while executing fsck.swap for /dev/hda6
> 
> What do I do next? I have current backups, but I don't want to trash the
> partition table. 
> 
> I'm looking to see how to find fsck.swap, it seems to be missing
> somehow...

AFAIK, there is no such thing.  A swap partition has no filesystem so
there is no reason to run a filesystem check (fsck) on it.  You can
simply run mkswap/swapon on it.  You should first verify the partition
table by running fdisk on it. 

The ext2 errors are probably unrelated, although it sounds as if you
should run fsck on your other partitions.

Regards,

-- 
Cliff Wells, Software Engineer
Logiplex Corporation (www.logiplex.net)
(503) 978-6726  (800) 735-0555




From drl at drloree.com  Thu Sep  4 14:33:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Sep  4 14:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
In-Reply-To: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1062711759.585.59.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 13:58, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I've got a remote server that I visited today. It was running very badly
> and I couldn't figure it out. After an hour, I went for a reboot.
> 
> On reboot, I discovered that it did not think it still had a /dev/hda6
> swap partition. dmseg shows:
> 
> Partition check:
>  hda: hda1 hda2 < hda5 >
>  hdb: [PTBL] [1247/255/63] hdb1 hdb2 < hdb5 hdb6 hdb7 hdb8 hdb9 >
> 
> and
> 
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is recommended
> 
> 
> 
> The system has been up for a year or so, maybe two. I ran:
> # fsck /dev/hda6
> fsck 1.26 (3-Feb-2002)
> fsck: fsck.swap: not found
> fsck: Error 2 while executing fsck.swap for /dev/hda6
> 
> What do I do next? I have current backups, but I don't want to trash the
> partition table. 

fsck is a file system checking utility, not a partition checking
utility.  Use fdisk /dev/hda to find out how the partition table is set
(don't worry, it won't write to the partition table unless you tell it
to).  This drive is probably starting to go bad, and should be
thoroughly tested with the manufacturer's utilities.
> 
> I'm looking to see how to find fsck.swap, it seems to be missing
> somehow...

No need for such a tool:

swapoff /dev/hda6
mkswap /dev/hda6
swapon /dev/hda6

will reset a swap file system, but only if /dev/hda6 can be found.

HTH

Derek Loree

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Sep  4 14:46:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Sep  4 14:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Odd perms on vmware:/mnt/hgfs
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309041422310.10120@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Note: This message mentions proprietary software. If you are
      philosophically opposed to such things, don't read this message.
      If you feel obliged to reply to the effect of "why in the ^%##$
      are you using unFree software?" then please direct your message
      elsewhere, to someone who cares.

One of our users had me install VMware on his laptop, which runs
Windows 2000, and then install Linux in a virtual machine. I haven't
had much experience with VMware, but after a couple tries I got things
running smoothly.

One of this guy's requirements was that he be able to read and write
to the Windows filesystem from the Linux host. It turns out that
VMware supports this sort of thing natively, no samba required, via a
proprietary kernel module, vmhgfs. I exported his entire c: drive
under the share name 'c-drive'.

The resulting filesystem, typically /mnt/hgfs, is an odd thing:

* it won't show up when you run mount without arguments
* it won't show up in df results
* do a lsattr, chmod, chown, or chgrp on it, and all you'll get for
  your efforts is a bunch of error messages

The permissions look really restrictive to /bin/ls or a gui file
manager like nautilus. I'm doing this from memory, but this is pretty
close:

  dr-x------  root  root  /mnt/hgfs
  drwx------  root  root  /mnt/hgfs/c-drive

Oddly, however, is that a Linux user can still cd into those
directories, read and create files, etc.

Wierd, eh?

Anyway, I just thought I'd pass this along in case someone (else :-)
gets tripped up over the permissions on the exports, which look
restrictive but aren't.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Mike

Most likely, this is because Windows doesn't really have the same 
concept of user permissions as *nix.

The same reason you'll have a similar experience with samba and a 
Windows machine.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Sep  4 15:15:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Sep  4 15:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Odd perms on vmware:/mnt/hgfs
In-Reply-To: <3F57B5B9.9040202@dimstar.net>

 <3F57B5B9.9040202@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309041506050.10120@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 4 Sep 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> > The permissions look really restrictive to /bin/ls or a gui file
> > manager like nautilus. I'm doing this from memory, but this is
> > pretty close:
> >
> >   dr-x------  root  root  /mnt/hgfs
> >   drwx------  root  root  /mnt/hgfs/c-drive
>
> Most likely, this is because Windows doesn't really have the same
> concept of user permissions as *nix.

Maybe. My hunch is that it has more to do with how the VMware kernel
module operates than the NTFS filesystem -- but it's just a hunch. You
could easily be correct.

> The same reason you'll have a similar experience with samba and a
> Windows machine.

Except that with samba, the permissions look somewhat normal, even if
they're inaccurate. E.g.,

  directories == drwxr-xr-x    1 heinlein heinlein
  files       == -rwxr-xr-x    1 heinlein heinlein

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Thu Sep  4 16:45:02 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Thu Sep  4 16:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
In-Reply-To: <1062711759.585.59.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <1062709131.1632.30.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> 
	<1062711759.585.59.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <1062719062.1155.46.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 14:42, Derek Loree wrote:
> No need for such a tool:
> 
> swapoff /dev/hda6
> mkswap /dev/hda6
> swapon /dev/hda6
> 
> will reset a swap file system, but only if /dev/hda6 can be found.
> 

That was the trick. top now reports swap usage.

I poked around in fdisk to be certain that the partition was actually
there, first. 

I hadn't seen this before, it was a little freaky.

Mike

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Thu Sep  4 18:07:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Thu Sep  4 18:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
In-Reply-To: <FDEF90F7203F4F46BDE4151DE7A0752D2C8A07@cvgexsrv1.sdrc.com>
References: <FDEF90F7203F4F46BDE4151DE7A0752D2C8A07@cvgexsrv1.sdrc.com>
Message-ID: <200309041544.37649.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

On Thursday 04 September 2003 14:17, Grigsby, Garl wrote:
> Doh! I guess I should read the message more carefully (and turn my brain
> on). You won't have a fsck.swap because you don't fsck swap partitions. Try
> fdisking the drive to see what is really in the partition table. Does hda6
> exist? If not, then it maybe something old that is left over in you fstab
> file. If it does exist, you might still try reformatting it.
>
> Garl
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Grigsby, Garl
> > Sent: Thursday, September 04, 2003 2:10 PM
> > To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > Subject: RE: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
> >
> >
> > I was thinking you could just replace the fsck.swap from
> > another running machine, but in the mean time you can just
> > reformat the swap partition (mkswap /dev/hda6) and then turn
> > the swap partition on (swapon -a).
> >
> > Garl
> >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Mike De La Mater [mailto:mikedela at ipns.com]
> > > Sent: Thursday, September 04, 2003 1:59 PM
> > > To: PLUG general list
> > > Subject: [PLUG] no more /dev/hda6
> > >
> > >
> > > I've got a remote server that I visited today. It was running
> > > very badly
> > > and I couldn't figure it out. After an hour, I went for a reboot.
> > >
> > > On reboot, I discovered that it did not think it still had
> >
> > a /dev/hda6
> >
> > > swap partition. dmseg shows:
> > >
> > > Partition check:
> > >  hda: hda1 hda2 < hda5 >
> > >  hdb: [PTBL] [1247/255/63] hdb1 hdb2 < hdb5 hdb6 hdb7 hdb8 hdb9 >
> > >
> > > and
> > >
> > > EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is
> >
> > recommended
> >
> > > EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is
> >
> > recommended
> >
> > > EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is
> >
> > recommended
> >
> > > EXT2-fs warning: mounting unchecked fs, running e2fsck is
> >
> > recommended
> >
> > > The system has been up for a year or so, maybe two. I ran:
> > > # fsck /dev/hda6
> > > fsck 1.26 (3-Feb-2002)
> > > fsck: fsck.swap: not found
> > > fsck: Error 2 while executing fsck.swap for /dev/hda6
> > >
> > > What do I do next? I have current backups, but I don't want
> > > to trash the
> > > partition table.
> > >
> > > I'm looking to see how to find fsck.swap, it seems to be missing
> > > somehow...
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > --
> > > Mike De La Mater
> > > Small Business Networks and Consulting
> > > 503-702-6749
> > > mikedela at ipns.com

Mike,

Another possibility that you might want to consider is that the drive is 
failing.  You might want to check your logs for warnings and errors when 
attempting to do I/O on the drive.  If it is failing, you'll want to move 
everything off of it and onto a replacement drive a.s.a.p.  Drive failures 
are the most frequent hardware failures and they happen more often than most 
people would expect.

Mark

See http://www.amath.washington.edu/~mmartin/resume/ for details.

From jorgens at coho.net  Thu Sep  4 18:23:01 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Thu Sep  4 18:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
Message-ID: <01C37311.FC4C8F60.jorgens@coho.net>

On Thursday, September 04, 2003 10:28 AM, Cliff Wells 
[SMTP:logiplex at qwest.net] wrote:
...
> That sounds more like "systems you *don't* know".  If other systems take
> you that much longer, it's most likely because you aren't familiar with
> those systems.
>
> > There are a lot of database situations with less than 5 users.
>
> True.  And more than 1 user is a problem for Access (using JET).

That's simply a load of hooey.  I've run several systems with 10 or 20 
users, and they all worked fine.  Occasional corruption was always 
repairable except in one case, and that's what backups are for.  Of course, 
if the loss of a 1/2 days work is costy, then I agree, JET/MDB is not the 
right database engine, though at least for reporting, Access is still 
definitely the best front-end I know of.

...
> > Years ago I built an ERP/sales tool with
> > Access and sold it to companies with 2~15 users. I moved away and on,
> > don't support it any more but they still use it as the main tool for
> > bidding, ordering and invoicing, warehouse management and stuff.
>
> And have you actually followed up to see these user's experiences?  I'm
> aware of plenty of systems where users have simply become used to the
> flaws and don't complain about having to restore data, getting locked
> out, crashes, having to avoid certain features, etc, etc.  They consider
> it a basic cost of using computers.  It doesn't mean that there's
> nothing wrong with the application, just that the users have figured out
> how to live with it.

I'm an Access developer, and I support the systems I create.  Right now, 
I'm helping a client update a system that's been running 'til now in Access 
2.0 (16-bit).

> > If we want to compete against an established monopoly it doesn't help 
to
> > ignore its strengths.
>
> Not competing.  Simply using the best tools.

Well, best depends on what you're trying to accomplish, and in how much 
time.  it also depends on whether you want your client to be able to do 
basic maintenance themselves without having to learn a programming 
language.

> 1. Gleefully ignoring reality since 1994.

Or simply working on projects with different priorities.




From jorgens at coho.net  Thu Sep  4 18:41:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Thu Sep  4 18:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
Message-ID: <01C37314.7B309EF0.jorgens@coho.net>

On Thursday, September 04, 2003 10:10 AM, Cliff Wells 
[SMTP:logiplex at qwest.net] wrote:
> > Well, MS bashing is fun, but Access has managed to pretty much wipe 
DBase,
> > Paradox, et al. right off the map for a reason.  It works pretty well.
>
> So Access sits at the top of the heap of toy databases.  Not much of an
> accolade, IMO.

Is a spreadsheet Excel a toy because it's for smaller jobs?  Tell that to 
your CEO.  I'd say "small" rather than "toy" furthermore, I would not limit 
the scope to single-user systems.  Say what you will, database servers 
require at least part time database administrators, and require a 
maintenance of staff expertise during turnovers, etc.  In many cases, there 
is not a requirement for 24-hour up-time, rapid recovery from failures, 
ultra-fast performance, or lock-tight security.  In these cases, the cost 
of maintaining a server database is vastly too high.

> >  Also, JET is the file-based database.  Access is a database front-end 
that
> > includes JET if that's what you want to use.
>
> True.  And Access is fine for painting simple GUI's.

For certain values of simple, and I agree.  Up to department scale, Access 
advantages outweigh its disadvantages.  Above than, the lack of better OOP 
and the invisibility of large parts of the application to the compiler lead 
to higher than acceptable defect ratios.

> >  And for all the disadvantages
> > of a file-based system, it has plenty of advantages.
> > Some databases need relational and weak ACID capabilities, but they are 
> > used more in the context of documents than in the context of 
repositories.
> >  You want to be able to make copies and open them on the fly like
> > documents, etc.  If server daemons are such a great idea, why doesn't
> > Gnumeric install a spreadsheet server?
>
> Because spreadsheets aren't typically used in a multi-user application
> setting.  The basic paradigms don't fit.  How would an application
> handle one user editing cell A1 while another tried to calculate the sum
> of a range that included that cell?  I don't think you thought this out
> very well.

I don't see that we are disagreeing that much.  I would use JET for a 10 
user syste, and you wouldn't use it for more than 1.  We both agree it's 
not for large-scale deployments.

> > Regarding the file corruption issue, most Access database corruption
> > (in the back-end data files) arises from faulty NICs on an unswitched
> > LAN and rarely occurs on a well-maintained LAN.
>
> This is pure hooey ;)  I've never even used Access on an unswitched
> LAN.  Whether there were faulty NICs that somehow only corrupted Access
> data, I can't be certain, but any software this intolerant to a
> networked environment shouldn't be used in one.

Well, I don't know where your problems came from, then.  Access back-ends 
do corrupt from time to time as one would expect in any shared-file system. 
 I certainly never found this to be a chronic issue unless there was some 
kind of problem with the network.

> > I've supported systems in production for years that
> > demonstrate this.
>
> Well, I consider you very lucky ;)

I guess we'll agree to differ on this.  Access does require occasional 
compact/repair operations to clean up problems before they affect data. 
 Any decent Access app will have a feature for doing this built-in.

> > I'm not saying Access is perfect - I bitch about it every day
>
> Hm... I bitch about PostgreSQL every... well, let's see, um, I can't
> recall...

I'm working on an Access fron-end to a PostgreSQL database now, and the DBA 
is having a hulluva time with it.  Perhaps, you are just more intelligent 
than him, but that just underscores the difference in complexity and cost 
of maintaining a server vs a file.  I guess if you're a DBA yourself, it's 
easy to think maintaining a server is no big deal.

> > Microsoft's new licensing, only a Mother could love.  Every time I look 
for
> > something else with the advantages Access has for my clients, though, I 
> > don't find it.  I'm hoping Meargent or Open Office reaches a point 
where it
> > can work as a viable replacement soon, but as yet, they're not there.
>
> What is it you are looking for?  Is it simply the GUI builder?  Frankly,
> that's the only thing I can see where Access has any clear advantage
> over anything else.  And that advantage is strongly mitigated by the
> requirement to use VB.  Not to mention that the GUI builder, while
> convenient, is hardly viable for building complex GUIs.
>
> If you are simply looking for a good toolbox for developing database
> applications, I'd suggest the following:
>
> PostgreSQL (or MySQL, if your database requirements are simple)
> Python
> wxPython (see also Boa Constructor, for building GUI's)

That works out OK except the client has to pay me or another developer to 
come in and make any kind of a change.  That could price some of the 
projects I take out of the client's range.  Besides that, it takes no 
account of reporting.  Reporting is always a thorny issue, and Access 
handles it quite well.  There is also an appropriate amount of overlap 
between the Form/Report models so much of the GUI design and some of the 
code can simply be pasted from one to the other.

> Granted, you don't get the "all-in-one" development system Access
> provides.  You also don't get the lack of scalability, the data
> corruption, VB, the licensing fees, VB, VB, the vendor lock-in, etc.

All good things, and all reasons I'm always considering everything as an 
option.  I'm actually learning Java and C# just now as alternatives for 
some projects.

> What you do get is a robust and powerful database, a simple yet powerful
> programming language and a very flexible GUI toolkit.  And it's all
> cross-platform and open source.

All good things, and all without the other unique Access benefits I've 
outlined above.

From jorgens at coho.net  Thu Sep  4 21:06:02 2003
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Thu Sep  4 21:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
Message-ID: <01C37328.B6ED31B0.jorgens@coho.net>

Sorry - my bad.  I just realized how much traffic I was contributing, and 
it's not exactly on-topic.  I just get tired of everyone thinking that you 
can plug-and-play replace any app with a bunch of scripts, and be just as 
productive.

If an app fills a niche well, it's very valuable in the context it fills. 
 To replace it, you have to actually design something that has roughly the 
same advantages.  In this case, it hasn't been done, and I'm waiting for 
the day.  I think Meargent may get there soon.

I'm done adding to this thread now, and sorry for the excessive OT posting.

From baloo at ursine.ca  Thu Sep  4 21:37:01 2003
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)

authenticated SMTP. So they don't care what email address I use as the
>From field since they can trace it to me if they have to (i.e. if I'm
abusive). This is quite normal practice.

From freyley at gmx.net  Thu Sep  4 21:53:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu Sep  4 21:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <20030905044529.GL2556@ursine.ca>
References: <3F5525A7.90406@selover.net> <20030904093145.GI3105@ursine.ca>
	 <1062693389.2673.55.camel@halo>  <20030905044529.GL2556@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1062737520.6969.26.camel@localhost>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 21:45, Paul Johnson wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
> 
> On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 09:36:28AM -0700, Holger Stephan wrote:
> > Works like a charm and costs next to nothing.
> 
> Don't take this the wrong way, but are you high, or just loaded with
> money and forgotten the value of a dollar?  MS Access is $279 per
> user.  In your scenario, how does $558 equate to "next to nothing?"
> For that money, I could go apt-get install mysql and go spend that
> $558 on rent and groceries and *still* have money left in my wallet.

Yes, but at $120/hr, which is what I believe Wil charges for consulting
services, the scripts to do with mysql which a computer literate college
graduate making $12/hr could do (assuming the same amount of time for
the scripts vs the gui) works out to about the same. And you don't have
to bring the consultant back in to change something minor in Access.

Access corrupts data, it's a closed, proprietary format, and its default
format is not an ACID-compliant database, but I can teach a monkey to
use it.

Anyway, I'm not sure why I even bothered to contribute to this, except
to say that I am very sad that there is not a good set of gui database
management tools out there for Linux, but either I don't know of them,
or they don't exist (and don't point me to a window wrapper around the
mysql command line. I'm talking about something that saves time. It's
true, when you're writing large applications, large databases, etc,
command line stuff saves time. But when you're putting together
something small, something quick and dirty, or something just quickly, a
full-fledged database SUCKS. Actually writing SQL for it SUCKS. And
nobody has recognized this.

I think I lost track of a parenthese.

Jeff

On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 07:27:15AM -0700, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> Well, MS bashing is fun, but Access has managed to pretty much wipe DBase, 
> Paradox, et al. right off the map for a reason.  It works pretty well. 

Yeah, in the whole single-user,
can't-share-your-data-with-others-at-the-same-time-you're-using-it
sort of way.  If all that's using it is exactly one person, then yeah,
Access does it's job.  Or if you're using Access as a client for a
real DB.

> If server daemons are such a great idea, why doesn't Gnumeric
> install a spreadsheet server?

Because spreadsheets tend to be used as ledgerbooks, not interactive
data collection from 2 or more users.

> Regarding the file corruption issue, most Access database corruption
> (in the back-end data files) arises from faulty NICs on an
> unswitched LAN and rarely occurs on a well-maintained LAN.

What makes you think that, when the problem has to do with two users
trying to write the same file with conflicting information?

On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 06:43:42PM -0700, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> Is a spreadsheet Excel a toy because it's for smaller jobs?  Tell that to 
> your CEO.  I'd say "small" rather than "toy" furthermore, I would not limit 
> the scope to single-user systems.  Say what you will, database servers 
> require at least part time database administrators, and require a 
> maintenance of staff expertise during turnovers, etc.

I'm no database administrator and mysql mostly maintains itself.  And
it has a far smaller memory footprint than Access, and quite a bit
zippier, even for single user jobs.  Odd how heavy Access is for a
single-user-only operation, yet doesn't scale at all.

> In many cases, there 
> is not a requirement for 24-hour up-time, rapid recovery from failures, 
> ultra-fast performance, or lock-tight security.  In these cases, the cost 
> of maintaining a server database is vastly too high.

Now you're just trying to justify wasting a career fixing broken toys.

> I don't see that we are disagreeing that much.  I would use JET for a 10 
> user syste, and you wouldn't use it for more than 1.  We both agree it's 
> not for large-scale deployments.

2 is a large scale?

> Well, I don't know where your problems came from, then.  Access back-ends 
> do corrupt from time to time as one would expect in any shared-file system. 

Which is why you run a server so only one entity is accessing the
files themselves, letting the users worry about actually doing their
jobs than if they're going to throw out today's work thanks to
corruption.  Why do you find wasting people's professional time that
way acceptable?

>  I certainly never found this to be a chronic issue unless there was some 
> kind of problem with the network.

If that were the case, then it would cause similarly frequent problems
for other kinds of files.  Notice how it doesn't.

> I guess we'll agree to differ on this.  Access does require occasional 
> compact/repair operations to clean up problems before they affect data. 

SQL in the same small user environments doesn't.

>  Any decent Access app will have a feature for doing this built-in.

And a real database wouldn't have to.

> That works out OK except the client has to pay me or another developer to 
> come in and make any kind of a change.

Or read Carla Schroeder's(?) howto in Computer Bits from a couple
months back.  I believe that article listed off some open-source
alternatives as well.

From freyley at gmx.net  Fri Sep  5 01:52:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Fri Sep  5 01:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Saving bandwidth...
In-Reply-To: <20030905081033.GD2556@ursine.ca>
References: <1062630870.14708.95.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <1062633412.5302.18.camel@localhost> <20030905035724.GI2556@ursine.ca>
	 <1062736599.6972.19.camel@localhost>  <20030905081033.GD2556@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1062751859.6969.33.camel@localhost>

On Fri, 2003-09-05 at 01:10, Paul Johnson wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
> 
> On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 09:36:40PM -0700, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> > > On Wed, Sep 03, 2003 at 04:56:52PM -0700, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> > > > 1) how do you define a forged header? I have email accounts that do not
> > > > have SMTP servers,
> > > 
> > > Then how are you sending or getting replies to them?
> > 
> > My ISP, and various of my accounts that do have SMTP servers, all use
> > authenticated SMTP.
> 
> Then you *do* have SMTP servers for all those accounts, you're just
> using your ISP's to send instead.

No, I do not.

Examine this example: accounts a and b.

Account A has POP or IMAP access only -- on their servers, there is no
SMTP server that I am allowed to use.

Account B has a POP or IMAP server, but also an authenticated SMTP
server.

To send email from account A, I log in to the SMTP server for Account B,
authenticate, and then send an email whose From: header says Account A,
thereby forging the signature, technically.

Jeff




From baloo at ursine.ca  Fri Sep  5 01:56:01 2003

You're misunderstanding.

email through an SMTP server, very indirectly. But directly, for sending
email, I have NO ACCESS, to the SMTP server. I get my mail through POP
or IMAP. To send an email from this email address, I have to use another
system's SMTP server.

Jeff

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Sep  5 07:54:02 2003

	 <1062553974.3672.10.camel@localhost>

	 <1062694925.27984.10.camel@localhost> <20030905035154.GG2556@ursine.ca>
	 <1062741907.3712.4.camel@localhost>  <20030905081708.GE2556@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1062773571.3886.4.camel@localhost>

On Fri, 2003-09-05 at 01:17, Paul Johnson wrote:

> On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 11:05:08PM -0700, AthlonRob wrote:
> > Ugh... Debian's apt system is way too cumbersome and ugly for my use. 
> 
> Never try any of the frontends, like gnome-apt, kpacakge, or aptitude?

You misunderstand.

Any binary-based package management system, IMHO, sucks totally.  I use
binary packages only as a last resort, because they tend to be
cumbersome and ugly.  If you start throwing wild dependencies into the
mix, it only gets uglier.

Gentoo's portage system I can stand to use.  It's *very simple* to get
it to do exactly what I want it to do, then it tracks packages enough to
make uninstallation simple enough.  On any real... production system...
I compile most everything from source, using Slackware's setup as a nice
customizable base.

Rob




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Sep  5 08:22:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Sep  5 08:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Creating vector plots: xfig? sketch? Something else?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309050814100.30483@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  For the book I'm writing now I need to create many illustrative plots.
These are line graphs (Y axis on the left, X axis on the bottom) with
bell-shaped curves, S-curves, Z-curves, triangular curves or trapezoidal
curves. Many figures will have multiple curves on the same set of axes.

  If I had real data to plot I'd use gri. However, these are illustrations,
not real data plots so it would be a major effort to cobble together a
contrived data file to draw each illustration using gri.

  So I'm looking for an alternative. The 'dia' Web site appears to be down.
I believe that 'sketch' is a possibility and I strongly suspect that xfig
would do a top-notch job (if I knew how to use it). I would greatly
appreciate feedback, suggestions and advice from those of you who have used
any of these tools (particularly xfig). The output needs to be .eps for
inclusion in a LaTeX document (go LyX!).

  I've scanned the sketch Web site and read the xfig man page. Having used
neither I've no feel for capabilities or ease of learning/use.

TIA,

Rich

From logiplex at qwest.net  Fri Sep  5 09:34:02 2003
From: logiplex at qwest.net (Cliff Wells)
Date: Fri Sep  5 09:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent
In-Reply-To: <01C37311.FC4C8F60.jorgens@coho.net>
References: <01C37311.FC4C8F60.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <1062779615.28388.1870.camel@software1.logiplex.internal>

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 18:25, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> On Thursday, September 04, 2003 10:28 AM, Cliff Wells 
> [SMTP:logiplex at qwest.net] wrote:
> ...
> > That sounds more like "systems you *don't* know".  If other systems take
> > you that much longer, it's most likely because you aren't familiar with
> > those systems.
> >
> > > There are a lot of database situations with less than 5 users.
> >
> > True.  And more than 1 user is a problem for Access (using JET).
> 
> That's simply a load of hooey.  

Hey.  That's *my* line ;)

> I've run several systems with 10 or 20 
> users, and they all worked fine.  Occasional corruption was always 
> repairable except in one case, and that's what backups are for.  Of course, 
> if the loss of a 1/2 days work is costy, then I agree, JET/MDB is not the 
> right database engine, though at least for reporting, Access is still 
> definitely the best front-end I know of.

To me, "occasional corruption" is unacceptable in a database. 
Especially one you have to pay per seat licensing for.  I ran a MySQL
database for over a year with over 90 users and *never* had any
corruption.  All software has problems, however I prefer to stick with
software where problems are exception, rather than the rule.

> ...
> > > Years ago I built an ERP/sales tool with
> > > Access and sold it to companies with 2~15 users. I moved away and on,
> > > don't support it any more but they still use it as the main tool for
> > > bidding, ordering and invoicing, warehouse management and stuff.
> >
> > And have you actually followed up to see these user's experiences?  I'm
> > aware of plenty of systems where users have simply become used to the
> > flaws and don't complain about having to restore data, getting locked
> > out, crashes, having to avoid certain features, etc, etc.  They consider
> > it a basic cost of using computers.  It doesn't mean that there's
> > nothing wrong with the application, just that the users have figured out
> > how to live with it.
> 
> I'm an Access developer, and I support the systems I create.  Right now, 
> I'm helping a client update a system that's been running 'til now in Access 
> 2.0 (16-bit).

You didn't address what I said.  Logiplex has customers still running
Xenix.  Doesn't mean they don't hate it ;)

> > > If we want to compete against an established monopoly it doesn't help 
> to
> > > ignore its strengths.
> >
> > Not competing.  Simply using the best tools.
> 
> Well, best depends on what you're trying to accomplish, and in how much 
> time.  it also depends on whether you want your client to be able to do 
> basic maintenance themselves without having to learn a programming 
> language.

That is certainly true.  However, I still stick with my earlier premise
that using toy software in a commercial deployment is a risk.  People do
it all the time and manage, but you have to wonder what they could have
accomplished had they chosen to go with a better system.  Having a SQL
server allows for a lot of integration and centralization of data.  You
can probably manage the same with Access, but the more data you start
storing in your database, the more reliability and scalability become a
factor, and these are the places Access is way behind other products.

> > 1. Gleefully ignoring reality since 1994.
> 
> Or simply working on projects with different priorities.

Possibly.  However, I also try not to look at a project's priorities
without considering things like long-term expandability and
interoperability.  If a customer just wants a simple database for
storing inventory, Access sounds good.  But I also consider the
probability that they will also eventually want accounting and payroll,
customer lists, that they might one day want to stick that data behind a
web server for online transactions*, etc.  There might be a bit of
initial overhead to using a SQL server, but in the long run it pays off.

*Yes, I know some people have used Access as a backend for web
applications.  Please don't admit to being one of those ;)


Regards,

-- 
Cliff Wells, Software Engineer
Logiplex Corporation (www.logiplex.net)
(503) 978-6726  (800) 735-0555

Message-ID: <86wucnjik6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Brent" == Brent Rieck <bsr at spek.org> writes:

AR> Any binary-based package management system, IMHO, sucks totally.
AR> I use binary packages only as a last resort, because they tend to
AR> be cumbersome and ugly.  If you start throwing wild dependencies
AR> into the mix, it only gets uglier.

AR> Gentoo's portage system I can stand to use.  It's *very simple* to
AR> get it to do exactly what I want it to do, then it tracks packages
AR> enough to make uninstallation simple enough.  On any
AR> real... production system...  I compile most everything from
AR> source, using Slackware's setup as a nice customizable base.

Brent> Why do you prefer to manually manage dependencies and compile
Brent> from source?

Preface this with the fact that I am a mostly happy Debian user from
way back, but one of the things binary-based package systems tend to
do is freeze in what ought to be optional dependencies.  For example,
the Debian Samba packages used to (still does?) depend on a particular
printing system (CUPS, I think), which seems just wacky to me.  Once
you have to start dragging around these superfluous tentacles, you can
end up sweeping along a _lot_ of stuff you never really wanted to
begin with.  Now, the one thing about dragging around these
superfluous dependencies is that it is _mostly_ painless with Debian,
because Debian makes that part easy.

The nice thing about something like Gentoo, which I've just started
playing with, is that there is a little more opportunity to fiddle
with compile-time choices.  Karl Hegbloom once muttered something
about being able to do this from Debian source packages, but I have
never managed to concentrate long enough to understand all of the
build goo that Debian uses well enough to mutate reliably.  So far,
I've been able to comprehend Gentoo's build system a little better.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

I may be speaking out of turn, but with Gentoo you're not manually managing your
dependencies.  You are able to cut out some dependancies that a precompiled
version would force on you.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Sep  5 09:47:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Sep  5 09:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Package management (was : Q: comparison of video
	formats)
In-Reply-To: <1062776252.25732.4986.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <16212.15242.958764.822432@vzavenue.net>
	 <1062553974.3672.10.camel@localhost>
	 <16214.61550.787809.638630@vzavenue.net>
	 <1062694925.27984.10.camel@localhost> <20030905035154.GG2556@ursine.ca>
	 <1062741907.3712.4.camel@localhost>  <20030905081708.GE2556@ursine.ca>
	 <1062773571.3886.4.camel@localhost>
	 <1062776252.25732.4986.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <1062780361.18598.8.camel@localhost>

On Fri, 2003-09-05 at 08:37, Brent Rieck wrote:

> Why do you prefer to manually manage dependencies and compile from
> source?

Source dependencies are a lot more flexible than binary dependencies. 
Rarely is the source code released against a very specific set of
library versions or 'extras' that may or may not be present on my
system.

For example... I can compile GAIM with or without PERL support.  If I
don't feel like installing Perl on a system, I just don't put it on
there.  However, if said binary distribution decided to build GAIM with
Perl support, now everybody who uses GAIM needs Perl installed on their
system.

When you compile software on your system, it builds it against your
system... its headers and libraries.  If you start switching out those
libraries, you run in to problems.  If you build from source, however,
you just don't run in to those problems... sure, dependency tracking
comes in to play to save the day there, but it seems so much uglier from
my point of view.

And... I've never seen an optimized distribution.  I pick my CXXFLAGS
and CFLAGS depending on what I'm compiling and on what system I'll be
using it on.  If stability isn't paramount, but speed is... I season to
taste.

You just can't beat the power you gain over a system if you drop all
those binary packages out the window.  :-)

Rob




From logiplex at qwest.net  Fri Sep  5 09:50:02 2003
From: logiplex at qwest.net (Cliff Wells)

Subject: [PLUG] MS Access Equivalent

On Thu, 2003-09-04 at 18:43, Steve Jorgensen wrote:
> On Thursday, September 04, 2003 10:10 AM, Cliff Wells 
> [SMTP:logiplex at qwest.net] wrote:
> > > Well, MS bashing is fun, but Access has managed to pretty much wipe 
> DBase,
> > > Paradox, et al. right off the map for a reason.  It works pretty well.
> >
> > So Access sits at the top of the heap of toy databases.  Not much of an
> > accolade, IMO.
> 
> Is a spreadsheet Excel a toy because it's for smaller jobs? 

You are comparing apples and oranges.  Is Word a toy because it's not a
server?  How about Mozilla?  Please stop.

>  Tell that to 
> your CEO.  I'd say "small" rather than "toy" furthermore, I would not limit 
> the scope to single-user systems.  Say what you will, database servers 
> require at least part time database administrators, and require a 
> maintenance of staff expertise during turnovers, etc.

I thought you were doing that for Access databases?  Or are you claiming
that they maintain themselves?  If so, what do your customers pay you
for?

>   In many cases, there 
> is not a requirement for 24-hour up-time, rapid recovery from failures, 
> ultra-fast performance, or lock-tight security.  In these cases, the cost 
> of maintaining a server database is vastly too high.

There is always a requirement for these things.  The only reason people
don't think there is is because of the shoddy state of commercial
software these days.  Microsoft has lowered people's expectations.

> > >  Also, JET is the file-based database.  Access is a database front-end 
> that
> > > includes JET if that's what you want to use.
> >
> > True.  And Access is fine for painting simple GUI's.
> 
> For certain values of simple, and I agree.  Up to department scale, Access 
> advantages outweigh its disadvantages.  Above than, the lack of better OOP 
> and the invisibility of large parts of the application to the compiler lead 
> to higher than acceptable defect ratios.

Yes, that is what I meant.

> > >  And for all the disadvantages
> > > of a file-based system, it has plenty of advantages.
> > > Some databases need relational and weak ACID capabilities, but they are 
> > > used more in the context of documents than in the context of 
> repositories.
> > >  You want to be able to make copies and open them on the fly like
> > > documents, etc.  If server daemons are such a great idea, why doesn't
> > > Gnumeric install a spreadsheet server?
> >
> > Because spreadsheets aren't typically used in a multi-user application
> > setting.  The basic paradigms don't fit.  How would an application
> > handle one user editing cell A1 while another tried to calculate the sum
> > of a range that included that cell?  I don't think you thought this out
> > very well.
> 
> I don't see that we are disagreeing that much.  I would use JET for a 10 
> user syste, and you wouldn't use it for more than 1.  We both agree it's 
> not for large-scale deployments.

Okay, so I guess we can simply define our disagreement as a matter of
scale (1 vs 10).  And I'll point out again that I don't have too much of
a problem using Access as a client to a server backend.  Not necessarily
what I'd choose most of the time (I still hate VB), but a reasonable
configuration that leverages the strengths of both approaches.

> > > Regarding the file corruption issue, most Access database corruption
> > > (in the back-end data files) arises from faulty NICs on an unswitched
> > > LAN and rarely occurs on a well-maintained LAN.
> >
> > This is pure hooey ;)  I've never even used Access on an unswitched
> > LAN.  Whether there were faulty NICs that somehow only corrupted Access
> > data, I can't be certain, but any software this intolerant to a
> > networked environment shouldn't be used in one.
> 
> Well, I don't know where your problems came from, then.  Access back-ends 
> do corrupt from time to time as one would expect in any shared-file system. 
>  I certainly never found this to be a chronic issue unless there was some 
> kind of problem with the network.

There are undoubtedly problems in most networks of any reasonable size. 
This will also probably increase as low-cost networking hardware becomes
more common due to increased home use.  However, my point remains that
software that is meant to run in a networked environment should be
somewhat tolerant to this.  Access' architecture (file locking/sharing)
has long been considered the most brittle way of sharing resources.

> > > I've supported systems in production for years that
> > > demonstrate this.
> >
> > Well, I consider you very lucky ;)
> 
> I guess we'll agree to differ on this.  Access does require occasional 
> compact/repair operations to clean up problems before they affect data. 
>  Any decent Access app will have a feature for doing this built-in.
> 
> > > I'm not saying Access is perfect - I bitch about it every day
> >
> > Hm... I bitch about PostgreSQL every... well, let's see, um, I can't
> > recall...
> 
> I'm working on an Access fron-end to a PostgreSQL database now, and the DBA 
> is having a hulluva time with it.  Perhaps, you are just more intelligent 
> than him, but that just underscores the difference in complexity and cost 
> of maintaining a server vs a file.  I guess if you're a DBA yourself, it's 
> easy to think maintaining a server is no big deal.

Well, since you said something about me being smart, I'll have to agree
with whatever else you were saying ;)

> > > Microsoft's new licensing, only a Mother could love.  Every time I look 
> for
> > > something else with the advantages Access has for my clients, though, I 
> > > don't find it.  I'm hoping Meargent or Open Office reaches a point 
> where it
> > > can work as a viable replacement soon, but as yet, they're not there.
> >
> > What is it you are looking for?  Is it simply the GUI builder?  Frankly,
> > that's the only thing I can see where Access has any clear advantage
> > over anything else.  And that advantage is strongly mitigated by the
> > requirement to use VB.  Not to mention that the GUI builder, while
> > convenient, is hardly viable for building complex GUIs.
> >
> > If you are simply looking for a good toolbox for developing database
> > applications, I'd suggest the following:
> >
> > PostgreSQL (or MySQL, if your database requirements are simple)
> > Python
> > wxPython (see also Boa Constructor, for building GUI's)
> 
> That works out OK except the client has to pay me or another developer to 
> come in and make any kind of a change.  That could price some of the 
> projects I take out of the client's range.  Besides that, it takes no 
> account of reporting.  Reporting is always a thorny issue, and Access 
> handles it quite well.  There is also an appropriate amount of overlap 
> between the Form/Report models so much of the GUI design and some of the 
> code can simply be pasted from one to the other.

Reporting is a PITA, in fact in the past I've used Python and COM to
generate reports in Excel which I found to be a fairly usable combo. 
There are also modules for Python for generating PDF files (ReportLab)
so that probably wouldn't be necessary today.

> > Granted, you don't get the "all-in-one" development system Access
> > provides.  You also don't get the lack of scalability, the data
> > corruption, VB, the licensing fees, VB, VB, the vendor lock-in, etc.
> 
> All good things, and all reasons I'm always considering everything as an 
> option.  I'm actually learning Java and C# just now as alternatives for 
> some projects.

You are going to make me cry ;)  Please try a decent language first.

http://www.python.org

> > What you do get is a robust and powerful database, a simple yet powerful
> > programming language and a very flexible GUI toolkit.  And it's all
> > cross-platform and open source.
> 
> All good things, and all without the other unique Access benefits I've 
> outlined above.

Which is why, in your particular case, I'd suggest that perhaps Access
over PostgreSQL (or even MySQL) would be a good fit.

stepped in to ask that a thread be moved off line, but that's 
exceedingly rare.

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Fri Sep  5 10:33:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Fri Sep  5 10:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Protecting bandwidth...
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C730@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Paul Johnson:
> On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 02:42:56PM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > That doesn't hide the fact that something went from you to 
> > them, or vice versa.
> 
> Sure it does.  Nobody but your correspondent can read it, so you could
> have encrypted a whole lot of nothing for all anybody else is 
> concerned.

  This is an intelligence art called "pattern analysis".  You don't need to
read the message to glean information about the communication.  You can tell
a lot about an organization by watching the information that leaks out
around the edges.

  This is serious stuff.  The Pentagon set up an in-house pizza delivery
after reporters started getting hot "something's happening" tips from
Domino's delivery boys.  A lot of the overhead reconnaissance stuff is based
on pattern analysis tricks.  

  "Zero knowledge" means not leaking *any* information your attacker could
use. 

Steve D...

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Sep  5 10:40:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Sep  5 10:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sftp with perms and subdirs
In-Reply-To: <1062781947.1150.485.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1062781947.1150.485.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309051036500.5776@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 5 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I'm having difficulty getting sftp to download a sir with subdirs.

afaik, sftp got recursive capabilities only recently. If you're
running an older version, then you're out of luck.

Try scp instead:

  cd /local/target/dir
  scp -r remote.host.tld:/remote/target/dir .

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Sep  5 10:43:01 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri Sep  5 10:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SMP kernel timebase question
Message-ID: <20030905174219.DC16E8F1C@tinman.seitzassoc.com>


In an SMP kernel, what is the impact of the CPU timebases not being
synchronized?  For instance, imagine a two CPU system where each CPU's timer
interrupt is 180 degrees out of phase relative to the other.  How might
this impact performance or behavior?

thanks,
galen




From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Fri Sep  5 11:08:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Fri Sep  5 11:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SMP kernel timebase question
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C731@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Galen Seitz:
> In an SMP kernel, what is the impact of the CPU timebases not being
> synchronized?  For instance, imagine a two CPU system where 
> each CPU's timer
> interrupt is 180 degrees out of phase relative to the other.  
> How might this impact performance or behavior?
> 
  I don't think it would make a difference.  My SMP machine has a
"ksoftirqd" process for each CPU.  Tasks get pulled off the queue and then
run on the "correct" processor.  The definition of "correct" depends on the
kernel version you're using.

  Each task doesn't know or care what CPU it's scheduled to run on.  Good
SMP programming practices should take care of any other issues.  

Steve D...



From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Sep  5 11:15:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Sep  5 11:22:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Sep  5 11:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] sftp with perms and subdirs
In-Reply-To: <1062781947.1150.485.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1062781947.1150.485.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1062786724.16492.10.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2003-09-05 at 10:12, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I'm having difficulty getting sftp to download a sir with subdirs.
> 
> I can get the command line fine for all files okay, but subdirs is
> kicking me. I know this is prob simple, and I've looked at the man and
> usage notes.

As far as I know, sftp can't do recursion.  The way I do it (when I use
command line for this) is to do an ls, and lmkdir all directories, then
lcd and cd into each directory, look for more directories to create. 
Once the directories are all in place, you can start to copy files.  If
you started copying files before the directories were created, sftp will
abort while trying to read a directory as a file, and a file will be
created with the name of the directory.

The easy way out of this is to create a tar ball (compressed if you are
copying over the Internet), then copy just the one file.
> 
> I'm trying 
> sftp> get * -P (with and without mkdirs)
> to no avail. Am I supposed to invoke it with a secret code or something?
> 
> Thanks for all of the help with my crashed swap partition yesterday. I
> was stumped, and Google was not yielding same-scenario issues.
> 
Your welcome,

Derek Loree




From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Sep  5 11:24:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri Sep  5 11:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla config from WinXP to Linux
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309051042030.19419-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309051042030.19419-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <3F58D448.8040309@dimstar.net>

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> I'm currently stuck using a WinXT system at work but am able to use
> Mozilla.  The issue is I often work from home (sometimes 'cause I hasta
> and sometimes 'cause I wantta) and but don't have all the bookmarks I've 
> created at work and can't always remember what they are.
> 
> Is there a fairly painless way to copy the WinXP Mozilla stuff to a Linux 
> Mozilla user?
>    I've tried modifying the Linux/Mozilla bookmarks file both from within 
> a X-Windows System session (not good) and from a console login with 
> varying success.  Seems Mozilla creates two (or more) users directories 
> per user ... sometimes.  Damn confusing.

Go to Bookmarks>File Bookmarks. This will open the bookmark manager.

In the bookmark manager, go to Tools>Export. From there, you can export 
an html version.

On the other system, open the bookmark manager and go to Tools>Import. 
Select the file, and there ya go.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
Home:	http://www.dimstar.net
LDP:	http://ldp.dimstar.net

From felix.1 at canids.net  Fri Sep  5 11:42:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri Sep  5 11:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Package management (was : Q: comparison of video formats)
In-Reply-To: <E19vJdG-000165-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> on Fri, 05 Sep 2003 16:39:51 -0000.
Message-ID: <20030905184158.4B46215916A@kanga.canids.net>

Brent wrote:
> Why do you prefer to manually manage dependencies and compile from
> source?

Dependencies in portage are as automatic as any binary package
system, and a little more flexible.

One of the reasons I installed Gentoo is I found that, for me,
binary-based distributions were encouraging bad habits.  I no
longer had any intuitive feel for the size or complexity of any
piece of software I was using.  I was falling into black-box
debugging helplessness.  I was getting locked into finding and
installing exact version numbers of shared libraries.  I was
running out-of-date software simply because it wasn't easy to
upgrade just one thing, I'd have to upgrade the whole system
because of all the interrelated dependencies.  etc.

After installing Gentoo... I've discovered I need a _lot_ more
disk to do a debuggable source-based installation these days.
And more ram and cpu power would help for building all those
things that want to compile with -O3 or so.
--



From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Fri Sep  5 11:50:02 2003

On Friday 05 September 2003 09:40, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Hokay, xfig will do the job. As a matter of fact, the new X-spline
> routine (that's replaced the former B-spline and Bezier-spline) is
> absolutely ideal for my needs. I can change the curve response on a
> point-by-point basis to get exactly the shape I need.
>
>   Excelsior!
>
> Rich

Hey Rich,

I missed your question in all of the recent shouting about Access and the 
absolute superiority of some distros over others.  You might also take a look 
at Xmgrace, which descended from Xmgr.  It is available at

http://plasma-gate.weizmann.ac.il/Grace/

It has very nice features, is more polished than Xfig (which I also like very 
much), and gives you complete control over your plots.  But I haven't played 
with the spline feature and can't say whether it will satisfy your needs.

Mark

Mark,

  Polished, schmolished. As long as it creates the figures I'm happy.
There's also xfigure (or something like that).

  After trying to figure out gnuplot a number of years ago I stumbled across
Gri and I've used that ever since for scientific data plots. When I asked
the authors why they wrote it -- since it essentially duplicates gnuplot --
they told me that they weren't aware of gnuplot (!!) so they created their
own for oceanic research.

  And, of course, in the bitmapped graphic world, there's GIMP, xv and a
bunch of others.

  Because I'm essentially a really lazy curmudgeon, I pick one that does
what I need to have done, learn it and go on to trying to make money.

Thanks for the pointer,

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Sep  5 13:46:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Sep  5 13:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Drawing programs: a follow-up
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309051331380.31158@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  Mark Martin suggested a tool called 'grace' as a replacement for xfig.
However, from my understanding of the Web site it is another replacement for
gnuplot: a data plotting program. These programs take data points and plot
them using various formats.

  Plotting applications are a completely different application from a vector
drawing application. The later uses vector primatives such as points, lines,
circles and rectangles to produce a drawing that is not tied to any measured
data set. They are the digital equivalent of the Etch-A-Sketch (TM) deluxe
edition.

  The third category of graphics applications are the bit-mapped ones such
as xv, the gimp, xpaint and probably a dozen others. Rather than working
with geometric objects (as the vector drawing applications do) or data files
(as the plotting applications do), this class works with pixels.

  An analogy, but arguably not a terribly good one, is the range of text
processing applications. There are plain text editors (such as emacs, vi,
joe) that are ideally suited for a certain category of tasks (system/network
administration, coding, e-mail). For different needs, there are the word
processors such as OpenOffice.org's Writer, KWord and AbiWord. These use a
proprietary or tagged format for the data files and provide formatting and
other desireable features when the text needs to be distributed as treeware.
The final text application class consists of typesetting software; TeX and
its derivatives LaTeX and LyX are the only occupants of this niche to my
knowledge.

  So, while I appreciate the helpful pointer, grace is not capable of doing
the illustration drawings I need.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Fri Sep  5 14:18:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Fri Sep  5 14:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Drawing programs: a follow-up
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309051331380.31158@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309051331380.31158@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200309051418.05565.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

Rich,

I just read your additional posting and I know the difference between vector 
and raster graphics.  Xmgrace allows you to create vector plots and it will 
create Postscript (encapsulated or otherwise), PDF, and SVG (i.e. scalable 
vector graphics) output, which *are* vector formats.  It also allows you to 
use splines, which is what you said you needed.  But, if it isn't for you, it 
isn't for you.  Flame away, if you must.

Mark

P.S. I felt compelled to respond to both threads of this discussion.  
Apologies to those of you who read this twice.

To beat a dead horse (since you already found a solution you like), part of 
what I mean by "polished" is "less buggy".  I've had Xfig crash at 
inopportune moments (Of course, I not sure when the opportune moments to 
crash are.) but I've never had this problem with Xmgrace.  Xfig has been 
around for over 10 years, in my recollection, but it's still a little rough 
around the edges.  (Maybe Xfig's development community is no longer very 
large or maybe even nonexistent?)

vector graphics) output, which *are* vector formats.  It also allows you to

I used to xfig to create the house plans to get remodeling permits.  It is 
amazingly capable--got several comments on how nice the drawings were.  It's 
little quirky, like DrawPerfect was.  The online help is the best I've ever

improvements.

You should be able to make wavy lines just fine.
