This is weird.  Python appears to be importing a file that doesn't
exist.  The "import mailbox" command doesn't try to import the one in
/usr/lib/python2.2.  It seems to be importing one from
/var/lib/mailman/Mailman.

That is a directory I mounted via samba so I could install mailman on
the machine that has postfix (the web server is on a different
machine).

On machine A: 
$ ls -al /var/lib/mailman/Mailman/mailbox.py
-rwxr--r--    1 root     root         3876 Sep  5 15:01
/var/lib/mailman/Mailman/mailbox.py

The mailman directory is the mount point for /var/lib/mailman on
machine B

On machine B:
# ls -al /var/lib/mailman/Mailman/mailbox.py
ls: /var/lib/mailman/Mailman/mailbox.py: No such file or directory

A "find / -name mailbox.py -print" only turns up one file (on each
system)

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Fri Sep  5 15:47:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Fri Sep  5 15:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Hostile Targets (was Verify plug-admin@...)
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C733@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Jeff Schwaber:
> > I was there once.  Make yourself a hostile target and report
> > spammers.  I got my users to report spam themselves (and if they're
> > lazy, forwarding me their spam), my site is a pretty hostile target.
> > Spammers learn, though slowly.
> 
> You know, I vaguely remember there being a law against sending spam in
> Oregon or Washington, not sure which, but I thought it was Oregon, and
> there being stories of people successfully getting checks for 
> $300-$500
> out of spamming companies by sending them letters threatening 
> to sue in
> small claims court. Anyone know anything about this? I have 
> the time, i could go after spammers...

  Make yourself a *really* hostile target, *and* find a rewarding, well
paying, socially active hobby.  Sue the spammers!

Zen and the art of small claims

  "This guide is written for those who want to better the world and the self
through lawsuits. It focuses on filing small claims against telemarketers
who use recorded calls, junk faxers and a large percentage of spammers."

http://www.smallclaim.info/

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Fri Sep  5 17:47:02 2003
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Fri Sep  5 17:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Drawing programs: a follow-up
In-Reply-To: <200309051418.05565.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309051331380.31158@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <200309051418.05565.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

After re-reading Rich's posts, I will admit that Xmgrace is probably not the 
best tool for his purposes and that I should have read his messages more 
carefully.  But you *can* draw in Xmgrace as well as plotting data and 
someone could benefit from using it for vector drawings, especially if they 
need to mix plots of data and drawings as I have had to do in the past.

As usual, for whatever it's worth,

Mark

From baloo at ursine.ca  Sat Sep  6 00:06:12 2003

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Fri, Sep 05, 2003 at 10:08:16AM -0700, Cliff Wells wrote:
> Well, I haven't used Debian, so perhaps apt performs some magic there
> that I'm not aware that I'm missing, but having used it for the last
> year or so on RedHat I haven't had any real problems.  In fact it seems
> to work better than most of the alternatives.  It might work best on
> Debian, but I'd hardly categorize it as working "poorly" on RedHat.

The problem with using any sort of package management on RPM based
systems is that RPM is utterly broken thanks to multiple distros all
producing their own versions of the same packages in RPM, none of them
compatible.  Further complicating things, often times people have a
tendancy of writing depends on individual files instead of packages,
and nobody in the RPM world seems to be able to decide just what
package is supposed to be called what.

In the .deb world, everybody's debs are compatible with each other's
distros, you can mix and match without too much hassle.  If you want
to switch between .deb based distros, no re-installation is
necissary.  Just change your sources.list to some other distro's
package servers, apt-get update, apt-get dist-upgrade and after
everything's downloaded, you've changed distros.  Depending on
individual files is (thankfully) not possible, so we don't suffer from
that sort of stupidity, and everybody just uses the Debian package
names to prevent the package naming stupidity chronic to RPM.

- -- 
 .''`.     Paul Johnson <baloo at ursine.ca>
: :'  :    
`. `'`     proud Debian admin and user
  `-  Debian - when you have better things to do than fix a system
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----
Version: GnuPG v1.2.3 (GNU/Linux)

=o9YA
-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----

On Fri, Sep 05, 2003 at 10:12:44AM -0700, david pool wrote:
> Some of the Uber-sensitive folks moved over to PdxLug, but yes there are 
> still plenty of OT sensitive folks on this list. I suppose what annoys 
> me the most is the amount of bandwidth that ends up being wasted by 
> people saying "This is sooooo off topic, blah, blah, blah, take it off 
> list: Is not: Is too: IS NOT: IS TOO...etc". The irony slays me.

I agree.  Posting exclusively to say that something is off topic is
always, in itself, off topic.  Bonus points is it makes the person
doing it look about as bright as the average AOL user.  procmail is
your friend.

> Which isn't to say people don't stray off topic, but it's just not that 
> hard to ignore a thread (IMHO).

Especially if you use a MUA that understands threads properly (using
the References header or equivilent, instead of subject).  This is
also a good reason *NOT* to start a new thread by hitting reply in
another thread:  It appears as topic drift mid-thread to people with
non-broken MUAs[1].


[1] IMHO, your MUA is broken if it doesn't, at the very least, support
proper threading and have Reply-to-List.

From baloo at ursine.ca  Sat Sep  6 02:24:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Debian Samba

--EVF5PPMfhYS0aIcm
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I know someone mentioning samba in Debian and CUPS, I had the same
thought the other day.  dman gives explaination:  Samba doesn't depend
on cups and never has; the library suggests cups and by default, apt
goes for suggestions.  You can change this behaviour prodding around
in /etc/apt/

On Fri, Sep 05, 2003 at 12:56:44AM -0700, Paul Johnson wrote:
| On Thu, Sep 04, 2003 at 10:15:24PM -0500, Shyamal Prasad wrote:
| > Slackware, I switched to Debian somewhere in 2000). It worked great
| > for me, and I'm not sure CUPS is any better (yet).
|=20
| I still wonder why the hell samba depends on CUPS.

It doesn't.  It only depends on the client library (libcupsys2).
It needs libcupsys2 because it was compiled with CUPS support so that
samba can automatically determine all the available printers from the
CUPS infrastructure.  (that doesn't mean you need to run cups, or even
if you use cups the 'cupsd' server could be on a different machine)

-D

and your plans will succeed.

> 
> On Fri, Sep 05, 2003 at 10:08:16AM -0700, Cliff Wells wrote:
> > Well, I haven't used Debian, so perhaps apt performs some magic there
> > that I'm not aware that I'm missing, but having used it for the last
> > year or so on RedHat I haven't had any real problems.  In fact it seems
> > to work better than most of the alternatives.  It might work best on
> > Debian, but I'd hardly categorize it as working "poorly" on RedHat.
> 
> The problem with using any sort of package management on RPM based
> systems is that RPM is utterly broken thanks to multiple distros all
> producing their own versions of the same packages in RPM, none of them
> compatible.  Further complicating things, often times people have a
> tendancy of writing depends on individual files instead of packages,
> and nobody in the RPM world seems to be able to decide just what
> package is supposed to be called what.

I certainly can't argue with this.  It doesn't seem to be rpm that's so
broken as much as the packagers ;)  I usually stick with freshrpms.net
(which includes official RH updates) so as to avoid getting stuff from
all over.  There's also some work between the maintainers of the major
apt repositories for RH to increase compatibility with each other, so
hopefully that will help to set some sort of standard.

> 
> In the .deb world, everybody's debs are compatible with each other's
> distros, you can mix and match without too much hassle.  If you want
> to switch between .deb based distros, no re-installation is
> necissary.  Just change your sources.list to some other distro's
> package servers, apt-get update, apt-get dist-upgrade and after
> everything's downloaded, you've changed distros.  

I don't think you'd want to try that in the RPM world ;)  I have used
quite a few Mandrake and Connectiva on RH, but I don't think I'd try to
upgrade to their distro w/o a reinstall ;)

> Depending on
> individual files is (thankfully) not possible, so we don't suffer from
> that sort of stupidity, and everybody just uses the Debian package
> names to prevent the package naming stupidity chronic to RPM.

Got me (or rather, rpm) there too =)

-- 
Cliff Wells, Software Engineer
Logiplex Corporation (www.logiplex.net)
(503) 978-6726  (800) 735-0555




From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sat Sep  6 10:58:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sat Sep  6 10:58:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Email spam...
Message-ID: <1062871013.1606.40.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Well I've discovered the hard way that blocking ips doesn't work very
well though I am wondering if I the following is a reasonable anti
smut approach:

Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
DROP       all  --  67.30.135.152        0.0.0.0/0          
DROP       all  --  63.66.136.100        0.0.0.0/0          
DROP       all  --  67.30.133.77         0.0.0.0/0          
DROP       all  --  64.214.130.56        0.0.0.0/0          

These sites are either directly sending it to me or in
some cases I think they are relays.

I've sent a complaint to abuse at level3.com, maybe they
can stop some of the the porn properly.  It's frustrating, 
anyone can sign you up for something where there seem to 
be no rules that a content provider has to honor to get 
you off their mailing lists.  Some of these sites say 
don't enter if your under age, but anyone can go into
a lot of them.  I wonder how an undercover police person 
would feel if he/she couldn't get off one of these sites
after investigating it?

I get some stuff that I'm fairly sure nobody ever 
subscribed to.  Viagra ads are pretty common.

Looking at email's form it seems if a header 
is at all faked that there's a high probability 
it's spam.  How do you find out if certain sites 
only send objectionable material as I would think 
you could just block them.  If you filter email
at your own site, that in affect encourages the 
sender to keep sending it to you.  Unfortunately,
the approach of blocking email servers comes with 
other problems.  I think part of the problem is 
that a lot of the porn mail sources appear to be 
individual private email addresses.  There are
darn near an infinite number of private email
addresses compared to the number of ISP's
and formal content providers.

How does sendmail or any other MTA decide to 
send to an intermediary mail transfer agent 
instead of attempting a direct connection to 
the destination?

Is it me or is AT&T really bad about relaying
pornographic materials?  If I didn't know any
better, I'd think it's a big business for some
of these phone companies to distribute this
stuff to whomever they can.  It's probably 
as bad for some people as it would
be to put a bar in an alcoholic's house 
where only the alcoholic frequents it 
and the bar never goes dry.
 
There's other problem areas for Internet 
delivered content as well, some video 
games have absorbed people so completely 
that they have committed suicide just to 
stop playing.

     --  Michael

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Sat Sep  6 15:07:01 2003
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Sat Sep  6 15:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Updating PHP in RedHat 7.3
Message-ID: <3F5A5A3D.2000603@adnap.no-ip.com>

Hello everyone,

I am trying to update PHP on my system from 'php-4.1.2-7.3.6' to 
'php-4.3.2-7'.  Having seen all the trashing of RPM lately, I thought it 
would be a fun time to bring up my problems with RPM dependencies. ;-)

Here's what happens:

[root at adnap root]# ls php-* | cat
php-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
php-imap-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
php-ldap-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
php-mysql-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
php-odbc-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
php-pgsql-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
php-snmp-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
[root at adnap root]# rpm -Uhv php-*
error: failed dependencies:
         httpd-mmn = 20020903 is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libaspell.so.15   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.3)   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libcrypto.so.4   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libdb-4.1.so   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libpng12.so.0   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libpspell.so.15   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libssl.so.4   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
         libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.3)   is needed by php-imap-4.3.2-7
         libcrypto.so.4   is needed by php-imap-4.3.2-7
         libssl.so.4   is needed by php-imap-4.3.2-7
         libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.3)   is needed by php-pgsql-4.3.2-7
         libpq.so.3   is needed by php-pgsql-4.3.2-7
         libcrypto.so.4   is needed by php-snmp-4.3.2-7
         libnetsnmp.so.5   is needed by php-snmp-4.3.2-7
[root at adnap root]# rpm -q glibc
glibc-2.2.5-43
[root at adnap root]#

Does this look like reasonable depenencies?  Does it look like I will be 
able to meet them (and not break everything)?

It's important that PHP not be broken for any length of time.

I am considering switching distros if I can't fix this.  In that case, 
what is the best distro for being able to update software without 
updating the entire system?

Thanks,
Evan




From dgc at easystreet.com  Sat Sep  6 15:22:01 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Sat Sep  6 15:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Email spam...
In-Reply-To: <1062871013.1606.40.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1062871013.1606.40.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <3F5A5DE7.4080001@easystreet.com>

> ... It's frustrating, 
> anyone can sign you up for something where there seem to 
> be no rules that a content provider has to honor to get 
> you off their mailing lists.  ...

Spammer gangs are CONTINOUSLY taking email addresses found by their
dirty trick programs, and "laundering" them by submitting those
addresses to whatever site they can find.  That is the source of their
claims that they have hundreds of millions (or more; I saw a piece of
spam recently that claimed the con artist had 2.8 billion email
addresses, all of which were eager to receive msgs from the con
artists clients).

A few years ago a reporter (in the Seattle area, I think), followed up
one of the ads you occasionally see stuck up on telephone poles about
making money with your home computer.  The so called job he was given
was to register lists of email addresses with different sites.  He was
to be paid a few cents per address.

Spammer gangs also sign up for mailing lists (like the ones associated
with sourceforge projects, etc.) and try to use their membership status
to get a list of members.  They then add those addresses to their ill
gotten lists, trade them back and forth to try to hide their origin,
sign them up for lists so they can claim you've "opted in", etc.

That's just a small bit of my rants on spam....

More related to the the original message, you can try blocking senders
using your firewall, but you could easily hit capacity problems.  It's
better to block using sendmail, postfix, etc. access lists.

I currently have almost 8000 ip addresses, email addresses, domains and
sub-domains blocked because spammer gangs have used them to "try" to
send junk to me.  The list grows on average by at least 10-20 a week.

dgc

> Does this look like reasonable depenencies?  Does it look like I will be

It looks like it requires glibc 2.3, which could break a lot of stuff
when it upgrades. =)

You could try the apt tool for red hat, though I'm not sure how to go
about doing that, since I don't use it.

> It's important that PHP not be broken for any length of time.
> 
> I am considering switching distros if I can't fix this.  In that case, 
> what is the best distro for being able to update software without 
> updating the entire system?

s/best/only

debian-based. Not necessarily debian, just debian based. Knoppix,
Xandros, or any other debian-based distro will work beautifully for
this. 

In addition, if you want to use Debian with the Progeny installer (much
easier to use), or the old, defunct Stormix / StormLinux (if you can get
a copy) those will both work to install sufficient of a debian system on
them that you can then upgrade to the current version. Now if you want
PHP 4.3, you're going to have to go to testing (sarge). Stable has an
older version than that.

Everybody says shitty things about Debian's installer, and they're right
(though not for servers--it's just setting up X that's a pain). But
nobody really says anything bad about Debian once its set up. 

Jeff

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Sep  6 15:46:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Sep  6 15:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Email spam...
In-Reply-To: <1062871013.1606.40.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1062871013.1606.40.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200309061547.35180.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 06 September 2003 10:56 am, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Well I've discovered the hard way that blocking ips doesn't work very
> well though I am wondering if I the following is a reasonable anti
> smut approach:

Blocking IPs does not work because spammmers are shifty devious bastards who 
keep moving around. They exploit open relays and open proxies. The 
relationship between spam and viruses is not accidental- spammers love all 
those easily owned Windows boxes to relay their spew through.

<snip>
>
> These sites are either directly sending it to me or in
> some cases I think they are relays.

Trying to block email based on content is not going to work very well. It's 
the same problem that Web filters like Net Nanny run into- software is 
incapable of evaluating context.

>
> I've sent a complaint to abuse at level3.com, maybe they
> can stop some of the the porn properly.  It's frustrating,
> anyone can sign you up for something where there seem to
> be no rules that a content provider has to honor to get
> you off their mailing lists.  Some of these sites say
> don't enter if your under age, but anyone can go into
> a lot of them.  I wonder how an undercover police person
> would feel if he/she couldn't get off one of these sites
> after investigating it?

I shall bite back the obvious smart-aleck reply.... :) Expecting spammers of 
any kind, or spam-friendly service providers, to behave honestly or honorably 
is not going to work either. 

>
> I get some stuff that I'm fairly sure nobody ever
> subscribed to.  Viagra ads are pretty common.
>
> Looking at email's form it seems if a header
> is at all faked that there's a high probability
> it's spam.  How do you find out if certain sites
> only send objectionable material as I would think
> you could just block them. 

Again, content-based filtering doesn't work. Your best bet is to block spam, 
period. 

> Is it me or is AT&T really bad about relaying
> pornographic materials?  If I didn't know any
> better, I'd think it's a big business for some
> of these phone companies to distribute this
> stuff to whomever they can.  It's probably
> as bad for some people as it would
> be to put a bar in an alcoholic's house
> where only the alcoholic frequents it
> and the bar never goes dry.
>
> There's other problem areas for Internet
> delivered content as well, some video
> games have absorbed people so completely
> that they have committed suicide just to
> stop playing.

Interesting issues, that are probably better suited to plug-talk. On the issue 
of fighting spam, which has become an interesting sideline for me, there are 
many strategies to choose from. To simply keep it out of your inbox, a 
combination of DNSRBLs and Spamassassin work very well. 

To fight back to try to stop the spew, which can consume a lot of time and 
energy, you can do things like report spams through Spamcop.net, sue under 
any applicable laws, post spams to news-admin net-abuse-sightings, and 
support anti-spam legislation, should you find any worth supporting. Start 
with the Spamfaq at http://www.spamfaq.net/, it's a good introduction.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Sep  6 15:53:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Updating PHP in RedHat 7.3

Message-ID: <200309061555.01726.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 06 September 2003 3:37 pm, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> Everybody says shitty things about Debian's installer, and they're right
> (though not for servers--it's just setting up X that's a pain). But
> nobody really says anything bad about Debian once its set up.
>
> Jeff

And Libranet, Xandros etc. take the pain out of installation. The latest 
Libranet- 2.8.1- is great for a desktop Debian. It's based on Sarge, so the 
apps are up-to-date, and Libranet's hardware detection is very good.

For users who want to stick with Red Hat, try the Ximian desktop with Red 
Carpet. Red Carpet is the most pain-free installer and updater in the Red 
Hat/ Mandrake world, IMO it is the best solution for someone wanting a Red 
hat-based desktop system, without getting sucked into RPM hell.

From ramunro1 at ix.netcom.com  Sat Sep  6 17:13:01 2003
From: ramunro1 at ix.netcom.com (Robert Munro)

Message-ID: <1062893538.2928.207.camel@griffin>

> From: "Michael C. Robinson" <michael at goose.robinson-west.com>
<snip>
> Well I've discovered the hard way that blocking ips doesn't work very
> well though I am wondering if I the following is a reasonable anti
> smut approach:
> 
> Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
> target     prot opt source               destination         
> DROP       all  --  67.30.135.152        0.0.0.0/0          
> DROP       all  --  63.66.136.100        0.0.0.0/0          
> DROP       all  --  67.30.133.77         0.0.0.0/0          
> DROP       all  --  64.214.130.56        0.0.0.0/0          
> 
> These sites are either directly sending it to me or in
> some cases I think they are relays.
<snip>

Firewall rules aren't a good way to block spam -- they're too rigid and
high maintenance to provide a practical, long-term protection approach.

SpamAssassin is much easier and more effective:  http://spamassassin.org

Robert Munro

On Sat, Sep 06, 2003 at 10:56:53AM -0700, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Well I've discovered the hard way that blocking ips doesn't work very
> well though I am wondering if I the following is a reasonable anti
> smut approach:

Don't try to attack the catagories of spam, attack the whole problem.
I'm down to about .0098% spam with my solution.  First half is using
the setup described recently (did you search the archives?).  Second
half is report all the spam you get after that.

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Tue, Sep 02, 2003 at 02:21:23PM -0700, David Duncan wrote:
> I'll be reviewing the 'spam' issue again and deciding if I need to tune my
> rules or try a new system.  Suggestions on practical alternatives to the
> challenge-response system would be appreciated.

First off, like most of the HOWTOs I've seen on tldp, I assume Debian
because it's what I use[1].  If this doesn't match up with your RPM based
distro, that's a personal problem, switch to Xandros, Knoppix
installed to a hard drive, Debian, or another similarly sane distro.
8:o)

Here's what I have done to get my site down to ~0.009% spam.  All
packages are in sid, so if you're using woody, don't be stupid, use
backports and DO NOT USE APT-PINNING.  If you need to know why, google
for apt pin harmful site:lists.debian.org.

Get exim-daemon-heavy and sa-exim (it'll pull in the necissary
depends, like spamassassin).  Out of the box, you'll have an automatic
teergrube (anything that scores higher than 30 gets teergubed instead
of delivered, watch the headers sa-exim puts in
/var/log/exim4/reject.log to make sure this is a sane number, though
the default is high enough that I've yet to see any ham get nailed by
it).

Then, go dig around through
/etc/exim4/conf.d/acl/30_exim4-config_check_rcpt and add this to the
(empty) blacklist section.  Please note: When you use RBLs, please do
the RBL maintainers a *huge* favor by *not* mentioning them in your
reject messages (do not use the defaults).  It only appears to serve
to confuse users and anger some, the angry ones then turn around and
harass the RBL maintainers for blocking their email, something that
the maintainers had zero to do with.  Also, spammers that use
dropboxes in their From: will get the bounces, see who is giving them
the most grief, and DDOS them (witness osirusoft).

<example>

  # Currently spamming

  deny  message         = Your mail server is currently spamming.  You can either wait it out or find an ethical ISP.
        log_message     = $sender_host_address is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = bl.spamcop.net

  # Broken sites that refuse bounce messages, God only knows if
  # they'll get this.

  deny  message         = Your domain refuses bounce messages, despite breaking RFCs 821, 2821, 2505 and 1123.  Contact your mail provider to have this fixed.
        log_message     = $sender_address_domain is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = dsn.rfc-ignorant.org/$sender_address_domain

# There are a *lot* of ignorant/retarded sites that fail to have a
# postmaster.  This would probably make a better spamassassin +1.000 rule.

#  deny message         = Your domain refuses mail to postmaster, despite breaking RFC 2821.  Contact your mail provider to have this fixed.
#       log_message     = $sender_address_domain is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
#       dnslists        = postmaster.rfc-ignorant.org/$sender_address_domain


# Sites with bad whois data are almost always spammers, except in the
# UK.  The UK, for reasons beyond my comprehension, has no whois.  The
# British seem to put the fear of God into people trying to spam
# through them, hence the exception for *.uk in the rule below.

  deny  message         = Your domain has bad whois information, despite breaking RFC 954.  Please contact your mail provider to have this problem fixed.
        log_message     = $sender_address_domain is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        sender_domains  = !*.uk
        dnslists        = whois.rfc-ignorant.org/$sender_address_domain

# Fortunately, it doesn't appear anybody legitimate has a broken
# ipwhois (or if I'm wrong, I haven't been burned by it yet).

  deny  message         = Your domain has bad ipwhois information, despite breaking RFC 954.  Please contact your mail provider to have this problem fixed.
        log_message     = $sender_host_address is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = ipwhois.rfc-ignorant.org

# Known spam havens.

  deny  message         = All mail from China, South Korea, Hong Kong, Brazil, Nigeria and Taiwan is rejected.  Please clean up your collective act and kill your spammers.
        log_message     = $sender_host_address is listed at $dnslist_domain ($dnslist_value: $dnslist_text)
        dnslists        = brazil.blackholes.us : cn-kr.blackholes.us : nigeria.blackholes.us : taiwan.blackholes.us

</example>

This combinations of RBLs turns up about one false positive every four
months or so for my site.



[1] I feel the whole United Linux and LSB issues are solutions looking
for problems Debian solved years ago...

- -- 
 .''`.     Paul Johnson <baloo at ursine.ca>
: :'  :    
`. `'`     proud Debian admin and user
  `-  Debian - when you have better things to do than fix a system

From techmage at aracnet.com  Sun Sep  7 11:32:01 2003
From: techmage at aracnet.com (Prutzer)

Perhaps it is a symptom of aging. He was boorish when I was in high
school 35 years ago. Now when I read him, his use of the English
language is superior to many of my present college level Professors
and far exceeds most, if not all, the tech writers and novelist I
read. Part of his humor is in the exact use of a word in a critical
space. Thirty years from now, perhaps he will once again be boorish in
his interpretation of social events of the moment.

From alan at clueserver.org  Sun Sep  7 14:15:04 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Sun Sep  7 14:15:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Updating PHP in RedHat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <3F5A5A3D.2000603@adnap.no-ip.com>
References: <3F5A5A3D.2000603@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <1062969139.12537.6.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Sat, 2003-09-06 at 15:05, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I am trying to update PHP on my system from 'php-4.1.2-7.3.6' to 
> 'php-4.3.2-7'.  Having seen all the trashing of RPM lately, I thought it 
> would be a fun time to bring up my problems with RPM dependencies. ;-)

Sounds like that version was built for a different set of packages than
you have installed.

Rebuild the rpms from the source rpm and see if that works better.

rpmbuild --rebuild php-4.3.2-7.src.rpm


> 
> Here's what happens:
> 
> [root at adnap root]# ls php-* | cat
> php-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> php-imap-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> php-ldap-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> php-mysql-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> php-odbc-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> php-pgsql-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> php-snmp-4.3.2-7.i386.rpm
> [root at adnap root]# rpm -Uhv php-*
> error: failed dependencies:
>          httpd-mmn = 20020903 is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libaspell.so.15   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.3)   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libcrypto.so.4   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libdb-4.1.so   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libpng12.so.0   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libpspell.so.15   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libssl.so.4   is needed by php-4.3.2-7
>          libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.3)   is needed by php-imap-4.3.2-7
>          libcrypto.so.4   is needed by php-imap-4.3.2-7
>          libssl.so.4   is needed by php-imap-4.3.2-7
>          libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.3)   is needed by php-pgsql-4.3.2-7
>          libpq.so.3   is needed by php-pgsql-4.3.2-7
>          libcrypto.so.4   is needed by php-snmp-4.3.2-7
>          libnetsnmp.so.5   is needed by php-snmp-4.3.2-7
> [root at adnap root]# rpm -q glibc
> glibc-2.2.5-43
> [root at adnap root]#
> 
> Does this look like reasonable depenencies?  Does it look like I will be 
> able to meet them (and not break everything)?
> 
> It's important that PHP not be broken for any length of time.

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep  7 15:59:09 2003

Date: Sun Sep  7 15:59:09 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
Message-ID: <1062975470.16730.7.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I have a large 30 gig hard drive that has one bad sector which I want to
use for an experiment.  I'm assuming the Redhat 7.3 installer is
crashing because of this sector.  I've isolated the sector to be
somewhere on the last gig of the drive.  I'm trying to adjust some 
fat32 partitions using ranish to get a tight fit around it, though 
this is not proving easy.  The idea is to get a 10 gig parition 
around it and then use Linux fdisk to figure out what the area of 
the disk has the trouble sector as close as possible.  I figure I
can simply leave a hole between partitions in that area of the 
disk.

Is there an easier way to get the absolute location of the trouble spot?
I'm surprised that hard drives can't compensate for a single bad sector
by remapping all the sectors after it so that it essentially drops out
of the sector list.

Another hard drive from the same era has completely failed, maybe 
I am getting there on this one too.

     --  Michael

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep  7 17:00:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep  7 17:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Selectively sealing workstations inside your own network...
Message-ID: <1062979090.17357.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I have a masquerading router right now and what I'd like 
to do is selectively, when I'm running Windows on my own 
computer, deny Internet browsing.  Can I do this with 
ZoneAlarm?  Anyone know of a slick trick if I have to do 
this on the Linux server end?  For one thing, this 
feature is something I want to give the end user the 
authority to engage/disengage.

I'm surprised ZoneAlarm doesn't have an option to deny
sending out anything that's destined for any net other
than the local one.  It seems like ZoneAlarm assumes
that interfaces are either local or not, but this is 
not accurate at all in a masquerading environment.

     --  Michael



From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep  7 18:07:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep  7 18:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Masquerading question...
Message-ID: <1062983160.17357.50.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

If I want to disable a host's Internet access when it may be 
receiving data from a masquearading server, will the masq 
server terminate connections with Internet hosts because it 
can't send data to the local host anymore or does the local 
host have to terminate those connections?  I would think 
since the masq box pretends to be the local host that it 
should simulate being down when the local host is down and 
terminate any data stream destined to that host.

Out of curiosity, is there a port of iptables for Windows 98 
Second Edition?  I want to use it to set up rules that drop 
all packets outbound to the Internet and inbound from it on 
individual workstations at will.  

Ultimately, I guess the simple masquerade for any local address 
rule has to be replaced with something more complex like a user 
defined chain for each host that the appropriate masquerading 
rule can be put into and flushed out of at will.  There are hosts 
that should be allowed to traverse the local network prevented
from getting past the gateway and receiving data from the 
Net when a user wants or needs this.  This is something where
a utility would be well placed on my private internal web 
server, perhaps a CGI script.  The alternative to CGI is
an X terminal based utility.  This has the advantage that
people have to authenticate by logging in on a local Linux 
server before they can change their Internet access setting.

     --  Michael



From freyley at gmx.net  Sun Sep  7 18:52:02 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Sun Sep  7 18:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Selectively sealing workstations inside your own
	network...
In-Reply-To: <1062979090.17357.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1062979090.17357.9.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1062985872.8766.25.camel@localhost>

On Sun, 2003-09-07 at 16:58, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> I have a masquerading router right now and what I'd like 
> to do is selectively, when I'm running Windows on my own 
> computer, deny Internet browsing.  Can I do this with 
> ZoneAlarm?  Anyone know of a slick trick if I have to do 
> this on the Linux server end?  For one thing, this 
> feature is something I want to give the end user the 
> authority to engage/disengage.

As this is a Linux user group, I'm not sure how much response you'll get
asking about Windows products. However, I will say this:

if the masquerading server is running linux and is running a standard
firewall based on iptables, iptables can easily do this. The firewall
may or may not have settings for it, but should be modifiable to do
this. Add webmin and you can allow the user to do this, if they are
allowed access to configuring the firewall, which is probably a bad
idea. Otherwise, you can write a simple cgi script, make it available
internally only on the firewall, and have it dynamically add or subtract
a preset iptables rule (do not allow it to take user input regarding the
rule, or you have one hell of a security breach). 

Jeff




From beattie at beattie-home.net  Sun Sep  7 19:08:02 2003
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: Sun Sep  7 19:08:02 2003

On Sun, 2003-09-07 at 15:58, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> 
> > P.S. What does "Dont immanentize the eschaton" mean? :-/ 
> 
> 
> Here's a reference: http://www.propositionsonline.com/html/uncertain.html
> 
> It's amazing what google can find. :)

So basically this is a religious comamndment, as it is clearly rooted in
a particular set of religious philosophies. 

"Consequently, to immanentize the eschaton is to commit a basic error in
self-understanding. It is to assume wrongly that human aspiration and
destiny are coterminous with the natural world. It is to assume wrongly
that metaphysical questions, which are life?s core questions, either do
not exist at all, or can be rationally investigated only through the
methods of physics, which in practice tends to be another way of
defining such questions as unanswerable and therefore irrelevant. In
sum, to immanentize the eschaton is to assume wrongly that ultimate
reality, of which God is the final measure, is instead some form of
this-world reality, of which man is presumed to be the final measure."

Of course this paragraph assumes a number of facts, that would could
reasonably debate. :)

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Sep  8 01:19:02 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon Sep  8 01:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
In-Reply-To: <1062975470.16730.7.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309072301080.558-100000@joan.burling.com>

On 7 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> Is there an easier way to get the absolute location of the trouble spot?
> I'm surprised that hard drives can't compensate for a single bad sector
> by remapping all the sectors after it so that it essentially drops out
> of the sector list.
>
> Another hard drive from the same era has completely failed, maybe
> I am getting there on this one too.
>
The command ``mkfs -c" will remap bad sectors. So will the related
commands for other file systems. Check the man pages.

Geoff




From mwlist at planetwills.com  Mon Sep  8 07:05:02 2003
From: mwlist at planetwills.com (Mark Wills)
Date: Mon Sep  8 07:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
In-Reply-To: <1062975470.16730.7.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMAEAKDKAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>

>-----Original Message-----
>...
>I'm surprised that hard drives can't compensate for a single bad sector
>by remapping all the sectors after it so that it essentially drops out
>of the sector list.

Modern hard drives do automatically map out bad sectors. The fact that you
see a bad sector means it has already delt with a large number of them and
is on a downward spiral toward total failure. I wouldn't use the hard drive!
It is running on borrowed time.

Mark




From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Mon Sep  8 09:52:01 2003

From plug at Blain.org  Mon Sep  8 10:50:02 2003
From: plug at Blain.org (Jeff Blain)
Date: Mon Sep  8 10:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Port sniffing?
Message-ID: <20030908174954.GA19980@blain.org>

What program could I use to listen to a certain port to see what is
being sent to it. My firewall is being hit pretty hard on several ports,
that I can't find any information on over the web. Any tools for linux
or OpenBSD would be greatly appreciated.

Jeff



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Sep  8 11:05:03 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Sep  8 11:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Port sniffing?
In-Reply-To: <20030908174954.GA19980@blain.org>
References: <20030908174954.GA19980@blain.org>
Message-ID: <1063044257.3843.11.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2003-09-08 at 10:49, Jeff Blain wrote:
> What program could I use to listen to a certain port to see what is
> being sent to it. My firewall is being hit pretty hard on several ports,
> that I can't find any information on over the web. Any tools for linux
> or OpenBSD would be greatly appreciated.

Are the ports closed, or open?  If they're closed, and you want to open
some sort of pipe to see what the connecting protocol might be, 'nc'
will let you do this.  If the ports are open, then 'tcpdump' or another
of other sniffers will let trace the traffic.  My preferred way of using
it is to run tcpdump with the '-w' option to dump the packets to a file
and then copy the file to my workstation and analyze it with Ethereal.

All of these applications run on both Linux and OpenBSD.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
*   Naked Ape Consulting                 http://nakedape.cc  *

From lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com  Mon Sep  8 13:01:02 2003
From: lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com (lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com)
Date: Mon Sep  8 13:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
Message-ID: <OFF370FC56.6F6E8119-ON88256D9B.006C090C-88256D9B.006D6554@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>

                                                                                                              
                                                                                                              
                                                                                                              





>>-----Original Message-----
>>...
>>I'm surprised that hard drives can't compensate for a single bad sector
>>by remapping all the sectors after it so that it essentially drops out
>>of the sector list.
>
>Modern hard drives do automatically map out bad sectors. The fact that you
>see a bad sector means it has already delt with a large number of them and
>is on a downward spiral toward total failure. I wouldn't use the hard
drive!
>It is running on borrowed time.

Not always.  Modern drives will automatically map out sectors that they can
recover the data from.  Once the sector read fails to recover the data, the
drive
will not do anything with it, leaving that up to the user/host operating
system.

Sometimes that bad sector is the result of a incompleted write.  No amount
of
reading will recover the sector but by re-writing the block, all is well
and good.

Best bet for checking whither the drive is in the process of dying is to
check
the smart attributes values and compare these to the threshold values.  If
the
values are close ( they are clocked down toward the thresholds) then it's
time
to backup and replace.

(Plug for Plug Advanced Topics Meeting; I'll explain what smart is and why
you
 should be paying attention to it. Sept 17)

----
Larry Brigman
Fujitsu Computer Products of America
503.693.2051 lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com
Coins 87-7935-2051

What is the most common cause of hard drive failure?  I had a 
fujitsu drive from the same period as this one that is supposed 
to have a higher MTBF than an IBM deskstar, but the fujitsu 
failed first.  One guess I have is that fujitsu got booted 
more often.  When it failed it just disappeared.  I opened 
it up to look at it but there is nothing obvious inside.

the point where anyone can recover data off of it short of 
sending it to a trusted recycling shop?

sprayed on them that's magnetic.  As far as bad sectors, are they
mostly caused by spikes in power to the drive head or does the
magnetic material deform beyond manipulation by the head after 
a while?  Is exposing the platters to the air enough to permanently
prevent anyone from getting remnants of the data that was on it?

>

> Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

I think it's because inetd doesn't have any throttling capability.
Something about stampede, inetd not doing well in situations
where a herd requests service all at once.  I also 
believe that xinetd is considered cleaner because services
can be put into their own files and the functionality of
tcp_wrappers is part of xinetd.

One problem I have with xinetd is not knowing the syntax so
that I can write control files for certain services.  In the
inetd days most everything was there and you just uncommented
a service to enable it.

I believe xinetd has traffic shaping functionality that inetd
does not have.  Something in the howto about inetd becoming
unreliable under heavy load was under the xinetd HOWTO if
I remember correctly.

     --  Michael

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Sep  8 15:34:11 2003

Date: Mon Sep  8 15:34:11 2003

On Mon, 2003-09-08 at 14:52, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Will someone please remind me why running inetd is not a good idea? I
> don't run it, but I could not explain to someone else why not. I forgot!
> 
For some services it isn't a bad idea, usually this is referring to
services that are not accessed very often.  However, for services that
need to be stopped at will, or that get lots of requests, running as a
stand alone deamon is much more manageable.  Examples of these are
Apache, Samba and ftp.  

I hope that answers your question.

Derek Loree





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Sep  8 15:34:25 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Sep  8 15:34:25 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
In-Reply-To: <1063054551.24180.6.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <7514-86836@sneakemail.com>

On 8 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson michael-at-goose.robinson-west.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> What is the most common cause of hard drive failure?

Try a quick read through this PDF from the fine folks at Seagate:

http://www.seagate.com/content/docs/pdf/whitepaper/D2c_More_than_Interface_ATA_vs_SCSI_042003.pdf

My take on the most common causes of hard drive failure are:
  + heat
  + failed spindle motor bearings
  + power surge/lag damage
  + vibration (often temporary "failure")

> When it failed it just disappeared.

Sounds like the electronics/controller died if you couldn't even get the
drive to identify itself.

One note on MTBFs-- in order to compare them you'll need to know the
assumptions made by each manufacturer with regard to the test
environment.  Were the drives on continually?  Were they only on 8
hours/day?  Was there a single power on per day or multiple?  What was the
ambient temperature kept at?  Etc. etc.

> I opened it up to look at it but there is nothing obvious inside.  

My guess is that the insides were probably completely functional when you
opened it.  Neat stuff in there, eh?

> What do you have to do to manually erase a hard disk beyond the point
> where anyone can recover data off of it short of sending it to a
> trusted recycling shop?

Writing once to each sector on the filesystem is enough to deter anyone
without access to a data recovery shop.  This is obviously hard to do if
the drive is inaccessible.

After that you'll simply need to weigh your paranoia vs. the time and
effort you want to spend.  For the truly paranoid, converting the entire
drive to plasma and dispersing it slowly into the atmosphere at high speed
and high altitude is probably sufficient.

> I've heard that hard disks have aluminum platters with something
> sprayed on them that's magnetic.

Glass was a more common substrate as of 2001.  It's smoother than
aluminum.  Manufacturers may well be on to something new now.

You're right about the thin layer of depositted magnetic material though.

> As far as bad sectors, are they mostly caused by spikes in power to
> the drive head or does the magnetic material deform beyond
> manipulation by the head after a while?

Hard drives use complex algorithms that extract a tiny signal from the
background noise.  The denser you pack the bits, the closer the signal
gets to the noise.  (And there is a strong financial motivation to pack
the bits as close as possible.)

If the magnetic properties of a microscopic magnetic domain change
slightly over time due to heating/cooling, oxidation, etc. the noise may
eventually engulf the signal.

Severe shock to the drive can also result in head/platter contact which
vaporizes some of the material from the surface and exposes nearby areas
to extremely high heat.  (Think of what your Dremel at 15,000 RPMs does to
what it touches.)  This alters the magnetic properties of a large area of
the surface and can easily create sudden nonrecoverable failures.

In modern drives, the slow creep of heat + oxidation happens so often that
when the algorithm can't cope with the change any more, and the logic in
the sector headers can't cope with the change any more that sector gets
remapped transparently to the host controller.  Note the key is that this
happens slowly-- the drive itself is aware that it can't read this area as
well as it used to before the area becomes completely unreadable.  (This
is where SMART comes in-- providing this information back to the host
controller.)

The magnetic material itself does not "wear out" from being magnetized.

> Is exposing the platters to the air enough to permanently prevent
> anyone from getting remnants of the data that was on it?

Anyone?  Nope.  Most folks?  Yep.

I find exposing the platters to a 3 pound sledge helps prevent even more
folks from getting remnants of the original data.  Microwaving is also
fun, though I usually reserve that fate for my CD-R media.

  -- Steve

On Mon, 2003-09-08 at 15:31, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   According to the notice from the Slackware security e-mail I received

> over a short period of time. And, it would remain shut down for 10 minutes.
> So, a DoS could be effective by sending a very few packets every 10 minutes

> 
>   It may be that xinetd avoids the problem.
> 
>   But, neither appear to be required so why run them anyway?

demand. I almost never run them on workstations and I try
to avoid using them on servers. 

Ed




From lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com  Mon Sep  8 16:34:02 2003
From: lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com (lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com)
Date: Mon Sep  8 16:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
Message-ID: <OF3B8328CA.F63CFC7D-ON88256D9B.007E0B73-88256D9B.00815F3C@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>


>> Best bet for checking whither the drive is in the process of dying is to
>> check
>> the smart attributes values and compare these to the threshold values.
If
>> the
>> values are close ( they are clocked down toward the thresholds) then
it's
>> time
>> to backup and replace.
>>
>> (Plug for Plug Advanced Topics Meeting; I'll explain what smart is and
why
>> you
>>  should be paying attention to it. Sept 17)
>>
>
>
>What is the most common cause of hard drive failure?  I had a
>fujitsu drive from the same period as this one that is supposed
>to have a higher MTBF than an IBM deskstar, but the fujitsu
>failed first.  One guess I have is that fujitsu got booted
>more often.  When it failed it just disappeared.  I opened
>it up to look at it but there is nothing obvious inside.

Failures: Head/media interface: mechanical shock and particle
contamination.
Boards: mechanical shock and vibration, electrical shock (static).

The Fujitsu problem I'll refer you here:
http://www.theregister.co.uk/content/archive/28384.html
as I cannot publicly comment on it.  If you bought it directly from
us or a distributor and it's in warranty, we will replace it.

>What do you have to do to manually erase a hard disk beyond
>the point where anyone can recover data off of it short of
>sending it to a trusted recycling shop?

If it functions then a format (low level or interface level) followed
by random data write to the full surface (raw device, no filesystem) or
two full surface random data writes.

Non-function. Disassembly and use a magnet, the one from the actuator
will do nicely, if you can get it apart (watch you fingers).

>
>I've heard that hard disks have aluminum platters with something
>sprayed on them that's magnetic.  As far as bad sectors, are they
>mostly caused by spikes in power to the drive head or does the
>magnetic material deform beyond manipulation by the head after
>a while?

Yes most platters are aluminum with multiple layers of magnetic
material.

A large percentage of failures we see are interrupted writes (most
of our customers use MS).  A lockup while trying to write followed by
the power switch or hard reset can cause this problem.

The ability for the magnetic material to record data is only effected by
heat or in the case of platters the lack of magnetic material cause by
the heads hitting the disk.

>Is exposing the platters to the air enough to permanently
>prevent anyone from getting remnants of the data that was on it?

No there is air in the drive and it is recirculated from the outside
through a breather hole (filtered).

----
Larry Brigman
Fujitsu Computer Products of America
503.693.2051 lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com

commented out are these:

# Red Hat Linux 7.3
rpm http://ayo.freshrpms.net redhat/7.3/i386 os updates freshrpms
rpm-src http://ayo.freshrpms.net redhat/7.3/i386 os updates freshrpms

are commented out.

From ian at znark.com  Mon Sep  8 23:38:02 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Mon Sep  8 23:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Updating PHP in RedHat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <3F5D17ED.3090501@adnap.no-ip.com>
References: <FDEF90F7203F4F46BDE4151DE7A0752D2C8A1A@cvgexsrv1.sdrc.com> <3F5D17ED.3090501@adnap.no-ip.com>
Message-ID: <3F5D7504.1090702@znark.com>

Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> 
> So I looked at the manpage, and tried this:
> 
> [root at adnap root]# apt-get install php=4.3.2-7
> Reading Package Lists... Done
> Building Dependency Tree... Done
> E: Version '4.3.2-7' for 'php' was not found
> [root at adnap root]# apt-get install php=4.3.2
> Reading Package Lists... Done
> Building Dependency Tree... Done
> E: Version '4.3.2' for 'php' was not found
> [root at adnap root]# apt-get install php=4.3
> Reading Package Lists... Done
> Building Dependency Tree... Done
> E: Version '4.3' for 'php' was not found
> [root at adnap root]#
> 
> No luck with that either.  I'm looking at 'dist-upgrade' in the 
> manpages.  Is that what I need to try next?
 >

You would need to find a repository containing the new version.  The 
default /etc/apt/sources.list contains the RedHat 7.3 distribution and 
updates.  That has an older version.  There are some good apt-enabled 
repositories out there but none of them contain php.

Did you try looking on rpm.pbone.net and rpmfind.net?  A brief search 
showed a couple of packages for RH8 and 9.  The package you had before 
looked like it was built against one of those.  Getting all the 
dependencies to install will be equivalent to upgrading the machine to 
RH 8/9.  I did see a php-4.3.1-1 in the RedHat contrib section that 
looks like it is compatible with RH 7.3.  Using that as a basis for 
building 4.3.2 or 4.3.3 may work well.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/




From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Tue Sep  9 02:40:02 2003

Oh, I did have to replace the first fujitsu drive I got.  The
replacement that failed lasted quite a while.  Is it true that
Fujitsu America is out of business?  

What's the deal with IBM getting out of the drive business?  
Who is buying out Seagate?  Some say high quality hard drives, 
used to be IBM and Fujitsu, don't sell well because few realize 
that the price is well worth paying.  If a cheap component 
fails prematurely, your not really saving any money.  

It's said that backup is essential for data on hard disk, but 
there's hardly anything out there now that writes more than 
once capable of holding as much as today's hard drives.  
Try buying a tape drive these days, if your an average 
user you'll probably think $1000 is too much where that's
a low estimate.  I've yet to see anyone for example sell a 
200 gig tape system at a reasonable price, there are hard
disks this big and larger already though.

I suppose anymore one has to hope any data they need to
keep fits on a CD.

One thought is raid boxes.  The drives probably destroy
each other though because of the amount of vibration.

Who is making hard drives these days?  How many companies are
competing with so many brands disappearing? 

     --  Michael C. Robinson



From root at loraksus.d2g.com  Tue Sep  9 03:38:01 2003

>What's the deal with IBM getting out of the drive business?
google "ibm deathstar" you will find many happy people and great stories.

I like western digital's 3 year warranty 8mb buffer drives, and I've never
had to rma one. Good for heat too.
I've rma'd two maxtors, but I noticed the ticking and got my data off first,
and the turnaround was quick - both drives were the 2mb pos "guaranteed not
to break until 1 year is up" editions, so I kind of deserve it. I don't
think they have many quality controls on the 1yr/2mb cheapo drives - and I
think this is not isolated to a single manufacturer - I've gotten cheapo
drives that came with damaged ide cables inside the shrink wrapped box
/shrug.

Of course, the techs never want to rma a drive with occasional ticking, etc,
so I keep an old 4.5 gb 7200 rpm seagate baracuda that screams so loud you
can hear it 40 feet away handy - just stick that to the phone and instant
rma >;)
The above smiley looks like terrance and phillip, so I must be a bit tired.

From lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com  Tue Sep  9 08:51:01 2003
From: lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com (lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com)
Date: Tue Sep  9 08:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
Message-ID: <OFAEE3494E.67B15CC4-ON88256D9C.0053325C-88256D9C.00569154@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>



... snip ...
>Is it true that Fujitsu America is out of business?

No, Fujitsu America is still in business.  Disk drives are
made by Fujitsu LTD and sold by Fujitsu Computer products of America
here in the US.

Fujitsu did stop playing in the cut-throat desktop market where
gross margins on these products have dropped down to the commodity level


>What's the deal with IBM getting out of the drive business?

IBM didn't fell it was profitable anymore and didn't see a long
term future.  They thought that Moore's law was going to run head
long into the wall for Disk drives.

>Who is buying out Seagate?

Seagate bought out Seagate.  They went public at some time in the
past but have now gone back private.

... snip ...
>Try buying a tape drive these days, if your an average
>user you'll probably think $1000 is too much where that's
>a low estimate.  I've yet to see anyone for example sell a
>200 gig tape system at a reasonable price, there are hard
>disks this big and larger already though.

Tape market is a slow trend follower as it is geared toward
businesses.  They are working toward 8 terabyte cartridge
capacity.

>I suppose anymore one has to hope any data they need to
>keep fits on a CD.
Looks like the DVD writers are starting to push the price down
to make these the new backup medium.

>One thought is raid boxes.  The drives probably destroy
>each other though because of the amount of vibration.

Not most of the time because they are normally isolated.  The
one thing most people didn't realize about raid is you buy all
the same drive (manufacturer,capacity, manufacture date) and
any failure you get is multiplied across the raid.  They could all
fail within days if it is a manufacturing defect or lot code material
problem.

>Who is making hard drives these days?  How many companies are
>competing with so many brands disappearing?

Hitachi www.hgst.com     Took over all of IBM's manufacturing sites.
Fujitsu www.fujitsu.com  Left desktop market in Sept 2001.
Maxtor  www.maxtor.com   Took over Quantum disk drives.  Quantum focusing
on tape.
NEC     www.nec.com      Mostly Japan domestic.
Toshiba                  Just laptop devices.
Seagate www.seagate.com
Western Digital  www.westerndigital.com   Lost money (lots) for about 3
years.
Samsung

----
Larry Brigman
Fujitsu Computer Products of America
503.693.2051 lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com

From plug at Blain.org  Tue Sep  9 09:13:02 2003
From: plug at Blain.org (Jeff Blain)
Date: Tue Sep  9 09:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Port sniffing?
In-Reply-To: <1063044257.3843.11.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <20030908174954.GA19980@blain.org> <1063044257.3843.11.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <20030909162827.GA16769@blain.org>

On Mon, Sep 08, 2003 at 11:04:17AM -0700, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-09-08 at 10:49, Jeff Blain wrote:
> > What program could I use to listen to a certain port to see what is
> > being sent to it. My firewall is being hit pretty hard on several ports,
> > that I can't find any information on over the web. Any tools for linux
> > or OpenBSD would be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Are the ports closed, or open?  If they're closed, and you want to open
> some sort of pipe to see what the connecting protocol might be, 'nc'
> will let you do this.  If the ports are open, then 'tcpdump' or another
> of other sniffers will let trace the traffic.  My preferred way of using
> it is to run tcpdump with the '-w' option to dump the packets to a file
> and then copy the file to my workstation and analyze it with Ethereal.
> 
> All of these applications run on both Linux and OpenBSD.

Thanks Wil. nc did exactly what I needed, and it was already installed. 

Jeff

--
Competing with Linux is like nailing jello to a tree.

linux ide=nodma

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Sep  9 11:20:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Sep  9 11:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] cupsd: Child exited on signal 11
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309090947310.4833-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309090947310.4833-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309091117190.22616@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 9 Sep 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:

> I upgraded from Mandrake 9.0 to 9.1 and now cups has a problem.  Whenever
> cupsd is started it reports: cupsd: Child exited on signal 11
>
> Anyone seen this?  Any suggestions for debugging?

Phil,

  No, I've not seen that one. But now and then -- _very_ infrequently -- I
have a printing problem with CUPS. Stopping and restarting cupsd almost
always helps. When it doesn't, I check the process list and discover that
something's stuck on the parallel port and holding it hostage. Killing the
process for lp0 clears up the problem. Of course, it usually takes me a
half-hour or more to think of checking the port. :-)

Rich

Subject:	Would like to get operating B4 Sep. 20, if poss.???

I'm a Linux neophyte living in the "thriving metropolis" of Donald, OR & 
who just bought Mandrake 9.1.  I'd previously used PartitionMagic 7.0 to 
create 2 partitions for Linux (L: = Ext2 of 2.416GB & M: = Swap File of 
305.9MB).  These 2 partitions are on their own hdd. with another 2+GB of 
the Logical partition still unused.

While installing from the 2 CD's, my mouse died.  This happened after 
the manual configure screen where I set my monitor resolution & printer 
configuration correction.  I was trying to configure my sound card when 
I evidently hit the mouse button too quick... (the Hourglass mouse icon 
was visible a long time & I couldn't hear nor see any hdd nor screen 
activity... it was like the system had hung).  Since the "3-finger 
salute" didn't work, I hit the power switch.  Upon restarting, the 
system went straight to Win2k.  I don't know how to get to the Linux 
user environment.  I assume there's still some configuration needed as I 
would think boot-up would present me with a menu from which to choose 
the OS I want to use... but that's not happening.

Win2k Pro OS = C: drive, Applications = D: drive, & Data = E: drive on 
PII 300MHz SuperMicro MBd, printer = HP 693C, mouse = MS PS/2 
wheelmouse, Kbd. = 108 key windows, video card = Diamond Fire GL1000 
Pro, monitor = Viewsonic P810-3, soundcard = Creative AWE64 16-bit, 
Network card = D-Link DFE-530TX PCI Fast Ethernet, plugged into 
SMC7004ABR Barricade Router, plugged into a Motorola SB4101 Surfboard 
cable Modem.  My wife's computer is on the Lan, also, but only running 
Win2k Pro, for now.

As usual, I thought I could do it alone... but not so.  I'd very much 
like to not have to wait until Sep. 20th for the Linux Clinic to get 
Linux up & running as all our (read the wife's) expenses are continually 
needing entry.  Yes the data is backed-up.

My end objective is to be weaned off MS's $$$ path & wholly onto Linux. 
 I'm now Retarded (as my brother-in-law calls it) & on fixed income so 
can't afford lots of s/w to update.  Any help you, or someone you know, 
can offer would be very greatly appreciated.  I also have a telephone 
within reach while at my computer.

Thank you for your consideration in this matter.
Dave

Given that this problem occurred after a software upgrade, it's unlikely
that this is a memory problem.  Nonetheless, I'd try running memtest86
just to be sure your machine is working properly.

galen

I just downgraded to the older cups rpms from Mandrake 9.0 - now at least 
cupsd starts and I can see stuff in the queue.  Still not getting any 
printouts, but I suspect it's 
something to do with shorewall.  Last night I downgraded shorewall to get 
it working right again (obviously there's still some configuration to be 
done, but I wasn't getting anywhere at all with the shorewall that came 
with 9.1).  I also have had a lot of trouble with the 2.4.21-mdk kernel 
that comes with Mandrake 9.1 - My machine would seize up when trying to access 
the CDROM for example - so I went back to the 2.4.19-mdk kernel that came 
with 9.0....  I'm beginning to wonder why I bothered to upgrade, it seems 
to have been a total waste of time.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Sep  9 13:05:12 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Sep  9 13:05:12 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: Would like to get operating B4 Sep. 20, if poss.???
In-Reply-To: <01C376C7.32502AF0.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
References: <01C376C7.32502AF0.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
Message-ID: <3F5E3239.8000906@pacifier.com>

da.haole.boy wrote:
> While installing from the 2 CD's, my mouse died.  This happened after 
> the manual configure screen where I set my monitor resolution & printer 
> configuration correction.  I was trying to configure my sound card when 
> I evidently hit the mouse button too quick... 

Since Mandrake & Red Hat are supposedly similiar, my guess is that the 
installer waits to the very end to write to the mbr and set up the 
bootloader.  This happened to me the other day when installing RH 8.0 (bad 
media).

I usually skip setting up X and sound until the OS is up and running.  Too 
many times the installer barfs on those two things and you need to 
reinstall.  Suspect that's what you'll have to do as well.

--
Kyle Accardi

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Sep  9 13:29:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla idea...
Message-ID: <20030909202814.GG21681@dalsemi.com>

I'm forever filling out forms on line; wikis, CMS'es, time sheets and I
hate not being to edit with my editor of choice.  Wouldn't it be sweet
if you could click inside one of those forms, hit a hot key, and have
it bring up gvim/xemacs/nedit/DreamWeaver/Quanta/Bluefish or whatever?

So I was wondering if there was anyone here who is a Mozilla/Epiphany
hacker who would be willing to take me under their wing and give me
some guidance to create my own plug-in to do this?

Thanks,
Colin

> > some guidance to create my own plug-in to do this?
> 
> There is already a plug-in to do this.  Check the plug-in sites; I
> forget what it's called.

It's called Electrix, and I'll let you know how it works.

Thanks, Wil!

Colin

From dzeut at microsharp.com  Tue Sep  9 20:22:02 2003
From: dzeut at microsharp.com (Dale)
Date: Tue Sep  9 20:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Mandrake 9.1 just isn't worth it
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309091257480.10673-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309091257480.10673-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <1063164092.4554.21.camel@mach3.intra.zeutenhorst.com>

I have been working with 9.1 for a while and have not had any problems
with cops - as long as I did not try to run in msec modes 5.

I did find a post where someone had an error 11 when upgrading to 9.0 -
the fix was to remove cups rpms and then delete the configuration files,
then install them again. 

If you have problems with shorewall - dump the Mandrake utils and use
Webmin to control it, much easier to use. 


On Tue, 2003-09-09 at 13:03, Phil Tomson wrote:

> 
> I just downgraded to the older cups rpms from Mandrake 9.0 - now at least 
> cupsd starts and I can see stuff in the queue.  Still not getting any 
> printouts, but I suspect it's 
> something to do with shorewall.  Last night I downgraded shorewall to get 
> it working right again (obviously there's still some configuration to be 
> done, but I wasn't getting anywhere at all with the shorewall that came 
> with 9.1).  I also have had a lot of trouble with the 2.4.21-mdk kernel 
> that comes with Mandrake 9.1 - My machine would seize up when trying to access 
> the CDROM for example - so I went back to the 2.4.19-mdk kernel that came 
> with 9.0....  I'm beginning to wonder why I bothered to upgrade, it seems 
> to have been a total waste of time.  
> 
> Phil

From miken at hotsushi.com  Tue Sep  9 20:36:02 2003
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Tue Sep  9 20:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Free Linux tutorials from IBM/Gentoo
Message-ID: <B0068956910@mail.oregoncoast.com>

from: Frank Carlos <solrac at us.ibm.com> 

Here's 5 excellent LPI certification 101 (release 2) exam prep tutorials:



LPI certification 101 (release 2) exam prep, Linux fundamentals

In this free tutorial, Daniel Robbins begins preparing you to take the 
Linux Professional Institute's Exam 101 Release 2. Daniel introduces you to 
bash (the standard Linux shell), shows you how to take full advantage of 
standard Linux commands such as ls, cp, and mv, explains inodes and hard 
and symbolic links, and much more. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have 
a solid grounding in Linux fundamentals and will be ready to begin learning 
some basic Linux system administration tasks.

tutorial link:

<http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir21-i.html?S_TACT=
103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LPIcert1rel2>http://www-106.ibm.com/develope
rworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir21-i.html?S_TACT=103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LP
Icert1rel2




LPI certification 101 (release 2) exam prep, Basic administration

In this free tutorial, Daniel Robbins, Chris Houser, and Aron Griffis 
prepare you for the Linux Professional Institute's Exam 101 Release 2. In 
this tutorial you will learn how to use regular expressions to search files 
for text patterns, how to locate files on your system, and how to take full 
control of Linux processes. You'll even get a whirlwind introduction to 
shell pipelines, redirection, and text processing commands.

tutorial link:

<http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir22-i.html?S_TACT=
103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LPIcert2rel2>http://www-106.ibm.com/develope
rworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir22-i.html?S_TACT=103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LP
Icert2rel2




LPI certification 101 (release 2) exam prep, Intermediate administration

This free tutorial is ideal for those who want to improve their knowledge 
of fundamental Linux administration skills. We'll cover a variety of 
topics, including system and Internet documentation, the Linux permissions 
model, user account management, and login environment tuning.

tutorial link:

<http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir23-i.html?S_TACT=
103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LPIcert3rel2>http://www-106.ibm.com/develope
rworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir23-i.html?S_TACT=103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LP
Icert3rel2




LPI certification 101 (release 2) exam prep, Advanced administration

In this free tutorial, we'll round out your knowledge of important Linux 
administration skills by covering a variety of topics including: Linux 
filesystems, the Linux boot process, runlevels, filesystem quotas, and 
system logs.

tutorial link:

<http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpri24-i.html?S_TACT=
103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LPIcert4rel2>http://www-106.ibm.com/develope
rworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpri24-i.html?S_TACT=103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LP
Icert4rel2




LPI certification 102 (release 2) exam prep, Compiling sources and 
managing packages

In this free tutorial, we'll show you how to compile programs from sources, 
how to manage shared libraries, and how to use the Red Hat and Debian 
package management systems.

tutorial link:

<http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir25-i.html?S_TACT=
103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LPIcert5rel2>http://www-106.ibm.com/develope
rworks/edu/l-dw-linux-lpir25-i.html?S_TACT=103AMW61&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-LPIw01LP
Icert5rel2

From brucek at kingkon.com  Wed Sep 10 10:03:02 2003
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Wed Sep 10 10:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: Would like to get operating B4 Sep. 20, if poss.???
In-Reply-To: <3F5E3239.8000906@pacifier.com>; from sandbox@pacifier.com on Tue, Sep 09, 2003 at 01:04:09PM -0700
References: <01C376C7.32502AF0.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com> <3F5E3239.8000906@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030910100201.A4592@defiant.ncplus.net>

Kyle Accardi's Log: StarDate 0909.1304:
> da.haole.boy wrote:
> > While installing from the 2 CD's, my mouse died.  This happened after 
> > the manual configure screen where I set my monitor resolution & printer 
> > configuration correction.  I was trying to configure my sound card when 
> > I evidently hit the mouse button too quick... 
> 
> Since Mandrake & Red Hat are supposedly similiar, my guess is that the 
> installer waits to the very end to write to the mbr and set up the 
> bootloader.  This happened to me the other day when installing RH 8.0 (bad 
> media).
> 
> I usually skip setting up X and sound until the OS is up and running.  Too 
> many times the installer barfs on those two things and you need to 
> reinstall.  Suspect that's what you'll have to do as well.

Same here. I have had plenty of problems setting up GUI preferences,
and other cute/useful widgets that sometimes lockup the GUI. So, I
always install to NOT launch X on startup. I have it boot to a
console, and then once I have a working system, I can put "startx" in
the ".bash_profile". Then, if something in the X bails, I can use
"ctl-alt-F7" to exit X and be back to the command line. If X won't
exit that way, I can usually use "ctl-alt-F2" to get to another
console login prompt where I can login and kill the X system to
recover without rebooting.

BTW -- has Donald grown recently? At my last visit, they had a diner
and a stop sign.... I used to live in Aurora (about 15 years ago).

-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland					       brucek at kingkon.com
Kingsland Konsulting    {dba: Renegaid Services}             360-531-3730

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Wed Sep 10 12:45:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Wed Sep 10 12:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101211410.22287@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101240380.10309-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>

I'm trying to set up masquerading / nat with iptables.

I downloaded a simple firewall script to get me started.  The last line of 
the script does:

iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o ppp0 -j MASQUERADE

However, this returns:
iptables: Invalid argument

if I remove the '-j MASQUERADE' part of the command, like so:

iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o ppp0

it's fine, but of course that does nothing....

Any idea why it doesn't like: '-j MASQUERADE'?

Phil





From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Wed Sep 10 13:06:02 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Wed Sep 10 13:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101240380.10309-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101305000.18555-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Wed, 10 Sep 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:

>
>I'm trying to set up masquerading / nat with iptables.
>
>I downloaded a simple firewall script to get me started.  The last line of 
>the script does:
>
>iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o ppp0 -j MASQUERADE
>
>However, this returns:
>iptables: Invalid argument
>
>if I remove the '-j MASQUERADE' part of the command, like so:
>
>iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o ppp0
>
>it's fine, but of course that does nothing....
>
>Any idea why it doesn't like: '-j MASQUERADE'?

Looks like the nat module is not auto-loading.

Try adding this to the top of your script:

	modprobe iptable_nat

-Eric




From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Sep 10 13:06:11 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Sep 10 13:06:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101240380.10309-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101240380.10309-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101301550.22287@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 10 Sep 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:

> Any idea why it doesn't like: '-j MASQUERADE'?

Did you try '-j MASQ'? That's used in the iptables man page in one
spot.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Wed Sep 10 13:26:01 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Wed Sep 10 13:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101305000.18555-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101318420.12377-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>

Turns out the problem was because I was booting up an older kernel 
(2.4.19mdk) instead of 2.4.21 (the one that came with Mandrake 9.1) 
because the laterr kernel was causing the machine to hang when accessing 
the CDROM.  Now that I've tried it with the 2.4.21 kernel I don't get the 
Invalid argument message.  Must be that the wrong modules were being 
loaded.

Phil
