From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 10 14:40:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Sep 10 14:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rpm spec for eclipse
In-Reply-To: <1063228281.4157.130.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101211410.22287@pecos.madboa.com>
 <1063228281.4157.130.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101434190.25866@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 10 Sep 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:

> I take it then you're actually running Eclipse... Lots of people are
> raving about it, but I started to look at it and it seemed to be 100+ MB
> download and there seemed to be some other stuff I wasn't ready to deal
> with (maybe the lack of a spec file was one of them).  So is it really
> good?  How is it for Perl and Python development?  Can you give us a 3
> minute report on it?

Wil,

  I'm just beginning to use it for java development of a very large project.
It came very highly recommended to me. It is large (rather slow on my
PII/333 MHz system) but it gets things done. I was told by Nathan Meyers
(some of you may remember him) that Eclipse was what took him away from vi
(or was it emacs?) to a GUI tool for writing all his java code. As far as
I'm concerned, there's no higher praise.

  If you want to go one step further, download the community (i.e., free)
edition of Posidon-for-UML. It's a terrific UML tool and will output code in
several languages. I know it does java and the java fits right in to
Eclipse.

Rich

Yes, previewing a message is equivalent to opening it, AFAIK.  But
there's no actual "interesting" code in the message you forwarded--it's

very new or just a one-off prank.

like a really dumb idea to forward it to a mailing list?

Previewing isn't "exactly" the same as opening.

There are some virii that run on preview, and there are some that run on 
opening. Still others, you have to open an attachment to actually 
activate the virus.

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Wed Sep 10 21:49:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Sep 10 21:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Possible worm, the attachment is the text source listing
	of the email in question.
In-Reply-To: <1063251136.7275.50.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <1063250062.4108.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 
	<1063251136.7275.50.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <1063255656.4312.31.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> And by the way, if you genuinely think it's dangerous, doesn't it seem
> like a really dumb idea to forward it to a mailing list?

That's why I didn't forward the actual message.  I copied the source 
of the email into a text file.  Last time I checked, text files are
viewed as plain text.
  
By making the suspicious email an attachment, it doesn't automatically
open.  Saving it as text, Windows won't even render it as html.  My
understanding is that attachments have to be opened to be dangerous. 
There isn't any Linux email program that will do that without a user
request, is there?  I did indicate that the attachment is the code of
this suspicious thing.  Surely no program will execute a text file.

What can I do in the future if I want to send a suspicious email
somewhere to be evaluated safely?  Good thing it's a hoax as it
couldn't have infected anyone anyways.  I really didn't think 
the way I packaged it that it could infect easily even if it 
was a real worm.  

It's the body of the message that outlook for example will 
execute, unless there was a command in that body to open the 
attachment as well, which there isn't.  I should point out 
that only the read bits are set on the attachment.  I 
sent it from a Linux machine allowing me to take this
precaution.

Had this suspicious thing been a binary, I wouldn't have 
forwarded it in any form.

     --  Michael

AFAIK, for Outlook and Outlook Express, previewing and viewing of
messages are handled by the same IE control -- there's literally no
difference, just different window dressing.  It's very different for
messages whose attack is triggered by attachment execution, but that's
another issue.

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Wed Sep 10 23:03:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Sep 10 23:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] inetd
In-Reply-To: <1063061368.4109.38.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309081451110.19533@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1063059107.24807.5.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0309081528480.19618@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
	<1063061368.4109.38.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1063260104.4312.38.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> You don't need them if you don't need to launch daemons on
> demand. I almost never run them on workstations and I try
> to avoid using them on servers. 
> 
> Ed

How is a daemon running all the time better than inetd or xinetd
launching a daemon on demand?  Wouldn't it make sense to have inetd
listen for services you offer when requests are very low and then
switch to a daemon when requests go up?  Potentially I see 
lightening up the number of daemons through inetd and xinetd 
which could improve performance.  The other thing is, doesn't
xinetd give a wrapper for controlling who can access a service
and at what rate which is more standard and easier to understand 
than each individual daemon that can be used instead?

     --  Michael

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Sep 10 23:17:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Sep 10 23:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] inetd
In-Reply-To: <1063260104.4312.38.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309081451110.19533@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1063059107.24807.5.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309081528480.19618@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1063061368.4109.38.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1063260104.4312.38.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1063260965.7275.68.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2003-09-10 at 23:01, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> How is a daemon running all the time better than inetd or xinetd
> launching a daemon on demand?  Wouldn't it make sense to have inetd
> listen for services you offer when requests are very low and then
> switch to a daemon when requests go up?  Potentially I see 
> lightening up the number of daemons through inetd and xinetd 
> which could improve performance.  The other thing is, doesn't
> xinetd give a wrapper for controlling who can access a service
> and at what rate which is more standard and easier to understand 
> than each individual daemon that can be used instead?

Yes, [x]inetd-style daemons are a bit easier to implement, because you
can rely on the super-server to manage access controls, forking, socket
handling, etc.  I've written shell-based HTTP servers with no task other
than sending a redirect message to another port (where a real HTTP
server was listening).  But for daemons that have fairly slow start-up
times, the overhead is too much.  And really, memory isn't so tight
these days, so a few extra MBs doesn't make that much of a difference. 
I doubt you'd see much of an improvement in any machine with more than
64MB of memory.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * * * * Good, fast and cheap: Pick all 3! * * * * * * *
*   Naked Ape Consulting                http://nakedape.cc  *

From holger at selover.net  Wed Sep 10 23:18:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Wed Sep 10 23:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Possible worm, the attachment is the text source listing
	of the email in question.
In-Reply-To: <1063250062.4108.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1063250062.4108.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1063261028.1544.125.camel@halo>

The message contained plain HTML which can't contain a worm because it
is only parsed and rendered but not executed. If there is no JavaScript
or other script or macro there is also no threat to text based
documents. 

Holger

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Wed Sep 10 23:29:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed Sep 10 23:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
In-Reply-To: 
	<OFAEE3494E.67B15CC4-ON88256D9C.0053325C-88256D9C.00569154@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.c
	om>
References: 
	<OFAEE3494E.67B15CC4-ON88256D9C.0053325C-88256D9C.00569154@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.c
	om>
Message-ID: <1063261685.4312.65.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> IBM didn't fell it was profitable anymore and didn't see a long
> term future.  They thought that Moore's law was going to run head
> long into the wall for Disk drives.

I read something on google that the company makes it's own 
motherboards from older technology because that fits their 
needs better.  If I understand Moore's law correctly, it's a 
theory that computing power will constantly increase through 
advances in IC manufacturing techniques.  It is evidently 
based on the idea that more and more demanding computer 
applications will feed investment into ever more expensive 
chip manufacturer processes,  whether that be .25 micron 
technology, .18 micron technology, etc.  One thing I came 
across that doesn't make sense is why it "always" costs
more to build a plant that produces the smallest possible 
IC's than it did to build one even a year earlier.  Not 
only that, one site suggested that the price is double or 
worse for the current generation plants than it is for the 
plants from the immediately preceeding generation.

What is considered profitable anyways?  Has trying to develop 
things quickly instead of fully hurt Intel and other companies 
in the PC business the most?

I think PC hardware manufacturers are intent on discontinuing
products ASAP so that people will be forced into newer stuff,
whether they need it or not.  I'd like to hear companies like
Intel, IBM, Sun, HP, etc. talk about what high tech is going
to be in the future without the funerals I've seemingly been
running into.  So people don't get to be million dollar 
wonders after one year in industry.  Who said that was ever
correct anyways?  I think the political pressure of 
monopolies on the industry is what's challenging Moore's
law more than anything.  Like many, I'm worried about
Computer Science and other related fields, especially
because of the scare talk that is going on in our post 
dot bust world.

I read somewhere that Moore thinks the post dot com computer
industry will be strong, but unprofitable.  Why would any of us
have to accept that?  I think there's plenty to do.

     --  Michael



From shahms at shahms.com  Thu Sep 11 08:28:02 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Thu Sep 11 08:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] rpm spec for eclipse
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101434190.25866@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101211410.22287@pecos.madboa.com>
	 <1063228281.4157.130.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309101434190.25866@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1063293894.24033.0.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

RedHat has made gcj-compiled (i.e. x86 native) Eclipse RPMS available
for a while now.  I don't remember the URL but a quick google should
turn up the page.

On Wed, 2003-09-10 at 14:38, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 10 Sep 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:
> 
> > I take it then you're actually running Eclipse... Lots of people are
> > raving about it, but I started to look at it and it seemed to be 100+ MB
> > download and there seemed to be some other stuff I wasn't ready to deal
> > with (maybe the lack of a spec file was one of them).  So is it really
> > good?  How is it for Perl and Python development?  Can you give us a 3
> > minute report on it?
> 
> Wil,
> 
>   I'm just beginning to use it for java development of a very large project.
> It came very highly recommended to me. It is large (rather slow on my
> PII/333 MHz system) but it gets things done. I was told by Nathan Meyers
> (some of you may remember him) that Eclipse was what took him away from vi
> (or was it emacs?) to a GUI tool for writing all his java code. As far as
> I'm concerned, there's no higher praise.
> 
>   If you want to go one step further, download the community (i.e., free)
> edition of Posidon-for-UML. It's a terrific UML tool and will output code in
> several languages. I know it does java and the java fits right in to
> Eclipse.
>

On Thu, 11 Sep 2003, Shahms King wrote:

> RedHat has made gcj-compiled (i.e. x86 native) Eclipse RPMS
> available for a while now.  I don't remember the URL but a quick
> google should turn up the page.

I hadn't know that -- though it wouldn't have made any difference.
It a) is not supported by Red Hat, b) requires a truck load of
nonstandard packages to make it work, and c) is Eclipse version 2.1,
whereas my folks wanted the relatively stable 3.0 milestone.

That said, it's a neat project. I hope that the gcc and Eclipse folks
find the Red Hat patches to their liking so that eclipse needn't rely
on a JVM.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Sep 11 10:12:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Thu Sep 11 10:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] inetd
In-Reply-To: <1063260104.4312.38.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309081451110.19533@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1063059107.24807.5.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309081528480.19618@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1063061368.4109.38.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1063260104.4312.38.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1063300706.1064.85.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2003-09-10 at 23:01, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> > You don't need them if you don't need to launch daemons on
> > demand. I almost never run them on workstations and I try
> > to avoid using them on servers. 
> > 
> > Ed
> 
> How is a daemon running all the time better than inetd or xinetd
> launching a daemon on demand?  Wouldn't it make sense to have inetd
> listen for services you offer when requests are very low and then
> switch to a daemon when requests go up?  Potentially I see 
> lightening up the number of daemons through inetd and xinetd 
> which could improve performance.  The other thing is, doesn't
> xinetd give a wrapper for controlling who can access a service
> and at what rate which is more standard and easier to understand 
> than each individual daemon that can be used instead?

1. I don't need inetd/xinetd access control mechanisms when I
   have better control at my firewall(s) and DNS server.

2. I don't run insecure daemons, like telnet, that typically
   are launched by inetd/xinetd. I use things like sshd, which are
   always running.

3. The daemons that I'd launch from inetd/xinetd are not that big.
   Memory is no longer a precious resource.

4. inetd does have some problems and I don't like the silly syntax
   of the xinetd configuration files - especially the disable=yes
   nonsense. If I wanted to launch daemons on demand I'd use
   Bernstein's tools.

Ed

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Sep 11 11:53:01 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Sep 11 11:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Information sources on .Xresources and .Xdefaults
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309111124330.29631@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309111124330.29631@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309111137340.27562@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 11 Sep 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> There are no man pages for ~/..Xdefaults and ~/.Xresources.

Ewww, look what you stepped in. :-) X resource files are incredibly
opaque. Try this:

  egrep -isr 'xdefaults|xresources' /etc/*

That'll at least tell you what files will (and won't, as is the case
of Xfce) be using the user's and/or system-wide resource files.

There are a number of man pages that mention the files in question:
X(7x), xrdb(1), xinit(1), and xdm(1).

If you're using xfce4, then your .Xdefaults file isn't being read at
all. You'll have to invoke it yourself once per session, e.g.,

  xrdb ~/.Xdefaults

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Sep 11 11:53:11 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu Sep 11 11:53:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Information sources on .Xresources and .Xdefaults
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309111124330.29631@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309111124330.29631@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3F60C479.9030805@pacifier.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   There are no man pages for ~/..Xdefaults and ~/.Xresources. I'd like to 1)
> learn the differences between the two (e.g., what each does that the other
> does not) and 2) learn the syntax so that two applications open to my
> preferred size rather than what they want. Specifically, LyX opens too small
> and xfig opens full-screen.

I believe .Xdefaults is depreciated in favor of .Xresources.  At least one 
can be a symlink to the other.

There is a tool (I can't remember the name) that will you use to click on 
parts of a running X app and it will spit out the property so you can stick 
it in your .Xresources.

I know with xfig you can specify the initail window size on startup:
from http://www.xfig.org/userman/options.html#com-sizes

-geometry [WxH]+x+y (-geom)
     Set the size and/or position of the xfig window. You may use this to 
set the size of the main xfig window, or you may instead set the size of the 
drawing canvas in inches or cm using the -pwidth and -pheight options.

--
Kyle Accardi

Kyle & Jeff, your re-install suggestion did the trick.  Being the 
"Chicken that I am", I put the boot loader on a floppy, though, for now. 
 I pretty much used a default install, except did manually get the Video 
card & monitor set correctly.  I put the boot loader on a floppy as I 
didn't know if it would cause a future problem (with it on the Win2k hhd 
or if Win2k would be accessible if it were on the Linux hhd.  Thank you 
both for your assistance.

Belarc's Advisor says my sound card is Creative's AWE64 16-bit Audio 
(SB16 compatible) with AWE64 Wavetable MIDI (AWE32 compatible).  I 
believe this is a PCI bus card, but the only options I saw when in the 
post install were ISA & something other than PCI (that dis ol' dog can't 
remember).  What need I do to configure this?

Respectfully, Dave

that LyX doesn't understand the right protocol.  But LyX does understand
the -geometry command line switch - you could use that as part of a
shortcut to fire up LyX, possibly?

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Thu Sep 11 19:32:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Sep 11 19:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using a hard disk with single bad sector.
In-Reply-To: <7514-86836@sneakemail.com>
References: <7514-86836@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1063333834.8148.14.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

So in ATA it takes fewer platters for higher capacity because of lower
rotational speeds allowing the use of thicker platters than in higher
performance drives.  Does the RPM contribute significantly to heat and
vibration sensitivity?  

If I want to raid 4 ATA disks together to take advantage of striping to
increase speed, can't I overcome heat and vibration problems by mounting
them significantly apart from each other in seperate racks or cages? 
I've seen IBM personal computers where the second hard drive mounts
about the power supply and the first mounts in a totally different
and distant location in the case.

If you build a raid over multiple machines the problem of being limited
to 2 to 4 drives becomes less significant, speed suffers though because
of low data transfer rates between machines.
One approach I could think of is to have multiple nics
between each box increasing inter machine throughput where
at $30 a card one time cost for a 100 mbps nic it seems fairly 
reasonably to increase the number of cards by 2. 
One gigabit card in each box in your raid cluster might 
be a better way to combat the bottleneck.

     --  Michael

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Thu Sep 11 20:29:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu Sep 11 20:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101318420.12377-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309101318420.12377-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <1063337260.8148.32.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Wed, 2003-09-10 at 13:25, Phil Tomson wrote:
> 
> Turns out the problem was because I was booting up an older kernel 
> (2.4.19mdk) instead of 2.4.21 (the one that came with Mandrake 9.1) 
> because the laterr kernel was causing the machine to hang when accessing 
> the CDROM.  Now that I've tried it with the 2.4.21 kernel I don't get the 
> Invalid argument message.  Must be that the wrong modules were being 
> loaded.
> 

Try going to http://www.kernel.org and use official kernel source
instead of Mandrake source.  One thing to try is to compile a kernel 
from kernel.org sources, then test it by setting it up as a
second boot option by putting it on a disk or adding it lilo/grub.
I don't use redhat source on my redhat systems except in some cases
the original kernel, it seems to me that things just work better
when you don't use vendor kernel sources.  If you look under /boot,
at least on Redhat, you'll find a file name config-x.y.z.  If this
is copied to /usr/src/linux/.config, assuming that's the redhat 
kernel source, the options Redhat selected will be preselected 
and you can go through them deselecting whatever isn't right.  

I for one would like to know how to install the modules to /boot 
under whatever name I want to.  This is especially nice if you 
install multiple Linux systems to the same drive where difficulties 
can arise determining which root partition goes with which kernel.  
One trick I have done that's useful is copying lilo.conf to /boot.
I don't know what Redhat's common files all are that are under /boot
such as modules-conf.  It seems that System.map is regenerated
at each boot.  The latter creates a problem if you put a read only
directive in fstab for the boot partition as a security measure.
What is System.map for anyways?

    --  Michael

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Sep 11 20:41:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu Sep 11 20:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Donald... & "Would like to get operating B4 Sep. 20"
In-Reply-To: <01C37890.1EC13C70.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
References: <01C37890.1EC13C70.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
Message-ID: <3F61404A.60503@pacifier.com>

da.haole.boy wrote:
> Belarc's Advisor says my sound card is Creative's AWE64 16-bit Audio 
> (SB16 compatible) with AWE64 Wavetable MIDI (AWE32 compatible).  I 
> believe this is a PCI bus card, but the only options I saw when in the 
> post install were ISA & something other than PCI (that dis ol' dog can't 
> remember).  What need I do to configure this?

I wish Red Hat would drag its sound config tool into this century.  It's not 
rocket science from a programmatic point-of-view and would make everyone so 
freaking happy.

Try this,
$ lspci

you might see something like this,
02:0a.0 Multimedia audio controller: Creative Labs SB Live! EMU10k1 (rev 0a)

so try, (as root)
	# modprobe emu10k1

if there are no complaints, that should have loaded the emu10k1 module plus 
the ones it relies on.  To confirm, list the loaded modules,
	$ lsmod

and look for a chain like this,
emu10k1                64320   2 (autoclean)
ac97_codec             13248   0 (autoclean) [emu10k1]
sound                  71532   0 (autoclean) [emu10k1]
soundcore               6468   7 (autoclean) [emu10k1 sound]

Now cd /usr/share/sounds and type ls, pick a .wav file that looks good and type
	$ play phone.wav

or whatever.

If all this worked, you're happy and all you need to do is add this line to 
your /etc/modules.conf
	alias sound-slot-0 emu10k1

If something along the way choked, let us know and we'll go from there.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

distributions?  What's the rationale for supporting daemons on 
demand other than saving memory?  Why does one need bernstein's
tools if there's no for need xinetd?  Does qmail need the daemons

connected to a number of packages?

the files that go with a package.  So short of doing an 
rpm -ql before uninstalling a package, one may not know 
what files are getting left behind.  I'm wondering if I
can and should remove xinetd.

> What's an easy way to find out if xinetd is what's launching some

reboot
then see if the daemon still starts.

On Thu, 2003-09-11 at 21:46, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> What's an easy way to find out if xinetd is what's launching some
> daemon?  

Look at the xinetd configuration files. If you want
to be certain that xinetd launched a currently running
daemon, I guess you could use ps and look at the parent
PID, though I've not done this yet.

> Doesn't a lot of stuff depend on it in a number of Linux
> distributions?  

No

> What's the rationale for supporting daemons on 
> demand other than saving memory?

Someone replied to this earlier - it's easier to develop
daemons that are launched by inetd/xinetd. Also, some
people might find the inetd/xinetd access controls easier
than learning how to configure their firewall or DNS.

> Why does one need bernstein's
> tools if there's no for need xinetd?

I generally don't need to launch daemons on demand so I
don't normally use inetd, xinetd, or Bernstein's tools.
However, if i do need to launch daemons in demand I
prefer the Bernstein stuff.


> Does qmail need the daemons on demand feature?

No

> On a Redhat system, 7.x on up, isn't xinetd
> connected to a number of packages?  

I don't know about Red Hat 9, but with earlier versions,
the only thing enabled is FAM. There are numerous configuration
files in /etc/xinetd.d but most of those files have the
"disable=yes" statement, so they're not active.

> One problem with rpm is that erase doesn't always destroys 
> the files that go with a package.  So short of doing an 
> rpm -ql before uninstalling a package, one may not know 
> what files are getting left behind.  I'm wondering if I
> can and should remove xinetd.

Dunno. I don't usually do rpm.

Ed

From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Fri Sep 12 12:50:02 2003
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (gilmanhunt at comcast.net)
Date: Fri Sep 12 12:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] network topology question
Message-ID: <E19xtvW-00028H-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Hi.
At work, where I handle the firewall for the company, we have two locations connected by 
a "leased line" dsl; it's all one big unhappy network. Recently, I've been asked to provide 
info on "if we get a DSL for the other location, how do the computers know which "line" to 
go out"? In other words; they'll need to split the network up and add routing etc.

I'm more perplexed about how this is negotiated with the DSL "modems" involved. 
Currently on each end of the "leased line" we have a modem connected right into the 
network. My firewall has another ethernet card we're not using currently- I imagine that I'll 
be using it to connect to the other network. Do I (basically) connect the firewall to the 
"modem" to the "leased line"?

And this message
http://archive.lug.boulder.co.us/bymonth/1999.12/msg00164.html
implies that I'll need:on the routers / firewalls: external IP address, gateway for network A, 
gateway for network B so basically each side of the DSL line will have one IP address 
from each network.  

Actually, I take it back; using one router here with no firewall over there (and the DSL line 
plugging directly into the network over there) wouldn't bother me much; it's the 
connection between the routers that's confusing me. :)

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Fri Sep 12 13:53:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Fri Sep 12 13:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] network topology question
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8FCB@orsmsx408>

> From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net [mailto:gilmanhunt at comcast.net]
> Sent: Friday, September 12, 2003 12:49 PM
> To: PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> At work, where I handle the firewall for the company, we have two
> locations connected by
> a "leased line" dsl; it's all one big unhappy network. Recently, I've
been
> asked to provide
> info on "if we get a DSL for the other location, how do the computers
know
> which "line" to
> go out"? In other words; they'll need to split the network up and add
> routing etc.

[Daniel Petcher] 
Determining which directions the packets should go is the function of
your router. There are several different protocols with varying levels
of sophistication and ease-of-configuration that your routers will use
in order to communicate with each other. The simplest protocol is called
RIP - Routing Information Protocol, but you may wish to take advantage
of more complex protocols like OSPF - Open Shortest Path First. If
you're not buying new routers, the capabilities of your existing routers
will make this decision for you.

It will be easier to break the network into segments in order for each
office to prefer its own local Internet connection. You will need some
sort of a router (or a multihomed computer acting as a router) at each
office, and if you've got two windows to the Internet, you'll need two
firewalls to keep naughty folk from tossing a brick through those
windows.

This looks like the simplest configuration:

Internet ---- DSL Modem --- Firewall A ---- Router A --- Office 'A' LAN
                                              |
                                              |
                                              |
                                          DSL Modem
                                              |
                                              |
                                       Private Leased
                                        DSL circuit
                                              |
                                              |
                                          DSL Modem
                                              |
                                              |
                                              |
Internet ---- DSL Modem --- Firewall B ---- Router B --- Office 'B' LAN

Each office's router knows that traffic for the other office should go
over the private link and traffic for the Internet should go through the
firewall.

After you've established the simple scenario, you can optionally add
complexity: What if office A's Internet access goes down? It would be
good for the link to failover and pass Office A's Internet traffic
through the private link and out office B's Internet connection. It
should also work in the opposite direction. The routers should be
programmed to handle this for you. Further desirable complexity would be
to set-up an encrypted connection between the firewalls through the
Internet to allow inter-office communication if the leased circuit
should ever fail.

An additional layer of complexity would be load balancing. If one of the
direct routes is congested, it might be faster to take the alternate
route. Routers can be programmed to handle this for you as well.

You can be your company's own network engineer, but you'll need to do
some reading to get the needed skills. Alternately, you can hire a
consultant. I would recommend contacting a network engineer rather than
trying to learn to BE a network engineer while you're under the pressure
of having to make it all work. A beginner's mistake could endanger your
reputation and perhaps your job.

-djp



From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Fri Sep 12 14:03:01 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Fri Sep 12 14:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] network topology question
Message-ID: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC0A8FCC@orsmsx408>

> > From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net [mailto:gilmanhunt at comcast.net]
> > Sent: Friday, September 12, 2003 12:49 PM
> > To: PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > At work, where I handle the firewall for the company, we have two
> > locations connected by
> > a "leased line" dsl; it's all one big unhappy network. Recently,
I've
> been
> > asked to provide
> > info on "if we get a DSL for the other location, how do the
computers
> know
> > which "line" to
> > go out"? In other words; they'll need to split the network up and
add
> > routing etc.
> 
> [Daniel Petcher]
> Determining which directions the packets should go is the function of
> your router. There are several different protocols with varying levels
> of sophistication and ease-of-configuration that your routers will use
> in order to communicate with each other. The simplest protocol is
called
> RIP - Routing Information Protocol, but you may wish to take advantage
> of more complex protocols like OSPF - Open Shortest Path First. If
> you're not buying new routers, the capabilities of your existing
routers
> will make this decision for you.
> 
> It will be easier to break the network into segments in order for each
> office to prefer its own local Internet connection. You will need some
> sort of a router (or a multihomed computer acting as a router) at each
> office, and if you've got two windows to the Internet, you'll need two
> firewalls to keep naughty folk from tossing a brick through those
> windows.
> 
> This looks like the simplest configuration:
> 
> Internet ---- DSL Modem --- Firewall A ---- Router A --- Office 'A'
LAN
>                                               |
>                                               |
>                                               |
>                                           DSL Modem
>                                               |
>                                               |
>                                        Private Leased
>                                         DSL circuit
>                                               |
>                                               |
>                                           DSL Modem
>                                               |
>                                               |
>                                               |
> Internet ---- DSL Modem --- Firewall B ---- Router B --- Office 'B'
LAN
> 
> Each office's router knows that traffic for the other office should go
> over the private link and traffic for the Internet should go through
the
> firewall.
> 
> After you've established the simple scenario, you can optionally add
> complexity: What if office A's Internet access goes down? It would be
> good for the link to failover and pass Office A's Internet traffic
> through the private link and out office B's Internet connection. It
> should also work in the opposite direction. The routers should be
> programmed to handle this for you. Further desirable complexity would
be
> to set-up an encrypted connection between the firewalls through the
> Internet to allow inter-office communication if the leased circuit
> should ever fail.
> 
> An additional layer of complexity would be load balancing. If one of
the
> direct routes is congested, it might be faster to take the alternate
> route. Routers can be programmed to handle this for you as well.
> 
> You can be your company's own network engineer, but you'll need to do
> some reading to get the needed skills. Alternately, you can hire a
> consultant. I would recommend contacting a network engineer rather
than
> trying to learn to BE a network engineer while you're under the
pressure
> of having to make it all work. A beginner's mistake could endanger
your
> reputation and perhaps your job.
> 
> -djp

Three things I neglected to mention above:
-Breaking your network into segments will almost always require changing
the IP addresses of network nodes in one or both offices.
-If your ultimate concern is $$$, the firewall and router functions can
be combined in a Linux computer with three network cards. It takes very
little computing power to route packets.
-If security is your biggest concern, it would be best to separate the
routing and firewalling functions into different boxen.




From drl at drloree.com  Fri Sep 12 15:06:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Sep 12 15:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] network topology question

connect a leased line to?  What routes are they worried about?

> network. My firewall has another ethernet card we're not using currently- I imagine that I'll 
> be using it to connect to the other network. Do I (basically) connect the firewall to the 
> "modem" to the "leased line"?


>

> implies that I'll need:on the routers / firewalls: external IP address, gateway for network A,

> from each network.  
>

> plugging directly into the network over there) wouldn't bother me much; it's the 
> connection between the routers that's confusing me. :)

Where is the other end of said DSL line?

I guess I don't understand what you network topology is and how you want
to change it.

Derek Loree

This Tuesday, September 16, at 6:30 pm is our first get together
for those interested in Tex, Latex, and related software. We'll
meet at Novell's office in Tigard across from Washington Square.
Directions are here:

http://panug.org/meetings/#direct

We'll decide then whether to meet at a more convenient place and time
in the future. We have a video projector available and I'll
bring a computer with TeX-related software and you're welcome to
as well. There's no set topics to be presented, presenters, or
even a format to be followed. We'll work that out when we meet.
There's certainly no shortage of things to be learned.

If anyone wants to setup a mailing list for the group's TeX-related
discussions, please do so.

Ed

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Sat Sep 13 11:54:02 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Sat Sep 13 11:54:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] scanned by filenet
Message-ID: <PLUOICJG51C7NMSMPJFBLYT4WTSC7SM.3f63679b@miked>

I was scanned on several filenet ports last night. UDP 32770, 32771, 32772, 32773, 32774.

Portsentry dutifully closed the connection and banned the offending system. I like portsentry.

The only problem is that the scanning machine was my ISP's name server, actually two of the name servers. 

Is there a vulnerability on this port? Is there a possibility that they've installed this software and let it 
try to index files on their subnet?

Any thoughts on the technical side welcomed. 

Mike

-----Original Message-----
From: aklug-bounce at aklug.org [mailto:aklug-bounce at aklug.org] On Behalf Of

Sent: Wednesday, September 10, 2003 3:08 PM
To: aklug at aklug.org
Subject: SCO and the US Federal Trade Commission


The message below came across the RedHat list that I read
and I just called the FTC myself and made a complaint.
It was very easy and I basically told the FTC that
this company SCO is committing major fraud by trying
to make people & companies pay for something SCO does NOT even own.
I got a case number in just a few minutes.

They simply dump the information into a database and the
FTC gentleman told me that if there are enough complaints
and there is a pattern, they will investigate the SCO Group.

So pass this around and start calling the FTC to stop the SCO Scumbags.
Read below.....

Andy

----- Forwarded message from Andy Firman <andy at firman.us> -----
Date: Tue, 9 Sep 2003 22:05:24 -0800
Subject: sco and ftc
User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.4i

[From a Slashdot posting....]

I just got off the phone with the FTC. If everyone calls and complains 
then the chances they will investigate SCO goes up. They look for 
patterns. In other words, if the majority of their calls are about SCO 
then they will investigate. It is time to take the Slashdot effect to the 
phones.

These are the key points to make:

-You did not purchase software from SCO
-The company that "produced" your software did not purchase it from SCO
-It was not marketed or packaged by SCO
-Despite this SCO is asking for $199 from home users (You) and $699 from 
business for 1 CPU

They will ask for your name, phone number, address etc. That is mostly to 
verify your identity and citizenship I think.

Here is the number:

1-877-382-4357 option 4

They are nice and listen well. The lady I talked to even took the time to 
get a better understanding of what Linux is. The best quote from her "You 
didn't purchase it from them and they want you to pay them? That sounds 
crazy."
--
Call FTC 1-877-382-4357 opt 4
-You didn't buy from SCO
-Vendor didn't either
-They want $199 ...

            Here's some information that may help. They actually asked for 
this info:

            The SCO Group
            355 South 520 West
            Suite 100
            Lindon, Utah 84042

            801-765-4999 phone

            The guy I spoke with was actually somewhat familiar with what 
Linux is. One of his first questions was how this company got involved 
with me, which my answer was "Well, that's the problem. They didn't."

            He eventually asked if SCO has contacted me personally with 
regard to this situation, which they have not. Don't lie to them. Be 
completely truthful. At the end of the call I got a reference number, and 
he said that if SCO does contact me personally, I should call back and let 
them know.

            It was very easy to do, and took about 5 minutes of my time. 
The recording while I wated for the counselor to pick up the phone did say 
that the FTC does track trends in complaints. If we get enough people to 
complain, something will happen. Please, take a few minutes and call!

From srau at rauhaus.org  Sat Sep 13 13:23:01 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Sat Sep 13 13:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] scanned by filenet
In-Reply-To: <PLUOICJG51C7NMSMPJFBLYT4WTSC7SM.3f63679b@miked>
References: <PLUOICJG51C7NMSMPJFBLYT4WTSC7SM.3f63679b@miked>
Message-ID: <20030913201632.GA6232@rauhaus.org>

* Mike De La Mater <mikedela at theplatinumrule.com> [030913 11:48]:
> I was scanned on several filenet ports last night. UDP 32770, 32771,
> 32772, 32773, 32774.
> 
> Portsentry dutifully closed the connection and banned the offending
> system. I like portsentry.
> 
> The only problem is that the scanning machine was my ISP's name
> server, actually two of the name servers. 

Since they are name servers, I would say there is a very high likelyhood
that those packets were replies to your own dns queries.

The destination udp port for a dns reply always equals the source udp
port of the original dns query.

--Stafford



From mikedela at ipns.com  Sat Sep 13 14:11:01 2003

From felix.1 at canids.net  Sat Sep 13 15:36:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Sat Sep 13 15:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] scanned by filenet
In-Reply-To: <1063487427.1073.20.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> on 13 Sep 2003 14:10:26 PDT.
Message-ID: <20030913223538.F046D159189@kanga.canids.net>

Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com>:
> So you're saying that my web server sent out DNS queries on these ports?

probably.

> Doesn't that sound pretty odd?

no.  it's like carrier pigeons.  if I send a carrier pigeon to a
server at (ip1, port1), I have to make a place at home, called
(ip0, port0), to receive a carrier pigeon with an answer.  and
since I share ip0 with thousands of other tenants (who often die
quickly), I have to find a port0 that isn't currently being used
by anyone else.  32768 is as good a place to start looking as any.

for linux, search for "ip_local_port_range".
--

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Sep 13 15:58:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Sep 13 15:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] scanned by filenet
In-Reply-To: <20030913201632.GA6232@rauhaus.org>
References: <PLUOICJG51C7NMSMPJFBLYT4WTSC7SM.3f63679b@miked>
	 <20030913201632.GA6232@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <1063493832.24538.20.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Sat, 2003-09-13 at 13:16, Stafford A. Rau wrote:
> * Mike De La Mater <mikedela at theplatinumrule.com> [030913 11:48]:
> > I was scanned on several filenet ports last night. UDP 32770, 32771,
> > 32772, 32773, 32774.
> > 
> > Portsentry dutifully closed the connection and banned the offending
> > system. I like portsentry.
> > 
> > The only problem is that the scanning machine was my ISP's name
> > server, actually two of the name servers. 
> 
> Since they are name servers, I would say there is a very high likelyhood
> that those packets were replies to your own dns queries.
> 
> The destination udp port for a dns reply always equals the source udp
> port of the original dns query.

I don't think this is usual BIND behaviour.  BIND listens on a set port
to send recursive queries and stays there throughout its lifetime; it
doesn't randomly bind for out-bound queries like usual clients.  It
seems likely this was a genuine scan to me.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

> > > 
> > > Portsentry dutifully closed the connection and banned the offending
> > > system. I like portsentry.
> > > 
> > > The only problem is that the scanning machine was my ISP's name
> > > server, actually two of the name servers. 
> > 
> > Since they are name servers, I would say there is a very high likelyhood
> > that those packets were replies to your own dns queries.
> > 
> > The destination udp port for a dns reply always equals the source udp
> > port of the original dns query.
> 
> I don't think this is usual BIND behaviour.  BIND listens on a set port
> to send recursive queries and stays there throughout its lifetime; it
> doesn't randomly bind for out-bound queries like usual clients.  It
> seems likely this was a genuine scan to me.
> 
> Wil

I'm not sure, but I think Wil is referring to a situation
different than what was being discussed. The original
discussion has about the ISP's DNS server responding to
queries from a DNS client. In that case, the destination
port in packets sent by the DNS server to the client will
be the same as the source port in packets sent by the
client to the DNS server.

I think Wil is commenting on BIND behavior when it is
behaving as a client and sending queries to another DNS
server. In that case, Will is correct for the versions of
BIND is done packet snooping on. However, this situation
is almost certain not to be the case unless the client
site is also running an authoritative DNS server.

Of course, I may not have interpreted the messages correctly.

Ed

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Sat Sep 13 18:28:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Sat Sep 13 18:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <1063411291.876.74.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309131816480.10255-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>

Sometime in the middle of last week I was at Beaverton Library and noticed 
that all of their PC's were down and there was no internet access.  Today 
I was there again, and the PC's were still down.  Now there were signs on 
them explaining that they had been hit by a virus and were tyring to 
recover - so far they've been trying to recover for something like at 
least 4 days.  So, not only can't you browse the web there, you can't look 
anything up in their online catalog either.  I guess people are back to 
using the card catalog (do they even still have those there, I kind of 
doubt it).

This got me to thinking: This is a perfect 'poster project' for open 
source.  Basically, all they've got to do is web browsing and lookup in 
their card catalog - I doubt those machines were even running office, but 
even if they were OpenOffice could be used.  So the question is, how do we 
get a group of Open Source folks together to propose the Linux (or *BSD) 
solution?  One of our big selling points right now for these library folks 
is that they'll be much less vulnerable to viruses... the price is right 
too, but right now that's probably a secondary issue for them.

Anyway, seems like an interesting opportunity for OSS if it can be pitched 
correctly and to the right people.  Seems like I've heard about an open 
source library project out there somewhere...

Phil

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Sun Sep 14 12:26:01 2003
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Sun Sep 14 12:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.1 working well for me
In-Reply-To: <20030910165039.73899.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030914192505.16625.qmail@web14410.mail.yahoo.com>

As a proxy server, running on everything from newer dual cpu Dell
servers to recycled PII workstations, Mandrake 9.1 has been quite
stable in my experience. I've had a few problems with 9.0, mostly
when used as a workstation and related to browser stability. 9.1 is
better, especially if you are fond of KDE. It has been quite stable
for home and 3D gaming use. I especially like the KDB CDR app, very
NERO like, and the apt-get fire and forget functionality of urpmi,
not to mention the easy package updater that doesn't require you to
register and maintain your service account like Redhat does. 9.2
should be out this month, so that's what I'm waiting for before I
upgrade my business workstation from 9.0. So far, it has met my
requirements quite well.

YMMV, Sean Harbour

Mike De La Mater <mikedela at theplatinumrule.com> wrote:

> Portsentry dutifully closed the connection and banned the offending system. I like portsentry.
> 
> The only problem is that the scanning machine was my ISP's name server, actually two of the name servers. 

This is exactly why I don't use a portsentry like program any longer. 

It's very easy for someone to inflict a DOS attach on you, using your own machine. They simply spoof packets coming from various places, your port sentry denies you access to those sites, and viola...

At least, that's the scenario from the last time I run portsentry. Do they have anything to protect you from this in there now?

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep 14 18:25:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep 14 18:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Can user defined chains be added...
Message-ID: <1063588992.4758.10.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

to the FORWARD chain?

I know this can be done with the INPUT and OUTPUT chains in iptables.

The following is an example of what I am trying to do with a
user defined chain I want to add to the FORWARD chain.
There is local DNS where goose is the hostname of one ip
address I want to work with.  The eth0 interface goes to
a lan.

#!/bin/bash

goose_ip=host goose|cut -d ' ' -f4

IN_INT_1="eth0"             # Internal network interface 1.


case "$1" in

open)

        iptables -F masq_goose

        iptables -A masq_goose -m state --state NEW,ESTABLISHED \
                               --in-interface $IN_INT_1 -s $goose_ip \
                               -j ACCEPT
                ;;

close|*)

        iptables -F masq_goose

                ;;
esac



The original piece where I use goose_ip is 192.168.1.0/24.  This is
part of a project to implement a selective Internet lock for
individual workstations.  If I can't add user defined chains to
the FORWARD chain, how can I find the rule that allows goose
out and remove just that rule?  If I'm not mistaken for say 
rules 1 through 5, deleting rule number 1 causes rule 2 to 
become rule 1.  The purpose of open is to add the forwarding
rule for goose if it isn't already added where close is supposed 
to remove the rule for goose.  Can you just write out the rule
you want deleted from the forward chain instead of using a number?

     --  Michael



From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep 14 19:38:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep 14 19:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Can user defined chains be added...
In-Reply-To: <1063588992.4758.10.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1063588992.4758.10.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1063593412.5286.3.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I've got a different approach than adding a chain to the FORWARD
chain which doesn't seem to work using the following script:

#!/bin/bash 
# Close or open Internet gateway for a specific host.
# First argument is open or close whereas second is the
# hostname of the host that needs to be open or closed.

close_number=`/sbin/iptables --line-numbers -L FORWARD | grep $2  | cut
-f1 -d ' '`
# Get the number of the rule that shouldn't exist or should be removed.

IN_INT=eth0
# This is the interface connected to the proper lan.

ip=`host $2 | cut -d ' ' -f4`
# Get the ip address of the host seeing a change in
# Internet connectivity status.

user=`whoami`

if [ $user == root ];then

case "$1" in

open)
        if [ ! $close_number ];then
		iptables -A FORWARD -m state --state NEW,ESTABLISHED \
         	         	    --in-interface $IN_INT -s $ip \
                       	            -j ACCEPT
        fi
		;;

close)

        if [ $close_number ];then
        	iptables -D FORWARD $close_number
 	fi
		;;
*)
	exit 1
esac

fi

The weakest is the part where I need to determine the rule number
since it assumes there will be one FORWARD rule by the hostname
that one desires to manipulate if there are any.  It would make
sense to test the arguments coming in too :-)  Course if I only
use this with a program that inputs the right arguments to it
there won't be any problems.

     --  Michael

From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Sun Sep 14 21:57:02 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Sun Sep 14 21:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <1063558527.25173.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309131816480.10255-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0309131853150.16430@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<1063558527.25173.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <16229.18258.587155.117997@vzavenue.net>

Michael C. Robinson writes:

 > >   Regardless of Web browsing, how is the card catalog run? It used to be
 > > 'dyna' and I could telnet to it from home. That suggests it's running on a
 > > non-Microsoft host somewhere central. If so, linux and the Web browser of
 > > your choice(s) would work just fine. OTOH, if it's a custom app running
 > > locally then it may work only with Microsoft.

What do you mean "locally"?  Doesn't all of Washington County use the
same system?  Probably centralized then, and out of one library's
hand.

 > For their card catalog is there any reason for them to not use a
 > proprietary protocol so as to be hardened against crackers?  The
 > other option is VPN, there's a place the OSS can community can
 > help.  Is it necessary really to replace Windows entirely or
 > can Linux be introducted at the just the network routing/network
 > firewall layers to raise the likelihood of it's acceptance?

I think a gradual approach would go over better with them.  For
instance, you could start just with all the browsers (that alone would
save thousands in license fees, assuming they keep upgrading, and
would get the most bang for the buck in putting Linux in the public
eye).

Probably what they would like would be for some volunteers to show up
and say, here's our general idea, now we'd like to talk to your IT
folks and study it for a few weeks, then we'll present our results.
Probably the head of the committee should be someone from Beaverton,
as that would look more like "community volunteer wants to help his
local library" rather than "activist with an ax to grind."  Though if
it works in Beaverton, no reason why it couldn't easily be ported to
the other Washington County libraries.

I first thought of contacting them and suggesting Linux when I read a
few months ago that they were cutting their hours to cut costs.  I was
then going to suggest this to PLUG, but decided to READ the PLUG mail
first.

Kevin



From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sun Sep 14 23:41:01 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sun Sep 14 23:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: mailq problem
In-Reply-To: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFEENKCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
References: <FCEBIHDEIPOEEPHFOCFFEENKCFAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.53.0309150008300.11413@antares.mpcu.com>

On Mon, 15 Sep 2003, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> 
> we're using postfix, how do i read the mails that is stuck in the mailq..
> 


One way, use any of the mail id's found in the first column of mailq 
output and search for it like this.


find /var/spool/postfix/ | grep 0E9AAAD0F


On my system, I found a file in /var/spool/postfix/deferred/0/E/0E9AAAD0F 
with an entry of: (using ls -l)

-rwx------ 1 postfix  postfix 5467 Sep 15  2003 /var/spool/postfix/deferred/0/E/0E9AAAD0F


Use a text pager like more or less and view the contents.

less /var/spool/postfix/deferred/0/E/0E9AAAD0F


be carefull of non-readable ASCII characters due to mime encodings.

and contains the second line of a mailq listing.  For this example:

0E9AAAD0F      5347 Fri Sep 12 12:11:09  MAILER-DAEMON
    (connect to mx1.fantasticbradleys.net[65.110.33.33]: Connection timed

From scott_list at mischko.com  Mon Sep 15 10:12:02 2003
From: scott_list at mischko.com (Scott Chapman)
Date: Mon Sep 15 10:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to tell how much tape I have left after a backup?
Message-ID: <200309151011.54514.scott_list@mischko.com>

I am backing up a Linux box to a DDS2 drive.  The backup shows that 4.7GB were 
backed up but it doesn't tell me how much of the tape is used to do this.

I'm simply tarring stuff off to tape here.  The tape is obviously compressing 
the data because 4.7GB is more than a DDS2 can hold uncompressed.  How do I 
tell how much of the tape is used (or what my compression ratio is)?

Scott



From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Sep 15 10:12:12 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon Sep 15 10:12:12 2003
Subject: [PLUG] scanned by filenet
In-Reply-To: <1063487427.1073.20.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1063487427.1073.20.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <20030915170508.GA23070@rauhaus.org>

* Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> [030913 14:05]:
> >Since they are name servers, I would say there is a very high
> >likelyhood
> >that those packets were replies to your own dns queries.
> >
> >The destination udp port for a dns reply always equals the source udp
> >port of the original dns query.
> >
> >--Stafford
> 
> So you're saying that my web server sent out DNS queries on these ports?
> Doesn't that sound pretty odd? I've removed the DNS servers from my
> blacklists, we'll see if it happens again.

Not exactly - do you know what was the source port of the packets you
saw from your ISP's nameservers?

Here's an example of what may have happened:

10:04:09.097639 192.168.151.10.1059 > 192.168.98.125.53:  32563+ A?
www.rauhaus.org. (33) (DF)
10:04:09.100304 192.168.98.125.53 > 192.168.151.10.1059:  32563 2/2/1
CNAME kort.rauhaus.org., (128) (DF)

192.168.151.10 is the client, and 192.168.98.125 is the name server. The
client sends a udp packet, source port 1059 and destination port 53 to
the name server for the dns request.

The server responds with an answer from source port 53 and
_destination_ port 1059, which was the source port from which the query
came.

It may be that portsentry doesn't know to watch your outgoing dns
queries so as not to classify the replies as being hostile.

Does that make sense? So if the packets you saw coming from your ISP
nameservers were source port 53, then they may have been innocuous.

One caveat would be that there are port scanners that purposely set
the source port of their packets to 53 to make them look like dns
replies and so get past intrusion detection systems and some firewalls.

--Stafford



From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Sep 15 10:26:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Sep 15 10:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to tell how much tape I have left after a backup?
In-Reply-To: <200309151011.54514.scott_list@mischko.com>
References: <200309151011.54514.scott_list@mischko.com>
Message-ID: <10658-00139@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 15 Sep 2003, Scott Chapman scott_list-at-mischko.com |PDX Linux|
wrote:

> I am backing up a Linux box to a DDS2 drive.  The backup shows that
> 4.7GB were backed up but it doesn't tell me how much of the tape is used
> to do this.
>
> I'm simply tarring stuff off to tape here.  The tape is obviously
> compressing the data because 4.7GB is more than a DDS2 can hold
> uncompressed.  How do I tell how much of the tape is used (or what my
> compression ratio is)?

Check out this page:

http://home.t-online.de/home/Andreas.Steinmetz/unix/ddsutil.html

Basically it says to use uncompressed DDS and to use host-side
compression.  Not only will you get better compression, but you'll be able
to tell how much you have used on each tape.

To answer your question, you can tell how much tape you have left by
writing more and more to the tape until you get a write error back.  Then
you have no space left.  Isn't hardware compression great?  :-(

  -- Steve



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Sep 15 14:09:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Sep 15 14:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to tell how much tape I have left after a backup?
In-Reply-To: <10658-00139@sneakemail.com>
References: <200309151011.54514.scott_list@mischko.com>
	<10658-00139@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <863cexg3os.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Steve" == Steve Bonds <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> writes:

>> I'm simply tarring stuff off to tape here.  The tape is obviously
>> compressing the data because 4.7GB is more than a DDS2 can hold
>> uncompressed.  How do I tell how much of the tape is used (or what
>> my compression ratio is)?

Steve> Check out this page:

Steve> http://home.t-online.de/home/Andreas.Steinmetz/unix/ddsutil.html

Steve> Basically it says to use uncompressed DDS and to use host-side
Steve> compression.  Not only will you get better compression, but
Steve> you'll be able to tell how much you have used on each tape.

Steve> To answer your question, you can tell how much tape you have
Steve> left by writing more and more to the tape until you get a write
Steve> error back.  Then you have no space left.  Isn't hardware
Steve> compression great?  :-(

I did some reading about the compression algorithm that these drives
use.  I dug up descriptions, but never having coded one of these
before and because the verbal descriptions were (to me anyway)
somewhat ambiguous, I never understood it sufficiently to implement.
The compression format is called DCLZ (google is your friend).
However, if one could implement a compressor/decompressor, they (and
all beneficiaries of this work) could determine tape usage _and_ use
hardware compression.

From miken at hotsushi.com  Mon Sep 15 16:46:01 2003
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Mon Sep 15 16:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux classes at PCC start next week
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030915164700.023c9030@www.hotsushi.com>

Hi,

Fall term starts next Monday and there are two Linux classes at PCC.

CIS240L is a Linux Installation and Configuration class covering the main 
tasks involved in setting up and administering a stand alone Linux 
box.  You should have a basic understanding of a *nix file system and basic 
command line utilities.  Two sections are offered, one on the Internet and 
one that meets at Sylvania from 6:00 PM to 9:00 PM on Monday nights.

CIS279L is a Linux Networking class covering TCP/IP plus network utilities, 
applications (NFS, Samba, DNS, DHCP, Apache, Sendmail, Postfix, etc.), 
troubleshooting and an introduction to security. One section is offered 
from 2 PM to 4 PM, Tuesday and Thursday.

Both classes are command line oriented and have lots of hands on labs.

Both classes

Go to www.pcc.edu and register online or just come to class and we'll 
figure it out from there.

Please e-mail me off list for more details or questions.

Thanks,
Mike Neal 




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Sep 15 17:58:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Sep 15 17:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to tell how much tape I have left after a backup?
In-Reply-To: <863cexg3os.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <200309151011.54514.scott_list@mischko.com> <10658-00139@sneakemail.com>
 <863cexg3os.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <16143-40892@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 15 Sep 2003, Russell Senior seniorr-at-aracnet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I did some reading about the compression algorithm that these drives
> use.  I dug up descriptions, but never having coded one of these before
> and because the verbal descriptions were (to me anyway) somewhat
> ambiguous, I never understood it sufficiently to implement. The
> compression format is called DCLZ (google is your friend). However, if
> one could implement a compressor/decompressor, they (and all
> beneficiaries of this work) could determine tape usage _and_ use
> hardware compression.

It seems like knowing the algorithm wouldn't help if the drive itself
didn't report the compression ratio or tape used.  To make use of it you
would need to:

  + compress the data to get the ratio
  + uncompress the data
  + send it to the drive
  + drive compresses it exactly the same way
  + during restore, drive uncompresses the data on the fly

I suppose if the drive supported it you could also:
  + compress the data to get the ratio
  + send it to the drive compressed
  + drive fails to compress it any more and just stores it
  + during restore, hopefully drive sees the DCLZ format data on the tape
and uncompresses it on the fly during or else you'll need a DCLZ
decompression utility for restores

The first method probably uses more CPU time than just running it through
a better compression algorithm.  The second method may not work if the
drive stores the DCLZ data flagged as "uncompressed" so it doesn't try to
decompress it on the way out.

In either case if I really needed to know how much of the tape is used,
I'd skip the DDS compression.  Normally I don't-- when the tape fills, I
just put in a new one.  ;-)  (Or as is more often the case, I put in a new
CD-R...)

  -- Steve



From ron at nutriware.com  Mon Sep 15 18:17:01 2003

-------- Original Message --------

September 15, 2003

Open Magazine - Your strategic guide to Open Source
http://www.open-mag.com/cgi-bin/opencgi/email/redirect.cgi?Open915

Big news from Geneva this week as the UN wraps up plans for the first 
World Summit on the Information Society. High on the list of priorities 
for WSIS is an action plan requiring governments to back Open Source 
Software so that more countries can cross the digital divide. Spurred on 
by the U.S. Commerce Dept., the U.S. delegation is attempting to water 
down the UN Action Plan while Microsoft's pet lobbying group muses about 
a cataclysmic counterstrike using the WTO. Learn more as we trace the 
latest global drumbeats for Open Source and the proprietary diplomats 
who can press the WTO button if polite diplomacy fails.

In San Francisco this week, the International Bar Association meets to 
discuss how to capitalize on hot case issues. Not surprisingly, both 
intellectual property and digital rights are on that list in this 
post-Napster world.

For this week's tensions, just click on:
  http://www.open-mag.com/cgi-bin/opencgi/email/redirect.cgi?Open915
And remember to send a copy to your friends mired in proprietary systems.

Regards,

The editors of Open magazine

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Mon Sep 15 20:46:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Mon Sep 15 20:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: The UN is set to back Open Souce, can MS nix the
	deal?]
In-Reply-To: <3F66644C.1060505@nutriware.com>
References: <3F66644C.1060505@nutriware.com>
Message-ID: <1063683864.11625.20.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Fascinating site by the way.  I like open-mag a lot.  How can 
third world countries promotion of open source software be any 
kind of world trade violation?  Microsoft should get off it's 
high horse and work on improving interoperability and the 
clearing away of bugs instead of attacking the freedom of 
individuals and even whole countries to take full advantage 
of open source options.  So much effort on locking people 
into Windows seems like a terrible waste to me.  If Microsoft 
would restructure to be OSS friendly, I'm sure the company 
can survive after a change of heart.

The greater concern I have with increasing Internet access is 
the need to address the problems on this network better for 
people who will be facing them in ever increasing numbers for 
the first time in the near future.  Unlike traditional media 
and traditional advertisement, the Internet creates a totally 
new dynamic between people.  All the more reason OSS is 
more appropriate than ever for the needs of the world at
large is it's security record and flexibility.

     --  Michael



From carla at bratgrrl.com  Mon Sep 15 20:53:01 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon Sep 15 20:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Verisign hijacks DNS
Message-ID: <200309152056.07706.carla@bratgrrl.com>

Doubtless you've heard of this by now. (see Slashdot)

Here are my fave quotes from news.admin.net-abuse.email:

"The incompetent amoral liars at Verisign have made it impossible to 
reject mail from .net and .com addresses whose domain parts do not 
exist, by setting up wildcard DNS on the gtld-server.net machines"

"Verisign has destroyed the root domain hierarchy! Make up any bloody domain 
name, and what do you get? The domain exists, the response mail adddress is 
nstld.verisign-grs.com, the authoritative nameserver is a.gtld-servers.net

And it advertises their services. Holy crap."

"Yes, that's right.  It doesn't matter what a client says, Verithief's
"stub" mail server says 220, 250, 250, 550, 250, 221-close.

This is presumably the SMTP equivalent of flipping one's finger over
one's lip and going "buh buh buh".

Thank goodness we have the spineless, useless ICANN overseeing these 
matters....I feel so much better now...
-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

On Mon, 2003-09-15 at 20:44, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> Fascinating site by the way.  I like open-mag a lot.  How can 
> third world countries promotion of open source software be any 
> kind of world trade violation?  Microsoft should get off it's 
> high horse and work on improving interoperability and the 
> clearing away of bugs instead of attacking the freedom of 
> individuals and even whole countries to take full advantage 
> of open source options.  So much effort on locking people 
> into Windows seems like a terrible waste to me.  If Microsoft 
> would restructure to be OSS friendly, I'm sure the company 
> can survive after a change of heart.

I'm sorry to say it like this, but is this a joke or are you really this
naive?

Microsoft makes a killing on proprietary software, Red Hat makes a bare
survival off Open Source (it's doing better recently, but nowhere near
Microsoft).

And there's a logical fallacy in your argument, indeed in almost
everything you write: there is a difference between what should be and
what is. You do not make the law, and the law does not usually derive
from what "should" be. Anytime you find yourself tempted to write what
"should" be, you might want to think about what _is_ instead. If you
want to make what "should" be happen, you need to understand why things
are the way they are.

I sincerely apologize to you and anyone else who considers this harsh. I
write this because you've written a lot of naive interpretations of what
should be, ignoring what is, and why it is this way. 

and yes, this is way off topic now.

Jeff

From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Mon Sep 15 21:47:02 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Mon Sep 15 21:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309141212170.30481@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309131816480.10255-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>

Message-ID: <16230.39050.464479.185744@vzavenue.net>

Rich Shepard writes:

 >   I accessed the Multnomah County library with a Web browser just a couple
 > of weeks ago. For whatever reason, telneting to dyna from a virtual terminal
 > didn't want to work. The browser did.

I don't know about dyna in particular.  Obviously it's a dumb
terminal-oriented system, right?  Did you use a VT100 emulator?
That's what most of them expect.

BTW, I sent an e-mail to the library (librarymail at ci.beaverton.or.us)
suggesting they consider switching to Linux (appended below).  It was
a general address (off their website -- they don't know about munging
addresses) so they told me they were forwarding it to their tech
planning group.  If anyone else is inclined to write, don't mention
this letter or they'll write it off as a campaign.

Kevin

------------------------------------------------------------------

I'm a resident of Hillsboro who regularly uses the Washington County
libraries (Shute Park, Tanasbourne, and Beaverton).  While visiting
the Beaverton library yesterday, I saw notices about the computers
being down due to the worm attacks.  I would like to suggest a way to
improve the security of the library's computers, as well as cut costs.
That is to migrate its computers from Microsoft Windows to Linux.

As your IT department probably knows, the recent worm attacks
exploited a vulnerability in the core Microsoft Windows operating
system.  But this is not an isolated incident.  View any of the
websites devoted to computer security, and you'll see the vast
majority of the security advisories pertain to vulnerabilities in
Windows systems.  There are many reasons why Microsoft has such a poor
security record, too many to go into here.  But suffice it to say that
people running Linux and Unix machines with a modest amount of
security knowledge have not had any problems.

Another reason to switch as many machines as possible to Linux would
be enormous cost savings.  The Beaverton library has dozens of
computers just for public use, not to mention the ones used by the
staff.  Most of these machines are just used for browsing and perusing
the library catalog.  These functions can be performed just as well by
systems based on free software (Linux or FreeBSD, for instance),
saving thousands of dollars in licensing costs in a single library
alone.  Furthermore, switching to Linux can lead to hardware savings
as well, as it is much easier to strip a Linux machine down to only
its essential applications.  This means that Linux clients can
typically run fine on older hardware which would not be fast enough to
run a current version of Windows.

An additional savings of Linux would be eliminating the administrative
costs of license bookkeeping.  As Oregon's schools found out last
year, Microsoft likes to spring surprise audits on large
organizations, knowing that given enough machines, they can usually
find a few in which the paper licenses have been lost, in which case
they can use the threat of a lawsuit to coerce a new licensing deal
which is favorable to them.  Are YOUR licenses all in order?

I know several people in the Washington County area who would be
interested in studying what could be done to lower the library's costs
while improving its security.  Please reply to this e-mail if you
think you would be interested.

Sincerely,

Kevin Theobald
Hillsboro
