On Mon, 2003-09-15 at 21:13, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> On Mon, 2003-09-15 at 20:44, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> > Fascinating site by the way.  I like open-mag a lot.  How can 
> > third world countries promotion of open source software be any 
> > kind of world trade violation?  Microsoft should get off it's 
> > high horse and work on improving interoperability and the 
> > clearing away of bugs instead of attacking the freedom of 
> > individuals and even whole countries to take full advantage 
> > of open source options.  So much effort on locking people 
> > into Windows seems like a terrible waste to me.  If Microsoft 
> > would restructure to be OSS friendly, I'm sure the company 
> > can survive after a change of heart.
> 
> I'm sorry to say it like this, but is this a joke or are you really this
> naive?
> 
> Microsoft makes a killing on proprietary software, Red Hat makes a bare
> survival off Open Source (it's doing better recently, but nowhere near
> Microsoft).

Microsoft can hang itself on it's own proprietary software 
where OSS is gaining clout and people are starting to realize, 
as they always should, that there are multiple software options.
Windows is getting worse programming wise where pushing other 
vendors out of Windows, Microsoft is slowly but surely hurting 
itself.  Ironically, it's the closed endedness of Windows that 
will make it a platform supporting fewer and fewer apps.  NT
hasn't taken over from Linux/UNIX and I'll bet Gate's $6 billion
dollars that it won't take over by any future date.  Sloppy
coding can only work for so long.
 
If anything, open source systems do not automatically translate 
to zero money made on programs and services.  Microsoft would 
have a lot easier time helping with the task of fixing bugs 
in Linux than it does trying to write a closed system that's 
anywhere near comparable.  The company is fool hardly being 
seen as a monopolist for not behaving appropriately enough
to even begin to mitigate that conception.  For one thing,
it shows a total lack of gratitude for the country that 
allowed so much monetary success amid years of 
anticompetitive activities.

I like what the free software foundation says about it not being
important to make the most money to have real clout.  Why do we 
blindly accept money clout instead of evaluating on more than one 
criteria?  I don't see anything fundamentally wrong with talking 
about how things should be and why, this in and of itself is not 
a logical fallacy though I may annoy people who only want change 
now, etc.
  
Linus's project was to create a kernel, he didn't tell 
anyone at any time not to say, "hey, I have this 
proprietary program/library or pay for service offer to help 
you use that kernel more affectively."  There is nothing 
stopping Microsoft, accept perhaps incompetence, from 
using Linux as it's base operating system and writing software,
libraries, etc. to run on top of it.  The other thing is, why 
won't we move on instead of accepting Microsoft's claim that 
it has some right to charge whatever for anything that can 
be construed to be software?

----------------------------------------------------------------------
And there's a logical fallacy in your argument, indeed in almost
everything you write: there is a difference between what should be and
what is. You do not make the law, and the law does not usually derive
from what "should" be. Anytime you find yourself tempted to write what
"should" be, you might want to think about what _is_ instead. If you
want to make what "should" be happen, you need to understand why things
are the way they are.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

I wasn't aware I am writer of any laws at all.  In fact, I'm not.  I'm
not trained or even qualified to cause change.  I only see laws change
when I have a chance to vote and my vote wins.  It's early for Linux
based companies.  There's a misconception out there that no services are
needed for Linux systems or that offering such services won't pay.  This
is wrong though I'll admit I'm not lobbying for all the Linux people to
become millionaires like historic Microsoft employees.  There are people
who can obtain high levels of skill in working with information and
programming systems who will be paid something to support Linux because
there is a need out there.

The accusations quoted are not very good as they are not detailed
enough where the purpose of these accusations is also alien to me.

If hoping Microsoft will have a change of heart with regard to
attacking the GPL and advocating enslavement of all people to
a excessively confining software model naive, call me naive then.

Obviously the issue is with me and not with Linux, so why did
you post to the list Jeff creating spam for everyone?

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Tue Sep 16 00:08:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Tue Sep 16 00:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Goodbye...
Message-ID: <1063696008.12197.154.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I appreciate all the help I've gotten from various people but it's not
doing much good to be on here anymore because of a few people, who know
who they are, that seem to think it's necessary to pick on other
posters for kicks.

As far as the complaint I don't recognize how things are instead of
talking about what they should be or perhaps could be, that's rude.  
A friend of mine got off the list claiming that one of the OT topics 
got really raunchy.  I've had it.  I'm not intentionally trying to
insult anyone, yet I'm still catching flak far too often.

Some inclusive community this is shaping up as.  I think a couple
of individuals need to be kicked off the list to restore decency.  
I'm sure these individuals contributed to Ken Barber's decision 
to get off the list.


     --  Michael C. Robinson

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Sep 16 09:35:03 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue Sep 16 09:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SSH exploit in the wild
Message-ID: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>

Troubling news this morning:

http://slashdot.org/articles/03/09/16/1327248.shtml?tid=126&tid=172

Apparently there's an SSH exploit out there.  Most of the links
are already slashdott'ed, but here's another one that hasn't been
yet:

http://docs.freebsd.org/cgi/getmsg.cgi?fetch=2498+0+current/freebsd-security

Basically they recommend 3 alternatives until the exploit is found
and patched:

1) Switch to lsh
2) Add explicit rules to all your edge devices allowing ssh from
   only-known hosts.
3) Put ssh behind a VPN on RFC-1918 space.


Would anyone like to explain to me (us) what alternative #2 is and how
to implement it?

Colin



From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Sep 16 09:44:01 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Sep 16 09:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SSH exploit in the wild
In-Reply-To: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>
References: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309160940211.32754@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 16 Sep 2003, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> Basically they recommend 3 alternatives until the exploit is found
> and patched:
>
> 1) Switch to lsh

This code base isn't mature. It's not an option.

> 2) Add explicit rules to all your edge devices allowing ssh from
>    only-known hosts.

You can use tcpwrappers (/etc/hosts.{allow,deny}), if you've compiled
sshd against libwrap. Or, you can use the AllowUsers directive in
sshd_config to allow only certain users from certain hosts.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Tue Sep 16 11:04:01 2003
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (gilmanhunt at comcast.net)
Date: Tue Sep 16 11:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Previous request for network topology help.
Message-ID: <E19zKAv-0007pc-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I was over thinking the problem.

I found the resolution, basically, in this document:
http://www.linuxguruz.com/iptables/howto/2.4routing-5.html
specifically section 5.3 on GRE tunnels.

To restate; I was having a conceptual problem figuring out how to set up two linux routers 
at two seperate locations. Each one has it's own connection to the internet, and they are 
connected via a leased-dsl line, and the networks behind each router need to "see" each 
other (specifically, the warehouse needs to see the servers here).

Currently, the warehouse shares our internet connection over the leased DSL line, and 
at "some point in the next three months" I will be asked how to configure the two boxes. 
And thanks to this document I think I can do it (I have a fairly good grasp of TCPIP and 
routing, I just had a hard time imagining what I was setting up where- the hardware was 
hard for me to figure out, if that makes sense.).

Thanks to all of you for your brain-cycles. :)

Russ

From boro at borosenclave.com  Tue Sep 16 11:12:02 2003
From: boro at borosenclave.com (borodimer)
Date: Tue Sep 16 11:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SSH exploit in the wild
In-Reply-To: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <NFBBJJGLMCCHDEEELDPGMEKFDHAA.boro@borosenclave.com>

Here is RH's security update notification:

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

- ---------------------------------------------------------------------
                   Red Hat Security Advisory

Synopsis:          Updated OpenSSH packages fix potential vulnerability
Advisory ID:       RHSA-2003:279-01
Issue date:        2003-09-16
Updated on:        2003-09-16
Product:           Red Hat Linux
Keywords:
Cross references:
Obsoletes:         RHSA-2003:222
CVE Names:         CAN-2003-0693
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Topic:

Updated OpenSSH packages are now available that fix a bug that may be
remotely exploitable.

2. Relevant releases/architectures:

Red Hat Linux 7.1 - i386
Red Hat Linux 7.2 - i386, ia64
Red Hat Linux 7.3 - i386
Red Hat Linux 8.0 - i386
Red Hat Linux 9 - i386

3. Problem description:

OpenSSH is a suite of network connectivity tools that can be used to
establish encrypted connections between systems on a network and can
provide interactive login sessions and port forwarding, among other functions.

The OpenSSH team has announced a bug which affects the OpenSSH buffer
handling code.  This bug has the potential of being remotely exploitable.

All users of OpenSSH should immediately apply this update which contains a
backported fix for this issue.

4. Solution:

Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata
relevant to your system have been applied.

To update all RPMs for your particular architecture, run:

rpm -Fvh [filenames]

where [filenames] is a list of the RPMs you wish to upgrade.  Only those
RPMs which are currently installed will be updated.  Those RPMs which are
not installed but included in the list will not be updated.  Note that you
can also use wildcards (*.rpm) if your current directory *only* contains the
desired RPMs.

Please note that this update is also available via Red Hat Network.  Many
people find this an easier way to apply updates.  To use Red Hat Network,
launch the Red Hat Update Agent with the following command:

up2date

This will start an interactive process that will result in the appropriate
RPMs being upgraded on your system.

If up2date fails to connect to Red Hat Network due to SSL Certificate
Errors, you need to install a version of the up2date client with an updated
certificate.  The latest version of up2date is available from the Red Hat
FTP site and may also be downloaded directly from the RHN website:

https://rhn.redhat.com/help/latest-up2date.pxt

5. RPMs required:

Red Hat Linux 7.1:

SRPMS:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.1/en/os/SRPMS/openssh-3.1p1-9.src.rpm

i386:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.1/en/os/i386/openssh-3.1p1-9.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.1/en/os/i386/openssh-clients-3.1p1-9.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.1/en/os/i386/openssh-server-3.1p1-9.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.1/en/os/i386/openssh-askpass-3.1p1-9.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.1/en/os/i386/openssh-askpass-gnome-3.1p1-9.i386.rpm

Red Hat Linux 7.2:

SRPMS:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.2/en/os/SRPMS/openssh-3.1p1-10.src.rpm

i386:
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.2/en/os/i386/openssh-3.1p1-10.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.2/en/os/i386/openssh-clients-3.1p1-10.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.2/en/os/i386/openssh-server-3.1p1-10.i386.rpm
ftp://updates.redhat.com/7.2/en/os/i386/openssh-askpass-3.1p1-10.i386.rpm

These packages are GPG signed by Red Hat for security.  Our key is
available from https://www.redhat.com/security/keys.html

You can verify each package with the following command:

    rpm --checksig -v <filename>

If you only wish to verify that each package has not been corrupted or
tampered with, examine only the md5sum with the following command:

    md5sum <filename>

On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 18:39, Cory Bertsch wrote:
> Anyone who needs information about updating their Gentoo system can look 
> here:
> 
> http://forums.gentoo.org/viewtopic.php?t=84879&highlight=ssh

emerge sync
emerge --upgrade openssh

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Tue Sep 16 12:07:01 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Sep 16 12:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SSH exploit in the wild RH
In-Reply-To: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>
References: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <1063739052.1072.157.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

I'm a prime sucker. I have on 7.1 system that I didn't update the SSH
certificate on. Now, when I need to update it, I need to update the
up2date, too. I got the files, and went into upgrade vortex. the new
up2date needs mkinitrd >= 3.2.2. The lowest package that satisfies that
is 3.2.6-1, which requires filesystem >= 2.1.0.

That sounds serious. This system is only running an old website for a
customer until I force him to review and upgrade (it's a long story).

Since I have physical access to the system should I screw with it or
just turn SSH off?

Suggestions welcomed

Mike










From alex at daniloff.com  Tue Sep 16 12:27:02 2003

Rich,
I've heard from one developer, that LaTeX may die in a nearest 
future, when everybody switches to XML/XSLT/Schema/SAX/DOM standards.
I was considering using LaTeX while I was developing company's
documentation system, but XML/SAX/Perl approach bound to MySQL worked 
the best.

Just my $0.02

Alex

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Tue Sep 16 12:48:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)

On Tue, 16 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I'm a prime sucker. I have on 7.1 system that I didn't update the SSH
> certificate on. Now, when I need to update it, I need to update the
> up2date, too. I got the files, and went into upgrade vortex. the new
> up2date needs mkinitrd >= 3.2.2. The lowest package that satisfies that
> is 3.2.6-1, which requires filesystem >= 2.1.0.
> 
> That sounds serious. This system is only running an old website for a
> customer until I force him to review and upgrade (it's a long story).
> 
> Since I have physical access to the system should I screw with it or
> just turn SSH off?


With an exploit in the wild it's a matter of time before the host is 
compromised.  either enable tcp_wrappers for the host or turn ssh off.

BTW, I haven't used up2date in quite awhile to keep a rpm based system 
updated.  Rsync and "rpm -Fvh" have all that I have needed to do.



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Sep 16 12:49:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Sep 16 12:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX in the real world
In-Reply-To: <200309161921.h8GJLUD30569@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200309161921.h8GJLUD30569@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309161243580.4558@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 16 Sep 2003, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> I've heard from one developer, that LaTeX may die in a nearest future,
> when everybody switches to XML/XSLT/Schema/SAX/DOM standards. I was
> considering using LaTeX while I was developing company's documentation
> system, but XML/SAX/Perl approach bound to MySQL worked the best.

Alex,

  If you listen to people in the computer industry you'll get the answer you
received. Yes, for computer documentation, XML, DocBook and the like are a
great way to go. However, for _typeset_ output there's nothing like TeX and
the LaTeX macros.

  One-size-fits-all solutions don't. You need to consider the vested
interests of the solution promoter/provider as well as your intended use
before making a decision.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

Skip up2date and all of its dependencies. Just download the ssh rpm files 
from Red Hat and apply them manually with the rpm utility:

   rpm -Fhv openssh*.rpm

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Sep 16 13:22:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue Sep 16 13:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SSH exploit in the wild RH
In-Reply-To: <20030916195318.GA28462@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <20030916163444.GE11670@dalsemi.com>
	 <1063739052.1072.157.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	 <20030916195318.GA28462@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <1063743640.12317.49.camel@localhost>

On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 12:53, Terry Griffin wrote:

> Skip up2date and all of its dependencies. Just download the ssh rpm files 
> from Red Hat and apply them manually with the rpm utility:
> 
>    rpm -Fhv openssh*.rpm

wget ftp://updates.redhat.com/8.0/en/os/i386/openssh-*-5.i386.rpm
rpm -Fvh openssh-*-5.i386.rpm

...if you're using 8.0.

You probably need to adjust the 8.0 and the -5 to match up with whatever
version you're on.

(patched a friend's RH box since he's at work with no SSH access)

Rob

7.1 is still supported. 7.0 is not.

Side note: If you have a 7.0 system, my experience so far is that all
Red Hat 7.1 RPM updates that have come out since 7.0 support was 
discontinued work ok on 7.0, excluding the 2.4 kernel and related packages
like modutils. (7.0 was the last to run a 2.2 kernel.)

From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Sep 16 16:01:01 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Sep 16 16:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl / Javascript question
Message-ID: <54786.68.107.223.201.1063753255.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I have a Javascript popup window where the user chooses some settings and
then clicks submit.  After submitting, the form vars are sent to a perl
script that saves the vars as cookies on the user's box.  I would like the
popup window to close when they click submit, so I added
onsubmit="window.close()", but when I do this the cookies are no longer
set.  It's as if the window is closed before the perl script is called. 
Any suggestions on how to fix this?  I know I could just set the cookies
with Javascript, but I'm curious about how to make this way work.
Thanks,
~M

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Tue Sep 16 16:10:03 2003
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Tue Sep 16 16:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl / Javascript question
In-Reply-To: <54786.68.107.223.201.1063753255.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <54786.68.107.223.201.1063753255.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1063755077.2193.27.camel@localhost.localdomain>

you could have the perl script do/return the following:

#!/path/to/perl -wT

# processing stuff

print "Content-Type: text/html\n\n";

# split into 2 print statements for mail client readability
print "<html><head></head><body onLoad=\"window.close()\">"; 
print "Close Me</body></html>";


On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 19:00, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I have a Javascript popup window where the user chooses some settings and
> then clicks submit.  After submitting, the form vars are sent to a perl
> script that saves the vars as cookies on the user's box.  I would like the
> popup window to close when they click submit, so I added
> onsubmit="window.close()", but when I do this the cookies are no longer
> set.  It's as if the window is closed before the perl script is called. 
> Any suggestions on how to fix this?  I know I could just set the cookies
> with Javascript, but I'm curious about how to make this way work.
> Thanks,
> ~M
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Brian Horan <bhoran at hexdev.com>




From freyley at gmx.net  Tue Sep 16 16:16:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Tue Sep 16 16:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl / Javascript question
In-Reply-To: <54786.68.107.223.201.1063753255.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <54786.68.107.223.201.1063753255.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1063753637.4406.84.camel@localhost>

On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 16:00, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I have a Javascript popup window where the user chooses some settings and
> then clicks submit.  After submitting, the form vars are sent to a perl
> script that saves the vars as cookies on the user's box.  I would like the
> popup window to close when they click submit, so I added
> onsubmit="window.close()", but when I do this the cookies are no longer
> set.  It's as if the window is closed before the perl script is called. 
> Any suggestions on how to fix this?  I know I could just set the cookies
> with Javascript, but I'm curious about how to make this way work.
> Thanks,
> ~M

Yes, the javascript runs before the data is submitted, and therefore
you're closing the window before the data is submitted. You've got two
choices, or at least, two obvious choices:

1) have the perl script return a page which has a button which says
"close window." This is a standard solution.
2) have javascript set the cookies. The reason this is less preferable
is that javascript is ... well, many people write poor javascript, and
the quality of the javascript interpreters has varied over the years,
and so it's less guaranteed that this will work for all users and won't
kill other things (i.e. all instances of the browser by accident =).
Still, you could do it, if you wrote impeccable javascript and assumed
everybody will be using a modern browser

Jeff 




From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Tue Sep 16 16:56:01 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Tue Sep 16 16:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Compile problem

From rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com  Tue Sep 16 17:03:01 2003
From: rschlosser at newedgenetworks.com (Schlosser, Ryan)
Date: Tue Sep 16 17:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] FW: OpenSSH 3.7.1 released
Message-ID: <170830AA1EB8D611AD2300508B6BD10A05992178@smaug.newedgenetworks.com>

For those who just patched this morning - we salute you.

For those who will be patching again - TONIGHT - we salute you.

-----Original Message-----
From: owner-announce at openbsd.org [mailto:owner-announce at openbsd.org]On
Behalf Of Markus Friedl
Sent: Tuesday, September 16, 2003 4:13 PM
To: announce at openbsd.org
Subject: OpenSSH 3.7.1 released


OpenSSH 3.7.1 has just been released. It will be available from the
mirrors listed at http://www.openssh.com/ shortly.

OpenSSH is a 100% complete SSH protocol version 1.3, 1.5 and 2.0
implementation and includes sftp client and server support.

We would like to thank the OpenSSH community for their continued
support to the project, especially those who contributed source and
bought T-shirts or posters.

We have a new design of T-shirt available, more info on
        http://www.openbsd.org/tshirts.html#18

For international orders use https://https.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/order
and for European orders, use https://https.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/order.eu

Security Changes:
=================

  All versions of OpenSSH's sshd prior to 3.7.1 contain buffer
  management errors.  It is uncertain whether these errors are
  potentially exploitable, however, we prefer to see bugs
  fixed proactively.

  OpenSSH 3.7 fixed one of these bugs.

  OpenSSH 3.7.1 fixes more similar bugs.

Changes since OpenSSH 3.6.1:
============================ 

* The entire OpenSSH code-base has undergone a license review. As
  a result, all non-ssh1.x code is under a BSD-style license with no
  advertising requirement. Please refer to README in the source
  distribution for the exact license terms.

* Rhosts authentication has been removed in ssh(1) and sshd(8).

* Changes in Kerberos support:

    - KerberosV password support now uses a file cache instead of
      a memory cache.

    - KerberosIV and AFS support has been removed.

    - KerberosV support has been removed from SSH protocol 1.

    - KerberosV password authentication support remains for SSH
      protocols 1 and 2.

    - This release contains some GSSAPI user authentication support
      to replace legacy KerberosV authentication support. At present
      this code is still considered experimental and SHOULD NOT BE
      USED.
  
* Changed order that keys are tried in public key authentication.
  The ssh(1) client tries the keys in the following order:

     1. ssh-agent(1) keys that are found in the ssh_config(5) file
     2. remaining ssh-agent(1) keys
     3. keys that are only listed in the ssh_config(5) file

  This helps when an ssh-agent(1) has many keys, where the sshd(8)
  server might close the connection before the correct key is tried.

* SOCKS5 support has been added to the dynamic forwarding mode
  in ssh(1).

* Removed implementation barriers to operation of SSH over SCTP.

* sftp(1) client can now transfer files with quote characters in
  their filenames.

* Replaced sshd(8)'s VerifyReverseMapping with UseDNS option.
  When UseDNS option is on, reverse hostname lookups are always
  performed.

* Fix a number of memory leaks.

* Support for sending tty BREAK over SSH protocol 2.

* Workaround for other vendor bugs in KEX guess handling.

* Support for generating KEX-GEX groups (/etc/moduli) in ssh-keygen(1).

* Automatic re-keying based on amount of data sent over connection.

* New AddressFamily option on client to select protocol to use (IPv4
  or IPv6).

* Experimental support for the "aes128-ctr", "aes192-ctr", and
  "aes256-ctr" ciphers for SSH protocol 2.

* Experimental support for host keys in DNS (draft-ietf-secsh-dns-xx.txt).
  Please see README.dns in the source distribution for details.

* Portable OpenSSH:

    - Replace PAM password authentication kludge with a more correct
      PAM challenge-response module from FreeBSD.

    - PAM support may now be enabled/disabled at runtime using the
      UsePAM directive.

    - Many improvements to the OpenSC smartcard support.

    - Regression tests now work with portable OpenSSH.
      Please refer to regress/README.regress in the source distribution.

    - On platforms that support it, portable OpenSSH now honors the
      UMASK, PATH and SUPATH attributes set in /etc/default/login.

    - Deny access to locked accounts, regardless of authentication
      method in use.

Checksums:
==========

- MD5 (openssh-3.7.1.tgz) = 3d2f1644d6a3d3267e5e2421f1385129
- MD5 (openssh-3.7.1p1.tar.gz) = f54e574e606c08ef63ebb1ab2f7689dc


Reporting Bugs:
===============

- please read http://www.openssh.com/report.html
  and http://bugzilla.mindrot.org/

OpenSSH is brought to you by Markus Friedl, Niels Provos, Theo de Raadt,
Kevin Steves, Damien Miller, Ben Lindstrom, Darren Tucker and Tim Rice.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Tue Sep 16 18:01:01 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Tue Sep 16 18:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Replacement for bind
In-Reply-To: <20030916235918.GD22332@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <20030916235918.GD22332@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <200309161804.32910.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Tuesday 16 September 2003 4:59 pm, Russ Johnson wrote:
> I'm looking at replacing bind. I looked at tinydns, but it won't do zone
> transfers, and I need that.

Yes it does. Use rsync over ssh, which is sane and dependable, or 
djbdns-axfrdns. Visit http://cr.yp.to/djbdns.html, everything is completely 
documented. See http://cr.yp.to/djbdns/run-server.html for zone transfers. As 
Ed, my favorite cranky DNS guru said once, it's just moving plain text files, 
for gosh sakes, you don't need some freaky horrid BIND hack.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

You can do zone transfers between BIND and tinydns. As Carla
mentioned, this is done with axfrdns. It takes a little
setup to get working though - nothing tough, just attention
to detail.

From ed at alcpress.com  Tue Sep 16 21:39:01 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue Sep 16 21:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Replacement for bind
In-Reply-To: <20030917041256.GA23049@wirex.net>
References: <20030916235918.GD22332@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	 <20030917041256.GA23049@wirex.net>
Message-ID: <1063773990.1980.22.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 21:12, Steve Beattie wrote:
> On Tue, Sep 16, 2003 at 04:59:18PM -0700, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > I'm looking at replacing bind. I looked at tinydns, but it won't do zone
> > transfers, and I need that. 
> > 
> > I host two domains myself, and I have secondary server duties for about
> > 8 other domains. 
> > 
> > Is there something besides bind that does this?
> 
> Giving a cursory glance to Rick Moen's list of free software bind
> replacements <http://www.linuxmafia.com/~rick/linux-info/dns-servers>,
> it appears that at a minimum MaraDNS does this.

This is a nice comprehensive list that he's put together.
Just note that Rick is biased against tinydns. You can see
this for yourself on the above referenced web page. He
placed djbdns in the Proprietary category for two reasons.
He doesn't like the fact that Bernstein doesn't use the GPL.
It seems that he thinks that anything that is not GPL'ed is
proprietary software.

He also believes that tinydns is not RFC-compliant because it
doesn't support BIND-like zone transfers - and anything that
is not RFC-compliant shouldn't be used. I disagree strongly
with this assertion but I've failed to convince him otherwise.

Ed




From krisa at subtend.net  Tue Sep 16 21:39:14 2003
From: krisa at subtend.net (Kris)
Date: Tue Sep 16 21:39:14 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Replacement for bind
In-Reply-To: <1063773301.2019.11.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20030916235918.GD22332@sthelens.dimstar.net> <200309161804.32910.carla@bratgrrl.com> <3F67D6AB.5030201@dimstar.net> <1063773301.2019.11.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030917043843.GB22279@subtend.net>

On Tue, Sep 16, 2003 at 09:35:02PM -0700, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> You can do zone transfers between BIND and tinydns. As Carla
> mentioned, this is done with axfrdns. It takes a little
> setup to get working though - nothing tough, just attention
> to detail.

It works great.  I use tinydns/dnscache for internal IP space and an external server
running tinydns/axfrdns for real IP space.  I have three secondary Sprint DNS server
pulling zone transfers without issue from the external server.

Internally I use rsync-over-ssh to push to secondary djbdns servers.  Again.. works
great.

-- 
I'm just a packet pusher.

Try reading the docs. You can do zone transfers between BIND and tinydns just 
fine. You didn't say you wanted to be a secondary to BIND servers; that 
limits your choices of how to actually make zone transfers.

I don't care what you use, use trained pigeons for all I care. Just don't run 
around saying it can't be done, because it can.

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Sep 17 00:15:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Sep 17 00:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] the struggle for coexistance
In-Reply-To: <A9ED9854LHLFCA31KJZT3209746ZQK52.3f67f32d@miked>
References: <A9ED9854LHLFCA31KJZT3209746ZQK52.3f67f32d@miked>
Message-ID: <1063783507.1139.39.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

This is a little story about the struggle to understand the workings of
the brains in Redmond.  It starts with a linux server called
"newserver".  This server is being set up to be transported off to do
some real good in the world.  The lowly test technician has just set up
Samba.  He changes the workgroup name to "WG", he makes the home
directories writable, and then he creates a common share called "share"
and makes it writable.  After running the command 

/etc/init.d/samba restart

the server starts with no complaints.

Now the fun starts, the lowly tech then goes to an XP (pro edition)
machine to test the newly started samba server.  "Where the hell is the
workgroup browsing link", he screams, "all I get with the Network
browsing button is the last share I logged into, I know the network is
bigger than that!"  After intense searching, the Workgroup browse link
suddenly appears in a spot that had been thoroughly searched before.

"Whew", he says, "now lets see if we can find the "WG" workgroup.  Ah,
there it is, but nothing is in it!"  Having seen this before, the lowly
tech then changed the XP's workgroup to "WG", did the mandatory reboot
and finally found newserver.

Now, lurking in the background is another server called "bigserv" in
another workgroup called "shop".  This server is also running bind with
an experimental gforge  install.  During the installation, the zone file
for shop was heavily modified, including a wildcard entry that points to
bigserv.

So, lowly tech logs into newserver, got the username and password
prompt, and then was shown a list of shares.  But wait, there is
something fishy about those shares.  Those are the share on bigserv!  He
confirmed this by going into his home directory, sure enough, that is
the home directory on bigserv, not the nice clean directory of the fresh
new newserver.

After the wildcard entry was deleted, the XP box did log into the
correct server, but the lesson had been learned!  You can't trust
anything that XP tells you about the network, particularly the name of
the server that you are logging into!

Thanks for letting me vent.

Derek Loree




From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Sep 17 09:39:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Sep 17 09:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl / Javascript question
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C766@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Matt Alexander queried:
> I have a Javascript popup window where the user chooses some 
> settings and
> then clicks submit.  After submitting, the form vars are sent 
> to a perl
> script that saves the vars as cookies on the user's box.  I 
> would like the
> popup window to close when they click submit, so I added
> onsubmit="window.close()", but when I do this the cookies are 
> no longer
> set.  It's as if the window is closed before the perl script 
> is called. 
> Any suggestions on how to fix this?  I know I could just set 
> the cookies
> with Javascript, but I'm curious about how to make this way work.

  Cookies are browser based.  You'll need to set the cookie value in the
browser before you submit the form.  The current cookie values are sent to
the CGI script with the HTTP GET.  You can't set the values after the
submit.  It's too late.

  I had a similar situation with a little web app I recently wrote.  I was
using cookies to maintain state information about the display pages.  The
cookie *has* to be set before submit so the CGI script receives the correct
cookie values.  I tried a bunch different techniques.  I finally used
Javascript to get it working correctly. 

Steve D...

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 17 10:38:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] [slackware-security]  OpenSSH updated again (SSA:2003-260-01) (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309171036470.7898@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 17 Sep 2003 10:00:07 -0700 (PDT)

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

[slackware-security]  OpenSSH updated again (SSA:2003-260-01)

Upgraded OpenSSH 3.7.1p1 packages are available for Slackware
8.1, 9.0 and -current.  These fix additional buffer management
errors that were not corrected in the recent 3.7p1 release.
The possibility exists that these errors could allow a remote
exploit, so we recommend all sites running OpenSSH upgrade to
the new OpenSSH package immediately.


Here are the details from the Slackware 9.0 ChangeLog:
+--------------------------+
Wed Sep 17 01:25:22 PDT 2003
patches/packages/openssh-3.7.1p1-i386-1.tgz:  Upgraded to openssh-3.7.1p1.
  The OpenSSH advisory was updated (http://www.openssh.com/txt/buffer.adv)
  and now says that you need at least version 3.7.1, which fixes some
  more buffer problems like those fixed by 3.7.
  (* Security fix *)
+--------------------------+


WHERE TO FIND THE NEW PACKAGES:
+-----------------------------+

Updated package for Slackware 8.1:
ftp://ftp.slackware.com/pub/slackware/slackware-8.1/patches/packages/openssh-3.7.1p1-i386-1.tgz

Updated package for Slackware 9.0:
ftp://ftp.slackware.com/pub/slackware/slackware-9.0/patches/packages/openssh-3.7.1p1-i386-1.tgz

Updated package for Slackware -current:
ftp://ftp.slackware.com/pub/slackware/slackware-current/slackware/n/openssh-3.7.1p1-i486-1.tgz


MD5 SIGNATURES:
+-------------+

Slackware 8.1 package:
c3b50ac3f2cd52c7ad10a0fbb141efe9  openssh-3.7.1p1-i386-1.tgz

Slackware 9.0 package:
0362f59c065c79c3eb733519394d0a60  openssh-3.7.1p1-i386-1.tgz

Slackware -current package:
e6e9cb0a9811f982d615e7a96c6c76e9  openssh-3.7.1p1-i486-1.tgz


INSTALLATION INSTRUCTIONS:
+------------------------+

(This procedure is safe to do while logged in through OpenSSH)

Upgrade using upgradepkg (as root):
# upgradepkg openssh-3.7.1p1-i386-1.tgz

Restart OpenSSH:
. /etc/rc.d/rc.sshd restart

From freyley at gmx.net  Wed Sep 17 12:03:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Sep 17 12:03:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl / Javascript question
In-Reply-To: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C766@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
References: 
	 <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C766@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <1063825309.5228.10.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 09:37, Daggett, Steve wrote:
> Matt Alexander queried:
> > I have a Javascript popup window where the user chooses some 
> > settings and
> > then clicks submit.  After submitting, the form vars are sent 
> > to a perl
> > script that saves the vars as cookies on the user's box.  I 
> > would like the
> > popup window to close when they click submit, so I added
> > onsubmit="window.close()", but when I do this the cookies are 
> > no longer
> > set.  It's as if the window is closed before the perl script 
> > is called. 
> > Any suggestions on how to fix this?  I know I could just set 
> > the cookies
> > with Javascript, but I'm curious about how to make this way work.
> 
>   Cookies are browser based.  You'll need to set the cookie value in the
> browser before you submit the form.  The current cookie values are sent to
> the CGI script with the HTTP GET.  You can't set the values after the
> submit.  It's too late.
> 
>   I had a similar situation with a little web app I recently wrote.  I was
> using cookies to maintain state information about the display pages.  The
> cookie *has* to be set before submit so the CGI script receives the correct
> cookie values.  I tried a bunch different techniques.  I finally used
> Javascript to get it working correctly. 
> 
> Steve D...

There's a slight difference between the cases: he's talking about the
perl script setting the cookies (which it can do) before going on to do
other things. You're talking about a submit box to a script which needs
the cookies already set. If they have to _already_ be set by the time
the script acts, then you need javascript (or an intervening script). If
they are set by this particular script (it sounds likely that this is an
intermediary script specifically for setting cookies, since it's in a
popup window) then it can be set by perl or by javascript. If it's set
by javascript, it doesn't even need to send anything to the server, and
you might be able to do it with a java applet, instead. But in either
case, they're different situations.

Jeff




From freyley at gmx.net  Wed Sep 17 12:06:02 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Sep 17 13:14:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Sep 17 13:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to determine if my dual processors are being
	recognized
In-Reply-To: <L79oP58yLhJb9ABPakLFyIj+xeFa@4ax.com>
References: <L79oP58yLhJb9ABPakLFyIj+xeFa@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <1063829604.4117.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 13:10, Prutzer wrote:
> Hi All,
> I'm trying to find a way to determine if both my dual processors are
> being recognized and utilized by my RedHat OS.
> I know there must be a command like df or something, but my brain just
> can't remember where I saw it. 
> Any body got a clue bat?

cat /proc/cpuinfo

Wil

On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 12:04, Jeff Schwaber wrote:

> it's not ati or r128?
> 
> the inspirons have been using ATI cards for a while, but I'm not sure
> that they still do. What do you get from this command?

Actually, Dell's Inspirons have had a few options for a while now...
depending on the model, you can use Intel integrated graphics, ATi
graphics, or nVidia graphics.  I chose nVidia GeForce2 Go for my i2650
about a year ago.

My friend has an ATi chip in his i8600, IIRC.

The 'super small' laptops tend to go with the Intel chips, though...
ugh.

Sorry I can't help the OP with his Intel graphics chip, I rarely play
with anything except nVidia graphics these days.

Rob

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Sep 17 14:04:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Sep 17 14:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to determine if my dual processors are being recognized
In-Reply-To: <1063829604.4117.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <L79oP58yLhJb9ABPakLFyIj+xeFa@4ax.com> <1063829604.4117.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309171316590.6175@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 17 Sep 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:

> On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 13:10, Prutzer wrote:
> >
> > I'm trying to find a way to determine if both my dual processors
> > are being recognized and utilized by my RedHat OS. [...]
>
> cat /proc/cpuinfo

Wil's answer is the most general, and the one I would have posted had
he not done it first. Since he did the basic work, however, I'm free
to post some, er, idiosyncratic answers:

* More specifically:

  grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo

* More obscurely, Red Hat style:

  rpm --eval %_smp_mflags | sed 's![^0-9]!!g'

* One-liner:

  ps auxw | grep -c 'ksoftirqd_CPU[0-9]'

* Obligatory Perl solution:

  head -n 1 /proc/interrupts | perl -nle 'print tr/C//'

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Sep 17 14:07:01 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Sep 17 14:07:01 2003

> > 2) using imap?
> > 3) reading folders via nfs?
> > 4) something different from 1-3?

mailboxes.

How 'bout this. Do "less /var/spool/mail/$LOGNAME" on your server. Are
you seeing mail in less that you can't see in pine?

Another solution which may not be available in all distributions is to
type the 'top' command and examine the top of the screen to see if
activity is reported on more than 1 processor.

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Wed Sep 17 14:41:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Wed Sep 17 14:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to determine if my dual processors are being
 recog nized
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C767@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Wil Cooley:
> On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 13:10, Prutzer wrote:
> > Hi All,
> > I'm trying to find a way to determine if both my dual processors are
> > being recognized and utilized by my RedHat OS.
> > I know there must be a command like df or something, but my 
> brain just
> > can't remember where I saw it. 
> > Any body got a clue bat?
> 
> cat /proc/cpuinfo

  As a more general use solution, I keep "xosview" running on my desktop.
It's an old application, but still a goodie.  The RPM is in the Redhat
distro, but doesn't install by default. 

  It shows separate status bars for CPU 0 and 1.  It's fun watching
non-threaded, CPU intensive, tasks bounce between CPU's as they runs.  

Steve D...

I want to put together a 2U rack-mounted server. Anyone know of a local
shop that sells rack-mounted cases? I build a system a few months ago,
but used an old rack-mounted case from an older computer, and had to do
some minor modifications to make it work.

I'd like the case to accept standard commodity components, such as a
standard ATX motherboard and power supply.

My rack is a Compaq.

I'm very happy with the server I built recently. Dual Xeon 1.8 GHz, 2
gigs, 2 120 gig IDE, mirrored, Red Hat 9. It cost me around 1/3 what it
would cost from Dell.

Thanks,

	 <1063825496.5228.13.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <1063840953.1139.104.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 12:04, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 10:18, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> > Hello Linux folkz,
> > Just tried to configure Xserver for Dell Inspiron 1100 laptop.
> > Xserver can't find modes for its graphic chipset i845 using driver
> > i810. So now it runs in VESA mode with ugly 680x480 resolution.
> > Could somebody please give me a hint if this laptop's
> > graphic chipset is supported in Linux at all.
> > How can I fix this issue.

The only way I could get an i845 to display an x-server is to use
framebuffer in the kernel and the fbdev driver in xfree86-4.  At least
it will do a better resolution than 680x480.

If you're using a stock kernel, it may already be compiled in.  I also
had to change color depth to 8 the first time I got it to start
successfully.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree




From techmage at aracnet.com  Wed Sep 17 16:14:02 2003
From: techmage at aracnet.com (Prutzer)
Date: Wed Sep 17 16:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to determine if my dual processors are being recognized
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309171316590.6175@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <L79oP58yLhJb9ABPakLFyIj+xeFa@4ax.com> <1063829604.4117.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309171316590.6175@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <suVoPxohNuuXXphkWwObIIVL5f0Q@4ax.com>

On Wed, 17 Sep 2003 14:03:11 -0700 (PDT), you wrote:

>On Wed, 17 Sep 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:
>
>> On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 13:10, Prutzer wrote:
>> >
>> > I'm trying to find a way to determine if both my dual processors
>> > are being recognized and utilized by my RedHat OS. [...]
>>
>> cat /proc/cpuinfo
>
>Wil's answer is the most general, and the one I would have posted had
>he not done it first. Since he did the basic work, however, I'm free
>to post some, er, idiosyncratic answers:
>
>* More specifically:
>
>  grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo
>
>* More obscurely, Red Hat style:
>
>  rpm --eval %_smp_mflags | sed 's![^0-9]!!g'
>
>* One-liner:
>
>  ps auxw | grep -c 'ksoftirqd_CPU[0-9]'
>
>* Obligatory Perl solution:
>
>  head -n 1 /proc/interrupts | perl -nle 'print tr/C//'
>
>--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

okay the readouts are:
==================================================
[root at Maodhog2 root]# cat /proc/cpuinfo 
processor       : 0
vendor_id       : GenuineIntel
cpu family      : 6
model           : 5
model name      : Pentium II (Deschutes)
stepping        : 3
cpu MHz         : 451.029
cache size      : 2048 KB
fdiv_bug        : no
hlt_bug         : no
f00f_bug        : no
coma_bug        : no
fpu             : yes
fpu_exception   : yes
cpuid level     : 2
wp              : yes
flags           : fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge
mca cmov pat pse36 mmx fxsr
bogomips        : 897.84

processor       : 1
vendor_id       : GenuineIntel
cpu family      : 6
model           : 5
model name      : Pentium II (Deschutes)
stepping        : 3
cpu MHz         : 451.029
cache size      : 2048 KB
fdiv_bug        : no
hlt_bug         : no
f00f_bug        : no
coma_bug        : no
fpu             : yes
fpu_exception   : yes
cpuid level     : 2
wp              : yes
flags           : fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge
mca cmov pat pse36 mmx fxsr
bogomips        : 901.12

[root at Maodhog2 root]#  rpm --eval %_smp_mflags | sed 's![^0-9]!!g'
2
[root at Maodhog2 root]#  ps auxw | grep -c 'ksoftirqd_CPU[0-9]'
2
[root at Maodhog2 root]#  head -n 1 /proc/interrupts | perl -nle 'print
tr/C//'

2
[root at Maodhog2 root]# 
[root at Maodhog2 root]#  grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo
2
[root at Maodhog2 root]# 
[root at Maodhog2 root]# 
==================================================
Interesting.

Also, when in X  I see where to locate the Processor info and it shows
two as well. So, it's seeing both processors. Good. Thanks again for
the clue bats.
HWACK! :)

Harry

> type the 'top' command and examine the top of the screen to see if
> activity is reported on more than 1 processor.
> -djp
> 

And "uname -r" will also give a small tidbit of info.

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Wed Sep 17 17:42:02 2003

I've got a dual Xeon system, and doing a "cat /proc/cpuinfo" it shows
as four processors. This is because of Intel's "hyperthreading" which
is where one processor acts like it is two.

Yes.  Plenty of whitebox vendors use plain old boards in 1U and 2U
cases.  You have to get special riser boards to put cards in them, but
they're reasonably standard and can be had from a place like NWCA or
Fry's.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Sep 17 22:50:02 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed Sep 17 22:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] consumer v. enterprise disk drives
Message-ID: <20030918054914.1BC628F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

To follow up on something I mentioned at tonight's meeting, here's an
article which describes differences between consumer and enterprise
disk drives.  I seem to recall seeing this mentioned on the list
earlier, but here it is again for those who missed it.

http://www.seagate.com/content/docs/pdf/whitepaper/D2c_More_than_Interface_ATA_vs_SCSI_042003.pdf


Here's another interesting paper.
http://www.acmqueue.org/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=46

galen

From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Wed Sep 17 23:37:02 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Wed Sep 17 23:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX in the real world
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309161150230.4228@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309161150230.4228@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <16233.21816.862839.327075@vzavenue.net>

Rich Shepard writes:
 >   I spoke this morning with my editor at Academic Press. She said that they
 > use only LaTeX there, but she hadn't heard before of LyX. So I gave her the
 > URL.

My wife did her masters thesis in LyX.  For a hardcore LaTeX user, LyX
can be irritating because of what LaTeX capabilities you don't get,
but it's probably good for the "if it doesn't have a GUI then it must
be bad" types.  (I haven't seriously tried LyX for a few years, so for
all I know they could have improved.  The screenshots I've seen look
pretty impresssive.)

 >   It's nice to know that not all the rest of the world works (in a manner of
 > writing) with winWord. :-)

Or its clones, such as OpenOffice.

LaTeX is still the text processor of choice in some areas of academia,
especially math and CS.  (Though there is increasing pressure for
conferences to accept things in Word format.)

What I think is most funny is that LaTeX seems to be the text
processor of choice at Microsoft Research.  (A few years ago, MS
decided to set up a research lab, and went around buying up a lot of
big-name profs in areas like compilers.  Most of these people have
just continued their previous lines of research, which have led some
observers to suggest this was just PR, so that MS would have its name
attached to a lot of papers in the big research conferences (such as
PLDI) so that academics wouldn't be able to diss them for not making
any real contributions to CS.  Anyway, a colleague of mine was invited
there for a visit, and he noticed that the people there weren't forced
to eat Microsoft's dog food, and were mostly using Emacs and LaTeX.

Kevin

From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Sep 18 08:37:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Sep 18 08:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
Message-ID: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I have 6 numbers that appear at the end of a line of text.  The 6 numbers
may or may not have spaces between each.  So, for example, I could have:

1 234 5 6
or
1234 56

I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:

$line =~
s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;

This works, but it's long and I'm curious if there's a shorter, more
clever way.
Thanks,
~M

> know of a local
>                            ^
>                       this |
>

> months ago,
> > but used an old rack-mounted case from an older computer, 
> and had to do
> > some minor modifications to make it work.
> > 
> > I'd like the case to accept standard commodity components, such as a
> 
> and this |
>          v
> > standard ATX motherboard and power supply.
> 
> Would be somewhat incongrous.  Is my thinking wrong?

  I was looking at 2U ATX chassis earlier this year.  They have great rack
density and price point if you're looking for cheap MIPS with few or no PCI
cards.

http://www.rackmount.com/Chassis.htm

  Of course, you get what you pay for.  This is all commodity class
hardware.  I was looking at building redundant servers.  I could afford to
lose a machine from time to time.  Mission critical services should still be
run on enterprise class hardware.  

Steve D...

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Sep 18 09:51:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Thu Sep 18 09:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
References: <mailman.1063899437.2501.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86y8wmjb9r.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Matt" == Matt Alexander <m at pdxlug.org> writes:

Matt> I have 6 numbers that appear at the end of a line of text.  The 6 numbers
Matt> may or may not have spaces between each.  So, for example, I could have:

Matt> 1 234 5 6
Matt> or
Matt> 1234 56

Matt> I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:

Matt> $line =~
Matt> s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;

Matt> This works, but it's long and I'm curious if there's a shorter, more
Matt> clever way.

s#((?:\d\s*){6}$)#
  my $s = $1;
  $s =~ tr/\d//cd;
  $s;
#e;

--

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Sep 18 10:06:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Sep 18 10:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
In-Reply-To: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309180927510.14172@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:
>
> $line =~
> s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;

Interesting problem. I take it that the text preceding the six digits
is expendable, right?

For starters, ditch the character class and the opening grouping:

  s/^.*(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?$/$1$2$3$4$5$6/;

Grouping would allow you to do it in two (shorter) steps:

  s/^.*(\d\s?\d\s?\d\s?\d\s?\d\s?\d)\s?$/$1/;
  s/\s//g;

This might buy you some maintainability, and it might even be faster,
since you're only producing $1, not $1 .. $7.

If you're up for it, you can make the second half of the regex
executable:

  sub nospace { my $x = shift; $x =~ s/\s//g; $x; }
  s/^.*((\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d))\s?$/nospace($1)/e;

But this doesn't buy you anything, and it's likely to be much slower
since you've got a subroutine call in every regex.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

     <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309180927510.14172@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Paul Heinlein said:
> On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
>
>> I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:
>>
>> $line =~
>> s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;
>
> Interesting problem. I take it that the text preceding the six digits
> is expendable, right?

I assign $1 to another variable to preserve the preceding text.

> For starters, ditch the character class and the opening grouping:
>
>   s/^.*(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?(\d)\s?$/$1$2$3$4$5$6/;
>
> Grouping would allow you to do it in two (shorter) steps:
>
>   s/^.*(\d\s?\d\s?\d\s?\d\s?\d\s?\d)\s?$/$1/;
>   s/\s//g;
>
> This might buy you some maintainability, and it might even be faster,
> since you're only producing $1, not $1 .. $7.

Thanks.  This is what I'll use (making a couple small changes to preserve
the preceding text, of course).
~M

discussion of Open Source. Panelists included

David Pool with Naked Ape Consulting (on SB 941)

CreationGroundMedia.com Produced the show
Pressman Productions did the soundtrack

Here's the schedule:

discuss open source software
Mon Oct 6 06:30PM Ch:11 Selected Dates

The 2003 Portland ITEC Show is December 10-11, 2003 at the
Oregon Convention Center. The show includes an Open Source
Pavilion where Linux/Open Source-focused companies can
participate at low cost (compared to the cost of normal
exhibit space). I'm handling the details of the Linux
Pavilion, so contact me for information or to sign up.

You can have 6 feet of table exhibit space for only $1000.
This also includes:

Company name listed on Portland ITEC web site
300 complimentary ITEC tickets for marketing purposes
ITEC e-ticket for marketing purposes
Open Source Pavilion banner above exhibit space
Carpet
Chair
Electricity

Note that normal exhibit space costs $2,195 per 10x10.
For small companies that can't afford the $1000, I'll be
coordinating the sharing of table space.

The Open Source Pavilion will be marketed on every ITEC
medium available (direct mail, email, e-tickets, hard tickets,
local Business Journal, etc.) ITEC expects to attract over
5,000 attendees.

Call me at 503-635-6370 for more information or to sign up.

Richard,

Here are the latest viruses found in the last 24 hours:

  W32.Swen.A at mm
  W32.Yaha.AB at mm
  W32.Moks
  W32.HLLW.Gaobot.AF
  Backdoor.IRC.RPCBot.F
  W32.Vybab at mm

Check sarc.com, do a search there to find out which one is pestering
you.

I'm just glad that Sobig.F finally took a break. We received 24,000
Sobig-infected emails in the past few weeks, but it has been tapering
off, and none have hit our mail server this week. That's not counting
the many thousands of emails from stupid postmasters telling me our
servers sent it to them, ignorant of the fact that Sobig.F spoofs the
sender email address.

-Scott

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Sep 18 12:59:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Sep 18 12:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
In-Reply-To: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I have 6 numbers that appear at the end of a line of text.  The 6 numbers
> may or may not have spaces between each.  So, for example, I could have:
>
> 1 234 5 6
> or
> 1234 56
>
> I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:
>
> $line =~
> s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;
>
> This works, but it's long and I'm curious if there's a shorter, more
> clever way.

Is this always six numbers and always last?

Assume your sting is $line.

my $foo = $line;

$foo =~ s/\s//g;

$foo = substr($foo,-6,6);

Doesn't that work?

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From freyley at gmx.net  Thu Sep 18 13:07:02 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu Sep 18 13:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1063915568.6224.27.camel@localhost>

On Thu, 2003-09-18 at 12:58, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > I have 6 numbers that appear at the end of a line of text.  The 6 numbers
> > may or may not have spaces between each.  So, for example, I could have:
> >
> > 1 234 5 6
> > or
> > 1234 56

> Doesn't that work?

Or, in a readable language, and without using regexes:

#!/usr/bin/python
# get your string from somewhere, save it in variable line

i=0, end=-1, numbers=""
while i < 6:
    if line[end] != " ":
        numbers = numbers + line[end]
        i = i + 1
    end = end - 1

Of course, you never said anything about this either running incredibly
quickly (this is okay, but poky compared to a regex) or that spaces were
the only non-numeric characters in the midst of those numbers. Plus you
wanted to put it in a bash script.

But I'm just having fun. =)

Jeff




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Sep 18 13:21:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Sep 18 13:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
In-Reply-To: <1063915568.6224.27.camel@localhost>

	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1063915568.6224.27.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <1063916453.9536.2.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2003-09-18 at 13:06, Jeff Schwaber wrote:

> Or, in a readable language, and without using regexes:
> 
> #!/usr/bin/python
> # get your string from somewhere, save it in variable line
> 
> i=0, end=-1, numbers=""
> while i < 6:
>     if line[end] != " ":
>         numbers = numbers + line[end]
>         i = i + 1
>     end = end - 1
> 
> Of course, you never said anything about this either running incredibly
> quickly (this is okay, but poky compared to a regex) or that spaces were
> the only non-numeric characters in the midst of those numbers. Plus you
> wanted to put it in a bash script.
> 
> But I'm just having fun. =)

It's faster to do a join on a list than to concatenate strings, if
you're doing it a lot.

Wil

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Sep 18 13:27:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Sep 18 13:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
In-Reply-To: <1063915568.6224.27.camel@localhost>
References: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net> <1063915568.6224.27.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309181311340.14172@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Jeff Schwaber wrote:

> But I'm just having fun. =)

That's part of the allure of the *nix culture. You can approach
problems with a variety of toolsets, combining them playfully. The
long-term benefit of that culture is that its members become
producers, not consumers, of the solutions.

I don't know the source of the old quip, but it seems to apply
somehow: "A football game is 50,000 spectators who desperately need
exercise sitting in the stands watching 22 men on the field who
desperately need rest."

It's only the folks who play who get any real benefit out the game;
for the rest, it's just a passing entertainment.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From stevn.bartley at ints.com  Thu Sep 18 14:30:05 2003
From: stevn.bartley at ints.com (Stevn Bartley)
Date: Thu Sep 18 14:30:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What Microsoft virus is rampant today?
In-Reply-To: <20030918194914.50491.qmail@web40803.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030918194914.50491.qmail@web40803.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1063920529.9501.6.camel@aragorn>

Here is a handy way to obtain current viri information if you host a web
site or intranet.  Paste the following into a page, create the link to
that page and there you go.  Instant information from symantec's virus
notification.

<script src="http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/js/vir.js"></script>
<script src="http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/js/tools.js"></script>
<script src="http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/js/advis.js"></script>
<script src="http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/js/vir_display.js"></script>
<script>symDisplay();</script>

From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Sep 18 14:52:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Sep 18 14:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
     <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <48286.68.107.223.201.1063920571.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

Jeme A Brelin said:
>
> On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
>> I have 6 numbers that appear at the end of a line of text.  The 6
>> numbers
>> may or may not have spaces between each.  So, for example, I could have:
>>
>> 1 234 5 6
>> or
>> 1234 56
>>
>> I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:
>>
>> $line =~
>> s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;
>>
>> This works, but it's long and I'm curious if there's a shorter, more
>> clever way.
>
> Is this always six numbers and always last?
>
> Assume your sting is $line.
>
> my $foo = $line;
>
> $foo =~ s/\s//g;
>
> $foo = substr($foo,-6,6);
>
> Doesn't that work?

Yep, very easy to read later too, much more so than Randal's solution.  ;-)

> I was able to view it using the following tools, all from a RH 9 install.
> 
> bash-2.05b$ gv -v
> gv 3.5.8
> bash-2.05b$ ghostscript --version
> 7.05
> bash-2.05b$ xpdf -v
> xpdf version 2.02
> Copyright 1996-2003 Glyph & Cog, LLC

Interesting... It doesn't seem to be doing it now.

Wil

From Trench-Shoring at gmx.net  Thu Sep 18 17:13:02 2003
From: Trench-Shoring at gmx.net (Trench Shoring)
Date: Thu Sep 18 17:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] clinic
In-Reply-To: <1063917422.6224.37.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <5.0.0.25.2.20030918165959.021754c8@mail.gmx.net>

FreeGeek has been getting a number of higher end, (900mhz), machines that 
will not post. MOST of them have bad capacitors. Look on your motherboard 
for the largest cylinders. If they are poofed up on top or have dried goo 
near the bottom you may be able to salvage it,

http://www.pcguide.com/intro/fun/z_000841capacitor.jpg

TS

At 01:37 PM 9/18/2003 -0700, you wrote:
>folks,
>
>is there a clinic on Saturday? Where? And finally, I have a very
>hardware-sick computer that I would like to bring, and was hoping
>someone might be bringing expertise and maybe a few parts to swap in for
>testing, or an actual testing device.
>
>The computer, which does not POST, is an AMD T-Bird 900 or 1100 mhz
>(forget), but 200 mhz fsb, with 133 mhz SDRAM. The motherboard was made
>by Soyo.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Sep 18 20:29:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Sep 18 20:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SMART Client
In-Reply-To: <1741.216.99.218.67.1063937110.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <1741.216.99.218.67.1063937110.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <5603-40648@sneakemail.com>

On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Josh Orchard josh-at-emediatedesigns.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I'm looking for a SMART HD client.  I had some I/O errors today and with
> all the talk about using SMART to assess the state of the HD I would
> like to check the SMART settings.  Does anyone know where I can get one?
> Is it built into linux?  I have RH 7.3.

Install the kernel-utils RPM.  It contains smartctl, smartd, and other
handy utilities.

> Also, without opening the computer how do I find out what HD I have in
> the machine. It has been like 4 years or longer.  I really don't know.

cat /proc/ide/hda/model

  -- Steve

Not unless you're using a prepackaged kernel maintained by someone who
cares to set such things.

My favorite way to see how many active processors you've got is to set the
thing to boot with framebuffer consoles and count the penguins!

only indicative of the kernel loaded and not the fact that both processers 
are enabled.

short time.

From dfb2001 at earthlink.net  Fri Sep 19 09:00:03 2003
From: dfb2001 at earthlink.net (Dan Beale)
Date: Fri Sep 19 09:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] transferring Mozilla email
Message-ID: <1063987125.7560.9.camel@osca>

Hello,

My primary email client is Mozilla running on my Windows laptop. Trouble
is, after a few months I get so much email & so many attachments that
Mozilla gets sluggish.  I moved my email directory to my Unix
workstation, which has 16+ Gig of RAM. I installed Mozilla on the Unix
workstation and muddled through getting it to read my email from the
laptop, with all folders preserved.  Despite the volume of email, the
workstation handles it easily, allowing searches, i.e. of text in the
body of an email message, that would cause my laptop Mozilla to hang.

Trouble is, I need to keep using my laptop as my primary email client
because I travel with it and plug it into the company network at remote
company sites or access email via my DSL at home.  How can I concatinate
the latest batch of laptop email to the email directory I've set up on
my Solaris workstation?  The email appears to be saved in text format
with some embedded binary encoding for attachments.  Can I simply
concatinate each email file from the laptop at the bottom of the
corresponding file on the workstation?

Thanks,

Dave Bienvenu

P.S. I have about 20 email folders set up that I need to preserve.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Sep 19 09:24:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri Sep 19 09:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] transferring Mozilla email
In-Reply-To: <1063987125.7560.9.camel@osca>
References: <1063987125.7560.9.camel@osca>
Message-ID: <20030919092350.05d8a3e7.russj@dimstar.net>

On 19 Sep 2003 08:58:45 -0700
Dan Beale <dfb2001 at earthlink.net> wrote:

> How can I concatinate
> the latest batch of laptop email to the email directory I've set up on
> my Solaris workstation?  The email appears to be saved in text format
> with some embedded binary encoding for attachments.

I use an IMAP pipe through a ssh connection. 

Alternatively, you could set up the windows box to get pop mail, but don't delete it from the server on the Windows box. When you get the mail on the Solaris machine, it will remove the mail from the server. 

The advantage of the IMAP method is both machines see the same mail spool/archive. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Top post? http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

Random thought #9 (Collect all 20)
"There is no knowledge that is not power." - Mortal Kombat Three

From danh at fork.com  Fri Sep 19 11:37:01 2003
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Fri Sep 19 11:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Announcement: Linux Clinic this Saturday (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0309191127410.18132-100000@cohiba.fork.com>


(Sorry for the tardy announcement!)


          *** Portland Linux User's Group (PLUG) Announcement ***
                                     
             The Linux Clinic - third Saturday of every month
                                     
    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.
                                     
                               Linux Clinic
                              October 20, 2003
                                1PM - 4PM

                          Riverdale High School
                        9727 SW Terwilliger Blvd,
                           Portland, Oregon 
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials
       
   For directions to the school see:
   http://www.riverdale.k12.or.us/info/direct.html
   
   For questions regarding the Clinics email Dan Haskell at:
   dhaskell at acm.org
   
   For information about PLUG or the Clinics see:
   http://www.pdxlinux.org

From icepirate at comcast.net  Fri Sep 19 11:43:02 2003
From: icepirate at comcast.net (icepirate at comcast.net)
Date: Fri Sep 19 11:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: How to determine if my dual processors are being recognized
Message-ID: <E1A0QCi-0001cY-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Well, it turns out uname -v will tell you if you have SMP enabled
and /proc/cpuinfo to find out the number reported.  With hyperthreading that
will double the number.

> ack, silly web client:
> On Fri, 19 Sep 2003, lemming wrote:
> 
> > uname -p might do the trick though.  I'm on a single proc right now,
> > but since it's telling me what type of proc I've got, I'm thinking
> > it might tell me if SMP is enabled.
> 
> fwiw, itt doesn't do anything for me. On my dual-PIII, it reads,
> 
>   [heinlein]$ uname -p
>   i686



From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Sep 19 12:34:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Sep 19 12:34:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ITEC sessions
Message-ID: <1063997439.14667.66.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I'm putting together the sessions for the Linux/Open Source
track at the ITEC show. The sessions are geared to people
who are fairly new to Linux and Open Source - not to the
experts on this list. With this in mind, I'm interested in
your opinions about the subjects Linux newbies should be
told about.

We're limited to four 1-hour sessions so apologies in advance
if I don't use your suggestion no matter how good it is.

Ed




From miken at hotsushi.com  Fri Sep 19 12:38:04 2003
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Fri Sep 19 12:38:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Linux classes at PCC start next week
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030915155706.023bcec0@www.hotsushi.com>

Hi,

Fall term starts next Monday and there are two Linux classes at PCC.

CIS240L is a Linux Installation and Configuration class covering the main 
tasks involved in setting up and administering a stand alone Linux 
box.  You should have a basic understanding of a *nix file system and basic 
command line utilities.  Two sections are offered, one on the Internet and 
one that meets at Sylvania from 6:00 PM to 9:00 PM on Monday nights.

CIS279L is a Linux Networking class covering TCP/IP plus network utilities, 
applications (NFS, Samba, DNS, DHCP, Apache, Sendmail, Postfix, etc.), 
troubleshooting and an introduction to security. One section is offered 
from 2 PM to 4 PM, Tuesday and Thursday.

Both classes are command line oriented and have lots of hands on labs.

Both classes

Go to www.pcc.edu and register online or just come to class and we'll 
figure it out from there.

Please e-mail me off list for more details or questions.

Thanks,
Mike Neal




From Brian at MartinConsulting.com  Fri Sep 19 12:38:27 2003
From: Brian at MartinConsulting.com (Brian P. Martin)
Date: Fri Sep 19 12:38:27 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <20030914134132.23121.72911.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <000101c37aec$f15b7840$156fa8c0@office>

>   Regardless of Web browsing, how is the card catalog run? It used to be
> 'dyna' and I could telnet to it from home. That suggests it's running on a
> non-Microsoft host somewhere central. If so, linux and the Web browser of
> your choice(s) would work just fine. OTOH, if it's a custom app running
> locally then it may work only with Microsoft.

I agree we should get involved in this, and I think Linux can probably
provide a good solution once we know the requirements.  Web browsing
services are trivial, of course.  Regarding the card catalogs, surely
someone else has already wrestled with this problem, either victoriously or
otherwise.  I think we need to make contact with the Library staff, find out
what the requirements are, and then do some research on what's already been
done before we try to reinvent the wheel.

Possibly related, Ed Sawicki is part of a new venture in which they have
customized the kernel to provide a "sealed system".  The basic idea is that
the O/S has an area (probably a partition) for binaries and such that it
will refuse to update.  This is supposed make it highly resistant to
viruses, user tampering, etc.  This also makes it very easy to lock down the
systems.  I'm not sure if we need this, but it might be valuable in a
public-computer setting.  It might increase the Library's costs, but Ed may
be willing to make some sort of arrangement in exchange for exposure,
advertising rights, etc.  Ed, obviously, can explain his product and it's
benefits better than I.

-Brian

-------------------------------------------
Brian P. Martin
Martin Consulting Services, Inc.
Telephone:  503-617-4500

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Fri Sep 19 19:33:01 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Fri Sep 19 19:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PDXLINUX Services Inturption
In-Reply-To: <3F6BB888.5010701@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309191930500.18609-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Fri, 19 Sep 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:

>Dale Zeutenhorst wrote:
>> Note to all - our ISP had a router melt down here in Vancouver and we have
>> been down for a few hours.
>
>Is the mail spool lost--should we resend stuff that never made it to the 
>list?  Or just "relax, don't worry, and have a homebrew"?

Relax & have a home brew. Your mail server will keep trying to send
the mail to the list for at least 48 hours (assuming you have a 
reasonable mail exchanger & the destination's mail exchanger has the
proper DNS records).

It may take an hour or two, however. Expect PLUG mail to trickle in
slowly and in an odd order. If you have a second homebrew, it might
not seem so odd ;-)


-Eric
