From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Sep 19 20:09:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Sep 19 20:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] postfix, virtual domains, and the ghost in the machine.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309191951540.20997@shaft.bitmine.net>

OK, I have a mail server at a remote site that is configured as the mail
host for several domains.  Authenticated ESMTP and IMAP and POP3 all seem
to work just dandily (SSL comes later).

HOWEVER...

One domain just doesn't want to work correctly.  The error message seems
to keep changing, though.

When I send mail to one of the domains from anywhere on the net, the
message is delivered fine.

But when I send mail to another domain, I get an error (more on that in a
moment).  However, I DO NOT get this error when I send from my home
machine and some few spammers seem to get through.

Roughly, the mail configuration follows the one described here:
<URL: http://www.marlow.dk/tech/postfix.php >

At first, the rejected mail was coming back with "553, sorry, that domain
is in my list of allowed rcpthosts" or similar.  So I made some changes to
the postfix_access table, that did nothing.  So I removed all entries from
that table... now the error message has changed and everything else
continues on in the same way.

550:  The domain to which you are trying to send does not exist.

Or words to that effect.

Near as I can tell, the domains are configured identically... and, again,
they BOTH WORK FINE when I mail from here (brelin.net, my house).

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org



From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Sep 19 20:14:02 2003
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri Sep 19 20:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ITEC sessions
In-Reply-To: <1064001010.16341.78.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1064001010.16341.78.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <2945.134.244.174.84.1064005437.squirrel@sautez.com>

> Pardon the possible duplicate message. I didn't see the
> first one come through.
>
> I'm putting together the sessions for the Linux/Open Source
> track at the ITEC show. The sessions are geared to people
> who are fairly new to Linux and Open Source - not to the
> experts on this list. With this in mind, I'm interested in
> your opinions about the subjects Linux newbies should be
> told about.
>
> We're limited to four 1-hour sessions so apologies in advance
> if I don't use your suggestion no matter how good it is.
>
> Ed

Ed,

A co-worker of mine is learning linux from an administration point of view.  My
first question to you would be if this was intended for end-users or Admins.  This
would help you determine what section is more important to teach in your 4 hours.

I'm guessing that you are thinking end-users.  In that case, the basics of KDE/GNOME
or some window manager is always the best and less threatening to anyone.  You could
show them the CLI as well.  In fact, I was just showing another admin how you set
things executible from the CLI yesterday.  He thought it was funny you needed to
know what the bits meant.  Which is true.

None the less, I would first decide which users you plan to address and then set up
a small good to know information.  Most end-users will want to know how to open a
file.  Where the editor is.  And many, how to run their application tool.  While the
admins should learn the basics of where files are installed and the file system
structure.

Josh



From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Sep 19 20:17:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Sep 19 20:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] postfix, virtual domains, and the ghost in the machine.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309191951540.20997@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309191951540.20997@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309192013390.20997@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 19 Sep 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Near as I can tell, the domains are configured identically... and,
> again, they BOTH WORK FINE when I mail from here (brelin.net, my house).

HA!

I found it!

I started reading PLUG to clear my head and NOT think about my mail
problem and I read the thread about mail to uce at ftc.gov not going through
properly... and then y'all go on to talk about the output for `host -t mx`
for the domain.

So I check the MX records on these domains, and SURE ENOUGH, the failing
domain has the wrong mail exchanger... and the MX host is a hostname that
resolves to the right address on my network, but not to the outside world!

I'm SURE that's going to solve it.

Is this going to take time to propogate?

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From ian at znark.com  Fri Sep 19 21:39:01 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Fri Sep 19 21:39:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] transferring Mozilla email
In-Reply-To: <1063987125.7560.9.camel@osca>
References: <1063987125.7560.9.camel@osca>
Message-ID: <3F6BD98E.3040208@znark.com>

Dan Beale wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> My primary email client is Mozilla running on my Windows laptop. Trouble
> is, after a few months I get so much email & so many attachments that
> Mozilla gets sluggish.  I moved my email directory to my Unix
> workstation, which has 16+ Gig of RAM. I installed Mozilla on the Unix
> workstation and muddled through getting it to read my email from the
> laptop, with all folders preserved.  Despite the volume of email, the
> workstation handles it easily, allowing searches, i.e. of text in the
> body of an email message, that would cause my laptop Mozilla to hang.
> 
> Trouble is, I need to keep using my laptop as my primary email client
> because I travel with it and plug it into the company network at remote
> company sites or access email via my DSL at home.  How can I concatinate
> the latest batch of laptop email to the email directory I've set up on
> my Solaris workstation?  The email appears to be saved in text format
> with some embedded binary encoding for attachments.  Can I simply
> concatinate each email file from the laptop at the bottom of the
> corresponding file on the workstation?
> 

Mozilla stores mail folders in the plain text mbox format.  The .msf 
files are temporary indexes and are reconstructed as needed.  I had no 
trouble copying all the files from Windows to Linux when I migrated my 
home machine.  You might have trouble keeping the two machines synchronized.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/




From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Sep 19 22:41:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Fri Sep 19 22:41:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Long Perl regex...
References: <47932.68.107.223.201.1063899364.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309181221020.9304@shaft.bitmine.net> <mailman.1063921940.4382.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <867k44hved.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Matt" == Matt Alexander <m at pdxlug.org> writes:

Matt> Jeme A Brelin said:
>> 
>> On Thu, 18 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
>>> I have 6 numbers that appear at the end of a line of text.  The 6
>>> numbers
>>> may or may not have spaces between each.  So, for example, I could have:
>>> 
>>> 1 234 5 6
>>> or
>>> 1234 56
>>> 
>>> I constructed the following regex to strip out the spaces:
>>> 
>>> $line =~
>>> s/(.*)([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?([0-9])\s?$/$2$3$4$5$6$7/;
>>> 
>>> This works, but it's long and I'm curious if there's a shorter, more
>>> clever way.
>> 
>> Is this always six numbers and always last?
>> 
>> Assume your sting is $line.
>> 
>> my $foo = $line;
>> 
>> $foo =~ s/\s//g;
>> 
>> $foo = substr($foo,-6,6);
>> 
>> Doesn't that work?

Matt> Yep, very easy to read later too, much more so than Randal's solution.  ;-)

Ahh, I misread the problem.  I'd write that as:

my $nums = $line;
$nums =~ tr/0-9//cd;
substr($nums, 0, -6) = "";

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Sep 20 14:03:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat Sep 20 14:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SATA Drives?
Message-ID: <1064091746.11810.303.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>


After having had my prejudices against IDE drives confirmed by Larry and
the papers Galen posted, I'm wondering where SATA drives fall.  I'm
seeing them offered in a lot of higher-end systems and with RAID
controllers and they're only slightly less expensive than SCSI.  I don't
know much about them, other than they're somehow ATA interfaces adapted
to a serial bus, like SSA or FCAL.  Are they being designed and
manufactured as Enterprise Storage devices, or Personal Storage?  Are
they so expensive just because they're still new?

Wil

From ian at znark.com  Sat Sep 20 18:46:02 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sat Sep 20 18:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SATA Drives?
In-Reply-To: <1064091746.11810.303.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <1064091746.11810.303.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <3F6D0286.70607@znark.com>

Wil Cooley wrote:
> After having had my prejudices against IDE drives confirmed by Larry and
> the papers Galen posted, I'm wondering where SATA drives fall.  I'm
> seeing them offered in a lot of higher-end systems and with RAID
> controllers and they're only slightly less expensive than SCSI.  I don't
> know much about them, other than they're somehow ATA interfaces adapted
> to a serial bus, like SSA or FCAL.  Are they being designed and
> manufactured as Enterprise Storage devices, or Personal Storage?  Are
> they so expensive just because they're still new?
> 

It looks like there are both enterprise and consumer SATA hard drives 
available.  The consumer ones are more common; they are 7200 RPM with 
80, 120, 180, etc sizes.  WD is selling a 36 GB, 10000 RPM ones 
described as Enterprise SATA.  The prices for the consumer SATA drives 
are only slightly more expensive ($10-30) than the equivalent IDE ones.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

I am not sure if there is currently a better method, but you've at
least got grep.  Just grab:

  <http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug.mbox/plug.mbox>

and away you go (at least back to about February 2002).  It's only
about 67 meg.  ;-)

I've personally accumulated raw data (thanks to generous
contributions) for the main PLUG list going back much further (with a
smattering of coverage back to at least mid-1995), but haven't
mustered the energy to finish cleaning it up.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep 21 13:51:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun Sep 21 13:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Replacement for bind
In-Reply-To: <1063773990.1980.22.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <20030916235918.GD22332@sthelens.dimstar.net> 
 <20030917041256.GA23049@wirex.net> <1063773990.1980.22.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309211347390.18808@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 16 Sep 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> This is a nice comprehensive list that he's put together. Just note that
> Rick is biased against tinydns.

He's biased against non-openness of either codebase or protocol.  I think
that's a reasonable bias to hold.

He doesn't just have a meaningless grudge.

> You can see this for yourself on the above referenced web page. He
> placed djbdns in the Proprietary category for two reasons. He doesn't
> like the fact that Bernstein doesn't use the GPL. It seems that he
> thinks that anything that is not GPL'ed is proprietary software.

How is DJB's license NOT proprietary?  Can I make changes and distribute
them without DJB's permission?  Then it's his property... proprietary to
him.

> He also believes that tinydns is not RFC-compliant because it doesn't
> support BIND-like zone transfers - and anything that is not
> RFC-compliant shouldn't be used. I disagree strongly with this assertion
> but I've failed to convince him otherwise.

Standards are what keep the network sane.  Interoperability should be the
number ONE goal of networking software (ahead of security, ease of use, or
efficiency).  It's about communicating, brother.

J.

Hello,
  How do I configure postfix to deliver mail to a particular address to
a program?  I've gotten as far as figuring out that I need to define a
transport in master.cf but how to I define a single address that will
use my new transport?

thanks,
Brent



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sun Sep 21 21:53:01 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sun Sep 21 21:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] postfix question
In-Reply-To: <1064205154.18626.23.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <1064205154.18626.23.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <1064206301.15845.33.camel@localhost>

On Sun, 2003-09-21 at 21:32, Brent Rieck wrote:

>   How do I configure postfix to deliver mail to a particular address to
> a program?  I've gotten as far as figuring out that I need to define a
> transport in master.cf but how to I define a single address that will
> use my new transport?

Deliver it to a program?  Like pipe it to something?

I think the way to do it is to put a .forward in that address' home
directory with the single line:

|/some/program/somewhere

Unless I misunderatnd your question... in which case I apologize.

Rob




From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep 21 22:04:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun Sep 21 22:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] postfix question
In-Reply-To: <1064205154.18626.23.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <1064205154.18626.23.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309212201440.18900@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 21 Sep 2003, Brent Rieck wrote:
>   How do I configure postfix to deliver mail to a particular address to
> a program?  I've gotten as far as figuring out that I need to define a
> transport in master.cf but how to I define a single address that will
> use my new transport?

Doesn't postfix use the same /etc/aliases syntax as sendmail?

address_alias:  "|/path/to/program"

You don't need a real user for that.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Sep 21 22:58:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun Sep 21 22:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] postfix question
In-Reply-To: <1064207285.15845.35.camel@localhost>
References: <1064205154.18626.23.camel@obelisk.spek.org> 
 <1064206301.15845.33.camel@localhost>  <1064207078.18626.29.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
 <1064207285.15845.35.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309212256170.25778@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 21 Sep 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Sun, 2003-09-21 at 22:04, Brent Rieck wrote:
>
> > No, you understand, and that sounds like a pretty simple way to do it,
> > but I don't want to have to create a user for each email address I want
> > to have.
>
> I understand now.  :-)
>
> I'm pretty sure Jeme's method is the way to do it.  If that doesn't
> work, I'll go googling.

That's the way to do it, but you may have to create a new aliases hash or
something.  Depends on how you've got your aliases loading in your
main.cf.

If you're doing virtual hosting, it's a bit trickier.  You have to
redirect the virtual address to a local alias and then set the local alias
to deliver to a pipe.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

It sounds like your SCSI controller may be helpfully limiting your drive
capacity.  I'd check your controller settings or try a different one.

Low-level formatting is very seldom needed.

  -- Steve

From lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com  Mon Sep 22 08:42:02 2003
From: lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com (lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com)
Date: Mon Sep 22 08:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SMART Client
Message-ID: <OF5580F3A9.71F4D4F1-ON88256DA9.00546FE0-88256DA9.00562E12@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>


>>>
>>>Yes I can run this command and get a report but the one drive does not
>> have an error
>>>log in the report because it says "
>>>
>>>Device does not support Error Logging
>>>Device does not support Self Test Logging
>>>
>>>
>>>So, is there another way to test that drive for errors?  I saw something
>>> like fsck
>>>-c /dev/hda1 will do some error checking but thought SMART would be a
>> better way.
>>>Perhaps rebuilding the server is in order.  But that will have to wait a
>>> few weeks.
>>>Just want some assurance that the drive will last three more weeks.
>>
>> I haven't used the program but is there an option for running self test?
>> Error Logging and Self Test Logging are newer options.
>>
>> If smartctl doesn't dump stuff in a user readable format then I might
have
>> to
>> hack something into it.  I don't thing there is any active development
on
>> it.
>
>I notice that the some drives are ATA 4. Well they be able to show as many
things as
>the rest?  Or work will with the SMART utilities?
>
ATA 4 drives will allow you to monitor smart but not with the detail that
later drives provide.

The ATA 4 spec did not include the Error Logging pages.
ATA 5 rev 1.0 did and it seemed (by the date on the doc) that
it was released in May 1999.  Drives produced prior to this could
have supported it but would have been non-standard.

The ATA spec is currently at ATA6.  ATA7 seems to be in review.
For your bedtime reading here is the standards web site for ATA spec.
http://www.t13.org/









From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Sep 22 08:53:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Sep 22 08:53:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming photo files
In-Reply-To: <1064236984.1193.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030922155214.63431.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>

I use the rename command. For example, my camera names files something
like DSCP000001.JPG, DSCP000002.JPG, etc. If these photos were from a
camping trip in, I might want them to be renamed camping_2003_01.jpg,
etc. This command would do them all in this fashion:

  rename "DSCP0000" "camping_2003_" *.JPG

One weirdness of the rename command... case pseudo-insensitivity. I
prefer all lowercase filenames on my web pages, so I like to rename
.JPG to .jpg. But if you try to rename ".JPG" to ".jpg" it will not see
the difference, and do nothing. To work around this, I'll first change
".JPG" to ".xxx", then change ".xxx" ".jpg".

-Scott

--- Dirk Ouellette <hapibeli at comcast.net> wrote:

> Olympus camera. The file numbers are always the same in the camera,
> So
> how would I rename all photos in a directory in one command to make
> room
> for the new photos?
> Dirk

In-Reply-To: <1064028497.11810.279.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

	 <1064028497.11810.279.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <1064247129.14667.415.camel@localhost.localdomain>

If you're a programmer and are either out of work or have
far less work than you need because of the economy, you
may be interested in a project to produce vertical market
applications that are extremely secure, are trivial to
install and upgrade, and easier to support than conventional
software. These will be commercial applications - not free
software. If you're interested, please contact me via e-mail
at ed at alcpress.com.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Sep 22 10:38:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Printing pdf files from the command line

  I suspect that the only way to print a pdf file is to display it in xpdf
or acroread and print it from there. Is there a one-step means of printing
the file directly from the command line?

  Yes, I could run it through pdf2ps then print the resulting postscript
file, but that puts another, much larger, file on the disk. I'd like to feed
output directly to the printer.

Just curious,

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Sep 22 10:57:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Sep 22 10:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming photo files
In-Reply-To: <20030922155214.63431.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <1064236984.1193.8.camel@localhost.localdomain> <20030922155214.63431.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030922175622.GA12278@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Mon, Sep 22, 2003 at 08:52:14AM -0700, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
> One weirdness of the rename command... case pseudo-insensitivity. I
> prefer all lowercase filenames on my web pages, so I like to rename
> .JPG to .jpg. But if you try to rename ".JPG" to ".jpg" it will not see
> the difference, and do nothing. To work around this, I'll first change
> ".JPG" to ".xxx", then change ".xxx" ".jpg".


Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe rename takes a perl
reg. to perform the substitution.  This should work (although I can't
test it at the moment):

rename 's/\.JPG/\.jpg/' *

or, more generally:

rename 's/\.[jJ][pP][gG]/\.jpg/' *

-Rogan

> 
> -Scott
>

> > my
> > Olympus camera. The file numbers are always the same in the camera,
> > So
> > how would I rename all photos in a directory in one command to make
> > room
> > for the new photos?

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Sep 22 11:00:03 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Sep 22 11:00:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Printing pdf files from the command line
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309221035080.16294@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309221055400.6584-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Mon, 22 Sep 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I suspect that the only way to print a pdf file is to display it in xpdf
> or acroread and print it from there. Is there a one-step means of printing
> the file directly from the command line?
>
>   Yes, I could run it through pdf2ps then print the resulting postscript
> file, but that puts another, much larger, file on the disk. I'd like to feed
> output directly to the printer.

  pdf2ps file.pdf - | lpr

Specifying an output file of '-' sends output to stdout, which is then
piped to lpr, which by default sends its stdin to the printer.


Glad you asked,
  A "ceci ne pas un |" B




From jmplug at sourtrout.com  Mon Sep 22 11:07:02 2003
From: jmplug at sourtrout.com (jmplug at sourtrout.com)
Date: Mon Sep 22 11:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <000101c37aec$f15b7840$156fa8c0@office>
References: <20030914134132.23121.72911.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <000101c37aec$f15b7840$156fa8c0@office>
Message-ID: <20030922190241.GA29542@sourtrout.com>

* Brian P. Martin <Brian at MartinConsulting.com> [2003-09-19 13:34]:
> >   Regardless of Web browsing, how is the card catalog run? It used to be
> > 'dyna' and I could telnet to it from home. That suggests it's running on a
> > non-Microsoft host somewhere central. If so, linux and the Web browser of
> > your choice(s) would work just fine. OTOH, if it's a custom app running
> > locally then it may work only with Microsoft.

Sounds like probably dynix.  (In fact, I'm pretty sure it is.  If we are
talking about the Beaverton library, I know the director.  Used to be my
boss, in fact.  Very cool, smart guy.  Was sad to see him move on.)  I
remember him saying that he wasn't very impressed with dynix (or whatever
they have), but that's what was there when he got there.  (I'm not familiar
with it myself, so I can't help much more there.)


But I can give you plenty of background info as far as what is involved in
running library systems in general, and the kinds of things you'll find in
the library market. So here goes...


Library automation software (what you are thinking of as the catalog,
but it is far more than that) is usually a very large investment.  High 5
figures at least.  Migrating from one to another is a pretty drastic
financial decision, and migrating is a major project.  It's like a heart
transplant for the library... even when fully smooth and successful there
will be repurcussions for a long time afterward.  Months, or even a year.
I've done 2.

As far a linux goes, there's two different aspects.  One is as a platform
for the LAS to run on.

Myself (and many other admins) have been working on trying to convince our
respective vendors that we'd like to see linux available as a platform
option for a number of years now.  (Going back 5 years at least.)  But they
all seem slow to adopt any new platforms.  Even NT/Win2K was slow to be
taken up, even with as many requests as they got from their customer base. 
(Mostly admin-less libraries were asking for that.)  -- Interestingly
enough, most of the ones that run on windows don't even use the Win32
subsystem or hardly anything beyond the kernel and tcp stack at all. 
They're sitting on posix or even cygwin.  You can strip the machine away to
practically nothing, and are far more stable than any other windows servers
I've ever seen. :)  Anyway, more traditionally they are Solaris, AIX, HP-UX,
etc.  Heck, the one we had forever was MPE/iX (HP3000 series).  It all
depends on the vendor.  You pick the software, THEN you pick an available
platform... Not the other way around.  But dammit, we've been asking for a
linux option for years.  They're starting to get softer on the idea as time
goes on, so eventually I'm sure we'll have it.

Here is a list of LAS vendors: http://libinfo.com/vendors-systems.html

Some of them I've never even heard of.  Here are some major players everyone
seems to know about.  Google should tell you more:

Ameritech Library Systems
- Dynix
- Horizon

Sirsi Corporation (of note: swallowed major competitor DRA a year ago)
- Unicorn (Sirsi's flagship LAS)
- Taos (was DRA flagship, being phased out and absorbed into Unicorn)
- DRA Classic (legacy)
- MultiLIS (legacy)
- Inlex (legacy)

Gaylord
- Polaris

III
The Library Corporation (TLC Carl)
Innovative


The other aspect of course, would be an open source library automation
system.  There are actually a number of projects dedicated to that purpose,
in various states of completion.  But none of them are anywhere near being
replacements for existing, establishes LAS's.  Yet.  There is one that is at
a point where it could be a choice for a small library that has never had
any automation before... And that is the niche it is currently filling. 
Many MLS (actual librarians - Masters in Library Science degrees and all of
that) types that are programmers are working on bits and pieces that may
eventually fill in the gaps and provide a base for a full system to be built
on.  (Sort of like the GNU compiler and tools had to be there before
building anything else useful on top of them.)  I fully believe we'll have
one someday, but it is a long way off.  

Another note... Any web-based OPAC is usually somewhat tied to the LAS.  You can't
get away with setting up the Apache/linux box for to handle it, because
it'll probably need to run binary cgi's provided by the vendor in order to
interoperate.  Although many nowadays will let you choose which webserver
software you like.  And Apache will work, of course.


> I think Linux can probably provide a good solution once we know the
requirements.

The area most primed for some linux solutions is the public workstations. 
(As you've probably guessed, and seem to be focusing on anyway.  That's
good.)

I'm not going to go on about what might or might not work in a public
environment...  I'm sure any talented person can figure that out.




But here are some things that might be hangups, or things to watch out for:

- Of course, the setup needs to be as indesctructible and locked down as
possible.  Allow the user to do everything they need to do, but nothing they
don't.  The basic requirement is that when they log out (or otherwise tell
the machine they are finished) the machine should remain exactly as it was
before they started.  So that the next patrons has the same fully functional
not-screwed-up-by-someone-else mahine that the first got.

- Patrons will want to save stuff on disks.  Mounting/unmounting will need
to be automatic.

- The library probably has metering/tracking software of some kind.  This
stuff simply keeps counts of application usage (like simple tickmarks... Not
"who used what").  This is needed for statistical purposes (which in turn
means budget).  You know, to show that your services are actually being
used.  State reports want that info, too.

- They might also have a system where authentication to use the machine is
dependent on their library card number.  (Or a guest pass).  Which means
authenticating against the LAS somehow.  (Or simply against a text file
generated by a report on the LAS, and staged where accessible to the public
machine authentication system.  This is an old trick to avoid paying the
astronomical amounts of money vendors seem to want for a "patron
authentication server".  Which is is an LAS service designed to answer
authentication queries from 3rd party software. Grrr.)  In addition, there
may be time-limits involved.  Which can vary wildly.  (Certain machines may
have different time-limits.  Others may have none.  Patrons may be allowed a
certain amount of time for every individual machine, or category of
machines, etc.  Maybe a single time limit for usage of all computers usage. 
Or a nifty combination of all of the above.  15 minutes on those, 1 hour on
these, and 4 on those.  But never to exceed a grand total of 4.)  Lastly,
routing internet access through proxies etc may also depend on the patrons
age.  You can guess what that all means.

- There may be database or reasearch applications (things like encarta,
world book, and many library market stuff you may have never heard of) that
simply require their own windows client program.  End of story.  Sucks, but
all too true.  If it can be run in WINE, great.  If not, you're screwed. 
Unless they can be relegated to a few windows machines, while the others go
linux.  This is less of a problem than it used to be, though.  More and more
of these types of programs and services are becoming web-based all the time. 
Which is great for many reasons.  One is platform independence.  The other
is less work.  (The library doesn't have to run around anywhere updating
that data quarterly, monthly, or whatever.)

- Print control!  Some libraries control print costs by charging patrons for
pages printed beyond a certain amount.  Many do this in a low-tech fashion
(either honor system, or make you have to physically retrieve the pages from
a librarian).  But there are a lot of ways this is handled electronically. 
Sometimes tied to your library account, sometimes separate.  At any rate,
many libraries will need a print cost management system.

A lot of these issues are currently handled by software available for
windows desktops.  So if proposing switching them to another platform,
you'll need to be prepared to address them as well.

That's all I can think of at the moment.  I'm sure there's more, but those
are the biggies that spring to mind.  (Note: we don't necessarily do all of
that here.  But all libraries are different, and those are some of the
things you may find.)



> Regarding the card catalogs, surely someone else has already wrestled with
this problem,

There are going to be a few different catagories of access to the LAS.  When
you are referring to the card catalog, you are probably meaning the
interface that the public uses to search it for what they want.  Perhaps
also to place holds, renew items, etc.  This is usually called the OPAC. 
(Online Public Access Catalog.)  Most of them are web based nowadays, and
they don?t tend to be very browser specific.  A stripped and locked down
browser-only linux box that can only access a single site (the catalog)
would go a long way in that market.

The other interfaces are going to be what the staff uses for circulation,
cataloging, report building, acquisitions, configuration (policies, staff
accounts and access, patron account management, circ maps, hold filling
behavior, etc, etc), and maintenance utilities.  Sometimes they are all
accessible from one app, some systems have separate apps.  Unfortunately the
vast majority of these are going to be windows apps.  Perhaps WINE would be
able to run some of them.

> I think we need to make contact with the Library staff, find out
what the requirements are, and then do some research on what's already been
done before we try to reinvent the wheel.

There you go.  I'd love to see linux solutions available for the libraries. 
It'd be more stable, less work (less time fixing problems = more time to
improve services), and less cost in the long run.  I know other library
geeks that would love nothing more than to rip windows systems out and put
linux boxes in their place.  It's just that some of the stuff we need isn't
available, or just simply hasn't been put together with the parts that are
there.  And I certainly don?t have time to work on it.  (I'm taking enough
time just pounding out this email as it is.)  I'd love nothing more than to
be able to kiss my windows boxes goodbye! :)




From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Sep 22 11:08:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Sep 22 11:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] ITEC sessions
In-Reply-To: <1064028497.11810.279.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <1064001010.16341.78.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1064028497.11810.279.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <1064254629.16341.471.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2003-09-19 at 20:28, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Fri, 2003-09-19 at 12:50, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> > I'm putting together the sessions for the Linux/Open Source
> > track at the ITEC show. The sessions are geared to people
> > who are fairly new to Linux and Open Source - not to the
> > experts on this list. With this in mind, I'm interested in
> > your opinions about the subjects Linux newbies should be
> > told about.
> > 
> > We're limited to four 1-hour sessions so apologies in advance
> > if I don't use your suggestion no matter how good it is.
> 
> Are you looking only for ideas or are you looking for presenters too? 
> Are you looking more for tutorial how-to stuff, or broader descriptions
> of the things one can do with open source software?

The latter I think.
We're assuming that the audience will be mostly Windows-centric
people. Historically, that is correct for ITEC. Therefore, we
want to present topics and do demonstrations that show these
people that Linux/Open Source-based systems (desktops and servers)
are better. 

We should focus on how Linux/OSS-based systems are secure,
reliable, low-cost, and can do cool things. For example, UMLs
allow things that Windows systems cannot do. X allows remote
desktops while Windows can only do this with (usually)
extra-cost software and per-seat licenses. The Windows NTFS
file system allows users/attackers to hide files from an
administrator, while Linux file systems cannot.

I'm thinking that instead of one speaker per session, we'll
have one main speaker that introduces other speakers who then
do short presentations and demonstrations on a particular
feature of Linux/OSS.

We're not going to go into a lot of technical detail in the 1-hour
sessions but there is time between sessions for people to ask the
Linux experts/enthusiasts in the room. 

Ed




From david.fleck at mchsi.com  Mon Sep 22 11:10:02 2003
From: david.fleck at mchsi.com (David Fleck)
Date: Mon Sep 22 11:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming photo files
In-Reply-To: <20030922175622.GA12278@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <1064236984.1193.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
 <20030922155214.63431.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>
 <20030922175622.GA12278@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <20030922130445.Y1035@grond.sourballs.org>

On Mon, 22 Sep 2003, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe rename takes a perl
> reg. to perform the substitution.  This should work (although I can't
> test it at the moment):

I think you're wrong.  Doesn't work on the RedHat 9.0 machine I just
tried; rename is a binary file.  You may be thinking of a small,
commonly-used perl script that behaves the way that you mention:

#!/usr/bin/perl -w
# rename - Larry's filename fixer
$op = shift or die "Usage: rename expr [files]\n";
chomp(@ARGV = <STDIN>) unless @ARGV;
for (@ARGV) {
    $was = $_;
    eval $op;
    die $@ if $@;
    rename($was,$_) unless $was eq $_;
}
#-----------------------------
#% rename 's/\.orig$//'  *.orig
#% rename 'tr/A-Z/a-z/ unless /^Make/'  *
#% rename '$_ .= ".bad"'  *.f
#% rename 'print "$_: "; s/foo/bar/ if <STDIN> =~ /^y/i'  *
#% find /tmp -name '*~' -print | rename 's/^(.+)~$/.#$1/'
#-----------------------------
#% rename 'use locale; $_ = lc($_) unless /^Make/' *
#-----------------------------


 --
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Sep 22 12:19:02 2003

> xpdf or acroread and print it from there. Is there a one-step means of

Um, aren't you using one of the automatic filters?  Foomatic, autofilter,
or the like will just plain do the right thing.

`lp file.pdf`

Of course, you won't get this because you plonked all my mail out of

From freyley at gmx.net  Mon Sep 22 12:37:01 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Mon Sep 22 12:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Vertical Market Applications
In-Reply-To: <1064247129.14667.415.camel@localhost.localdomain>

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Mon Sep 22 12:40:05 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Mon Sep 22 12:40:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <20030922190241.GA29542@sourtrout.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309221234200.6611-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>


You sound like an expert in this area.

Have you heard of the Koha project:

http://pate.eylerfamily.org/geek/Koha.html

Blurb from the koha page:

The Koha Project is a free library automation system. It was originally 
developed by Katipo Communications for the Horowhenua Library Trust. Since 
it's inception, it has been installed at a number of libraries around the 
world.

The guy who runs the Koha project (Pat Eyler) is up in Seattle.  I've met 
him a few times.

Phil

On Mon, 22 Sep 2003 jmplug at sourtrout.com wrote:

> 
> Sounds like probably dynix.  (In fact, I'm pretty sure it is.  If we are
> talking about the Beaverton library, I know the director.  Used to be my
> boss, in fact.  Very cool, smart guy.  Was sad to see him move on.)  I
> remember him saying that he wasn't very impressed with dynix (or whatever
> they have), but that's what was there when he got there.  (I'm not familiar
> with it myself, so I can't help much more there.)
> 
> 
> But I can give you plenty of background info as far as what is involved in
> running library systems in general, and the kinds of things you'll find in
> the library market. So here goes...
> 
> 
> Library automation software (what you are thinking of as the catalog,
> but it is far more than that) is usually a very large investment.  High 5
> figures at least.  Migrating from one to another is a pretty drastic
> financial decision, and migrating is a major project.  It's like a heart
> transplant for the library... even when fully smooth and successful there
> will be repurcussions for a long time afterward.  Months, or even a year.
> I've done 2.
> 
> As far a linux goes, there's two different aspects.  One is as a platform
> for the LAS to run on.
> 
> Myself (and many other admins) have been working on trying to convince our
> respective vendors that we'd like to see linux available as a platform
> option for a number of years now.  (Going back 5 years at least.)  But they
> all seem slow to adopt any new platforms.  Even NT/Win2K was slow to be
> taken up, even with as many requests as they got from their customer base. 
> (Mostly admin-less libraries were asking for that.)  -- Interestingly
> enough, most of the ones that run on windows don't even use the Win32
> subsystem or hardly anything beyond the kernel and tcp stack at all. 
> They're sitting on posix or even cygwin.  You can strip the machine away to
> practically nothing, and are far more stable than any other windows servers
> I've ever seen. :)  Anyway, more traditionally they are Solaris, AIX, HP-UX,
> etc.  Heck, the one we had forever was MPE/iX (HP3000 series).  It all
> depends on the vendor.  You pick the software, THEN you pick an available
> platform... Not the other way around.  But dammit, we've been asking for a
> linux option for years.  They're starting to get softer on the idea as time
> goes on, so eventually I'm sure we'll have it.
> 
> Here is a list of LAS vendors: http://libinfo.com/vendors-systems.html
> 
> Some of them I've never even heard of.  Here are some major players everyone
> seems to know about.  Google should tell you more:
> 
> Ameritech Library Systems
> - Dynix
> - Horizon
> 
> Sirsi Corporation (of note: swallowed major competitor DRA a year ago)
> - Unicorn (Sirsi's flagship LAS)
> - Taos (was DRA flagship, being phased out and absorbed into Unicorn)
> - DRA Classic (legacy)
> - MultiLIS (legacy)
> - Inlex (legacy)
> 
> Gaylord
> - Polaris
> 
> III
> The Library Corporation (TLC Carl)
> Innovative
> 
> 
> The other aspect of course, would be an open source library automation
> system.  There are actually a number of projects dedicated to that purpose,
> in various states of completion.  But none of them are anywhere near being
> replacements for existing, establishes LAS's.  Yet.  There is one that is at
> a point where it could be a choice for a small library that has never had
> any automation before... And that is the niche it is currently filling. 
> Many MLS (actual librarians - Masters in Library Science degrees and all of
> that) types that are programmers are working on bits and pieces that may
> eventually fill in the gaps and provide a base for a full system to be built
> on.  (Sort of like the GNU compiler and tools had to be there before
> building anything else useful on top of them.)  I fully believe we'll have
> one someday, but it is a long way off.  
> 
> Another note... Any web-based OPAC is usually somewhat tied to the LAS.  You can't
> get away with setting up the Apache/linux box for to handle it, because
> it'll probably need to run binary cgi's provided by the vendor in order to
> interoperate.  Although many nowadays will let you choose which webserver
> software you like.  And Apache will work, of course.
> 
> 
> > I think Linux can probably provide a good solution once we know the
> requirements.
> 
> The area most primed for some linux solutions is the public workstations. 
> (As you've probably guessed, and seem to be focusing on anyway.  That's
> good.)
> 
> I'm not going to go on about what might or might not work in a public
> environment...  I'm sure any talented person can figure that out.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> But here are some things that might be hangups, or things to watch out for:
> 
> - Of course, the setup needs to be as indesctructible and locked down as
> possible.  Allow the user to do everything they need to do, but nothing they
> don't.  The basic requirement is that when they log out (or otherwise tell
> the machine they are finished) the machine should remain exactly as it was
> before they started.  So that the next patrons has the same fully functional
> not-screwed-up-by-someone-else mahine that the first got.
> 
> - Patrons will want to save stuff on disks.  Mounting/unmounting will need
> to be automatic.
> 
> - The library probably has metering/tracking software of some kind.  This
> stuff simply keeps counts of application usage (like simple tickmarks... Not
> "who used what").  This is needed for statistical purposes (which in turn
> means budget).  You know, to show that your services are actually being
> used.  State reports want that info, too.
> 
> - They might also have a system where authentication to use the machine is
> dependent on their library card number.  (Or a guest pass).  Which means
> authenticating against the LAS somehow.  (Or simply against a text file
> generated by a report on the LAS, and staged where accessible to the public
> machine authentication system.  This is an old trick to avoid paying the
> astronomical amounts of money vendors seem to want for a "patron
> authentication server".  Which is is an LAS service designed to answer
> authentication queries from 3rd party software. Grrr.)  In addition, there
> may be time-limits involved.  Which can vary wildly.  (Certain machines may
> have different time-limits.  Others may have none.  Patrons may be allowed a
> certain amount of time for every individual machine, or category of
> machines, etc.  Maybe a single time limit for usage of all computers usage. 
> Or a nifty combination of all of the above.  15 minutes on those, 1 hour on
> these, and 4 on those.  But never to exceed a grand total of 4.)  Lastly,
> routing internet access through proxies etc may also depend on the patrons
> age.  You can guess what that all means.
> 
> - There may be database or reasearch applications (things like encarta,
> world book, and many library market stuff you may have never heard of) that
> simply require their own windows client program.  End of story.  Sucks, but
> all too true.  If it can be run in WINE, great.  If not, you're screwed. 
> Unless they can be relegated to a few windows machines, while the others go
> linux.  This is less of a problem than it used to be, though.  More and more
> of these types of programs and services are becoming web-based all the time. 
> Which is great for many reasons.  One is platform independence.  The other
> is less work.  (The library doesn't have to run around anywhere updating
> that data quarterly, monthly, or whatever.)
> 
> - Print control!  Some libraries control print costs by charging patrons for
> pages printed beyond a certain amount.  Many do this in a low-tech fashion
> (either honor system, or make you have to physically retrieve the pages from
> a librarian).  But there are a lot of ways this is handled electronically. 
> Sometimes tied to your library account, sometimes separate.  At any rate,
> many libraries will need a print cost management system.
> 
> A lot of these issues are currently handled by software available for
> windows desktops.  So if proposing switching them to another platform,
> you'll need to be prepared to address them as well.
> 
> That's all I can think of at the moment.  I'm sure there's more, but those
> are the biggies that spring to mind.  (Note: we don't necessarily do all of
> that here.  But all libraries are different, and those are some of the
> things you may find.)
> 
> 
> 
> > Regarding the card catalogs, surely someone else has already wrestled with
> this problem,
> 
> There are going to be a few different catagories of access to the LAS.  When
> you are referring to the card catalog, you are probably meaning the
> interface that the public uses to search it for what they want.  Perhaps
> also to place holds, renew items, etc.  This is usually called the OPAC. 
> (Online Public Access Catalog.)  Most of them are web based nowadays, and
> they don?t tend to be very browser specific.  A stripped and locked down
> browser-only linux box that can only access a single site (the catalog)
> would go a long way in that market.
> 
> The other interfaces are going to be what the staff uses for circulation,
> cataloging, report building, acquisitions, configuration (policies, staff
> accounts and access, patron account management, circ maps, hold filling
> behavior, etc, etc), and maintenance utilities.  Sometimes they are all
> accessible from one app, some systems have separate apps.  Unfortunately the
> vast majority of these are going to be windows apps.  Perhaps WINE would be
> able to run some of them.
> 
> > I think we need to make contact with the Library staff, find out
> what the requirements are, and then do some research on what's already been
> done before we try to reinvent the wheel.
> 
> There you go.  I'd love to see linux solutions available for the libraries. 
> It'd be more stable, less work (less time fixing problems = more time to
> improve services), and less cost in the long run.  I know other library
> geeks that would love nothing more than to rip windows systems out and put
> linux boxes in their place.  It's just that some of the stuff we need isn't
> available, or just simply hasn't been put together with the parts that are
> there.  And I certainly don?t have time to work on it.  (I'm taking enough
> time just pounding out this email as it is.)  I'd love nothing more than to
> be able to kiss my windows boxes goodbye! :)
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

> command? I find the reg. exp's to be invaluable for complex
> renaming..

Slightly aside: Red Hat's rename (/usr/bin/rename) comes as part of
the util-linux package, while Debian's appears to be part of the Perl
distribution. That'd explain the differences, for sure...

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Sep 22 13:03:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Sep 22 13:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming photo files
In-Reply-To: <1064236984.1193.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1064236984.1193.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <8665jk8uci.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Dirk" == Dirk Ouellette <hapibeli at comcast.net> writes:

Dirk> I now understand why the same photos show up when I mount
Dirk> /dev/sda1, my Olympus camera. The file numbers are always the
Dirk> same in the camera, So how would I rename all photos in a
Dirk> directory in one command to make room for the new photos? 

As the many answers indicate, there are many solutions to this
problem.  

The one I adopted is just to create a new directory for each camera
download.  The directory is named with a date in YYYYMMDD format.  If
I download the camera more than once in a day, I append a letter 'b',
'c', 'd', and so on to distinguish them.  The camera seems to notice
when it's been cleared and starts renumbering from zero again.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''



From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Sep 22 13:08:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Sep 22 13:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] custom scoring with spamassassin
In-Reply-To: <1064260270.2297.107.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1064260270.2297.107.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309221255540.29888@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 22 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I want to alter the weighting of the tests spamassassin assesses
> when an email fails one of it's tests.

In descending order of good taste and maintainability, try editing

* $HOME/.spamassassin/user_prefs
* <prefix>/spamassassin/user_prefs.template
* the actual rules file in <prefix>/spamassassin

On a Red Hat box, <prefix> == /usr/share; I can't speak for other
installations.

The Mail::SpamAssassin::Conf man/perldoc page will tell you how it's
done, but let's say that wanted to increase the point count for a
message containing the term 'viagra' in the subject line (rule name is
SUBJ_VIAGRA).

The default score is

  SUBJ_VIAGRA 2.896 2.592 1.878 3.482

To raise it to, say, 3.50 in all cases, then

  echo "score SUBJ_VIAGRA 3.50" >> $HOME/.spamassassin/user_prefs

Does that help?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From bsr at spek.org  Mon Sep 22 13:11:02 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Mon Sep 22 13:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] custom scoring with spamassassin
In-Reply-To: <1064260270.2297.107.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1064260270.2297.107.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1064261361.18626.121.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 12:51, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I want to alter the weighting of the tests spamassassin assesses when an
> email fails one of it's tests.

to do it just for your account look in ~/.spamassassin/user_prefs you'll
find some examples I believe towards the end that look something like
this:

        score DISGUISE_PORN 4
        score HTML_FONT_COLOR_UNSAFE 5
        score MIME_HTML_ONLY 3
        score FROM_ENDS_IN_NUMS 3
        

--Brent

From bsr at spek.org  Mon Sep 22 13:40:02 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Sep 22 13:42:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Sep 22 13:46:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Sep 22 13:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] postfix question
In-Reply-To: <1064263107.18626.152.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <1064205154.18626.23.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309212201440.18900@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1064214912.18626.33.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
	 <1064263107.18626.152.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <1064263505.11810.316.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 13:38, Brent Rieck wrote:
> Adding an alias that pipes to a program works like a charm, sorta..  
> The program runs fine from the command line when I pipe a raw email to
> it but won't execute when invoked by postfix, bouncing back with this
> message: "Command died with status 1:"
> 
> Does anybody know why this might be happening?

It sounds like your filter might be exiting with a non-zero return
value.  Try 'echo $?' right after running it by hand to see.  If that's
the case and the filter is written to return 1 on normal exit, you can
write a little shell wrapper that runs the program and checks it's
return value, returning 0 instead of 1 on normal exit.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

> > email fails one of it's tests.
> 
> to do it just for your account look in ~/.spamassassin/user_prefs you'll
> find some examples I believe towards the end that look something like
> this:
> 
>         score DISGUISE_PORN 4
>         score HTML_FONT_COLOR_UNSAFE 5
>         score MIME_HTML_ONLY 3
>         score FROM_ENDS_IN_NUMS 3
>         
> 
For system-wide instead of per-user settings, put these lines in file 
/etc/mail/spamassassin/local.cf.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Sep 22 13:55:02 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon Sep 22 13:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Strange hard drive capacity 2048GB !? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 22 Sep 2003 13:41:11 PDT."
             <1064263270.11810.312.camel@denk.nakedape.priv> 
Message-ID: <20030922205404.F32C98F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> wrote:

> On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 00:00, Steve Bonds wrote:
> 
> > Low-level formatting is very seldom needed.
> 
> The only time I've had to do it is when we bought a box of IBM drives
> from eBay that were formatted with 520 byte blocks, apparently pulled
> from an AS/400 or S/390 or some larger DASD installation than I've ever
> seen.
> 

I had something somewhat similar happen with an Ultra 60 system.  It was a 
refurbished machine, and the vendor had installed a 36GB IBM drive.
When I started installing Solaris 8, the drive was showing up as
~9GB.  It turns out that the drive had some sort of EDS disk type written
to the disk label.  Once I changed the type back to IBM and rewrote
the disk label, everything was back to normal.

galen

From felix.1 at canids.net  Mon Sep 22 14:25:19 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Mon Sep 22 14:25:19 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Renaming photo files
In-Reply-To: <20030922181631.GC12278@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU> on Mon, 22 Sep 2003 11:16:32 PDT.
Message-ID: <20030922212435.9C4C31584A0@kanga.canids.net>

Rogan Creswick <creswick at cs.orst.edu>:
> Good to know!  Does anyone know of an advantage to the binary rename
> command? I find the reg. exp's to be invaluable for complex renaming..

Perhaps the advantage is you don't need to know perl?

If you want to do more complex renaming than the perl rename
script can handle, I have a perl script
    http://canids.net/felix/cmv
that knows how to do tricks like
    cmv 'tr/xyz/yzx/' x y z
without losing any of the files.  You can also do tricks like
    cmv -d 's(-)(/)g' *
to split files into subdirectories.
--

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Sep 22 16:16:01 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon Sep 22 16:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SMART Client (SCSI drives)
In-Reply-To: <OF5580F3A9.71F4D4F1-ON88256DA9.00546FE0-88256DA9.00562E12@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>
References: <OF5580F3A9.71F4D4F1-ON88256DA9.00546FE0-88256DA9.00562E12@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>
Message-ID: <19857-94397@sneakemail.com>

One of the things I've noticed with "smartctl" is its limited support for
SCSI drives.  Larry mentioned in his presentation (a great one, BTW) that
most SCSI drives have additional diagnostics above and beyond SMART.
Unfortunately, I've been unable to find any information about standardized
diagnostics on SCSI drives aside from SMART.

Does anyone on the list (maybe even Larry) have suggestions on ways of
monitoring SCSI drives for impending failure?  Why is the SCSI support for
smartctl so limited?  Is this a limitation in the SMART implementaion for
SCSI drives, or just lack of coding within the smartctl application?

Pointers to more information are appreciated, particularly since smartctl
seems to be abandoned and poorly documented.  (Code is from Sep 2000, with
minor updates made Sep 2001. http://sourceforge.net/projects/smartsuite/)

  -- Steve

I'm running RedHat 6, and while booting, it gives me these messages, and fails 
to bring up the network:

Loading ne2k-pci module
ne2k-pci.c: author, etc.
ne2k-pci.c: No usable cards found, driver NOT installed.
/lib/ne2k-pci.o: init_module: Device or resource busy
Hint: insmod errors can be caused by incorrect module paramters,
including invalid IO or IRQ parameters

I have tried several kinds of network cards, and I know that at least some of 
them work, but I get the same message for all of them.

After booting, I do an insmod command and get the same errors.
I do an lsof to see if ne2k-pci.o is really busy, but it doesn't show up.

Any ideas?

Roger Vanderveen

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Sep 22 17:07:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] Graphic file shrinking
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309221700290.17330@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I have a Web page that I printed to a disk file (*.ps). Then I trimmed
away the unwanted text and other stuff which left the image itself. That I
ran through ps2eps. No problems here.

  However, the file size is 25M! I've tried loading it in xfig and tgif to
see if I can find out why it's so large and if it's possible to reduce the
size while not messing up the image itself. Neither application will display
it; only a box with the fully qualified file name.

  Because ps and eps are vector formats I suspect that The GIMP would not do
a very good job of manipulating the image without removing clarity or
otherwise degrading it.

  I know that some of you have extensive graphics experience so I'm looking
for advice on whether such a large file might contain bloat that could be
removed and, if so, how I would go about doing this.

From list at sonofhans.net  Mon Sep 22 18:32:01 2003
From: list at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Mon Sep 22 18:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Graphic file shrinking
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309221700290.17330@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309221700290.17330@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030922183156.19efe3ee.list@sonofhans.net>

Thus spoke Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>
( Mon, 22 Sep 2003 17:05:44 -0700 (PDT) ):

> I have a Web page that I printed to a disk file (*.ps). Then I
> trimmed away the unwanted text and other stuff which left the
> image itself.

It bugs me sometimes when people respond by trying to redefine the
question instead of answering it.  So I'll save that for the end :)

> However, the file size is 25M! I've tried loading it in xfig and
> tgif to see if I can find out why it's so large

The size isn't surprising.  It's easy to get a raster image from a
vector; going the other way is difficult even for trivial images.  I'm
not sure how you printed your PS file, but it likely contains nothing
but thousands of single-color entity descriptions.  Vector formats
aren't optimized for this:  the description for each pixel/line/entity
is very heavy compared with linear raster formats (e.g. TIFF).

> and if it's possible to reduce the size while not messing up the
> image itself.

You can rasterize it (going full-circle) or edit it by hand in a
vector-manipulation program (e.g. KIllustrator, or whatever it's
called now).  The first option is pointless, since you could trivially
get the original raster image (unless I'm wrong -- see below).  The
second option would take forever.

Most vector-manipulation programs have ways of simplifying images, and
I'm sure there are command-line tools available, but I've not seen any
that are very good.  Unless you're writing your own AI image-
recognition tool for this job you'll have a hard time of it.

> Because ps and eps are vector formats I suspect that The GIMP would
> not do a very good job of manipulating the image without removing
> clarity or otherwise degrading it.

I suspect you're right.

> I know that some of you have extensive graphics experience so I'm
> looking for advice on whether such a large file might contain bloat
> that could be removed and, if so, how I would go about doing this.

See up a couple paragraphs.  If there's a way I don't know of it.

It really sounds like you're making a lot of work for youself.  If you
only want the image all browsers I know of [that display images] will
let you save them individually.  If you're looking for a production
solution (i.e. many many images), 'wget' should do just what you want,
even if it's a dynamically-created image.

If it's something nastier, like an image displayed in Java or Flash,
then I bet you're going to be better off getting a screen dump than
doing through the print/parse routine.  Even screen dumps can be
automated.

HTH,

Randall

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Mon Sep 22 20:35:02 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Mon Sep 22 20:35:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Science lesson for the day: What is a Caldera?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309222012540.16917-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

I was just checking out some of the images that Galileo took of volcanic
activity on Io[1], one of Jupiter's moons.

One of NASA's Jet Propulsion Labs pages[2] covers plumes, calderas, and
flows. The caption released with the image defines a caldera:
 
   What's a caldera? Calderas are large, usually roughly circular
   depressions that form by collapse over shallow magma chambers that
   have been partially emptied by volcanic eruptions.

So as far as I understand it, if you start off with a shallow base and
then spew toxic fumes/magma into the environment, structural integrity
will be compromised and the whole mess will collapse upon itself leaving
a big stinking hole in the ground. That is how a caldera is made.

On Earth the process is similiar, except you start off with a Caldera,
spew toxic fumes/magma, and have the whole mess collapse upon itself
leaving a big, stinking hole in the ground. Some observers have referred
to the results as a Santa Cruz.

This concludes today's science lesson.

-Eric

[1] http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/galileo/images/io/ioplume.html
[2] http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA02566




From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Mon Sep 22 23:28:02 2003
From: kevintheobald at vzavenue.net (Kevin Theobald)
Date: Mon Sep 22 23:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <20030922190241.GA29542@sourtrout.com>
References: <20030914134132.23121.72911.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	<000101c37aec$f15b7840$156fa8c0@office>
	<20030922190241.GA29542@sourtrout.com>
Message-ID: <16239.60084.526163.393873@vzavenue.net>

 > Library automation software (what you are thinking of as the catalog,
 > but it is far more than that) is usually a very large investment.  High 5
 > figures at least.  Migrating from one to another is a pretty drastic
 > financial decision, and migrating is a major project.  It's like a heart
 > transplant for the library... even when fully smooth and successful there
 > will be repurcussions for a long time afterward.  Months, or even a year.
 > I've done 2.

As an undergrad, I had a part-time job in my university's library,
working in the card catalog.  When it was really a CARD catalog
(millions of cards in drawers).  The old ones were all done manually
(with typewriters).  At some point (I think 1973), they subscribed to
a service where they would send the LC numbers of all the books they
had recently ordered, and they would gat back standardized cards for
each book (usually around 5 cards per book, since there were author,
subject and title cards, plus a master card, for each).  Of course,
that made life much easier for everyone.

I'm wondering how this is done with online systems.  Does each OPAC
vendor have a service to update the databases automatically?  Or are
there centralized servers, with the OPAC vendors providing import
tools.  And is the info in an open-enough format that an open-source
version could be made?

(BTW, relying on outside sources for cataloging information had the
downside that the "authoritative" sources of information were
sometimes just plain stupid.  My #1 complaint at both the McGill and
U. of Delaware libraries was that different years of the same computer
conference would be scattered about willy-nilly all over the QA range
(if you were lucky enough that they didn't put some in the TK area).
Which would be a royal PITA if, say, you wanted to browse all the PLDI
proceedings because you heard of a paper by Prof. Smith in PLDI but
you didn't know which year.  When I complained that the first three
years of the HPCA conference were in THREE DIFFERENT PLACES, the
librarian told me, "that's how the Library of Congress did it."  I
asked if the LoC hired rejects from the Patent office; she didn't get
the joke.)

 > - Patrons will want to save stuff on disks.  Mounting/unmounting will need
 > to be automatic.

Easy, but risks comtamination by viruses.  (Though most of them will
probably be DOS or Windows viruses, so no problem.)

 > - There may be database or reasearch applications (things like encarta,
 > world book, and many library market stuff you may have never heard of) that
 > simply require their own windows client program.  End of story.  Sucks, but
 > all too true.  If it can be run in WINE, great.  If not, you're screwed. 

I think VNC could be useful.  Though I don't know if it is possible to
have more than one person logged into NT at a time over VNC.
Certainly the other way (multiple people on Windows logged into a
Linux box via VNC) works fine.

Kevin

On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 23:50, Kevin Theobald wrote:
> Paul Heinlein writes:
> 
>  > But once the text is in Publisher, afaik, there's no getting it back.

IIRC, this is true. It's the moral equivalent of M$Works spread sheets,
there's no way out.

> 
> Couldn't it be converted back into .doc (and thereupon into OO)?

Nope. It's got all kinds of other formatting stuff in it. If one copied
and pasted the text into word, it will do it.

> Anyway, why is the school demanding work be in some proprietary format
> (and a less common one at that)?  Do lots of people have MS Publisher
> at home?  Why won't they accept PDF, or PS or HTML?  Aren't there any
> Mac users to complain?

I don't know if there are enough mac users or not, but even Win users
should complain. M$Pub is not the right tool to do anything other than
layout existing text in for newspapers and newsletters.

Not only is it a bod tool to teach kids to word process in, it's a
pretty poor tool in it's own right. 

Publisher is avail on it's own, and it's in some of the Office bundles,
(there are several. some include Access, most do not, some include
FrontPage, most do not...) only two of the five I'm aware of.

Some thing is rotten in Denmark, especially if she's not in a yearbook
or newspaper class...

FWIW, I taught M$ Office to 7th through 11th graders. 

My 2 cents.

Mike






From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Sep 23 10:24:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Sep 23 10:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl, recursion, and finding your place when a script dies
Message-ID: <51395.68.107.223.201.1064337794.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I have a Perl function that takes an array of the alphabet, does some
stuff, and if a certain criteria is met then it calls itself again and
adds another letter to the array.  So for example, this might occur:

a...
[some criteria met]
aa...
ab...
ac...
[some criteria met]
aca...
acb...
acc...
[some criteria met]
acca...
accb...
...
accz
acd...
...
acz...
ad...
ae...
...
az...
b...

And so on...  Sometimes the script dies for reasons that I'm unable to
control and I'd like to be able to start up the script and have it
continue on with wherever it was in the recursive process.  Any
suggestions?
Thanks,
~M

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Sep 23 11:13:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, Matt Alexander wrote:
> And so on...  Sometimes the script dies for reasons that I'm unable to
> control and I'd like to be able to start up the script and have it
> continue on with wherever it was in the recursive process.  Any

This is sort of a deep structural question.

There are several workable designs, but I think they depend heavily on how
the string relates to the conditions you're trying to meet, how the data
is stored internally and externally, and whether or not you care about
speed.

This is a totally unhelpful email, but if you were more specific, I could
probably be helpful.

J.

From m at pdxlug.org  Tue Sep 23 12:33:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue Sep 23 12:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl, recursion,
      and finding your place when a scriptdies
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309231110470.16175@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <51395.68.107.223.201.1064337794.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> 
     <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309231110470.16175@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <53824.68.107.223.201.1064345575.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

Jeme A Brelin said:

> This is a totally unhelpful email, but if you were more specific, I could
> probably be helpful.

Here's some sample code.  My goal is to be able to restart the script and
pick up where I left off, if say, we're deep in a recursion with letters
abcdefg when the script dies.


recurse_letters('a'..'z');

sub recurse_letters {
   foreach $letter (@_) {
      do_stuff_here;
      if ($something == 1000) {
         my @letters = ();
         foreach $newletter ('a'..'z') {
            push @letters, $letter . $newletter;
         }
         print "\@letters is now @letters\n";
         recurse_letters(@letters);
      } elsif ($something == 0) {
         shift @letters;
      } else {
         print "Processing $letter\n";
         shift @letters;
         do_other_stuff_here;
      }
   }
}



From felix.1 at canids.net  Tue Sep 23 13:38:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue Sep 23 13:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl, recursion, and finding your place when a script dies
In-Reply-To: <51395.68.107.223.201.1064337794.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org> on Tue, 23 Sep 2003 10:23:14 PDT.
Message-ID: <20030923203721.3F9671584A0@kanga.canids.net>

"Matt Alexander" <m at pdxlug.org>:
> And so on...  Sometimes the script dies for reasons that I'm unable to
> control and I'd like to be able to start up the script and have it
> continue on with wherever it was in the recursive process.  Any
> suggestions?

I'd rewrite it without recursion.  Explicitly represent the
current state of the script as a data structure.  Data structures
are easy to save/restore.

something like
    $tasks->push('a'..'z');
    while (!$tasks->empty()) {
        my $task = $tasks->pop();
        my @more = run($task);
        if (@more) {
            $tasks->push(@more);
        }
        $tasks->save()
    }
--



From jmplug at sourtrout.com  Tue Sep 23 14:58:02 2003
From: jmplug at sourtrout.com (jmplug at sourtrout.com)
Date: Tue Sep 23 14:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] RE: the plight of Beaverton Library
In-Reply-To: <16239.60084.526163.393873@vzavenue.net>
References: <20030914134132.23121.72911.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <000101c37aec$f15b7840$156fa8c0@office> <20030922190241.GA29542@sourtrout.com> <16239.60084.526163.393873@vzavenue.net>
Message-ID: <20030923225421.GA4793@sourtrout.com>

* Kevin Theobald <kevintheobald at vzavenue.net> [2003-09-23 00:25]:
> 
> (with typewriters).  At some point (I think 1973), they subscribed to
> a service where they would send the LC numbers of all the books they
> had recently ordered, and they would gat back standardized cards for
> each book (usually around 5 cards per book, since there were author,
> subject and title cards, plus a master card, for each).  Of course,
> that made life much easier for everyone.
> 
> I'm wondering how this is done with online systems.  Does each OPAC
> vendor have a service to update the databases automatically?

No, or at least none that I know of.

>  Or are there centralized servers, with the OPAC vendors providing import
> tools.

Pretty much.  OCLC is a big one.  (LC is a source also.)  I'm not a
librarian, so I'm not completely familiar with what they actually do.  (A
lot of stuff, beyond the scope of this).  Here's my oversimplified (and
possibly not-quite-accurate) summary.  Basically, member libraries
download bibliographic records, make some adjustments to them to reflect
local organization and usage, then import them into their own system. If
a record doesn't exist for an item, they will just create one, and
send it in.  It is probably stamped for approval at some point, and is then
available to everyone.  You could probably draw some analogies between these
types of services and CDDB type services.

>  And is the info in an open-enough format that an open-source
> version could be made?

Version of what?  Central databases?  Or the data itself?

I can tell you that here they log into OCLC via a terminal program (provided
by OCLC) and work with records within their system.  When the cataloger is
finished with a batch of records, they are downloaded to a local file.  We
send that over to our system and import it.

The data is in MARC format, which is a standard.  I'm iffy on the finer
details, but MARC is a standard for both the organization of the
data (logically) and of the files themselves.  They're raw data files that
one can pick through and read with a text editor, but you wouldn't really
want to work with them that way.  There are lots of tools that can convert
them into plain text and back again, and others that let you edit them
directly.  I believe some of them are open source.

Here's a good place to learn about MARC: http://www.loc.gov/marc/

It is also possible to connect and transfer data around library systems via
a standard called Z39.50.  (Z39.50 client connects to a Z39.50 server and
speaks Z39.50.  Gets data, etc.)

Look into that a little more here: http://www.loc.gov/z3950/agency/

 
> (BTW, relying on outside sources for cataloging information had the
> downside that the "authoritative" sources of information were
> sometimes just plain stupid.

Heh, heh, heh.  The head of technical services (which includes cataloging)
sits right next to me.  I get to hear all about them all the time.  :)


> librarian told me, "that's how the Library of Congress did it."  I
> asked if the LoC hired rejects from the Patent office; she didn't get
> the joke.)

I guarantee that my friend over here would be rolling over that one. :)
It's true.  To try to keep standardized, you have to go more or less with
LOC, or not too far from it. She's always griping about strange desisions
coming out of there.

And yes, (in response to the post over on PLUG-TALK), cataloging really is a
Black Art.  I think that's the best explaination I've seen in a long time.


> I think VNC could be useful.  Though I don't know if it is possible to
> have more than one person logged into NT at a time over VNC.
> Certainly the other way (multiple people on Windows logged into a
> Linux box via VNC) works fine.


It can, but they would be sharing the same session, and fighting over
control of the machine.  But even if that wasn't the case, I'm not sure how
this would work for the public, or what it would be intended to do.
Remember, it isn't incredibly simple, it will not fly. :)

From lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com  Tue Sep 23 16:30:02 2003
From: lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com (lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com)
Date: Tue Sep 23 16:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SMART Client (SCSI drives)
Message-ID: <OFE412F8CE.3F61375F-ON88256DAA.007E8164-88256DAA.0080FA13@hb.fcpa.fujitsu.com>


>One of the things I've noticed with "smartctl" is its limited support for
>SCSI drives.  Larry mentioned in his presentation (a great one, BTW) that
>most SCSI drives have additional diagnostics above and beyond SMART.
>Unfortunately, I've been unable to find any information about standardized
>diagnostics on SCSI drives aside from SMART.

Because the standardized diagnostics have been in-place for a while.
To run diagnostics on the drive you issue a send diagnostic command with
various options.

>
>Does anyone on the list (maybe even Larry) have suggestions on ways of
>monitoring SCSI drives for impending failure?  Why is the SCSI support for
>smartctl so limited?  Is this a limitation in the SMART implementaion for
>SCSI drives, or just lack of coding within the smartctl application?

Because the SMART stuff in SCSI is very different.  It is built into the
log
pages.  If someone likes to dig through documents look at the SCSI Logical
Spec
for any SCSI drive.  It should be available for free, by asking.  The url
below has some info also.

If you really want to dive in, get the SCU utility and get the info
in raw mode directly from the drive.  Actually the SCU utility is nice
to have around as it has the ability to issue download command to update
drive microcode (actually it is write buffer with special options,
but it is part of the standard).
The utility has built in help.  It is not open source.


>Pointers to more information are appreciated, particularly since smartctl
>seems to be abandoned and poorly documented.  (Code is from Sep 2000, with
>minor updates made Sep 2001. http://sourceforge.net/projects/smartsuite/)

There is a different package that is derived from smart suite package,
which is smart monitor tools.  It looks like it in current development.

http://smartmontools.sourceforge.net/

I had actually found this while putting together the talk but it didn't
get into the references.  That and I don't really think we got to the
references.

----
Larry Brigman
Fujitsu Computer Products of America
503.693.2051 lbrigman at fcpa.fujitsu.com








From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Sep 23 17:17:01 2003

Date: Tue Sep 23 17:17:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Canon PowerShot G3 USB camera with Linux

I don't have a G3, but I have a 10D (and before that D60, and before that
I borrowed a D30). All of them are handled by usb_storage module
and appear as regular SCSI hard disks. You can mount them and
copy all photos over to a directory, then sort it out from there.

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Sep 23 17:52:02 2003
