From sharbours at yahoo.com  Tue Sep 23 22:35:03 2003
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Tue Sep 23 22:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Help with log file merge script?
Message-ID: <20030924053449.34303.qmail@web14404.mail.yahoo.com>

Can someone provide me with an example on how to do this? I have two
log files that are in this format, a date stamp and a value:

log file 1		Log file 2

200309231012	50	200309231012	25
200309231013	75	200309231013	50
...

I want to create a third log file that is has the aggregate values of
the first two log files, that looks like this:

log file aggregate of 1 and 2

200309231012	75
200309231013	125
...

What's a quick way to do this?
I've got as far as sketching out creating two arrays in a bash
script, adding the 2nd value of each array into a third array and
dumping this back to a file, but there has got to be a nice simple
way to do this. It doesn't have to be all that fast, it's a cron job
that runs every 5 minutes and handles about 1000 data points max.

Sean Harbour

From kevintheobald at vzavenue.net  Tue Sep 23 22:55:02 2003

jmplug writes:

 > > I think VNC could be useful.  Though I don't know if it is possible to
 > > have more than one person logged into NT at a time over VNC.
 > > Certainly the other way (multiple people on Windows logged into a
 > > Linux box via VNC) works fine.
 > 
 > 
 > It can, but they would be sharing the same session, and fighting over
 > control of the machine.  But even if that wasn't the case, I'm not sure how
 > this would work for the public, or what it would be intended to do.
 > Remember, it isn't incredibly simple, it will not fly. :)

You'd have a VNC client on the linux box (probably iconified, with the
icon saying Expedia or whatever the Windows-only database is) and then
when you click on it and get the VNC window, you can interact with
that app, which is really running on the NT server.

Kevin

> You'd have a VNC client on the linux box (probably iconified, with the
> icon saying Expedia or whatever the Windows-only database is) and then
> when you click on it and get the VNC window, you can interact with

You can't have multiple people logged on to the same NT box at once (you
can, via VNC, but they fight against one another for control)... without
Windows Terminal Server, which costs you per-seat.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Sep 24 00:52:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Sep 24 00:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Help with log file merge script?
In-Reply-To: <20030924053449.34303.qmail@web14404.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030924053449.34303.qmail@web14404.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <86r826sjxe.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Sean" == Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour <sharbours at yahoo.com> writes:

Sean> Can someone provide me with an example on how to do this? I have
Sean> two log files that are in this format, a date stamp and a value:

Sean> log file 1 Log file 2

Sean> 200309231012 50 200309231012 25 200309231013 75 200309231013 50
Sean> ...

Sean> I want to create a third log file that is has the aggregate
Sean> values of the first two log files, that looks like this:

Sean> log file aggregate of 1 and 2

Sean> 200309231012 75 200309231013 125 ...

Sean> What's a quick way to do this?  

Here's a first approximation (not tested):

  sort logfile1 logfile2 | awk '$1 != last { print last, sum ; sum = $2 } $1 == last { sum += $2 } { last = $1 } END { print last, sum }' > logfile3

This gives you an extra line at the top, but you can get rid of that
by branching around the first "print" if "last" is empty (or the lazy
way, by just stripping the first line of output with "tail -n +2").

If you are certain that the two input files are already sorted, then
you can give sort the "-m" option which will be faster.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Sep 24 06:37:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Sep 24 06:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Viewing messages in pine & filtering spam
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309240629330.23493@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  This question is to help me understand what's going on, and why my blank
message postfix regex works some times but not all the time.

  In /etc/postfix/body_checks I have the regex:
                             /^ $/	reject ...

I discovered that I needed the space between the line beginning and line
ending metacharacters or it did not work at all. Now, with the above, many
of the (apparent) spam/virus messages that come in with no body content are
rejected before they get in the door. However, some do end up in my inbox.

  When viewd in pine they appear no different: nothing's in the body.
Obviously, there are differences; perhaps more than a single space or a
non-printing/displaying character. I've not yet figured out how to
generalize the above regex without rejecting messages where a line has any
characters in it (e.g., reject only if there's noting but white space and no
characters at all in the message body).

  As I wrote above, this is more to satisfy my curiosity and to further my
understanding of what's going on so it's not a critical issue.

Many thanks,

Rich

From garl.grigsby at plms-eds.com  Wed Sep 24 08:19:01 2003

Once you get this error message hit Alt-F4. See if there are any errors regarding loading modules. Most of the time I have seen this it has been caused by something not loading correctly. We just need to figure out what it is.

Garl

From mikedela at ipns.com  Wed Sep 24 10:33:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Wed Sep 24 10:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] text file for procmail lookups
Message-ID: <1064424747.1150.83.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

I'm pretty happy with my spamassassin and procmail filtering for spam,
but from time to time, I want to add addresses to my procmailrc.

They're always in the same header, so I was thinking it would be nice to
have my procmailrc look up values in a file. Is this possible? I'm not a
programmer and don't play one on TV. There's nothing that I can find in
man procmailrc. for an example. I'm sure I'd need a variable declaration
somewhere, but I have no idea how to proceed. I was thinking something
like this:

VARIABLE=/etc/BADSPAMMERS
:0H 
* ^Received:. *.<VARIABLE>
/var/spool/mail/procmailspam/

This way I can just pop the offending domain, like "picaper.com" into
the /etc/BADSPAMMERS file and they're instantly nailed the next time
mail comes from them.

-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com





From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Wed Sep 24 10:47:02 2003
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Wed Sep 24 10:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: text file for procmail lookups
In-Reply-To: <1064424747.1150.83.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1064424747.1150.83.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.53.0309241113130.15762@antares.mpcu.com>

On Wed, 24 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I'm pretty happy with my spamassassin and procmail filtering for spam,
> but from time to time, I want to add addresses to my procmailrc.
> 
> They're always in the same header, so I was thinking it would be nice to
> have my procmailrc look up values in a file. Is this possible? I'm not a
> programmer and don't play one on TV. There's nothing that I can find in
> man procmailrc. for an example. I'm sure I'd need a variable declaration
> somewhere, but I have no idea how to proceed. I was thinking something
> like this:
> 
> VARIABLE=/etc/BADSPAMMERS

I believe this would assign the literal text string "/etc/BADSPAMMERS" to 
the variable named "VARIABLE".  To assign the contents of the file, 
/etc/BADSPAMMERS you would need to dump its output something like "cat 
/etc/BADSPAMMERS".  In the bash shell I would do something like 
	
	export VARIABLE=`cat /etc/BADSPAMMERS`

Not sure how you would do it in a .procmailrc.  If you don't get any other 
help on this list, I recommend the following for more details.

man procmailex

http://www.ii.com

and 

http://MailMan.RWTH-Aachen.DE/mailman/listinfo/procmail

beware though, the procmail list is very busy (high volume).  I found that 
only the postfix users list is even more busy.



> :0H 
> * ^Received:. *.<VARIABLE>
> /var/spool/mail/procmailspam/
> 
> This way I can just pop the offending domain, like "picaper.com" into
> the /etc/BADSPAMMERS file and they're instantly nailed the next time
> mail comes from them.
>

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309221700290.17330@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Sep 24 15:46:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Sep 24 15:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mini keyboards available locally?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309241522290.1916@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <7D6F4CF55743264F8B23E20353705EEC8837C7@orsmsx408>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309241522290.1916@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309241535530.21928@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 24 Sep 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Isn't it interesting that a smaller keyboard with fewer keys and
> other materials costs about three times as much as a "standard" one?

Heh. When I was working for Sears shipping arm many moons ago, I
noticed that nearly all inter-store transfers on the west coast went
through the Los Angeles cartage dock. If the Phoenix manager wanted to
transfer an item to the Tucson store, it went through LA. Sacramento
to Modesto? Same thing.

Booking a low-volume short haul was noticeably more expensive than
piggy-backing on an existing long-haul route -- even if it meant the
freight travelled hundreds of miles out of the way.

Either that, of the retailers of smaller keyboards are playing a
cynical game of, "OK, don't buy from us. Where else you going to
turn?"

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

>   My inexpensive Belkin keyboard is losing the labeling on some of the
> keycaps, and it has the separate keypad that I don't use anyway. I'd like to
> get a mini keyboard that has function keys and the four arrow keys; similar
> to a notebook computer keyboard.
> 
>   Does anyone know of a local vendor for these? I've found one that looks
> like it would work, but it's relative pricey. The Happy Hacking keyboards do
> not appear to have function or arrow keys and are very expensive.

The latest version of the Happy Hacking keyboard has arrow keys, but no
function keys.  It's possible to generate function key keycodes by 
holding down a special shift key and pressing the standard number keys
along the top row.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Sep 24 17:18:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Sep 24 17:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Beaverton Library again
Message-ID: <20030925001644.GB23369@gate.kl-ic.com>

Howdy, got to this discussion late.  About the Beaverton Library,
Welchia worms, Linux, and all.  I was also annoyed, looked into it,
and need to do more.  I think there is a project here.

Background:

First, there are three organizations involved in the Beaverton
library, and no doubt for the rest of Washington County.  (1)The
Beaverton library is owned and operated by the (2)City of Beaverton,
which does the computer maintenance on the computers, which are
city property.  Thus, anything affecting those computers requires
buyin from the city and the library bosses.  The library computers
talk to Wilinet, run by the (3) Washington County Interlibrary
Loan Service.

The public computers are mostly aging ~200MHz-ish Pentiums running
Windows NT, set up to always be in Internet Explorer.   The "card
catalog" computers have their browsers set up to always connect to
the Wilinet catalog system.  The "public internet access" computers
are set up to run through a (local) program that asks for a library
card number, then access Explorer.

There are also some computers "donated" by the Bill&Mel Gates 
Foundation.  What do you want to bet that the Beaverton Library
is contractually obligated to run Windoze on those computers?

The recent worm attack hit all those computers.  The Beaverton
maintenance types were fighting infection and re-infection.  The
machines were cleaned up, then left turned off until they had
cleaned up all the computers.  I wonder if they knew what they
were doing?  No doubt they will all go down again when the next
chinese virus hits, rumor has it in a few days.

The library card catalog system is accessed over the web.  The
central system for the entire county is Wilinet, the Washington
County Interlibrary Information Network.  It runs on Polaris 
library software, proprietary code from GIS Information Systems
of New York, http://www.gisinfosystems.com/default.asp .
This is a formidable mass of software, since it manages about
a million volumes at 18 libraries, hundreds of thousands of
subscribers with individual accounts, etc.  It serves general
users, library terminals, librarians, checkout clerks, etc.  It
has lots of extra functions such as making annoying phone calls
when books are overdue, ordering books from the cheapest vendor,
etc.   Big iron stuff.  It also runs on NT.  Can you say, virus
magnet? 

That said, Wilinet runs pretty well;  they recovered from Welchia
in hours, while it took the city a week.  There are open source
alternatives ( see www.koha.org ) but those are managing much
smaller collections right now, and probably lack the features.

A plan:

At the World Science Fiction Convention in Toronto, there was
an Internet Lounge with about 40 recycled computers similar to 
the old junk run by the Beaverton Library.  They were all 
running a homebrew version of Knoppix 3.2, assembled by Colin
McGregor.  That version did mail, web browsing, and attachment
viewing.  Everything ran off CDROM.  While we lost about four
computers that weekend from hardware failure, and had some
problems with the hotel network (too much cascaded NAT, I
wager), there was not one single user complaint (out of about
a thousand users, 24 hours, 5 days), no software crashes, and
nobody had problems adapting - not even the Mac people!

I have copies of that Knoppix disk.  May I humbly suggest that
we replace the splash screen with something Beaverton Library
oriented, tinker a bit, and make a few dozen copies for the 
local libraries to play with?  The next time a worm hits, they
can bring a few computers back up with the CDRom, certain that
these computers are virus-proof!  That will take some CDRom
drives, of course, and perhaps some mods to keep the disks
from wandering.  In the longer term, some sort of internal
USB flash reader might be better;  after all, when you strip out
everything but a web browser and a mailer, the compressed image
that results will be fairly small.  We might even be able boot
the machines from a boot server.

Again, this would be working with just the individual libraries
and municipalities to replace local software on machines effectively
operating as thin clients.  When that is done, and after Koha or
other open source solutions have had some time to grow, we can
lobby to install that, in Washington and Multnomah counties. 
That will probably be a few years out.


We might do better with Koha, in the short term, on some other
smaller library system somewhere in the state.  I am thinking
Benton County, City of Corvallis.  There are no doubt Corvallis
folks that would be glad to spearhead such a move (Dave M.?),
especially if the rest of us were around to help.

All you Washington County types that are interested, send me
some email.  We can arrange a meeting with the folks at the
Beaverton Library, or the Washington County Interlibrary
Loan Service (I have a number).  If we take this one step at 
a time - emergency disks for the librarians, then the whole
library, then things sorta gravitate towards permanence. 
Evolution takes patience, but always wins.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Sep 24 22:24:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Sep 24 22:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mini keyboards available locally?
Message-ID: <20030925052318.GD23369@gate.kl-ic.com>

Another source of keyboards is the Tektronix RAMs Country Store,
open Thursdays at 2pm.  Company excess stock, retired equipment,
etc.  Also about 30 weirdos that line up during the half hour before
opening and shoot the breeze.  In the basement of building 38
(used to be electrochem, what *is* that brown stuff dripping down
the walls, anyway?) on the main Tek campus, and since all Portland
area technologists over 40 used to work at Tek at one point or
another, just find an old fart and ask where that is.

They sometimes get minature keyboards.  Heck, once they had a
stack of brand new ones in the box for $5.  I got one, real handy
for troubleshooting.  Last I looked, they had a small heap of
Sun Sparcstation 5's and earlier, plenty of big keyboards, a few
300MHz Pentium towers, some old test equipment, and plenty of oddball
electronic components.  A week ago, they had a huge server rack
full of 4GB SCSI hotswap hard drives, $100 for 160GB the hard way.
So odds are low that you will find a mini keyboard, but not zero.
Fairly high that you will find something or someone interesting.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Keith Lofstrom writes:

 > The public computers are mostly aging ~200MHz-ish Pentiums running

Well, I can't complain about their choice of CPU. :-)

Of course, one question which they might ask is why they would want to
change (other than better virus immunity).  Unless they're under some
annual licensing scheme (like MS was trying to threaten everyone into
getting), they wouldn't save any money by moving to Linux, since they
BOUGHT the HW and they BOUGHT the SW.  Do they have any plans to buy
new equipment?  Are the users complaining about the machines being too
slow?  (Opportunity to make the "Linux is more efficient than Windows on
older hardware" argument.)

 > There are also some computers "donated" by the Bill&Mel Gates 
 > Foundation.  What do you want to bet that the Beaverton Library
 > is contractually obligated to run Windoze on those computers?

Those could be the servers for the legacy apps.

 > The recent worm attack hit all those computers.

Including Bill's donations?  Irony, irony...

 > chinese virus hits, rumor has it in a few days.

Chinese?

 > has lots of extra functions such as making annoying phone calls
 > when books are overdue, ordering books from the cheapest vendor,
 > etc.   Big iron stuff.  It also runs on NT.  Can you say, virus
 > magnet? 

How can "big iron" run NT?  Are you talking about something like a big
Unisys SMP server?

 > All you Washington County types that are interested, send me
 > some email.

Count me in.

 > Evolution takes patience, but always wins.

How does this compare to the article that was posted on Slashdot a few
weeks ago, arguing that a radical switch to Linux may be cheaper than
a gradual change?  (I think their main argument seems to be that
admins who are used to the MS way of doing things will try to do
everything the same way on the Linux boxes, which is sub-optimal.)

(Personally, I think the gradual way, especially the clients-first
approach, sems to have the best chance.)

Kevin

From freyley at gmx.net  Thu Sep 25 00:32:19 2003
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu Sep 25 00:32:19 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
References: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <1064475032.13260.7.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2003-09-24 at 23:24, Jon Jacob wrote:
> My son is turning nine next month and wants me to teach him how to
> program.  This is something I used to do (Perl mostly) but have lost my
> way.  Nonetheless, he has an interest and I would love to show him
> without turning him off.
> 
> Does anyone know of a book that might guide us through this?  I should
> also stress that right now his machine is Windoze machine because it is
> the family computer.  Eventually if he gets decent at it, I will get him
> a linux box, but right now I want him to start slow.

ActiveState Python and either a book on the subject or the Python
Tutorial.

Python is syntactically simpler than Perl, or in fact, any major
language, which makes it a great learning language. It's also very
powerful, which keeps them interesting, especially when you show them
the two lines of code required to open up the system's default web
browser and view a page[1]. I helped teach it to about 120 college
students who were only in the course to fulfil a science/math
requirement last year, and even the most braindead of sociology majors
managed just fine. Although the football players did resort to
cheating...

The real benefit of it is that ActiveState Python comes with a fabulous,
simple IDE for Python which gives immediate feedback so that it's easier
to program in it. Write a line or two of code, hit run, see if it works.
Get errors. The tutorial and documentation is in the help menu. 

Jeff

[1]
import webbrowser
webbrowser.open("http://www.google.com")

(and yes, that works on Linux: it just popped open my web browser. =)
 




From lamsokvr at xprt.net  Thu Sep 25 00:39:02 2003
From: lamsokvr at xprt.net (Marvin J. Kosmal)
Date: Thu Sep 25 00:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice
In-Reply-To: <1064475040.21215.14.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

and the user didn't pay (separately) for the latter in any case? If somone
offered to replace your computer with one exactly like it, would you
instantly jump on the opportunity? Of course not! So, OO.o sucks by design.

From brad at strong-box.net  Thu Sep 25 06:49:02 2003
From: brad at strong-box.net (Bradford Siemssen)
Date: Thu Sep 25 06:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SATA Drives?
In-Reply-To: <1064091746.11810.303.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <058CAD0D-EF14-11D7-80DC-000A95E2ABB4@strongboxnetworks.com>

On Saturday, September 20, 2003, at 02:02 PM, Wil Cooley wrote:

> After having had my prejudices against IDE drives confirmed by Larry 
> and
> the papers Galen posted, I'm wondering where SATA drives fall.  I'm
> seeing them offered in a lot of higher-end systems and with RAID
> controllers and they're only slightly less expensive than SCSI.  I 
> don't
> know much about them, other than they're somehow ATA interfaces adapted
> to a serial bus, like SSA or FCAL.  Are they being designed and
> manufactured as Enterprise Storage devices, or Personal Storage?  Are
> they so expensive just because they're still new?

It depends.

Maxtor, and Seagate have gone the low price road. Their drives are 
their better consumer grade drives (7200RPM 8MB Cache) repackaged to 
use SATA. Internally, many of their drives are really, old parallel IDE 
electronics, that have a SATA to PATA (Parallel ATA, or old IDE) 
converter added. Drives that use the SATA to PATA route will not be 
able to take advantage of the full 150MBps data rate that SATA allows, 
but the drives were typically, Ultra ATA 133, so they do get close.

Future iterations of drives from Seagate and Maxtor will eventually 
take better advantage of SATA and should get to where they can send the 
full 150MBps. The current price premium on SATA versus PATA is ~$30.

So for Seagate and Maxtor, SATA will filter from the top of the 
consumer market to down like all Ultra ATA 133, and Ultra ATA 100 
before it.

Western Digital is different. Initially, Western Digital decided to use 
SATA as an enterprise type of drive. The first Western Digital SATA 
drive was a 10K RPM ~36GB drive that costs almost as much as similar 
SCSI drives. I've recently seen advertisements for Western Digital 80GB 
drives with 8MB cache, for about $30 more than the PATA version of a 
similar drive. Which looks like more of a simple repackaging of current 
IDE offerings. So who knows.

It seems that SATA is going to be for both high and low end drives.

What I think will be the biggest pain for dealing with SATA is that 
there is only one drive per IDE channel. While this does mean no more 
dealing with master/slave/cable select, it also means motherboard 
manufacturers will need to put more channels on. The standard two 
channels just isn't going to cut it. Until that happens PCI SATA card 
makers will be happy.

All this to get rid of those short fat IDE ribbon cables....sigh...

  Cheers,
Brad

_____________________________
Brad Siemssen
Strongbox Network Services
www.strongboxnetworks.com
brad at strongboxnetworks.com
503.466.1416


-- 
This message checked for dangerous content by MailScanner on StrongBox.

>>>>> "Jeff" == Jeff Schwaber <freyley at gmx.net> writes:

Jeff> Python is syntactically simpler than Perl, or in fact, any major
Jeff> language, which makes it a great learning language.

Not a universal opinion, by the way, on any of those counts.

(For example, Perl v Python is merely a matter of exposure and
familiarity.)

But you knew that.

No, I'm not arguing for Perl. :-)

But Smalltalk is probably about the syntactically simplest language
(other than Lisp :), and is a much better learning language,
especially for OO concepts.

See www.squeak.org, and look for "Squeak: Object-Oriented Design with
Multimedia Applications" by Mark Guzdial (copies sitting on the
Powell's shelf right now), for a good cross-platform *real* IDE and
great learning environment.  Also check out www.squeakland.org for how
Squeak is being used in training environments.

From greg at green-mind.org  Thu Sep 25 09:50:03 2003
From: greg at green-mind.org (Greg R.)
Date: Thu Sep 25 09:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
References: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <3F731BF1.9030306@green-mind.org>

Why not JavaScript? Okay, sure, it's a buggy, ridiculous language, but 
there are some nice features - write a script to change the browsers 
color, things like that. Since it works within a web browser, there's an 
immediate sort of buy-in for beginners - it's not like you have to go 
through the process of explaining the command line. Plus, syntactically, 
it will provide somewhat of a bridge to Perl, Java, and C.
Jon Jacob wrote:

>My son is turning nine next month and wants me to teach him how to
>program.  This is something I used to do (Perl mostly) but have lost my
>way.  Nonetheless, he has an interest and I would love to show him
>without turning him off.
>
>  
>




From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Sep 25 10:05:02 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Sep 25 10:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Filling in an input type="file" field with the contents of a cookie
Message-ID: <37568.68.107.223.201.1064509471.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I have a webpage where a user selects a variety of parameters, including a
directory containing images, and these parameters are saved as cookies.  I
haven't found a way for the user to select a directory instead of a
specific file.  It looks like HTML only allows the selection of a specific
file and not an entire directory.  If anyone knows of a solution of how to
have the user browse their filesystem and choose only a directory, I'd
love to hear it, maybe using some other non-HTML method?  Currently the
user has to go into the directory and choose a specific image.  Then in my
Perl script I strip off the image name, leaving me with just the
directory, which works, but it's confusing to the user to select a
specific image.

In another unrelated field I have the user choose a specific file and I
save the path to that file in a cookie.  When the user returns to the
config form, I want the field to be automatically filled in with the
previous file name which would be retrieved from the cookie.  Using
onload="document.blahblahblah=cookievalue" in the body tag works for other
input types, such as text fields or pull-down menus, but it's not working
for input type="file".
Any suggestions, oh wise and knowledgable web developers?
Thanks,
~M



From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Sep 25 10:16:01 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Sep 25 10:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <86wubwrg05.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
References: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
	 <mailman.1064475162.29763.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	 <86wubwrg05.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <1064510135.9269.475.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2003-09-25 at 09:26, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> >>>>> "Jeff" == Jeff Schwaber <freyley at gmx.net> writes:
> 
> Jeff> Python is syntactically simpler than Perl, or in fact, any major
> Jeff> language, which makes it a great learning language.
> 
> Not a universal opinion, by the way, on any of those counts.

No doubt.

> (For example, Perl v Python is merely a matter of exposure and
> familiarity.)

I disagree.  The more Perl I do, the more I like Python.  I've had
adequate exposure to both, I think.  Sure, there are a handful of Perl
gurus like you who can keep the myriad of dark corners in your mind
(how's that for mixed-metaphor?), but I feel lost the more I know about
Perl.

I also seem to recall you saying once that the only parser that can
fully parse Perl is the Perl interpreter itself and that any other
parsers, like syntax high-lighters, were doomed either to failure or to
being as complex as the interpreter itself.  I seem to recall you were
bragging about it at the time and I was impressed at the time, but the
more I think about it, the less I think it's something to be proud of.  

I recall it having something to do with 'eval', so maybe Python is in
the same boat, since it has a similar mechanism.  I do note, however,
that there are at least three different implementations of the Python
interpreter: CPython (the one everyone uses), Jython (in Java), and
Stackless Python (which, uh, is stackless).  I cannot say whether this
means a Python interpreter is easier to implement or Python people just
love to implement interpreters; I'll leave that for the reader to
decide.

> But you knew that.
> 
> No, I'm not arguing for Perl. :-)
> 
> But Smalltalk is probably about the syntactically simplest language
> (other than Lisp :), and is a much better learning language,
> especially for OO concepts.
> 
> See www.squeak.org, and look for "Squeak: Object-Oriented Design with
> Multimedia Applications" by Mark Guzdial (copies sitting on the
> Powell's shelf right now), for a good cross-platform *real* IDE and
> great learning environment.  Also check out www.squeakland.org for how
> Squeak is being used in training environments.

SmallTalk is a cool language, from what I've read.  I learned enough of
it at one point to understand the handful of examples in "Design
Patterns" that were in SmallTalk.  But I think it has a few drawbacks,
particularly for a teaching language:

  o I don't think it's easy to learn mere procedural programming; OO
might be a little difficult for a 9-year-old to start with.  Maybe not.

  o The syntax is completely different from most of the other languages
one deals with, like C, Perl, Python, shell, etc.

I will also note that one of the Randal Schwartzes of the SmallTalk
world, Adele Goldberg, co-author of "SmallTalk-80", considered by many
to be bible of SmallTalk, gave a presentation this year at OSCON--on
using Python.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

*   Naked Ape Consulting                http://nakedape.cc  *

language. He claimed that users learned interesting and
useful things right from the start - unlike the less than
useful "hello world" exercises commonly done when starting
to learn other languages.

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Sep 25 10:42:02 2003

Jon Jacob:
> 
> My son is turning nine next month and wants me to teach him how to
> program.  This is something I used to do (Perl mostly) but 
> have lost my
> way.  Nonetheless, he has an interest and I would love to show him
> without turning him off.
> 
> Does anyone know of a book that might guide us through this?  I should
> also stress that right now his machine is Windoze machine 
> because it is
> the family computer.  Eventually if he gets decent at it, I 
> will get him
> a linux box, but right now I want him to start slow.

There is IBM Developer Works Robocode.  It will run on any Java2 compatible
platform.  

From:
http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-robocode/index.html

  Is it possible to learn inheritance, polymorphism, event handling, and
inner classes, all while dodging bullets and executing precision attack
maneuvers? A surprisingly addictive teaching-tool-turned-game-craze called
Robocode is about to make this a reality for Java developers worldwide.
Follow along as Sing Li disarms Robocode and starts you on your way to
building your own customized lean, mean, fighting machine.

  Robocode is an easy-to-use robotics battle simulator that runs across all
platforms supporting Java 2. You create a robot, put it onto a battlefield,
and let it battle to the bitter end against opponent robots created by other
developers. Robocode comes with a set of pre-fab opponents to get you
started, but once you outgrow them, you can enter your creation against the
world's best in one of the leagues being formed worldwide.

Robocode Home:
http://robocode.alphaworks.ibm.com/home/home.html

Steve D...

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Thu Sep 25 11:05:03 2003
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Thu Sep 25 11:05:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <1064510135.9269.475.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana> <86wubwrg05.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com> <1064510135.9269.475.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <200309251104.32091.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Thursday 25 September 2003 10:15, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Thu, 2003-09-25 at 09:26, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> > But Smalltalk is probably about the syntactically simplest language
> > (other than Lisp :), and is a much better learning language,
> > especially for OO concepts.
> >
> > See www.squeak.org, and look for "Squeak: Object-Oriented Design with
> > Multimedia Applications" by Mark Guzdial (copies sitting on the
> > Powell's shelf right now), for a good cross-platform *real* IDE and
> > great learning environment.  Also check out www.squeakland.org for how
> > Squeak is being used in training environments.
>
> SmallTalk is a cool language, from what I've read.  I learned enough of
> it at one point to understand the handful of examples in "Design
> Patterns" that were in SmallTalk.  But I think it has a few drawbacks,
> particularly for a teaching language:
>
>   o I don't think it's easy to learn mere procedural programming; OO
> might be a little difficult for a 9-year-old to start with.  Maybe not.
>
>   o The syntax is completely different from most of the other languages
> one deals with, like C, Perl, Python, shell, etc.
>
> I will also note that one of the Randal Schwartzes of the SmallTalk
> world, Adele Goldberg, co-author of "SmallTalk-80", considered by many
> to be bible of SmallTalk, gave a presentation this year at OSCON--on
> using Python.

I think Smalltalk is a great language to learn for a very important reason:

It was designed for children initially.

- OO is in the core.  This leads to an extremely simple syntax and ease of 
understanding.    Everything is an object.  Even the virtual machine is 
exposed as is GC, the memory subsystem etc.  

- Children were regularly exposed to it and taught to use it to see how well 
and how fast they could learn it.  Various things in the language were 
changed based on these experiments.  This is not to say that Smalltalk is a 
toy language, just that it is really easy to grasp and learn and has been 
designed to be so.

- Anthropomorphic projection is one of the key aspects of the way children 
think (and most adults).  We all tend to assume that everything around us has 
desires and feelings.  "My car didn't want to start this morning."  With a 
pure OO language, this natural psychological tendancy fits the system very 
well.

Smalltalk is one of the many things that came out of the Dynabook project(s) 
that Alan Kay has been working on in various ways for decades.  Squeak is 
what Kay and some of the other Smalltalk core people have been working on for 
a while.

That said, once you've used a good Smalltalk, programming in other languages 
seems cumbersome and frustrating, at best.  Of the languages I've looked at 
so far, only Ruby comes fairly close to Smalltalk (and it may be better than 
Smalltalk for just hacking together something that works).

So teaching your child Smalltalk may result in a precocious programmer, but 
also in one who detests C/C++/Java/Perl/C#/Python... :-)  I've known long 
time Smalltalk programmers who see little difference between programming in C 
and programming in assembly.  "Why would I focus on moving bits when I can 
focus on solving the problem?"  I'd assume that long time Lisp programmers 
feel much the same way.

Scheme is also a good learning language, but it might be a bit more abstract 
to deal with.

As I said above, Ruby seems something like the slightly odd offspring of Perl 
and Smalltalk.  Everything is an object, but it has a fairly rich syntax.  It 
has objects, classes, methods, regex syntax, closures, yadda yadda yadda.  If 
anything, it's problem is that, like Perl, it is pretty rich.  It is also 
fairly young and doesn't have the cohesive and consistent libraries found in 
CPAN or Smalltalk. Personally, I like what I see a lot, but what I see is 
mostly potential at this point.

I would definitely focus on the agile languages.  I'm old enough that I first 
learned to program in C. I feel this constrained my programming thought 
process to some extent.  I believe that, like natual languages, your thought 
processes are somewhat colored by what you first learn.

Best,
Kyle

From root at loraksus.d2g.com  Thu Sep 25 11:48:02 2003
From: root at loraksus.d2g.com (Karl Kulaga)
Date: Thu Sep 25 11:48:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C790@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <OBENLJCGLBNLOCJDNLOPIEMHCIAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>

Alright, I'm probably going to catch flames from damn near everyone on the
list for this, and perhaps rightly so, but hear me out on this.
vb
/ducks
Yeah, I know it has a ton of problems _but_
It is _painfully_easy_ to "program" simple programs with it - and he can add
pictures, sounds, stuff like that, stuff like output to a text file and
connecting to a sql database is _very_ simple.
Once he has a basic understanding you can introduce stuff like OpenGL
through it, which will probably catch his eye and you can lead him into
learning another language. It will also let you know that you messed up that
variable name or ?? as you are typing it (option explicit and option strict
on). MS gives away enough vb.net trial and beta copies you can almost
replace toilet paper and the documentation isn't too bad either. Of course,
if you've never touched vb, it probably would be a bad idea to introduce it.

	My "logic" if there is any in this reccomendation is that he is 9, he might
be a really bright kid, but I'm sure he gets bored pretty easily, and fresh
stuff helps to keep him interested - which, of course, is the entire point.
If he doesn't want to do it, he will go watch whatever mindless crap they
have on tv after school finishes or go play doom or whatever.

Alternatives?
x10 programming? I'm not sure how they are still around, but I got about 20
wall plugs and the serial controller and a bunch of remotes for about $6 a
while back - turning on / off lights etc might be interesting.

Those lego thingies that hooked up to the computer - still around?

A good java IDE for a kid, if one exists /shrug.
If you can dig up an old copy of qbasic and introduce him to some of the
graphical stuff first, that might keep him interested in it long enough,
although he might get bored.

I'd say c has a pretty steep learning curve before you get to do the "cool"
(9 year old kid's POV) stuff.

Javascript is also pretty cool, others have suggested it.
someone suggested robocode, he would probably be interested in that too.

If you have a windows based pocket pc (yeah, I'm going out on a limb here,
but I've pretty much guaranteed a beatdown at the next plug meeting, so why
not) programming for that is even easier - there are a lot less things to
deal with - and the "look ma! I hit a button on this thing and it shows a
picture of my hamster" factor might be a biggie here.




From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Thu Sep 25 11:54:02 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)

You're talking about Lego Mindstorms. Still around. Still having annual
competitions based on national standards and doing quite well. 

You can find them on www.lego.com. there's a dedicated site, too. The
Portland Robotics Club has stuff to do with it. Buy them at Fry's. 

All published software is Win based. there is a Linux port of the IR
software needed to program it.

Got a set. They're fun, but my 14 Y/O has been there, done that.

Mike

Thus spoke Alice Corbin <ali at axian.com>
( Thu, 25 Sep 2003 08:30:02 -0700 ):

> My old deskjet finally bit the dust, so I'm looking for a
> replacement. I was wondering what people might have bought recently
> that they are happy with.
> 
> I want something small and inexpensive.  I print colorful things 
> occassionally, but I don't need photo quality printing.

Consumer Reports' current top-rated inkjet is the Canon Photo Printer
S530D.  They've rated it a "best buy," which is very unusual for them.
 They say it's $150, very good quality, 8ppm.  The next best looks to
be a Epson Stylus C62 for $70: nearly as good, but noisy.

http://www.linuxprinting.org lists drivers for the C62 but not (that I
can find) the S530D.

From holger at selover.net  Thu Sep 25 12:09:01 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Thu Sep 25 12:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Filling in an input type="file" field with the contents
	of a cookie
In-Reply-To: <37568.68.107.223.201.1064509471.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <37568.68.107.223.201.1064509471.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1064516914.3443.255.camel@halo>

Matt,

I don't know of an easy solution. For a product I've done in the past I
used an ActiveX component and a Java applet. But they have to be signed
with a code signing certificate (or the user puts up with the warning
messages).

In order to give my family a means to upload a set of pictures to our
web album I gave them rsync and a Windows batch file. Here is a page
that explains the installation: http://selover.net/postpictures/.
Actually, they also get a SSH certificate and now they can upload
without login (not included in the download of above instructions). The 
pictures are put into a designated folder on the client and double click
on a shortcut uploads them without further interaction. Not pretty but
dead simple to use.

Holger

> haven't found a way for the user to select a directory instead of a
> specific file.  ...




From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Thu Sep 25 12:29:01 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Thu Sep 25 12:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <1064510135.9269.475.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309251217270.27579-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>


On Thu, 25 Sep 2003, Wil Cooley wrote:

> I also seem to recall you saying once that the only parser that can
> fully parse Perl is the Perl interpreter itself and that any other
> parsers, like syntax high-lighters, were doomed either to failure or to
> being as complex as the interpreter itself.  I seem to recall you were
> bragging about it at the time and I was impressed at the time, but the
> more I think about it, the less I think it's something to be proud of.  
> 
> I recall it having something to do with 'eval', so maybe Python is in
> the same boat, since it has a similar mechanism.  I do note, however,
> that there are at least three different implementations of the Python
> interpreter: CPython (the one everyone uses), Jython (in Java), and
> Stackless Python (which, uh, is stackless).  I cannot say whether this
> means a Python interpreter is easier to implement or Python people just
> love to implement interpreters; I'll leave that for the reader to
> decide.

but if that's your main criteria for choosing a language (ease of 
implementing an interpreter) then you should be going with some Lisp 
varient or perhaps Forth. (not saying that is your main critieria)

> 
> > But you knew that.
> > 
> > No, I'm not arguing for Perl. :-)
> > 
> > But Smalltalk is probably about the syntactically simplest language
> > (other than Lisp :), and is a much better learning language,
> > especially for OO concepts.
> > 
> > See www.squeak.org, and look for "Squeak: Object-Oriented Design with
> > Multimedia Applications" by Mark Guzdial (copies sitting on the
> > Powell's shelf right now), for a good cross-platform *real* IDE and
> > great learning environment.  Also check out www.squeakland.org for how
> > Squeak is being used in training environments.
> 
> SmallTalk is a cool language, from what I've read.  I learned enough of
> it at one point to understand the handful of examples in "Design
> Patterns" that were in SmallTalk.  But I think it has a few drawbacks,
> particularly for a teaching language:
> 
>   o I don't think it's easy to learn mere procedural programming; OO
> might be a little difficult for a 9-year-old to start with.  Maybe not.

I actually think it would be easier to teach a 9-year-old OO programming 
to start since it's very natural for people to think in terms of objects.  
The reason that picking up OO was difficult for some of us was that we had 
been steeped in procedural programming first (and for several years).  
I seem to recall a study that said it was easier to teach OO to new 
programmers than it was to teach it to seasoned procedural programmers.

> 
>   o The syntax is completely different from most of the other languages
> one deals with, like C, Perl, Python, shell, etc.

True.  But that's because we're more used to C-like syntaxes (I suspect).  
I believe one of the early reasons for creating Smalltalk was to teach 
non-programmers programming.  If you've never been exposed to any of those 
programming languages you mention, I suspect that Smalltalk syntax 
wouldn't seem any stranger than C|Perl|Python|Ruby etc.

> 
> I will also note that one of the Randal Schwartzes of the SmallTalk
> world, Adele Goldberg, co-author of "SmallTalk-80", considered by many
> to be bible of SmallTalk, gave a presentation this year at OSCON--on
> using Python.
> 

Well, it would seem ththat the Randal Schwartz of Perl just recommended 
SmallTalk.

While I would tend to recommend Ruby, I also think that Squeak would be a 
good choice for teaching kids to program.

Phil

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Thu Sep 25 12:49:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Thu Sep 25 12:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <200309251104.32091.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309251229380.27579-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>


On Thu, 25 Sep 2003, Kyle Hayes wrote:

> On Thursday 25 September 2003 10:15, Wil Cooley wrote:
> 
> I think Smalltalk is a great language to learn for a very important reason:
> 
> It was designed for children initially.
> 
> - OO is in the core.  This leads to an extremely simple syntax and ease of 
> understanding.    Everything is an object.  Even the virtual machine is 
> exposed as is GC, the memory subsystem etc.  
> 
> - Children were regularly exposed to it and taught to use it to see how well 
> and how fast they could learn it.  Various things in the language were 
> changed based on these experiments.  This is not to say that Smalltalk is a 
> toy language, just that it is really easy to grasp and learn and has been 
> designed to be so.
> 
> - Anthropomorphic projection is one of the key aspects of the way children 
> think (and most adults).  We all tend to assume that everything around us has 
> desires and feelings.  "My car didn't want to start this morning."  With a 
> pure OO language, this natural psychological tendancy fits the system very 
> well.
> 
> Smalltalk is one of the many things that came out of the Dynabook project(s) 
> that Alan Kay has been working on in various ways for decades.  Squeak is 
> what Kay and some of the other Smalltalk core people have been working on for 
> a while.
> 
> That said, once you've used a good Smalltalk, programming in other languages 
> seems cumbersome and frustrating, at best.  Of the languages I've looked at 
> so far, only Ruby comes fairly close to Smalltalk (and it may be better than 
> Smalltalk for just hacking together something that works).
> 
> So teaching your child Smalltalk may result in a precocious programmer, but 
> also in one who detests C/C++/Java/Perl/C#/Python... :-)  I've known long 
> time Smalltalk programmers who see little difference between programming in C 
> and programming in assembly.  "Why would I focus on moving bits when I can 
> focus on solving the problem?"  I'd assume that long time Lisp programmers 
> feel much the same way.

Yes, this is the risk: By teaching him SmallTalk first, he might be put 
off by any of the industrially popular languages  He encounters later.  I 
say this half in jest, but only half ;-)  On the otherhand, you may not 
want him to grow up to be a programmer anyway given the current and future 
instability of that profession.  But even if he doesn't end up being a 
programmer by profession, it's still good to know how to program. 


> 
> Scheme is also a good learning language, but it might be a bit more abstract 
> to deal with.
> 
> As I said above, Ruby seems something like the slightly odd offspring of Perl 
> and Smalltalk.  Everything is an object, but it has a fairly rich syntax.  It 
> has objects, classes, methods, regex syntax, closures, yadda yadda yadda.  If 
> anything, it's problem is that, like Perl, it is pretty rich.  It is also 
> fairly young and doesn't have the cohesive and consistent libraries found in 
> CPAN or Smalltalk. Personally, I like what I see a lot, but what I see is 
> mostly potential at this point.

Well, I would contend that Ruby's builtin libraries are very cohesive and 
consistent and for me that's part of the draw.  Now if you're talking 
about things like web progamming libraries, yes, there are lots of 
libraries and the community has not yet settled on which are the 'winners'
For some that might be a bit frustrating, but it also means that there is 
great opportunity to create soemthing that will become the next 
(useful|popular|elegant) web programming library.

I recall seeing a presentation at RubyConf2002 where a console app for 
making train reservations was converted to a web app by only changing two 
lines of code.  It even handled the back button correctly by making use of
continuations - very impressive.

> 
> I would definitely focus on the agile languages.  I'm old enough that I first 
> learned to program in C. I feel this constrained my programming thought 
> process to some extent.  I believe that, like natual languages, your thought 
> processes are somewhat colored by what you first learn.

Indeed.  Static typing only gets in the way when you're learning (and 
later on you learn that it only gets in the way period).  You're better 
off learning any of (Ruby|SmallTalk|Python) first instead of statically 
typed languages like (C|Java).

It's interesting that colleges and Univeristies have 'sold out' to 
commercial interests by teaching C,C# or Java as first languages.  Instead 
of trying to teach concepts first they're going for syntax first.  If you 
learn the concepts well, syntax is irrelevant; you can pick up any 
language

Phil




From list at sonofhans.net  Thu Sep 25 13:08:02 2003
From: list at sonofhans.net (Randall Hansen)
Date: Thu Sep 25 13:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [veering OT] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <1064519140.4973.266.camel@halo>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309251217270.27579-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
	<1064519140.4973.266.camel@halo>
Message-ID: <20030925130806.097bd1e6.list@sonofhans.net>

Thus spoke Holger Stephan <holger at selover.net>
( 25 Sep 2003 12:45:40 -0700 ):

> Teaching a 9 year old programming...hmm. I'm just glad that mine
> doesn't ask and instead goes to play outside with his buddies.

[ Snip my potential comments about well-balanced childhoods, etc,
which I know is part of your point and with which I agree. ]

Most people who play Go profesionally start learning the game when
they're 5 or 6.  It's very unusual for anyone who learns Go after the
age of 10 to make Pro.  The complexity that a young mind can deeply
aborb is stunning, and those years make a big difference.

I think it's good to expose children to as much complexity as they can
handle as early as they can handle it.  There's nothing to say that
teaching a child to program can't be concurrent with their having
friends and plenty of time to run around outside.

> He'll probably be spending enough time in front of a screen later in
> life.

I don't think that's the only issue.  Programming is creating
complex chunks of logic that can be understood by other complex
chunks of logic.  Learned early and properly it's a skill that maps
well onto many non-computer problems.

r

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Sep 25 13:54:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Sep 25 13:54:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <86wubwrg05.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
References: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
	<mailman.1064475162.29763.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	<86wubwrg05.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <863cekbney.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Randal" == Randal L Schwartz <merlyn at stonehenge.com> writes:

Randal> No, I'm not arguing for Perl. :-)

Randal> But Smalltalk is probably about the syntactically simplest
Randal> language (other than Lisp :), and is a much better learning
Randal> language, especially for OO concepts.

I'd say Scheme and Logo are two more candidates.  I actually have
never used Logo (or to my recollection even ever seen it running), but
it has a reputation as the canonical children's programming
environment.  Probably worth looking at.  E.g.:

  <http://el.media.mit.edu/logo-foundation/logo/programming.html>

Scheme, being another Lispy language[1], has very simple syntax rules.
There are some simple books for learning Scheme: _The Little Lisper_;
_The Little Schemer_ that teach by example (literally).  There are
some cool Scheme environments, like the MIT Scheme I think, which have
graphing libraries.  I recall there is one associated with _Structure
and Interpretation of Classical Mechanics_ (Sussman and Wisdom, MIT
Press), freely downloadable (the book and the software).

One of the very, I think, crucial things about good learning languages
is the Read/Eval/Print loop (the system reads your command, evaluates
it, and prints something, usually your result).  It gives the user
*immediate* feedback about what they just did.  No lengthy
edit/compile/debug cycle to get frustrated over.  Save that for after
they are hooked.  The immediate gratification will draw them in and
then (Vader: "If you only knew the *Power*!) it's all over.

[1] Curiously, Common Lispers don't like to acknowledge that Scheme is
    a Lisp with some justification that makes sense to them, while
    Schemers just assume that it is a Lisp and are amazed that there
    could even be such a controversy.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

On Thu, 25 Sep 2003, Anderson, Robert H - MWT wrote:

> True. Buy the kid a skateboard instead.

Unless the various alternatives are truly opposites (e.g., life and
death) or the situation demands only one choice (soup or salad :-),
posing an either/or question is usually fallacious. Would anyone
seriously ask, "What should I do, teach my child to talk or teach her
to read?"

Obviously, the question is one of balance.

Does nobody teach logic or rhetoric these days?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From ebrock-ml at wa-net.com  Thu Sep 25 14:09:01 2003
From: ebrock-ml at wa-net.com (Eric Brockman)
Date: Thu Sep 25 14:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
References: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <000d01c383a9$3327e4b0$44620ecf@office.wanet.com>

Jon,

    I learned how to "program" in about 5th grade and it was in qbasic
(that's why there are quotes around program).  Then I went off into VB3, 4,
5 and then 6, and then ASP, then i found my ways into PHP/Perl and some C
and became a linux admin.

If i could offer some advise, learn something that is cross platform.  C or
C++ would have been a much better language for me to start off with because
i used to think 'what does this in basic?' and i was screwed up for a long
time because of it.  I do a lot of PHP scripting now so it's not as big of a
deal.

PHP is easy to learn but maybe not as portable as universally accepted.  My
biggest issue was qbasic was the only thing readily accesible to me growing
up.  I didn't have linux or a webserver.  I'd stay mainstream with C++ to be
honest.  And if that is too complicated for a nine year old (which it could
tend to be i would think) I would go with PHP to create dynamic web sites
and stuff.

Overall, if you're a programmer you know this, you just need a purpose for
what you want to design.  If he wants to design graphical games C++ is the
engine, if he wants to go for database/web sites PHP.  I don't know, when i
was 12 i wanted to design games.  I just didn't have a compilier nor the
internet (man to think this was just 10 years ago :) ).

My two cents.

Thank you,

Eric Brockman
Network Administrator
World Access Network, Inc.
ebrock at wa-net.com
(800) 607-2502
(360) 574-4448

From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Sep 25 14:10:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Sep 25 14:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <863cekbney.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> on 25 Sep 2003 13:53:09 PDT.
Message-ID: <20030925210930.BEEFE158FA2@kanga.canids.net>

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com>:
> I'd say Scheme and Logo are two more candidates.  I actually have
> never used Logo (or to my recollection even ever seen it running), but
> it has a reputation as the canonical children's programming
> environment.  Probably worth looking at.  E.g.:

Logo is a pretty lisp-y language (minus the syntax).  We had it
on an Atari ST, I think it was standard on the system.  I tried
to show my younger brother how to program in it, but he wasn't
really into it.  Maybe he was too young at the time.  I don't
think there's any particular advantage to Logo over any other
interactive language, its big idea was "turtle graphics", which
is simple to use, but probably looks as boring (or as exciting)
as Spirograph to kids these days.
--

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Thu Sep 25 16:25:02 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Thu Sep 25 16:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C798@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

<< Many great suggestions snipped >>

If you are *really* interested in teaching your kid about programming, you
should:

1) Make three stacks of 3x5 cards.  On the first stack, write out a high
level description for a programming project.  On the second stack, name an
arbitrary software development methodology.  On the third stack, define an
arbitrary time frame.  Randomize the three stacks, and then deal your kid a
three card project.  Something like: "Card 1 - Implement a hardware device
driver, Card 2 - Using Object Fortran, Card 3 - within 30 days" would be
appropriate.  

2) Implement the most bizarre and difficult software version control system
possible.  Run a cron job to mung the database on a regular basis.  The
point is to spend more time futzing with the tools than writing code.

3) Declare that there is no time or budget for training.  Your kid will need
to learn programming on the job.  

4) Schedule daily update meetings to make sure your kid is working hard
enough.  

5) Reward yourself for doing a great job!  Buy yourself a new sports car.

6) Sell something completely different than what your kid is working on.
Don't tell your kid about the changes.  Whine that engineering doesn't
design products we can sell.  

7) Reorganize!  Put your wife in charge of programming.  Demand she cut the
schedule by 50%.  Slash your kid's allowance.  Demand he works longer hours.
Offer stock options and Pop Tarts if he sticks around until he's 18.  

8) Schedule twice daily update meetings to make sure your wife and kid are
working hard enough.  

9) End of quarter!!!!  Ship out your kid's bike, the stereo, the toaster,
and the microwave oven as product.  Apply the value to Accounts Receivable.
Report your profitable quarter with the SEC.  Send out a rosy press release
that the family is shipping product and "operating in the black".  Sell your
stock when the price spikes.  

10) Lay off the cat and dog.  Sell the family to the next-door neighbor.
Get yourself appointed to the Board of Directors of the new company.  

11) Outsource your family to India.  

12) Travel extensively throughout Asia and Europe while staying in 5 Star
resort hotels.  Claim you're "opening new markets".

13) Start a new family.  

With apologies,

Steve D...   ;-)

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Sep 25 17:03:02 2003

>

> death) or the situation demands only one choice (soup or salad :-),
> posing an either/or question is usually fallacious. Would anyone
> seriously ask, "What should I do, teach my child to talk or teach her
> to read?"

> Obviously, the question is one of balance.

> Does nobody teach logic or rhetoric these days?
>

On Thu, 2003-09-25 at 14:08, Eric Brockman wrote:
> Jon,
> 
>     I learned how to "program" in about 5th grade and it was in qbasic
> (that's why there are quotes around program).  Then I went off into VB3, 4,
> 5 and then 6, and then ASP, then i found my ways into PHP/Perl and some C
> and became a linux admin.
> 
> If i could offer some advise, learn something that is cross platform.  C or
> C++ would have been a much better language for me to start off with because
> i used to think 'what does this in basic?' and i was screwed up for a long
> time because of it.  I do a lot of PHP scripting now so it's not as big of a
> deal.
> 
> PHP is easy to learn but maybe not as portable as universally accepted.  My
> biggest issue was qbasic was the only thing readily accesible to me growing
> up.  I didn't have linux or a webserver.  I'd stay mainstream with C++ to be
> honest.  And if that is too complicated for a nine year old (which it could
> tend to be i would think) I would go with PHP to create dynamic web sites
> and stuff.
> 
> Overall, if you're a programmer you know this, you just need a purpose for
> what you want to design.  If he wants to design graphical games C++ is the
> engine, if he wants to go for database/web sites PHP.  I don't know, when i
> was 12 i wanted to design games.  I just didn't have a compilier nor the
> internet (man to think this was just 10 years ago :) ).
> 
> My two cents.
>

From mmckinst at umich.edu  Thu Sep 25 21:31:02 2003
From: mmckinst at umich.edu (Mark McKinstry)
Date: Thu Sep 25 21:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program
In-Reply-To: <OBENLJCGLBNLOCJDNLOPIEMHCIAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>
References: <OBENLJCGLBNLOCJDNLOPIEMHCIAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.4.58.0309260015050.15457@millipede.gpcc.itd.umich.edu>

> Alright, I'm probably going to catch flames from damn near everyone on the
> list for this, and perhaps rightly so, but hear me out on this.
> vb

I think VB would be a good starter language. Many a years ago I decided I
wanted to learn to program. I looked at what the popular languages were
and decided to learn C. I bought one of those tech yourself C in 21 days
books. I did a few of the days and lost interest. I didn't want ot program
some lame dos looking things, I wanted stuff that looked like it belonged
in Windows.

I kind of lost interest in programming. VB was my first "real" language I
learned. I don't consider Logo to be much of a language. In high school
the stupid computer teacher had us learn Logo on some super old Macs. Then
I took a specialed program at another school all about computers and
learned VB 5. I liked it a lot, programmed "real" apps that looked cool.
VB might not be the greatest of all languages but I thought it was fairly
simple to learn and you got impressive results in a short amount of time.

When I got to college it was all C/C++ and I came to appreciate C/C++,
also everything we did was on *NIX machines and I came to appreciate
and run *NIX.

Basically I'm trying to say is don't turn the kid off with some language
that's textual unless thats what he wants. I think most kids would be more
interested in creating something with a GUI.

Mark

From ian at znark.com  Thu Sep 25 23:25:02 2003
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Thu Sep 25 23:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Viewing messages in pine & filtering spam
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309240629330.23493@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309240629330.23493@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3F73DB9A.7000903@znark.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   This question is to help me understand what's going on, and why my blank
> message postfix regex works some times but not all the time.
> 
>   In /etc/postfix/body_checks I have the regex:
>                              /^ $/	reject ...
> 
> I discovered that I needed the space between the line beginning and line
> ending metacharacters or it did not work at all. Now, with the above, many
> of the (apparent) spam/virus messages that come in with no body content are
> rejected before they get in the door. However, some do end up in my inbox.
> 
>   When viewd in pine they appear no different: nothing's in the body.
> Obviously, there are differences; perhaps more than a single space or a
> non-printing/displaying character. I've not yet figured out how to
> generalize the above regex without rejecting messages where a line has any
> characters in it (e.g., reject only if there's noting but white space and no
> characters at all in the message body).
> 
>   As I wrote above, this is more to satisfy my curiosity and to further my
> understanding of what's going on so it's not a critical issue.
> 

I thought postfix body_checks regular expressions were applied to every 
line in the body.  Not the whole body at once.  Your regex would reject 
any message that has a line with a single space in it.  I think postfix 
can use PCRE regular expressions.  Since those are like Perl, they can 
be put in multiline mode and match against the whole string.  This regex 
should put match any body that only contains whitespace

/(?m)^\s*$/

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Sep 25 23:43:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Sep 25 23:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] firewire external enclosure
Message-ID: <86smmk59v7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

Last night I put together an external firewire/USB2 enclosure and
installed a firewire/USB2 card (Adaptec DuoConnect).  I recompiled a
2.4.22 kernel with the appropriate support.  USB2 is working fine and
satisfactorily, but for some reason the Firewire isn't.  When I plug
in, /var/log/messages gives me:

  Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: scsi3 : SCSI emulation for IEEE-1394 SBP-2 Devices
  Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: blk: queue dbb84818, I/O limit 4095Mb (mask 0xffffffff)
  Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Logged into SBP-2 device
  Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Reconnected to SBP-2 device

Then I try to mount /dev/sdc1 /mnt, and I get:

  # mount /dev/sdc1 /mnt
  /dev/sdc1: Input/output error
  mount: you must specify the filesystem type

When I try specifying the filesystem type:

  # mount -t ext3 /dev/sdc1 /mnt
  mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/sdc1,
         or too many mounted file systems

When I disconnect firewire and plug in USB2:

  Sep 25 23:31:41 celilo kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Logged out of SBP-2 device
  Sep 25 23:31:51 celilo kernel: hub.c: new USB device 02:08.2-4, assigned address 3

And then when I mount with "mount /dev/sdc1 /mnt":

  Sep 25 23:32:20 celilo kernel: kjournald starting.  Commit interval 5 seconds
  Sep 25 23:32:20 celilo kernel: EXT3 FS 2.4-0.9.19, 19 August 2002 on sd(8,33), internal journal
  Sep 25 23:32:20 celilo kernel: EXT3-fs: mounted filesystem with ordered data mode.

Any clues why the firewire isn't working?

--

On Wed, Sep 24, 2003 at 11:33:13PM -0700, Kevin Theobald wrote:
> Of course, one question which they might ask is why they would want to
> change (other than better virus immunity).  Unless they're under some
> annual licensing scheme (like MS was trying to threaten everyone into
> getting), they wouldn't save any money by moving to Linux, since they
> BOUGHT the HW and they BOUGHT the SW.

As much as I enjoy watching Beaverton twist in the wind and
(hopefully) approach bankruptcy, it would save them money to move away
from Windows.  IT guys having to do weekly diaper changes on all the
Wintendos gets costly quick.  Plus, if you want to upgrade to a newer
Windows OS, guess what?  You get to replace the hardware as well.  And
you can bet they're going to need to reinstall those machines more
times than WinXP allows per license.

> How can "big iron" run NT?  Are you talking about something like a big
> Unisys SMP server?

They ditched the perfectly good Dynix system they had and all the
terminals for a slew of i386 machines.

From root at loraksus.d2g.com  Fri Sep 26 05:23:02 2003
From: root at loraksus.d2g.com (Karl Kulaga)
Date: Fri Sep 26 05:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] recommendations for printers?
In-Reply-To: <20030925083002.B20493@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <OBENLJCGLBNLOCJDNLOPEENECIAA.root@loraksus.d2g.com>

Get a cheap laser printer - you can find cheap ones for ~$120 if you watch
the deal sites for a week or two and get a seperate color for the color
print outs, I think albertsons has a cheapo inkjet for $40 or something, if
you really don't care about print quality that much . . .

Now, my laser printer info / advice
If it is an newer lower end HP (like 1?00 series), call up their support and
get the 3 year extended warranty - it is around $40 and they send a unit out
to you next day air when and no matter how many times it breaks (and don't
be cheap on this, because it WILL break at least once in 3 years, and
shipping printers is expensive), I'm guessing the same thing for the other
brand's lower end lasers - generally the fusers aren't made to last 3 years,
most are designed to work for a year.

 Of course, check compatibility before you buy - I believe the laserjet 1200
had some issues with macs under X a while back, but I think it has been
rectified - just don't expect much support from any printer company (short
of processing rmas). And here's an hint for calling support about printers,
always try and get the mac folks - hold times are usually a lot shorter, and
if the printer is smoking, they won't ask you to do much software
troubleshooting ;)

You will save so much $ in ink that you will be very happy and you will
virtually never have to change the toner. Print quality for letters, etc is
much better too and no more smearing printouts in our great portland
climate. I've recently printed the better part of a _box_ of paper on 1
toner cartridge on my laserjet 3p that was made in '92.

If you want to do some fixup work (and probably changing the pickup rollers
is all you need to do), there are quite literally tens of thousands of
pre-carly (key word PRE) HP laserjets out there. Sure they are big, but they
will last (laserjet 3's, 4's, you probably want to avoid the 5's though, the
laserjet 4000 and 4050 are kind of big but I've seen several with a page
count of over a million pages - basically 3 or so years of printing 24-7,
work it out if you're bored.) virtually all are available for dirt cheap -
around / under $50 or so. You can always remove extra paper trays to save on
room and used wired print servers (like a 170x or 300x) go for cheap
nowadays so you can leave that printer into a different room.

Good luck. . .

Oh and on most hp laser printer's with a display, you can change the ready
message by sending the following code ;)

%-12345X at PJL RDYMSG DISPLAY="Message"
%-12345X





From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Sep 26 05:52:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

From pmvw at earthlink.net  Fri Sep 26 06:06:02 2003
From: pmvw at earthlink.net (Piet van Weel)
Date: Fri Sep 26 06:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Teaching My Son To Program -> ORTOP
In-Reply-To: <1064471074.8271.1109.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <001301c3842e$d6233720$6400000a@gamma>

Hey Jon...

Why don't you get your son and some of his friends and participate in the
ORTOP competitions. www.ortop.org or www.firstlegoleague.org 

It's a really cool way for the kids to learn to program a robot and compete
with it. The total cost is a little pricey... but if you get 5+ kids
involved you can split the cost. :)

I'm currently coaching a team of girls, and they're having a blast. It's a
great way for the kids to play with legos, learn to program a robot (a
LabView mutation), and have fun. You can go to the ORTOP site and see if
there is a local team in the area that your son can participate with. I know
that several schools are sponsoring teams... with your son being 9 he's
right at the beginning age for the competitions (9-14 year olds). 

Piet van Weel

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Sep 26 07:40:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Sep 26 07:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] email for kids
In-Reply-To: <1064586282.27566.44.camel@kokopelli>
References: <1064586282.27566.44.camel@kokopelli>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309260737250.20768@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 26 Sep 2003, Brian Beattie wrote:

> I'm taking a 6 month contract on the east coast my wife and the kids
> are staying here and I'm thinking about setting up email for my 9
> yo.  My wife and I use Evolution/Linux, but the kids computer is a
> windows box for his games.  He does not use the network much.  I was
> wondering if anybody had am opinions on what might work well.

It sort of depends on what sort of learner your son is: visual,
verbal, ...?

If he's a typical boy, he's probably a visual learner, in which case
most of the GUI clients (incl. Mozilla) will probably do fine.

If he's more verbal, PC Pine isn't such a bad choice -- plus it'll
shield him from viruses and obnoxious HTML mail messages. :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Sep 26 07:56:01 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)

>>>>> "Jon" == Jon Jacob <jon at manymoons.net> writes:

Jon> As as outside time...... been to Oregon much?  Winter is coming on and
Jon> its being hounded for TV, computer games, or learning something new.

Ahh, the cure for the "winter blues" is to take up winter sports.

Once I started skiing (and later snowboarding), I found myself every
fall just gleeming with anticipation for that first big cold storm.
And every formerly "yucky" day turned into "hooray - more powder!".
The first spring days brought me down a bit, and by the time the sun
was out for more than a week, I'd go into some serious depression.

It really changes your outlook about the weather.  Winter!  Love it!

>>>>> "Wil" == Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> writes:

Wil> I will also note that one of the Randal Schwartzes of the SmallTalk
Wil> world, Adele Goldberg, co-author of "SmallTalk-80", considered by many
Wil> to be bible of SmallTalk, gave a presentation this year at OSCON--on
Wil> using Python.

Sure, Adele is using Python (I'd call her the Tom Christiansen of the
Smalltalk world :).

But Alan Kay and Dan Ingalls (The Larry Wall and Randal Schwartz of
the Smalltalk world) are still actively developing Smalltalk as
Squeak, which is a direct descendent of the original Smalltalk-80
image that I used at Tektronix in 1981.  It's interesting to ask a
question on the squeak mailing list, and get an answer back from Dan
that starts with "Well, for Smalltalk-72, we considered that, but by
the time we got to Smalltalk-76, that feature had been dropped...".

From alan at clueserver.org  Fri Sep 26 14:38:02 2003
