Subject: [PLUG] firewire external enclosure
In-Reply-To: <86smmk59v7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86smmk59v7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1064612147.25477.15.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Thu, 2003-09-25 at 23:42, Russell Senior wrote:
> Last night I put together an external firewire/USB2 enclosure and
> installed a firewire/USB2 card (Adaptec DuoConnect).  I recompiled a
> 2.4.22 kernel with the appropriate support.  USB2 is working fine and
> satisfactorily, but for some reason the Firewire isn't.  When I plug
> in, /var/log/messages gives me:
> 
>   Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: scsi3 : SCSI emulation for IEEE-1394 SBP-2 Devices
>   Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: blk: queue dbb84818, I/O limit 4095Mb (mask 0xffffffff)
>   Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Logged into SBP-2 device
>   Sep 25 23:17:02 celilo kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Reconnected to SBP-2 device
> 
> Then I try to mount /dev/sdc1 /mnt, and I get:
> 
>   # mount /dev/sdc1 /mnt
>   /dev/sdc1: Input/output error
>   mount: you must specify the filesystem type
> 
> When I try specifying the filesystem type:
> 
>   # mount -t ext3 /dev/sdc1 /mnt
>   mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/sdc1,
>          or too many mounted file systems
> 
> When I disconnect firewire and plug in USB2:
> 
>   Sep 25 23:31:41 celilo kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Logged out of SBP-2 device
>   Sep 25 23:31:51 celilo kernel: hub.c: new USB device 02:08.2-4, assigned address 3
> 
> And then when I mount with "mount /dev/sdc1 /mnt":
> 
>   Sep 25 23:32:20 celilo kernel: kjournald starting.  Commit interval 5 seconds
>   Sep 25 23:32:20 celilo kernel: EXT3 FS 2.4-0.9.19, 19 August 2002 on sd(8,33), internal journal
>   Sep 25 23:32:20 celilo kernel: EXT3-fs: mounted filesystem with ordered data mode.
> 
> Any clues why the firewire isn't working?

Are you sure it is attaching the device as sdc?  Nothing from those
messages would indicate that.  Looks like it is not the right device
being used.

Try sda instead.  (Or is something else using that one?)

Also make sure all the firewire modules are loading.  My Canopus card
sometimes has problems due to only half the drivers getting loaded.

-- 
         alan at clueserver.org - alan at ctrl-alt-del.com

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Sep 26 15:14:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Fri Sep 26 15:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] firewire external enclosure
In-Reply-To: <86smmk59v7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86smmk59v7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1064614355.10179.313.camel@kat>

what does lsmod say?
 You should have somethinglike
sg                     36524   0  (autoclean)
sr_mod                 18136   0  (autoclean)
ide-scsi               12208   2 
scsi_mod              107544   5  [sbp2 sd_mod sg sr_mod ide-scsi]
ide-cd                 35712   0 
cdrom                  33728   0  [sr_mod ide-cd]
ohci1394               20168   0  (unused)
ieee1394               48780   0  [sbp2 ohci1394]


Is perhaps the usb2 driver locking the sdX device (i.e. reload the
modules or reboot).

You should see something like this is /var/log/messages
Sep 22 07:48:30 kat kernel: ieee1394: SelfID completion called outside of bus reset!
Sep 22 07:48:31 kat kernel: ieee1394: Node 00:1023 has non-standard ROM format (0 quads), cannot parse
Sep 22 07:48:33 kat kernel: ieee1394: Node 00:1023 has non-standard ROM format (0 quads), cannot parse
Sep 22 07:48:43 kat kernel: ieee1394: SelfID completion called outside of bus reset!
Sep 22 07:48:43 kat /etc/hotplug/ieee1394.agent: Setup sbp2 for IEEE1394 product 0x0004da/0x00609e/0x010483
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Logged into SBP-2 device
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: ieee1394: sbp2: Node[01:1023]: Max speed [S400] - Max payload [2048]
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: scsi1 : IEEE-1394 SBP-2 protocol driver (host: ohci1394)
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: $Rev: 707 $ James Goodwin <jamesg at filanet.com>
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: SBP-2 module load options:
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: - Max speed supported: S400
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: - Max sectors per I/O supported: 255
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: - Max outstanding commands supported: 64
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: - Max outstanding commands per lun supported: 1
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: - Serialized I/O (debug): no
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: - Exclusive login: yes
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel:   Vendor: QUANTUM   Model: FIREBALLP AS40.0  Rev:     
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel:   Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 06
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: Attached scsi disk sda at scsi1, channel 0, id 0, lun 0
Sep 22 07:48:44 kat kernel: SCSI device sda: 80288480 512-byte hdwr sectors (41108 MB)

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Sep 26 16:37:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] firewire external enclosure
In-Reply-To: <1064614355.10179.313.camel@kat>

Message-ID: <86fzijrul1.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Zot" == Zot O'Connor <zot at whiteknighthackers.com> writes:

Zot> what does lsmod say?  

Not going to help, since it is mostly compiled in, not modular.  Hmm.
I wonder if there are firewire parts that _are_ modular.  I'll go
look at my .config:

  #
  # IEEE 1394 (FireWire) support (EXPERIMENTAL)
  #
  CONFIG_IEEE1394=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_PCILYNX=m
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_OHCI1394=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_VIDEO1394=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_SBP2=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_SBP2_PHYS_DMA=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_ETH1394=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_DV1394=m
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_RAWIO=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_CMP=y
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_AMDTP=y
  # CONFIG_IEEE1394_VERBOSEDEBUG is not set
  CONFIG_IEEE1394_OUI_DB=y

I think the SCSI stuff should be all right, since it works with USB2.

experiment with the two and compare.  If I don't get firewire working,
then I can't do that.

what Nokkia did will not apply to Kyocera. And, what the other provider
accepts as commands may not be what Verizon wants.

                                  Fedor G. Pikus

From russell-evans at qwest.net  Fri Sep 26 23:19:01 2003
From: russell-evans at qwest.net (russell-evans at qwest.net)
Date: Fri Sep 26 23:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] email for kids
In-Reply-To: <1064586282.27566.44.camel@kokopelli>
References: <1064586282.27566.44.camel@kokopelli>
Message-ID: <E1A38PY-0004Dp-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Are you looking for safety / parental controls, client functionality, or both? 

ComputerBits used to have a series of articles devoted to Internet use by
children. They may still have the series going, I haven't been looking for new
hardware, so haven't been reading it lately.  There seem to be some resources
on a google of "email for kids". The k12linux list might be a better place to
ask. as I assume they have covered client, as will as safety, issues in their
project. 

I personally prefer to keep in touch with my family, mother and sisters, via
IM. We pass the occasional email, but mostly we chat. If you think this is an
option, then Trillian is my favorite client for windows. I would think that it
is easier to control unwanted contacts via IM, than via email. My experience
with this is limited, however. I usually sent up the accounts for my family so
that only people in their buddy list can contact them. I don't keep tabs on
what they do with it after I set it up as they are adults, so can't speak to
how safe this is. I have no experience in locking down a internet connected
computer so that it remains a safe envirnoment for children. 

Thank you
Russell


On 26 Sep 2003 07:24:42 -0700, Brian Beattie said:

> I'm taking a 6 month contract on the east coast my wife and the kids are
>  staying here and I'm thinking about setting up email for my 9 yo.  My
>  wife and I use Evolution/Linux, but the kids computer is a windows box
>  for his games.  He does not use the network much.  I was wondering if
>  anybody had am opinions on what might work well.




From jon at manymoons.net  Sat Sep 27 15:18:02 2003

I've recently started to wonder when my 9yo will be wanting email, but
fear the inevitable question: "Dad, what is viagra for? "  or "What is
the email about penis enlargers?"

Spam filters and such have been known to work well, but eventually one
slips through and I am left answering endless questions that I would
rather not answer.

from someone I didn't recognize, but the subject was a subject of an 
earlier email in my inbox.  So out of curiosity I opened it up and found 
out it was just a spam for 'herbal viagra'.  I closed it and then noticed 
that no subject was now shown in my inbox for this message (it was just 
blank).

Tell her not to publish her e-mail address, make it something unlikely 
to be hit by an automated bot, and put it on your own domain, on your 
own server, with a spam filter.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Sep 27 16:50:03 2003

On Sat, 2003-09-27 at 16:30, Phil Tomson wrote:
> This is from the "How do they do _that_?" department...

Sounds to me like a bug in pine - the subject was probably blank, but
when it was drawing itself, it didn't refresh the line the subject was
on until you left the message.

Also, would you mind composing a new mail to plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
instead of just hitting reply on any old message?  See, a great many of
us (the majority, I would guess) use threaded views for mailing lists
like this, so replies to earlier posts get threaded into a tree-like
view, similar to what you see with news readers.

If you just reply to a post like this, you're replying to 'email for
kids' rather than starting your own thread.

Rob




From bsr at spek.org  Sat Sep 27 17:55:03 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Sat Sep 27 17:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what IP does a web page come from
In-Reply-To: <200309271640.59996.carla@bratgrrl.com>

Message-ID: <3F763117.7040501@spek.org>

Carla Schroder wrote:
> How do you tell what server a particular Web page is from? Let's say the 
> identical page is on two different servers, on two different networks- how do 
> you know which one? (No, you cannot change one, it is not under your control)

Can't you just do:
   host <the part between the "http://" and the next "/">

or am I misunderstanding your question?

--Brent




From ed at alcpress.com  Sat Sep 27 18:09:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sat Sep 27 18:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what IP does a web page come from
In-Reply-To: <200309271640.59996.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200309271640.59996.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1064711953.14667.938.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sat, 2003-09-27 at 16:40, Carla Schroder wrote:
> How do you tell what server a particular Web page is from? Let's say the 
> identical page is on two different servers, on two different networks- how do 
> you know which one? (No, you cannot change one, it is not under your control)
> 
There's no easy way to know unless your Web browser stores
that information with the page when the page is loaded. I've
never seen one expose that information to you via the user
interface and I've never seen IP addresses in browser caches
but it could be there in binary and I would not have noticed.
It's possible that the IP address is in a cookie sent by the
site but you couldn't rely on this.

Web browsers don't generally keep log files so you're
out of luck there.  

I maintain mirrored servers and I try to put the server
identity as meta information in the <head> section of pages.

Ed


> thanks!




From ed at alcpress.com  Sat Sep 27 18:12:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sat Sep 27 18:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what IP does a web page come from

Message-ID: <1064712147.16341.942.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sat, 2003-09-27 at 17:53, Brent Rieck wrote:

When I replied to Carla, I assumed that the Web servers would have
different IP addresses - that we weren't talking about a cluster
of servers all with the same IP apparent address. If my assumption
is correct, asking DNS for the address would yield two or more
answers and she wouldn't know which one.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Sat Sep 27 19:01:01 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Sep 27 19:01:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] what IP does a web page come from
In-Reply-To: <1064712147.16341.942.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <200309271640.59996.carla@bratgrrl.com> <3F763117.7040501@spek.org> <1064712147.16341.942.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200309271905.51321.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 27 September 2003 6:22 pm, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> Re: [PLUG] what IP does a web page come from
> From: Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
>
> On Sat, 2003-09-27 at 17:53, Brent Rieck wrote:
> > Carla Schroder wrote:
> > > How do you tell what server a particular Web page is from? Let's say
> > > the identical page is on two different servers, on two different
> > > networks- how do you know which one? (No, you cannot change one, it is
> > > not under your control)
> >
> > Can't you just do:
> >    host <the part between the "http://" and the next "/">
> >
> > or am I misunderstanding your question?

>
> When I replied to Carla, I assumed that the Web servers would have
> different IP addresses - that we weren't talking about a cluster
> of servers all with the same IP apparent address. If my assumption
> is correct, asking DNS for the address would yield two or more
> answers and she wouldn't know which one.

Right. Doing any of the usual lookups- dig, host, nslookup- do not trace the 
origin of a specific page. I was futzing around with some domains hosted at 
different providers, and got sidetracked because each one uses the identical 
Apache Test page:

69.57.134.33  <-- new web host, citadelhost
207.218.248.34  <-- old web host, Page-zone

The Apache Test page displays when you enter the URL of a domain hosted on 
their server, but DNS is not caught up yet, for whatever reason. What would 
be lovely is each site putting some kind of identification on their default 
Apache pages. (I asked already)

For those who like to fool around with this kind of thing, try 
www.mtgadvocates.com and mtgadvocates.com. You'll either get the site, or an 
Apache Test page. There are a lot of chefs in this DNS kitchen: 
Easystreet.com manages their DNS. The site is hosted at Citadelhost.com. 
Easystreet configured them so:

;; ANSWER SECTION:
www.mtgadvocates.com.   77810   IN      CNAME   mtgadvocates.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       77813   IN      A       69.57.134.33
mtgadvocates.com.       77813   IN      A       69.57.134.153
;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
mtgadvocates.com.       77813   IN      NS      dns3.easystreet.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       77813   IN      NS      dns1.easystreet.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       77813   IN      NS      dns2.easystreet.com.


Querying both the Citadelhost nameservers looks like this:

69.57.134.33 
;; ANSWER SECTION:
www.mtgadvocates.com.   14400   IN      CNAME   mtgadvocates.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       14400   IN      A       69.57.134.33

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
mtgadvocates.com.       14400   IN      NS      ns5.xfwm.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       14400   IN      NS      ns6.xfwm.com.

69.57.134.153
;; ANSWER SECTION:
www.mtgadvocates.com.   14400   IN      CNAME   mtgadvocates.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       14400   IN      A       69.57.134.33

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
mtgadvocates.com.       14400   IN      NS      ns6.xfwm.com.
mtgadvocates.com.       14400   IN      NS      ns5.xfwm.com.

It wouldn't even be all that interesting, except the old host I moved 
mtgadvocates.com away from uses the exact same Apache Test page. So I got to 
wondering about how in the heck to know which one I was hitting? (I assume 
that once DNS propagation takes place (the DNS was changed yesterday) that 
ole test page won't come back. )

So that is how I waste^H^H^H^H gainfully spent my Saturday.

-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Sep 27 20:26:02 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Sep 27 20:26:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Odd spam behavior in pine
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309272011140.19726-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309272011140.19726-100000@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <1064719468.4188.40.camel@localhost>

On Sat, 2003-09-27 at 20:12, Phil Tomson wrote:
> On 27 Sep 2003, AthlonRob wrote:
>
> > If you just reply to a post like this, you're replying to 'email for
> > kids' rather than starting your own thread.
> 
> Even though I changed the subject line?  How does the threading get messed 
> up if the subject is different?  What information remains to tell it to go 
> to the old thread - just curious.

If you look at your message headers, you'll see this right under the
Subject line:

In-Reply-To:  <1064706556.4188.12.camel at localhost>

...and that's what it threads based on.  :-)

Your mua automagically inserts that when you decide to reply to an email
rather than starting a new email.

Rob

Hmmm... my message ID's end in @localhost?  That's not good.  :-\

we walked to school barefoot, 
in the 
	snow
		uphill 
			both
				 ways

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Sep 28 08:10:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Sep 28 08:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OO.o page style creation
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309280801500.30091@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I posted this question to the OO.o users mail list several days ago but
there have been no replies. How do I create a page style?

  Looks like a simple question, but the answer eludes me because there is no
"create", "creation" or equivalent entry under "styles" in the on-line help.
Worse yet, my trial-and-error fumblings have not produced results either.
Here's the context:

  Many letters I write are longer than a single page. The fist page is done
on a template that has the letterhead in the header, the current date and
the signature block. For subsequent pages, I want a page style that has a
header with the recipient's name, the letter creation date and the page
number. It's turning into a major project. I can create this second_sheet
(as I call it) as a template, but I need it as a style to be called by the
letter template for subsequent pages.

  I've tried using the stylist and Format > Styles > Catalog > New, but the
attempts don't stick and become visible in the page format dialog box for
the letter template.

  Has anyone nailed down this process of style creation? I'd really like to
know what I've missed here so I can get past this distraction and work on
the next one.

TIA,

Rich

In-Reply-To: <3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> <3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
Message-ID: <200309281416.56306.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 28 September 2003 1:48 pm, Grish wrote:
> Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> >This prevents using a smtpd restriction under Postfix that does address
> >checks on from: before granting a connection.
>
> /me waits for the long, drawn-out debate on the advantages and
> disadvantages of a ptr, flames against you for doing a reverse looking,
> flames to those flaming, multiple suggestions to allow
> lists.pdxlinux.org without a ptr, and then a full campaign to elect who
> should be in charge of implementing a ptr...
>

So... you've been following this list for awhile, haven't you. :)
The bottom line is many admins don't bother with PTRs, so I'm not sure I'd 
consider it reliable for any kind of filtering or blocking.

Just for fun, do traceroutes on samspade.org, it flags DNS errors. Almost all 
the time it's "xxx has no reverse DNS configured."

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep 28 14:47:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep 28 14:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NO ptr record for lists.pdxlinux.org...
In-Reply-To: <3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 
	<3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
Message-ID: <1064785440.22725.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 13:48, Grish wrote:
> Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> 
> >This prevents using a smtpd restriction under Postfix that does address
> >checks on from: before granting a connection.  
> >
> >  
> >
> /me waits for the long, drawn-out debate on the advantages and 
> disadvantages of a ptr, flames against you for doing a reverse looking, 
> flames to those flaming, multiple suggestions to allow 
> lists.pdxlinux.org without a ptr, and then a full campaign to elect who 
> should be in charge of implementing a ptr...

In the interest of spam control, one doesn't want 
to accept incoming smtp connections from people 
who won't identify themselves properly making it 
difficult to deal with them in an affective manner.  

Black hole is an option, but noone wants to receive 
stuff they don't want anyways just to throw it
away.
  
You need to know you don't want the email before you
grant the connection to download it, what are your
options here?

There are legal concerns with allowing connections 
for spammers of any sort unchecked, liability 
concerns.  For example, imagine someone decides
to figure out you have an email address and
then sends illegal material to it.  If law 
enforcement finds out about this material say 
you go to prison for it.  I think it's clear 
that you can be held responsible for anything 
on your computer no matter how it got there, 
even if only a ghost of it is left.

Why is anyone against requiring Internet sites 
to maintain proper PTR records for all mail service?  
Is a special dns record needed for each mail address 
at a site or is just a reverse record for the mail 
server's ip address needed?  Anyone have a better 
idea to address the problems of fake from, no abuse
address that works, fake reply, etc?

Yes this involves looking someone up before accepting 
them in, however, forcing spammers to use addresses 
that are registered is more likely to push them out 
into the open where it's possible to get them or 
someone relaying them to stop sending the messages
to your server.  The latter is usually the best 
solution.

The only alternative I can think of is to use Postfix's
pattern matching and limit acceptable addresses to the
one's I know I need to work with, for obvious
reasons this is a dubious approach as it doesn't 
allow for growth very easily where I don't know how
to do this either.

More on the legal end, how can you best protect yourself 
from what may come to you or go out from you via email?

     --  Michael C. Robinson



From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Sep 28 15:14:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Sep 28 15:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] forensics (WAS NO ptr record for lists.pdxlinux.org...)
In-Reply-To: <1064785440.22725.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
	 <1064785440.22725.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1064787836.14667.1055.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 14:44, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> There are legal concerns with allowing connections 
> for spammers of any sort unchecked, liability 
> concerns.  For example, imagine someone decides
> to figure out you have an email address and
> then sends illegal material to it.  If law 
> enforcement finds out about this material say 
> you go to prison for it.  I think it's clear 
> that you can be held responsible for anything 
> on your computer no matter how it got there, 
> even if only a ghost of it is left.

You've brought up an interesting forensics problem that
I've been concerned about for many years and have written
and lectured about. If, for example, child pornography is
attached to a message in your e-mail inbox, I doubt you'd
be prosecuted (even with the present administration)
because it can be assumed that it's unsolicited. 

But delete the message and the attachment and the data is
logically deleted but still there on your hard disk with,
perhaps, no way to determine that it's origin was 
unsolicited incoming e-mail.

However, this may have little to do with the discussion of
PTR records.

Ed






From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Sep 28 15:18:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Sep 28 15:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NO ptr record for lists.pdxlinux.org...
In-Reply-To: <1064785440.22725.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
	 <1064785440.22725.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1064788069.16341.1060.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 14:44, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> Why is anyone against requiring Internet sites 
> to maintain proper PTR records for all mail service?  
> Is a special dns record needed for each mail address 
> at a site or is just a reverse record for the mail 
> server's ip address needed?

Just a single record for the IP address (the in-addr.arpa
domain) normally maintained by your ISP or whoever the
ISP delegates that portion of the in-addr.arpa address
space to.

Ed

I've tried, in my naive way, to install this pkg. thus:  hda1 = /boot @ 
20MB; hda5 = / @ 1.7GB; hda6 = /home @400MB; hda7 = swapspace2 @ 2x 
SDRAM; 2.1GB Unallocated.  Hdb = Win2k w/several partitions.  Hda set up 
came from "Linux for Windows Addicts" by Michael J. Miller (who no 
longer has a valid e-mail adr. as published in his book).

With this partitioning set up, I assumed the /boot would be the 
partition that all boot-related files would go into, however, when I 
bootup, I don't get any OS choice.  To switch from Win2k to Linux, or 
vise versa, I have to either edit the default hdd in my BIOS, or leave 
it set to the Win2k hdd & use a floppy to get to Linux.  What's wrong

hand-edited, & if so what are the needed commands?

recommendations, or not???

word-like text editor to use in Linux?  My text editor of choice in DOS

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep 28 15:53:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep 28 15:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NO ptr record for lists.pdxlinux.org...
In-Reply-To: <200309281416.56306.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	<3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>  <200309281416.56306.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1064789427.23947.109.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> Carla Schroder
> www.tuxcomputing.com
> this message brought to you
> by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About six sites didn't resolve.  I think part of the problem is that
you often have to ask the ISP to enter a reverse record because the
ISP controls it.  I bet 90+% of UCE comes from sites that don't have 
a PTR record.  Sites need to be required to have abuse addresses
that work.  If you don't figure out how to deny a connection for
spammers, you've lost to them.  I think a lot of people spam 
regardless of whether or not they get the reply they want based 
on perhaps as little as where you've been or even less than that.

One option is a program that tests email to see if it's spam then
email a reply back if it is deemed so indicating why.  Unfortunately,
the reply-to address can be wrong or in the case of some spammers, 
disabled because they are abusive.  I've seen cases where the abuse
address is disabled also, this is true for yahoo.com.  I block 
yahoo.com now because I get spam from it and can't complain about
it.

At ftp://ftp.robinson-west.com I have rfc2505, rfc2505.txt, which
states that we should all be running PTR records and check for
them with our mail servers as one measure to control and reduce
spam.  My ISP controls my public subnet's reverse zone where I 
contact them about what records I need for it.  For my private
dns I do forward and reverse dns for every computer on my lan.
It's not hard to do reverse zones if you can do forward zones.

Well I have some classmates in physics whose email addresses are
the following, domain only: hotmail.com, msn.com, and hotmail.com
again.  Are there reverse records for these domains or do I need
to do something special under postfix to let my classmates email
me so as not to abandon the deny unknown clients in the from
line protection?

     --  Michael C. Robinson



From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep 28 16:30:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Sun Sep 28 16:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fortune program, I want to adjust it for my site...
Message-ID: <1064791607.23947.124.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I'm a novice C and C++ programmer so I thought I'd look at the source
code of fortune-mod to figure out how to add a feature that would make
it easy say in a gtk program to select individual fortunes for removal
and add new ones.  I can't read the code, it doesn't make sense.
Is there a way to easily a create a new fortunes database?

Anyone know of a good reference on Linux C as opposed to ansi C?
I want to know what the system libraries are being included and why
they are being included.  This Amy what's her name didn't put any
comments in the code to help me follow it where there seem to be
a lot of macros.  The makefile seems to be far more complex
than anything I've ever done.  My idea of a makefile is:

all:main.c etc.c
	gcc -o desired_name main.c etc.c
clean:
	rm -f *.o desired_name

A lot of packages require fortune-mod under Redhat, but I'm not sure
why.  I like the idea of a fortune program and wanda the fish is
cool, but I want to fix what the actual fortunes are.  There are text
files and .dat files.  Apparently the .dat files hold pointers into 
the text files.  Is there a way to update the text files, a.k.a delete
the fortunes I don't like, and then rebuild the .dat files?  There are a
lot of things I don't agree with in fortune or don't find particularly
funny.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Sun Sep 28 16:55:03 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sun Sep 28 16:55:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] NO ptr record for lists.pdxlinux.org...
In-Reply-To: <1064789427.23947.109.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> <200309281416.56306.carla@bratgrrl.com> <1064789427.23947.109.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200309281659.48687.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Sunday 28 September 2003 3:50 pm, Michael C. Robinson wrote:>
> About six sites didn't resolve.  I think part of the problem is that
> you often have to ask the ISP to enter a reverse record because the
> ISP controls it.  I bet 90+% of UCE comes from sites that don't have
> a PTR record.  Sites need to be required to have abuse addresses
> that work.  If you don't figure out how to deny a connection for
> spammers, you've lost to them.  I think a lot of people spam
> regardless of whether or not they get the reply they want based
> on perhaps as little as where you've been or even less than that.

The Holy Grail of email management is finding that magic method of identifying 
spam. Unfortunately there is no magic spam key. It's a continually escalating 
war, and the dirty bastards ruin everything they touch. They're like rats who 
piss on what they can't eat. William James said it best in "Thanks the 
Spammers", http://www.spamreaper.com/thankspammers.html

Spammers get paid to send zillions of messages. I doubt that many care how 
many are received, let alone read. 

> One option is a program that tests email to see if it's spam then
> email a reply back if it is deemed so indicating why.  Unfortunately,
> the reply-to address can be wrong or in the case of some spammers,
> disabled because they are abusive.  I've seen cases where the abuse
> address is disabled also, this is true for yahoo.com.  I block
> yahoo.com now because I get spam from it and can't complain about
> it.

Most spam not only has forged return addresses, they're sent via open relays 
and hijacked proxies. Any kind of autoreply is as useless and annoying as 
those lame anti-virus programs that autoreply to the forged sender. Which is 
what, all of them?

>
> At ftp://ftp.robinson-west.com I have rfc2505, rfc2505.txt, which
> states that we should all be running PTR records and check for
> them with our mail servers as one measure to control and reduce
> spam.  My ISP controls my public subnet's reverse zone where I
> contact them about what records I need for it.  For my private
> dns I do forward and reverse dns for every computer on my lan.
> It's not hard to do reverse zones if you can do forward zones.

No, it's not difficult at all. I don't know why so many admins don't.

>
> Well I have some classmates in physics whose email addresses are
> the following, domain only: hotmail.com, msn.com, and hotmail.com
> again.  Are there reverse records for these domains or do I need
> to do something special under postfix to let my classmates email
> me so as not to abandon the deny unknown clients in the from
> line protection?
>

Having good whitelists is crucial when using any kind of filtering or 
blocking. I think blocking mail based on PTRs is going to lose a lot of 
legitimate mail, if it were me I'd monitor the logs very closely, and make 
sure my whitelists were complete.

When you look at all the millions of winduhs boxes on cable/dsl that have been 
Trojaned and turned into happy little spam relays, and all the crap proxying 
software for winduhs that ships wide open, such as the extremely popular 
AnalogX, and all the other hijacked proxies and open relays in the world, and 
spam-friendly countries like Brazil, China, and Korea, and organized 
spam-crime gangs in Russia... well I don't what to think, except it's a 
complex problem. And it's frustrating to have a pile of perfectly good 
sticks, and no spammers at hand to beat.

--

Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

> I don't know the answer to your question, but I don't want you to feel

  Er, "Tim", we're writing about two different things. Strange as it may

styles for books, reports, articles, letters and so on. In OO.o there are
styles for paragraphs as well as for pages.

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Sep 28 17:57:02 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun Sep 28 17:57:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.1 Install - Boot Menu Not Avail.
In-Reply-To: <01C3841B.B6F0BE80.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
References: <01C3841B.B6F0BE80.drcaldwell@cablerocket.com>
Message-ID: <3F77832F.2000308@pacifier.com>

da.haole.boy wrote:
> hda1 = /boot @ 20MB; 
 > hda5 = / @ 1.7GB;
 > hda6 = /home @400MB;
 > hda7 = swapspace2 @ 2x SDRAM;
 > 2.1GB Unallocated.
 > Hdb = Win2k w/several partitions.

> With this partitioning set up, I assumed the /boot would be the 
> partition that all boot-related files would go into, however, when I 
> bootup, I don't get any OS choice.  

 > To switch from Win2k to Linux, or vise versa, I have to either edit the
 > default hdd in my BIOS, or leave it set to the Win2k hdd & use a floppy
 > to get to Linux.

This scheme looks okay, 20Mb used to be plenty for /boot, and will probably 
be okay as long as you don't install more than two Mandrake kernels.

Partitions are not your problem.  Looks like you don't have a boot loader 
installed or setup properly.  Mandrake is probably using 'grub' by now, the 
other option is 'lilo'.

Boot into Linux and look for the config file for your boot loader. (If using 
grub: /boot/grub/grub.conf, or if using lilo: /etc/lilo.conf)

If you don't find either of these, or do this anyway, find the X-windows gui 
app from your menu.  (I'm not familiar with Mandrake so you'll have to poke 
around.)  If you can't find anything at all in the menus, bring up a 
terminal (xterm, rxvt, gnome-terminal, whatever) and type,
	
	$ rpm -q grub
	
if it returns "package grub is not installed", then you now know you need to 
install it.  If it returns an affimative response, then post your grub.conf 
here and we'll see what we can see.


...
 > is there a more word-like text editor to use in Linux?  My text editor of
 > choice in DOS was QEdit...

I highly recommend 'nedit' (If it's not already installed or on your cd, get 
it here, http://www.nedit.org/)

Most excellent editor, no bullshit.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From bsr at spek.org  Sun Sep 28 19:11:01 2003
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Sun Sep 28 19:11:01 2003

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 18:49, Sandy Herring wrote:
> On Sun, 28 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote: 
> > I think my email address is too attractive.  Some of the stuff 
> > I'm getting, let's just say it's probably targeted at the name 
> > in my email address because it's a male name.  
> [...]
> 
> I don't think supposed gender of the username has anything to do with
> targeting. I get all kinds of crap for both sexes. Changing your username
> won't help unless you /never/ use it in a way that spammers can discern.
> 
> Sandy
> -- 
> Sandy Herring, RHCE                        o              sandy at herring.org
> Peck of Pickled Pisces               __  o               http://herring.org/
> UNIX or Web authoring questions?  |\/ o\  o  http://herring.org/finger.html
> ->http://herring.org/techie.html  |/\__/     http://herring.org/pub-key.asc

Has the time come to use organizations that understand one's beliefs and
preferences for email filtering with the technical skill to deal with
the current abuses.  It wastes your time and frankly some of this stuff
arguably shouldn't be dealt with for too long because it's nasty.  In
this scenario, your mail server can only connect to the proxy and it's
current identity is given to the proxy so that all email routed to you
goes to the proxy for checking and the proxy handles abuse claims, etc. 
Internet service providers in our country can block transmission to and
from the open proxies of foreign countries if there's an easy way to
detect these.  If these countries want to reach us, they'll close those
open proxies when they're blocked or set up acceptable exchangers.  
It's hardball, but I bet it would work.

One curiosity about the junk were all getting, has anyone found an easy
way to reduce getting the same stuff twice?  A sum of the characters in
the bodies of some of these messages would be enough for a test to find
and block subsequent copies as a lot of this spam seems to be the exact
same message multiple times.

Looking on one spam list I found out some of the stuff I'm getting is
definitely spam.

computer does. She can send email, I can ping my computer and the
firewall from her box but she suddenly can't send email from her box. My
machine has no such problem. I've tried Evolution and Mozilla Mail from

and hers. What could be the problem?

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Sun Sep 28 21:14:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 20:19, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> My wife's computer runs through the Ipcop firewall box just as my
> computer does. She can send email, I can ping my computer and the
> firewall from her box but she suddenly can't send email from her box. My
> machine has no such problem. I've tried Evolution and Mozilla Mail from
> her machine and neither works. Both smtp settings are the same in my box
> and hers. What could be the problem?
> Thanks, Dirk
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 

How does the ipcop firewall forward outbound requests for
masquerading?  In my environment you need to have the
correct ip to go out and the administrator needs to run
a command to add a specific forwarding rule for you.
Is the ipcop box an smtp server that needs to relay
her computer as well as yours?  Are you both on the
same subnet?  Do you know if there's a heavy load
of email or other data that could explain an
outage?  Does your machine and hers compare
performance wise?  How about programs she is
running in the background?

     --  Michael

From mikedela at ipns.com  Mon Sep 29 08:21:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Mon Sep 29 08:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] server unresponsive random Monday mornings
Message-ID: <1064848838.1265.14.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

I've got a RH 7.1 box that goes down on apparently random Sundays, some
time after 0400, after it runs it's nightly backups. By down, I mean
that it's powered up but unresponsive to the outside world in any
meaningful way. No display, no samba, no ssh, nothing I can verify from
my remote location. I have the customer power it down via big black wire
in the back (they broke the case switch, pressing too hard one Monday
morning a few months ago) 

It comes up just fine, ready to work it's heart out.

I cannot find anything in the logs that points me in a single direction
that I can tell.

Should I be keeping a new kind of log?

I'm not running any cron jobs on a weekly basis that could be jamming me
up, where do I find out when logrotate decides to do it's thing?

There is plenty of space on all partitions.

Historically, it has not failed,in any way, due to hardware.

There's this /var/log/samba/nmb.log entry this morning that makes me
curious, though:

[2003/09/27 04:02:57, 0] nmbd/nmbd.c:sig_hup(92)
  Got SIGHUP dumping debug info.
[2003/09/27 04:02:57, 0] nmbd/nmbd_workgroupdb.c:dump_workgroups(292)
  dump_workgroups()
   dump workgroup on subnet    192.168.10.1: netmask=  255.255.255.0:
        WORKGROUP(1) current master browser = NEW


Any thoughts or recommendations appreciated.

> [2003/09/27 04:02:57, 0] nmbd/nmbd.c:sig_hup(92)
>   Got SIGHUP dumping debug info.
> [2003/09/27 04:02:57, 0] nmbd/nmbd_workgroupdb.c:dump_workgroups(292)

> -- 
> Mike De La Mater
> Small Business Networks and Consulting
> 503-702-6749
> mikedela at ipns.com
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

The most consistent cause of system failure is flaky power
supplies, power connections, drive performance, and in the
case of one machine I had it was shorting.  Do you have enough
electrical power, I guess I recommend 300 watt or larger power
supply.  Are the drives that are installed designed for the
distances they are set apart from each other?  Does the processor
stay cool enough or does it overheat slowly and trigger an
emergency halt?  what does pstree give you and is the server
running anything it shouldn't?  What version of samba is running?
Can you put samba on a cheap say 486 to isolate it from this system
and see if in fact that is the part that's failing?  Do you have
one and a proper wins server set up?  Does your customer have too
many cascaded hubs?  Do you have one samba domain master browser?
Is authentication information for samba on this box or another,
you'd be amazed how often I cause a problem by taking down a 
system that another one depends on for it's operation.

     --  Michael  
 




From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Sep 29 08:46:22 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Sep 29 08:46:22 2003
Subject: [PLUG] server unresponsive random Monday mornings
In-Reply-To: <1064848838.1265.14.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1064848838.1265.14.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309290836000.6630@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 29 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I've got a RH 7.1 box that goes down on apparently random Sundays,
> some time after 0400, after it runs it's nightly backups.

Take a peek at /etc/crontab. It'll look something like this:

# run-parts
01 * * * * root run-parts /etc/cron.hourly
02 4 * * * root run-parts /etc/cron.daily
22 4 * * 0 root run-parts /etc/cron.weekly
42 4 1 * * root run-parts /etc/cron.monthly

System-level cron jobs scheduled for daily, weekly, or monthly
execution will run between 4:00 and 5:00 a.m.

In particular, the /etc/cron.weekly/* scripts are launched at 4:22 on
Sunday mornings.

> By down, I mean that it's powered up but unresponsive to the outside
> world in any meaningful way. No display, no samba, no ssh, nothing I
> can verify from my remote location.

A serial console connection might be useful in that case; of course,
if /bin/login is unresponsive, you're pretty well hosed. :-)

> I'm not running any cron jobs on a weekly basis that could be
> jamming me up, where do I find out when logrotate decides to do it's
> thing?

logrotate is runs at 4:02 every morning as part of /etc/cron.daily.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

is that you should be able to plug one in at any time to the

One thing that has been locking up on me in Redhat 7.3 is apm.
Why anything was ever implemented in bios for this I'll never know.
If manufacturers would stick to a standard or publish the apm design
they use with their products, it would help.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Sep 29 09:47:02 2003
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Sep 29 09:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Spam, bogofilter, other
Message-ID: <20030929164607.GB11205@gate.kl-ic.com>

> Complaints about spam.

Michael, the spam you are getting is not because you have a male name,
it is because you use a common one.  Initial+name cuts it way down.
Why?  Because sites that respond properly to incorrectly addressed
email let the spammer's bots know that "fred at site.com" "joe at site.com"
"sam at site.com" aren't valid, while passing through "michael at site.com". 
Sadly, adhering to RFCs isn't always wise.

Registered DNS + Common name + No bounce = new victim.  While jeme
probably gets spam, I betcha he doesn't get the 200 per day that he
would get as james.  Unless, of course, we are being less than
fastidious with this mail group, and it is being mined by spammers.

I installed bogofilter.  It is nowhere near perfect (specificially,
it is not tweakable to detect certain things like random title
characters, or html attachments only, as probable spam) but it
does knock out 90% of the stuff.  Keeps me sane.

On the one hand, spammers make me livid and I fear that if I ever
encounter one I would be in deep legal doodoo afterwards.  On the 
other hand, the reason spam happens at all is because a few people
want the products, and right now there is not a better way to serve
these customers.  If those customers could learn about their viagra
someplace else, and if the fraud merchants were identified and
jailed, and countries that ignored local fraud merchants saw
their international communication links go dead,  spam would be
far less profitable.  Most of the trailer-court DSL crowd would
have to find more honorable work, like armed robbery. 

Think about it.  Why would any merchant pay to insert their ads
into my mailflow (at $900/million current pricing, 0.03% response
rate) when they could pay far less for a venue that targets their
demographic?  Spam is ludicrously cheap, but a targeted alternative
with a 0.5% response has got to be a better way to spend a K buck, and
you don't have angry victims ready to run you through a meat slicer.

Spam is the price we pay for ineffectively serving some customers,
and treating some kinds of products with scorn, and not prosecuting
crimes that are already on the books.  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com  Mon Sep 29 09:59:01 2003
From: Steve.Daggett at fiserv.com (Daggett, Steve)
Date: Mon Sep 29 09:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Fortune program, I want to adjust it for my site...
Message-ID: <05AD3C7EEA42D311809300902785AC8A0559C7A1@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Michael C. Robinson:
> I'm a novice C and C++ programmer so I thought I'd look at the source
> code of fortune-mod to figure out how to add a feature that would make
> it easy say in a gtk program to select individual fortunes for removal
> and add new ones.  I can't read the code, it doesn't make sense.
> Is there a way to easily a create a new fortunes database?

  Fortune uses strfile.h to create a string database.  
> 
> Anyone know of a good reference on Linux C as opposed to ansi C?

  All the Linux distro's I've seen use GCC (EGCS) by default.  It's ANSI C
compatible.  You should be writing to POSIX, unless you intended your code
to only run on Linux.  The GTK+ and Gnome libs runs on non-Linux platforms.
See the GNU and Gnome pages for coding guidelines. 

> I want to know what the system libraries are being included and why
> they are being included.  This Amy what's her name didn't put any
> comments in the code to help me follow it where there seem to be
> a lot of macros.  The makefile seems to be far more complex
> than anything I've ever done.  My idea of a makefile is:

  Welcome to the joys of Open Source!  There are some *very* clever coders
out there.  All I can say is; study the O'Reilly "Using Make" book and then
go beat your head against the code until it makes sense.  
> 
> all:main.c etc.c
> 	gcc -o desired_name main.c etc.c
> clean:
> 	rm -f *.o desired_name
> 
> A lot of packages require fortune-mod under Redhat, but I'm not sure
> why.  I like the idea of a fortune program and wanda the fish is
> cool, but I want to fix what the actual fortunes are.  There are text
> files and .dat files.  Apparently the .dat files hold pointers into 
> the text files.  Is there a way to update the text files, a.k.a delete
> the fortunes I don't like, and then rebuild the .dat files?  
> There are a
> lot of things I don't agree with in fortune or don't find particularly
> funny.

Do: man fortune.  There are command line switches to modify fortunes
behavior.  man strfile will tell you how to access the string databases.  

Steve D...



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Sep 29 10:04:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Sep 29 10:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX in the real world
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309290948280.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309290948280.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Mon, 29 Sep 2003, Aaron Burt wrote:

> I've just started in the engineering program at PSU.  I'd heard
> engineering folks use TeX a lot, and lo and behold, my first math class
> discusses LaTeX in the syllabus.

Aaron,

  Take a look at LyX (http://www.lyx.org). It's a gui front-end to LaTeX and
it makes writing, math and tables much simpler than text-mode LaTeX (never
mind TeX -- except for Dean).

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Sep 29 11:17:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)

Subject: [PLUG] Setting up selective allow under Postfix...
In-Reply-To: <1064726344.12830.7.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291057300.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On 27 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

I thought you said you were leaving.  Welcome back.

> I am wondering how to create a list of allowed smtp senders under
> postfix

You mean restricting who can send mail out via your host?

> and I'm also wonder how the deny unknown clients in the from
> line for smtpd restrictions works since that option seems to block
> the plug list.  I want to implement this so I don't have to deal
> with people who forge the from, reply-to, etc.
>
> Unfortunately, seems like a lot of people's email is broken somehow
> and the lookups are failing even though they exist and are valid.

That's not broken, that's just atypical.

It sounds like you're trying to reinvent the wheel there, and making the
standard mistakes.  Have you considered simply using one of the excellent
anti-spam systems already out there?  SpamAssassin and smamc/spamd both
work well using the heuristic approach you seem to be taking, though
Bogofilter works well enough for me.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Sep 29 11:45:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Sep 29 11:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] server unresponsive random Monday mornings
In-Reply-To: <1064848838.1265.14.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291124330.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On 29 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I've got a RH 7.1 box that goes down on apparently random Sundays, some
> time after 0400, after it runs it's nightly backups.

Dang.  Sounds like it's dying during logrotate or backup, which can be
the highest-stress time for a typical office server.  There also may be a
problem with the backup hardware.

Do an "echo 1 > /proc/sys/kernel/sysrq" to turn on Magic Sysrq.  After
that, you may be able to get the keyboard and display back with an
Alt-PrintScreen-R.  Does it run X?

> I cannot find anything in the logs that points me in a single direction
> that I can tell.

Not even in the old messages or dmesg logs?

Unless it started immediately after you changed kernels, this is almost
certainly a hardware problem.  It sounds like the customer is very
frustrated with this problem, and I'd STRONGLY recommend you cut out
the diagnostics and fix it ASAP.

Compared to lost business, damaged reputation, ill will and legal
expenses, it's not terribly expensive or difficult to simply move the
drives and backup into another box and test the old one at your leisure.
And yes, that's even if you have to buy a ticket and fly there.

Make sure you run a full backup after the swap to make sure it's not the
backup system that's killing it.

Also, is the server on a decent UPS?  Maybe there's a regular brownout or
power spike that's doing it.




From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Sep 29 12:04:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Sep 29 12:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Spam, bogofilter, other
In-Reply-To: <20030929164607.GB11205@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20030929164607.GB11205@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309291146160.25972@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 29 Sep 2003, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> > Complaints about spam.
>
> Registered DNS + Common name + No bounce = new victim.  While jeme
> probably gets spam, I betcha he doesn't get the 200 per day that he
> would get as james.  Unless, of course, we are being less than
> fastidious with this mail group, and it is being mined by spammers.

I would guess that most of my spam comes to me via an address harvested
from this list.  The few other lists on which I participate use different
mail addresses.  This is the only list public list to which I subscribe
with my standard address.

But you're right.  I don't get anything like 200 spams each day.  And my
name (as well as Michael's) is gender-ambiguous and I would still say
nearly all of my spam is for viagra and penis enlargement systems.

This is one of the many reasons that, if I were ever in the unfortunate
circumstance of having to name a human being, I would certainly choose
something unusual if not downright unique.  While it's a pain the patootie
to have to spell your name to people all the time and have each teacher
call you something different your entire school career (until you get old
enough for proper respect and then they only botch your last name in a
couple of different ways), it's well worth it to be able to do a google
search and know the results are for you and to not get random spam and the
like.

I mean, until we start referring to everyone by their Universal Security
Identification Number, our given names should be unique handles.

> I installed bogofilter.  It is nowhere near perfect (specificially, it
> is not tweakable to detect certain things like random title characters,
> or html attachments only, as probable spam) but it does knock out 90% of
> the stuff.  Keeps me sane.

I use spamassassin and it works just handily-dandily.

I'm using the stuff at some fella's Debian backports archive.  I'll post
the apt.sources if anyone's interested.  It works great and I get fewer
than 1% error since I started feeding my mailboxes through as ham and the
missed spam as spam.

That reminds me, is it necessary to pass the filtered mail back through
spamassassin for extra weighting or is it just read once and counted?

I guess I'm just unsure of whether the system needs reenforcing.

> and [if] countries that ignored local fraud merchants saw their
> international communication links go dead, spam would be far less
> profitable.

Of course, that's illegal by treaty.  It's a restriction of trade and the
WTO forbids such interference.

> Most of the trailer-court DSL crowd would have to find more honorable
> work, like armed robbery.

I think it's the midwestern subdivision DSL crowd.  Those crackerjack
houses have replaced the trailer park as the signifier of poor white
america's delusion of success in the past twenty years.

> Spam is the price we pay for ineffectively serving some customers, and
> treating some kinds of products with scorn, and not prosecuting crimes
> that are already on the books.

Woah.

Spam is the price we pay for insisting that the only way to improve the
human condition is by driving up consumption at a rate faster than our
increases in productivity.  This requires a constant increase in the type
and quantity of items we purchase.  It's not good enough to just buy food,
clothing, and shelter.  The economy can't survive unless you're also
buying a bunch of shit you don't need like viagra, life-like baby dolls
(made from a latex cast of a still-born baby), and USB thumb-drive
vibrating "love" toys.

If we just did the RIGHT thing and brought up employment by dropping
profits, increasing wages, and decreasing work hours (like we did seventy
years ago), people could be employed honorably (producing food, clothing,
and shelter) and not turn to such dubious lines of income.

It's time for the 30 hour work week and a $15 minimum hourly wage.

J.

    jeme at brelin.net

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Sep 29 13:27:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Sep 29 13:27:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] X "pauses", kernel questions
In-Reply-To: <3F787513.5080206@spek.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291008270.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org> <3F787513.5080206@spek.org>
Message-ID: <20030929202608.GB4556@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Mon, Sep 29, 2003 at 11:08:19AM -0700, Brent Rieck wrote:
> Aaron Burt wrote:
> >Can you tell what the computer's doing during the pauses?  Is the hard
> >disk spinning up or is it thrashing about?
> 
> I can't tell, my case is too quiet when it's closed, too loud when it's 
> open, and I don't have a hard drive light.

Place the busness end of a screwdriver (#4 phillips works well) on the
drive before unlocking xlock and put the butt of the handle firmly
against your ear, you can almost always hear the vibrations of the
other end clearly through any background noise.

This is also great for localizing problems in general.

-Rogan

> 
> >I understand that the 2.4.10+ series is more "swappy" than others, but I
> >thought RH hacked a bit on that for their distro kernel.
> 
> Would upgrading to the latest 2.4.22 help you think?
> 
> thanks,
> Brent
> 
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Sep 29 14:23:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Sep 29 14:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pdf, postscript and text
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309291413100.6500@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm still having problems with this triad (ghostscript-6.52 on Red Hat
7.3) and I'm not sure where to go for help.

  First, I print a pdf file to disk (*.ps) and get two different file sizes:
10M with xpdf and 25M with acroread. Cannot understand why.

  Second, with this same pdf file, I cannot get pstotext, ps2ascii or
prescript to successfully disassemble the postscript file to a text file.
All this used to work, of course. The postscript file was created on a
Microsoft system at a federal agency.

  I've looked on the cmu "Gallery of Adobe Remedies", but that discusses
protected pdf files. I've found three different versions of prescript (-0.1,
-2.2 in python and one in perl) but no docs or explanation of why they may
not be working.

  The last time I tried to build ghostscript-7.07 from the .src.rpm, I ran
into a big bunch of compatibility problems with the existing 6.52
installation.

  If anyone is good with this type of conversion among text types, I'd
greatly appreciate some guidance or other help.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Sep 29 15:03:02 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Sep 29 15:03:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pdf, postscript and text
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309291413100.6500@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291451490.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Mon, 29 Sep 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I'm still having problems with this triad (ghostscript-6.52 on Red Hat
> 7.3) and I'm not sure where to go for help.
>
>   First, I print a pdf file to disk (*.ps) and get two different file sizes:
> 10M with xpdf and 25M with acroread. Cannot understand why.

Totally different PS generators, thus different PS code.  Differences in
graphics rendering and compression become significant here.

>   Second, with this same pdf file, I cannot get pstotext, ps2ascii or
> prescript to successfully disassemble the postscript file to a text file.
> All this used to work, of course. The postscript file was created on a
> Microsoft system at a federal agency.

>From the sound of it (beeeg PS files, no text) these are PDFs containing
bitmaps of printed or scanned output.  In other words, you don't have
text, just pictures of text.  Does the text select tool in acroread work?

Sounds like you're stuck with extracting bitmaps (GS can print to TIFF and
other formats) and feeding 'em through an OCR program.


That's your tax dollars at work,
  Aaron

From Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com  Mon Sep 29 15:20:03 2003
From: Anderson.Robert at menlolog.com (Anderson, Robert H - MWT)
Date: Mon Sep 29 15:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] cvs question
Message-ID: <25E622D843625C40BE0EEC150B437C1B0173EE75@cnfqe029.cnf.prod.cnf.com>

Use the commitinfo file in the CVSROOT to specify a program to run on
commit. Then write a perl script, or something to allow or disallow the
commit. See...

http://www.cvshome.org/docs/manual/cvs-1.11.6/cvs_18.html#SEC165

...for more details on the commitinfo file.

-Rob Anderson

do at this point:

Copyright (C) 2001 artofcode LLC, Benicia, CA.  All rights reserved.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Sep 29 17:09:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Sep 29 17:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Running gs on a .ps file for bit-mapped output
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309291550580.6500@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309291550580.6500@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86r81z3zps.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   I've read the gs man page several times without finding the
Rich> entire solution. From the command line I type:

  $ man gs

which says, in part:

    [...] Ghostscript may be built able to use many different output
    devices.  To see which devices your executable can use, run "gs
    -h".  [...]
   
So, try: 

  $ gs -h

Ooh.  "Available devices" looks promising.  Now, just compare "man
<ocr-program-name-here>" and you're on your way, if that is truly the
way you want to go.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Sep 29 18:13:02 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Mon Sep 29 18:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Can anyone rationally explain Open Office Presentor Stlye behavoir?
Message-ID: <1064884330.580.22.camel@kat>

[I am using ximian's rc4 of 1.1, but this happens all the time to every
version I have used.]

So I make a set of slides.

I use outline mode.

When I indent the outline level it changes the style (makes text
smaller).
When I modify the style, it modifies the text.

[This step may or may not be important]
Then I create a new slide.
I attempt to copy the slides from file 1 (open) to 2
It crashes


Now I save 1 as v3, and start to edit.

Now all the fonts are willy nilly.
When in outline mode, it uses the last font for the outline.  So if I am
sitting on the slide title, hit return, hit move right/indent/move in
outline, it stays at the title font, size, and attributes.  I can modify
the styles in present, which now have no bearing on the text.  If I
indent, it changes the bullet, but not the style.  

More often than not I cannot click on fill format mode (paint bucket). 
I read the help which says:

        Applies the selected style to an object on your slide. Click the
        paint bucket icon and then click an object in your slide to
        apply the style. Click the paint bucket icon again to exit this
        mode.

This does not appear to be true....


[Other factors]

For some reason it saved file 1 and file 2 as powerpoints.  I have no
idea why.

[History]

This has cost me untold hours of re-formating time for all the talks I
do. 

Can anyone explain how openoffice is *supposed* to work?

Thanks.  Sorry if this note is hard to follow, I am a bit frustrated.



-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com

>>>checks on from: before granting a connection.
>>>      
>>>
>>/me waits for the long, drawn-out debate on the advantages and
>>disadvantages of a ptr, flames against you for doing a reverse looking,
>>flames to those flaming, multiple suggestions to allow
>>lists.pdxlinux.org without a ptr, and then a full campaign to elect who
>>should be in charge of implementing a ptr...
>>
>>    
>>
>
>So... you've been following this list for awhile, haven't you. :)
>The bottom line is many admins don't bother with PTRs, so I'm not sure I'd 
>consider it reliable for any kind of filtering or blocking.
>

Indeed. I don't have a ptr on mine. :)

>Just for fun, do traceroutes on samspade.org, it flags DNS errors. Almost all 
>the time it's "xxx has no reverse DNS configured."

From guy1656 at ados.com  Mon Sep 29 23:43:02 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Mon Sep 29 23:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The battle for IOmega Ext. USB 250 Drive
Message-ID: <200309291610.10807.guy1656@ados.com>

This is REALLY getting frustrating:

I have an IOmega External ZIP drive (250MB)

It is simply a bitch to connect to my Mandrake 9.0 Box.

A good friend who first set up the system for me set it up so that I could 
jist type "mount /mnt/zip" from a command window and it would behave, just 
like say, mounting a floppy disk.

Then the computer changed, and figgured out how to disobey the command. Months 
ago, when I posted to this forum, a kind soul suggested:

 mount -t vfat /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/part4 /mnt/zip

... and that was miraculous. Then one day it too stopped working. The computer 
had figured out a way to beat me again.

So I installed VMWare and run W2K inside it. Because file system sharing in 
VMW 4.0 is straightforward enough for me to learn, I could fire up W2K, plug 
in my zip drive and have an info-box pop up ("W@#$# has found new Hardware: 
ZIP 250") and I could transfer files from the zip drive to my home directory 
(or whereever.)

Then computer got wise that I was actually getting things done, and I learned 
about "rmmod usb-storage" and "modprobe usb-storage."

But the computer has beaten me again: now VMWare won't even 'see' the USB 
drive when I plug it in.

MY QUESTION:

Is there an rpm (download & double-click to install, from your file system 
GUI) that will allow the ZIP drive to operate as flexibly as PLUG-n-PLAY is 
supposed to be? (OK, I'll tolerate one or two shell commands such as 
'mount.')

- GLL

of that and a perl-ified sed expression sounds like "appropriate
technology" in this case.

at Mr. Shell would also work.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep 30 01:57:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Sep 30 01:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] forensics (WAS NO ptr record for lists.pdxlinux.org...)
In-Reply-To: <1064787836.14667.1055.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1064781704.22725.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <3F77492D.2000108@egosurf.net>
	 <1064785440.22725.55.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	 <1064787836.14667.1055.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1064912161.580.35.camel@kat>

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 15:23, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 14:44, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> 
> You've brought up an interesting forensics problem that
> I've been concerned about for many years and have written
> and lectured about. If, for example, child pornography is
> attached to a message in your e-mail inbox, I doubt you'd
> be prosecuted (even with the present administration)
> because it can be assumed that it's unsolicited. 
> 
> But delete the message and the attachment and the data is
> logically deleted but still there on your hard disk with,
> perhaps, no way to determine that it's origin was 
> unsolicited incoming e-mail.
> 

While not Linux related I can speak to this directly.

Merely having child porn is not enough to convict.  You must be shown
that you know you have child porn.  Unfortunately that can be enough. 
Thus the reporters and researchers who have been prosecuted.

BTW, having worked a few cases,  there is usually *very* little doubt
when you have child porn on a machine.  Cases are not won on 1 images,
but often 100's, and 1000's.

I have seen some very air tight cases with 10's to 100's thrown out on
various technicalities.

So while it is possible to abuse civil rights in the name of protecting
children (i.e. get warrants, make people cough up information, change
laws), it is harder to actually jail someone based on the scenario
above.

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep 30 02:08:01 2003
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Sep 30 02:08:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] replacing multipule instances of text
In-Reply-To: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <1064912801.580.46.camel@kat>

On Tue, 2003-09-30 at 00:25, alex wrote:
> Hi All,
>         Ive searched high and low but have not been able to find a
> solution to this problem. For the background, I run a photo web
> server(around 600 pages or so and growing) at my home for a track club
> here in the Portland area. They recently acquired their own domain-name
> and I need
> to replace all the homepage links in the HTML with the updated address.
> 
> ex. replace www.foobar.com/RCTC/ with www.RCTC.com/
> 

The devil is in the details, but a quick hack that outlines the issues:

First we must list the files, then edit each file to a temp file, then
move the temp file over the original:

find /path/to/website/files -type f -exec sed -e 's/www.foobar.com\/RCTC\//www.RCTC.com\//g' {} > {}.sed \; -exec mv {}.sed {} \;

find find all files in the path given
  -type f says look at files.
  -exec save exec this until the \;
    {} is the filename being looked at (find subs in)
    sed runs the regex (-e) on the script
       the \ is to protect the / from looking like the end of the regex
       g says do global (i.e. work more than once a line).
     
Having not tried this I bet it fails for any of the following reasons.

I failed to escape the redirection '>'
The {}.sed does not work.
the second exec does not happen.
You have binaries with the expression in them.
You have other things besides links with the regex search pattern.
You have mixed case links.

So make sure you do this on a *copy* first.

For a fairly common thing to do, I have have not seen a common util to
do it.  Often the details cause this approach to work.  I know some web
editors will do this for you.

>         My question is..... is there an easy way to do this other than
> the obvious highlight and pasting of text?

-- 
Zot O'Connor

http://www.ZotConsulting.com
http://www.WhiteKnightHackers.com




From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Sep 30 02:13:02 2003

Date: Tue Sep 30 02:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OO.o page style creation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309280801500.30091@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309280801500.30091@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1064913095.580.50.camel@kat>

On Sun, 2003-09-28 at 08:09, Rich Shepard wrote:

Open a new doc for sanity sakes.

Hit F11 for the stylist.

Select the icon for page styles (4th one for me).

*Right Click* in the list.  You get New, or Modify (if you click on a
style).

Guess what New does :)

One nice thing is the definition of Next Style.  That means your
"first_page" style can always be followed by your "other_pages" style,
and other_pages are also followed by other_pages.

This can be used for number restarting and things like that.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Sep 30 02:26:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Sep 30 02:26:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] replacing multipule instances of text
In-Reply-To: <86ad8md5rj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
	<86ad8md5rj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <86r81ybpb7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

>>>>> "alex" == alex  <alexlinux at qwest.net> writes:

alex> ex. replace www.foobar.com/RCTC/ with www.RCTC.com/

alex> My question is..... is there an easy way to do this other than
alex> the obvious highlight and pasting of text?

Russell> I am not usually a Perl advocate, but Perl has an option to
Russell> do in-place editing (the -i option, I think).  Probably some
Russell> combination of that and a perl-ified sed expression sounds
Russell> like "appropriate technology" in this case.

According to Camel (2ed), page 332, you want something like:

   perl -p -i.bak -e "s/foo/bar/g;" <filenames>

If you've got a whole subtree of potential files to fix, get the
filenames to use with a recursive grep:

   grep -rl 'foo' . | xargs perl -p -i.bak -e "s/foo/bar/g;"

Lurking gurus welcome to correct as needed.  

Test before applying to valuable data.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``shtal latta wos ba padre u prett tu nashtonfi
seniorr at aracnet.com      mrlosh''  -- Bashgali Kafir for ``If you have
                         had diarrhoea many days you will surely die.''

Most deal with Logo, Lego, or game building.

I am trying to make most of the products work under linux or WINE for a
side project. 

http://www.ogi.edu/satacad/

For example:

Section 3: Six Wednesdays, October 15 - November 19 from 5:00 - 7:00 PM
at The OGI School of Science & Engineering at OHSU (Beaverton/Hillsboro)

Use game development to unlock the mystery of 'good' computer code. 

You will deconstruct and analyze the inner workings of the computer game
3-D Pong. This process will teach you about object-oriented design, data
logging and analysis, visual math and the intricacies of designing
user-friendly programs. By the end of the class, you will modify and add
to the game engine or design a multi-player computer game. 

Dr. Pavel Boychev of the University of Sophia in Bulgaria developed the
instructional game and engine.

INSTRUCTOR: Edwin Pilobello, a programmer for 25 years, is a Microsoft
and Visual NQC Developer and a Robolab beta-tester. 

GRADE LEVELS: 8 - 12 

TUITION: $135

Game Maker


DATES, TIMES & LOCATIONS: (Select one section.) 
Section 1: Five Saturdays, October 4 - November 1 from 9:30 AM - NOON at
Portland State University 
Section 2: Six Thursdays, October 16 - November 20 from 5:00 - 7:00 PM
at The OGI School of Science & Engineering at OHSU (Beaverton/Hillsboro)
Section 3: Six Mondays, October 20 - November 24 from 4:30 - 6:30 PM at
David Douglas District Office 
Section 4: Five Saturdays, November 8 - December 13 (no class on
November 29) from 1:00 - 3:30 PM at Portland State University 



 

  Create a video game using the technology of Game Maker. Learn how to
design and modify your own exciting PC game by studying examples from
Game Maker and analyzing the codes used. 

Begin by looking at basic games like Pong, then move up to more
intricate examples and coding language. With this understanding, you'll
learn how to control characters, objects and outcomes in your game, then
increase the difficulty level and add more features. If you've always
wanted to design a speed racing game or a version of PacMan, Mario, or
Dragon Drop, this class will provide the techniques you need. 

Game Maker is a freeware game engine designed by Dr. Mark Overmars of
the Computer Science Department of the University of Utrecht. 



INSTRUCTOR: Edwin Pilobello, a programmer for over 25 years, is a
Microsoft and Visual NQC Developer and Robolab beta-tester. 

GRADE LEVELS: 5 - 8 

TUITION: $145  

Edwin uses a set of free/share ware programs to teach with.  I recently
met with Edwin and he would love to see Linux ports of this language.

Contact me off list for more info.
