From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Tue Sep 30 03:07:02 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Tue Sep 30 03:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up selective allow under Postfix...
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291057300.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291057300.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <1064916272.30352.99.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Mon, 2003-09-29 at 11:15, Aaron Burt wrote:
> On 27 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> 
> I thought you said you were leaving.  Welcome back.
> 
> > I am wondering how to create a list of allowed smtp senders under
> > postfix
> 
> You mean restricting who can send mail out via your host?

I'm trying to control who can send mail to my host without blocking
valid email or making it overly difficult to increase the number of
people who can contact me through email.  Specifically, I latched on to
the PTR test thinking spammers love to use addresses that aren't
properly registered in dns.  Unfortunately, it appears that PCC isn't
properly registered either.  Is it pretty much settled that the
PTR check recommendation in rfc 2505 should be ignored?

Postfix has some ability to check dns based user maps, should I use
this and if so what should I set up?  I have the email addresses of
people that must get through to me.  To get pluglist through I
added it to mynetworks, there is probably a better way.
Considering the PTR checking has stopped most if not all the
trash, I like it unless there's a better way to do the same 
thing.  

In some cases to set up a mailing list for example it might make
sense to blacklist all people trying to send to it explicitly
whitelisting the people who are list members so that only 
trusted people can post.

Can spamassasin stop unsolicited or hostile connections based on 
content or does it only figure out what to throw away after it 
has been loaded down from wherever?  The latter can create the
impression a message is getting received which is something 
noone wants to portray when it comes to spam.

Would it be better to substitute greylisting for PTR checking? 
Something I read said that a lot of spam programs only transmit 
once where legitimate email sources will retransmit.  Essentially,
assume that a server that will retransmit is more trustworthy than 
one that won't.

One classmate got through to me, but evidently PCC addresses in 
general can't.

At one point if I have to receive spam I'm going to want a filter
to detect offensive patterns in email affectively and discard
those messages or at least move them out of the good stuff.

     --  Michael C. Robinson



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Sep 30 06:40:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Sep 30 06:40:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OO.o page style creation
In-Reply-To: <1064913095.580.50.camel@kat>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309280801500.30091@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <1064913095.580.50.camel@kat>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309300631340.9764@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Zot O'Connor wrote:

> Open a new doc for sanity sakes.

  Actually, Zot, this prevents a successful style creation. Read on.

> *Right Click* in the list.  You get New, or Modify (if you click on a
> style).

  This is not obvious; I learned this from a response on the OO.o users
list.

> Guess what New does :)

  True. Now try saving it and applying the new style to a template.

  It turns out that one needs to open the template for which the new page
style is intened to be applied (in my case, the 'letter' template with the
new page style as continuation pages).

  Now one can open the stylist (menu or F11), right-click for the menu and
create a new page style. After saving it, go to the template document and
add the new style in the Format > Page dialog box. Now it will be there.

  Also, by trial and error, I discovered that I needed to hit return until
the cursor moved to the next page in order to enter the information needed
in the header of the continuation pages. Saved modified style and went to
bed.

  One of the development team asked me to file a bug report because the
on-line help has nothing on creating a new style -- only how to create one
from selected text. So, I'll file a sharp point on the report for them.

Thanks,

Rich

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Sep 30 08:02:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Sep 30 08:02:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] replacing multipule instances of text
In-Reply-To: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309300745140.10999@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, alex wrote:

> I need to replace all the homepage links in the HTML with the
> updated address.
>
> ex. replace www.foobar.com/RCTC/ with www.RCTC.com/
>
> My question is..... is there an easy way to do this other than the
> obvious highlight and pasting of text?

Here's what I'd do, assuming that your example is correct. Let's say
that the documents are all in /var/www/rctc/public_html.

  #!/bin/sh
  #
  # out with old, in with the...
  oldurl="www.foobar.com/RCTC/"
  newurl="www.RCTC.com/"
  # make a backup copy of the document root
  mkdir /tmp/rctc
  cd /var/www/rctc
  tar cf - ./public_html | ( cd /tmp/rctc && tar xf -)
  # using the backup as a base, overwrite the production copies
  cd /tmp/rctc
  for f in $(grep -lr "$oldurl" public_html); do
    sed -e "s!$oldurl!$newurl!g" < $f > /var/www/rctc/$f
  done
  # make sure any remaining foobar references are valid
  grep -r 'www\.foobar\.com' /var/www/rctc/public_html/*

If something goes horribly wrong, you can always restore the temp copy
of the tree to the production environment. Otherwise, delete the temp
tree and head off to enjoy a cold beverage of your choice. :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I'd love to help out, Rich, but are those distro dependant?

Mike,

  I doubt that it's dependent on the distribution (which is RH 7.3 on this
box). I believe that the library name with the longest string is the "real"
file and all the shorter ones are symlinks. Here's what I have:

[root at salmo /usr/lib]# ll libcups*
-r--r--r--    1 root     root       853680 May 27 10:56 libcups.a
-r--r--r--    1 root     root       136522 Feb 14  2002 libcups.a.O
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           12 Jun 14 07:14 libcups.so -> libcups.so.2*
-r-xr-xr-x    1 root     root      1246408 May 27 10:56 libcups.so.2*
-r-xr-xr-x    1 root     root       800916 Feb 20  2002 libcups.so.2.O*
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root        99912 Mar  9  2003 libcups.so.2.saved*
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           14 Mar  9  2003 libcups.so.O -> libcups.so.2.O*
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root       319913 Apr 16  2002 libcupsdconf-gcc2.96.so*
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root         1170 Apr 16  2002 libcupsdconf.la*
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           23 Sep  4  2002 libcupsdconf.so -> libcupsdconf-gcc2.96.so*
-r--r--r--    1 root     root       519154 May 27 10:56 libcupsimage.a
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root        95078 Jun 13 11:04 libcupsimage.a.O*
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           17 Jun 14 07:14 libcupsimage.so -> libcupsimage.so.2*
-r-xr-xr-x    1 root     root      1238036 May 27 10:56 libcupsimage.so.2*
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root        68468 Apr 17  2002 libcupsimage.so.2.O*
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           19 Mar  6  2003 libcupsimage.so.O -> libcupsimage.so.2.O*

  So, I want to confirm that libcups.so.2 is the real file and
libcups.so.2.O should be a symlink, not an 800K file. Similarly with
libcupsimage.so.2.O. But, before I step on my toes and trip myself up I want
to confirm this.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Sep 30 09:37:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Sep 30 09:37:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] replacing multipule instances of text
In-Reply-To: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1064906744.13783.101.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <20030930163601.GA17660@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* alex <alexlinux at qwest.net> [2003-09-30 00:26]:
> ex. replace www.foobar.com/RCTC/ with www.RCTC.com/

#!/bin/sh

DIR=`ls -1`

for each in $DIR
do
	sed `s/www\.foobar\.com\/RCTC\//www\.RCTC\.com/g` $each > \
	/outputdir/$each
done

Run in each directory, making sure 'outputdir' exists beforehand.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Galen Seitz wrote:

> Rich, I know you have also used Lyx.  Why OO instead of Lyx for this
> task?

galen,

  Because I am writing this document for one agency to submit to another
agency on the former agency's letterhead. Therefore, I need to send it to
them in winWord format. If it was intended for submission on paper I'd use
LyX/LaTeX (which I'm getting to know _really_ well as I write my book).

  Besides, I write my letters with OO.o because it's much easier than
learning the idiosyncrasies of letter writing in LaTeX. Perhaps once I
create my letterhead as a graphic file for inclusion in a LaTeX letter I'll
change my mind.

Rich

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Sep 30 09:46:01 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Sep 30 09:46:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The battle for IOmega Ext. USB 250 Drive
In-Reply-To: <200309291610.10807.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <200309291610.10807.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <1064941061.1901.75.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-09-29 at 16:10, guy1656 wrote:
> This is REALLY getting frustrating:
> 
> I have an IOmega External ZIP drive (250MB)
> 
> It is simply a bitch to connect to my Mandrake 9.0 Box.
> 
> A good friend who first set up the system for me set it up so that I could 
> jist type "mount /mnt/zip" from a command window and it would behave, just 
> like say, mounting a floppy disk.
> 
> Then the computer changed, and figgured out how to disobey the command. Months 
> ago, when I posted to this forum, a kind soul suggested:
> 
>  mount -t vfat /dev/scsi/host0/bus0/target0/lun0/part4 /mnt/zip

This really should be the most reliable way of mounting the thing.  As
far as I can tell, there could only be four things that might have
changed;  the bus number, the target number, the lun number, or the
partition number.  The partition number will only change if you have
repartitioned the disk, try part1 instead.  The lun number probably
didn't change (I think only real scsi buses use it).  The target number
may have changed if you have plugged in some other USB device that acts
like a block device, try target1 instead.  The bus number might have
changed if you have plugged the drive into a different USB port, try
bus1 instead.

The log file should help out (/var/log/syslog), it should let you know
what it finds when the drive is plugged in.
> 
> ... and that was miraculous. Then one day it too stopped working. The computer 
> had figured out a way to beat me again.
> 
> So I installed VMWare and run W2K inside it. Because file system sharing in 
> VMW 4.0 is straightforward enough for me to learn, I could fire up W2K, plug 
> in my zip drive and have an info-box pop up ("W@#$# has found new Hardware: 
> ZIP 250") and I could transfer files from the zip drive to my home directory 
> (or whereever.)
> 
> Then computer got wise that I was actually getting things done, and I learned 
> about "rmmod usb-storage" and "modprobe usb-storage."

The results of these commands should show up in the syslog file.
> 
> But the computer has beaten me again: now VMWare won't even 'see' the USB 
> drive when I plug it in.
> 
> MY QUESTION:
> 
> Is there an rpm (download & double-click to install, from your file system 
> GUI) that will allow the ZIP drive to operate as flexibly as PLUG-n-PLAY is 
> supposed to be? (OK, I'll tolerate one or two shell commands such as 
> 'mount.')
> 
About the only thing I can think of is hotplug, but it most likely is
already installed.

HTH,

Derek Loree




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Sep 30 11:22:01 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue Sep 30 11:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] short usb and 2.4.20 saga
Message-ID: <20030930182103.D0E0D8F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Yesterday I decided switch to a usb keyboard and mouse.  Should be
simple these days, eh?  I was running a 2.4.20 kernel that I compiled
myself.  After connecting the keyboard, everything was fine in the bios
and grub, but the keyboard was dead after the kernel booted.  When I
switched back to redhat's 2.4.20 kernel, the keyboard would work.  I
checked my usb modules against the working redhat kernel.  Everything
seemed fine.  Extensive searching on google found that some people,
perhaps those with Via hardware, had usb keyboard problems around
2.4.20.  To make a long story short, the keyboard started working after
I moved to 2.4.22.

Maybe this will save someone here a few hours.

galen






From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Sep 30 11:34:01 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue Sep 30 11:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Library files and soft links
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309300814020.10236@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309300814020.10236@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3F79CC66.4010509@pacifier.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Will someone please tell me which of the /usr/lib/libcups and
> /usr/lib/libcupsimage are the real files and which are the soft links?
> That's become messed up here and I'd like to correct it properly on the
> first try.

If you installed an rpm, you can do

$ rpm -q --whatprovides /usr/lib/libcups.so.2

mine returns,
  cups-libs-1.1.14-15.4

then,
$  rpm -qilv cups-libs
<snip>
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root    root           111655 May 13 03:06 /usr/lib/libcups.so.2
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root    root            75802 May 13 03:06 
/usr/lib/libcupsimage.so.2

but there is one softlink libcupsdconf.so
so,
$ rpm -q --whatprovides /usr/lib/libcupsdconf.so
kdelibs-3.0.5a-0.73.2

and,
$ rpm -qilv kdelibs |grep libcups
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root    root           274709 Jul 14 07:57 
/usr/lib/libcupsdconf-gcc2.96.so
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root    root             1170 Jul 14 07:57 
/usr/lib/libcupsdconf.la
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root    root               23 Jul 14 08:15 
/usr/lib/libcupsdconf.so -> libcupsdconf-gcc2.96.so


Remember you need to use full path/filename for the -q switch.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Sep 30 12:16:01 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue Sep 30 12:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dialup internet access
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309301219520.16085-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

Since I got, first a hardware firewall with serial port (for a modem) and
then DSL I haven't had to deal with doing a dialup connection on a linux
box.  Back in the olden days I used diald which worked quite well but as
the kernel and distributions progressed diald seemed to disappear.  What
I've seen now requires manually making the connect and manually dropping
the connection or leaving it on full time.

We just got a call for setting up a SUSE machine and I've never dealt with
it besides looking at the box and watching someone else install it
stand-alone.
    Anyone using dialup access using just their distributions tools?  If
not what are you using?  I'm interested in all distributions and tricks.


TIA,
Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From marcpootmans at yahoo.com  Tue Sep 30 13:16:02 2003
From: marcpootmans at yahoo.com (Marc Pootmans)
Date: Tue Sep 30 13:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Canadian major ISP appear to be blocking a website
Message-ID: <20030930201602.69984.qmail@web20003.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi all,
  I'm tech rep on a website hosted in Portland by a linux group (linuforall) maintainer who has a direct dsl line to the net.
  The website owner has no, or irregular access to the site, and thus to his mail server as well. All other customers of the same isp Shaw Cable in Vancouver Canada have no access to his site either. Customers of ISP Telus DSL all have access. I have reliable access here, as do friends in Canada, USA and abroad. 
  His ISP claims the web host may be blocking them, or a DNS "push" may be the problem. So far they are looking into it, but claiming it isn't their problem. 
  The LUG web-hoster has confirmed he blocks no one.
  Without asking legal advice, my questions are
1) Does the technology exist (major ISP hardware and software) to block access to individual sites? Is it possible? Can it 'reasonably' happen by accident, or only intentionally?
2) Who would be best web contact orgs responsible for controlling, preventing or stopping such censorship, not just whining about it? (yes I am googling - so vast)
  The website owner previously discovered this same company doing religious censorship in their public kiosk computer terminals and has a Canadian Radio telecommunications Commision (CRTC) complaint over those events as do I. 
  His business is suffering due to his inability to access his website and mail.
  
Thanks all.
Marc

Do you Yahoo!?

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Sep 30 14:23:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Sep 30 14:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Canadian major ISP appear to be blocking a website
In-Reply-To: <20030930201602.69984.qmail@web20003.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030930201602.69984.qmail@web20003.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309301347330.10999@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Marc Pootmans wrote:

>   Without asking legal advice, my questions are

Question 0 ought to be, What troubleshooting steps can he take to
document the problem?

* Run a traceroute from his home computer to www.linuxforall.com to
  ensure that basic routing is in place. It may be that the ISP's
  internal routing tables are mucked up.

* Run dig/host in various ways against linuxforall.com and
  findmoore.net to ensure the nameservers, mail exchanges, etc. are
  configured correctly.

My cursory reading is that DNS is misconfigured for these domains.

Two of the four NS records for both domains point to non-existent
hosts:

  [tmp]$ for h in $(dig linuxforall.com ns +short); do host $h; done
  ns1.findmoore.com has address 208.187.227.114
  Host ns2.findmoore.net not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
  Host ns3.findmoore.net not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
  ns0.findmoore.com has address 208.187.227.113

Of the two valid names, one doesn't have a valid reverse pointer:

  [tmp]$ host ns1.findmoore.com
  ns1.findmoore.com has address 208.187.227.114
  [tmp]$ host 208.187.227.114
  Host 114.227.187.208.in-addr.arpa not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)

Additionally, the primary and secondary MX servers for linuxforall.com
are the same host:

  [tmp]$ dig linuxforall.com mx +short
  20 smtp.linuxforall.com.
  10 mail.linuxforall.com.
  [tmp]$ host smtp.linuxforall.com
  smtp.linuxforall.com has address 208.187.227.113
  [tmp]$ host mail.linuxforall.com
  mail.linuxforall.com has address 208.187.227.113

> 1) Does the technology exist (major ISP hardware and software) to
>    block access to individual sites? Is it possible? Can it
>    'reasonably' happen by accident, or only intentionally?

At this point, I'm more likely to believe the trouble is a DNS
misconfiguration than any form of censorship, intentional or
otherwise.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From pem at nellump.net  Tue Sep 30 14:44:01 2003
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Tue Sep 30 14:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] LaTeX in the real world
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309291443140.25972@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309291332310.1425-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0309291443140.25972@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20030930214251.GE646@nellump.net>

On Mon, Sep 29, 2003 at 02:43:47PM -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> Ahem.  Reply-To: munging strikes again.
> 
> Is there anyone here using so broken a mail client that we can't make this
> work properly?

The following procmail directive works for me and my mutt:

   # re-munge PLUG list's reply-to headers while sorting
   :0:
   * ^List-Post:.*plug at lists.pdxlinux
   | /usr/bin/formail -R "Reply-To" "X-Reply-To" >> l-plug

It may not be *pure* (since there's no "Reply-To" at all after it's done,
I'm assuming it must use the "From" header), but it does work.


- Paul, who can't take credit for the above hack. Someone else here
thought of it first.



From raanders at acm.org  Tue Sep 30 14:50:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue Sep 30 14:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dialup internet access
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0309301348190.10917@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0309301437440.17160-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Rod,
> 
>   Have you looked at the diald project on sourceforge?
>                   <http://sourceforge.net/projects/diald/>

I did several months, well actually many months ago, and it seems to have
gone stale - really stale.  It is up to version 1.0 but the docs (FAQs)  
reflect version 0.16.5.
   Diald was great when I used it.  In fact I installed it for several 
businesses and churches years ago.  I believe some are still using it but 
the slip gateway interface wasn't optimal and using the TUN (or another 
interface which I can't remember) wasn't documented worth diddly.  I then 
got, as I mentioned, a hardware firewall and diald wasn't needed any more.

Sad long store that.  The real downer is diald doesn't appear to be 
included with any distribution so it has to be found, packaged (floppy, 
CD), then loaded and configured.
   Well I might be doing this for our customers.  We anticipate an 
increase in linux users and in fact advertise we support Linux (just 
servers at this time  :-).

Thanks for reminding me of the sourceforge project.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."




From carla at bratgrrl.com  Tue Sep 30 14:51:02 2003
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Tue Sep 30 14:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Canadian major ISP appear to be blocking a website
In-Reply-To: <20030930201602.69984.qmail@web20003.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030930201602.69984.qmail@web20003.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200309301456.20964.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Tuesday 30 September 2003 1:16 pm, Marc Pootmans wrote:
> Hi all,
>   I'm tech rep on a website hosted in Portland by a linux group
> (linuforall) maintainer who has a direct dsl line to the net. The website
> owner has no, or irregular access to the site, and thus to his mail server
> as well. All other customers of the same isp Shaw Cable in Vancouver Canada
> have no access to his site either. Customers of ISP Telus DSL all have
> access. I have reliable access here, as do friends in Canada, USA and
> abroad. His ISP claims the web host may be blocking them, or a DNS "push"
> may be the problem. So far they are looking into it, but claiming it isn't
> their problem. The LUG web-hoster has confirmed he blocks no one.

First of all check to see if the site is on any RBLs. samspade.org checks all 
the major ones at once.

>   Without asking legal advice, my questions are
> 1) Does the technology exist (major ISP hardware and software) to block
> access to individual sites? Is it possible? Can it 'reasonably' happen by
> accident, or only intentionally? 

Sure, it's common to block by IP as a means of spam or content control. It 
could happen 'accidentally' if the site is part of larger netblock that is 
being blocked. There are also all kinds of content filters, like Net Nanny.

2) Who would be best web contact orgs
> responsible for controlling, preventing or stopping such censorship, not
> just whining about it? (yes I am googling - so vast) The website owner
> previously discovered this same company doing religious censorship in their
> public kiosk computer terminals and has a Canadian Radio telecommunications
> Commision (CRTC) complaint over those events as do I. His business is
> suffering due to his inability to access his website and mail.
>

"My server, my rules". If a private ISP wishes to filter traffic, that's their 
privilege. Absent any law compelling them to allow your traffic on their 
network, they don't have to. But you probably want to find out for sure 
before anything else. Like ask them directly?

--
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
www.tuxcomputing.com
this message brought to you
by Libranet 2.8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:

>    Diald was great when I used it.  In fact I installed it for several 
> businesses and churches years ago.

I previously used diald as well.  What I remember from the tail end of
that time period was that demand dialing capabilities of ppp were
becoming preferred over diald.  Have you investigated the current linux
ppp implementation?  It may already do what you want.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Sep 30 15:33:02 2003
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Sep 30 15:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Dialup internet access 
In-Reply-To: <20030930220151.32C998F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <20030930220151.32C998F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0309301528530.10999@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

I don't use modem connections any longer (though I ought to have it
configured, at least), but it appears that recent Red Hat
distributions use wvdial to handle modem configuration and PPP
connections:

  http://open.nit.ca/wiki/?page=WvDial

It appears that Red Hat, SuSE, and Debian all can/do include wvdial
packages at installation time.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue Sep 30 17:02:01 2003
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue Sep 30 17:02:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pdf, postscript and text
In-Reply-To: <28454-21217@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309301651500.447-100000@aluminum.bavariati.org>

On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Steve Bonds wrote:
> On Mon, 29 Sep 2003, Aaron Burt aaron-at-speakeasy.org |PDX Linux| wrote:
> > >From the sound of it (beeeg PS files, no text) these are PDFs containing
> > bitmaps of printed or scanned output.  In other words, you don't have
> > text, just pictures of text.  Does the text select tool in acroread work?
>
> If this is the case, how did it used to work?  Are these new/different PS
> files than before?

No, just wastefully generated ones.

> How are the PS files actually created?  Do you have any control over that
> process?  I.e. could you get them to stop pasting images of text into Word
> before they print and run it through their own OCR first like they used
> to?  ;-)

Heh.
Likely, these folks are opening the file in Wurd and printing to the Adobe
Acrobat PDF print driver, which looks like a printer but generates PDFs.
I don't know what particular setting would make that combo generate bitmap
PDFs, but it sounds like they've unfortunately hit on it.  If you can
figure out exactly what to change, and who to ask nicely, you might be
able to get 'em to change it on the grounds that the PDFs will then be
much smaller, thus making 'em available to folks with dialup.  Heck, they
may even be small enough to fit on a floppy.

A "plain text?  what's that?" B

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Tue Sep 30 21:19:23 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Tue Sep 30 21:19:23 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What a mess...  No reverse record for this PCC site...
In-Reply-To: <1064977290.1802.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309302050120.28747-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On 30 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

>Sep 29 14:44:39 goose postfix/smtpd[28525]: reject: RCPT from
>unknown[209.152.33.41]: 450 Client host rejected: cannot find your
>hostname, [209.152.33.41]; from=<jkissick at pcc.edu>
>to=<michael at goose.robinson-west.com>
>Sep 29 14:48:54 goose postfix/smtpd[28531]: reject: RCPT from
>unknown[209.152.33.41]: 450 Client host rejected: cannot find your
>hostname, [209.152.33.41]; from=<vschroed at pcc.edu>
>to=<michael at goose.robinson-west.com>
>
>pcc.edu has address 209.152.61.185
>
>I'm guessing PCC is allowing a server to send
>email out that is not masqueraded for or reverse 
>registered properly?
>
>Is there a way I can inject a PTR record into my own
>dns servers that 209.152.33.41 goes to pcc.edu?
>
>     --  Michael C. Robinson

So Michael, you ever feel like you are tilting at windmills?

I've been down this path, and I decided that banging my head 
against the monitor did not offer sufficient yields.

There seem to be very few fundamental rules of the internet. Just
about the time you think you have things nailed down, all the
rules change. Well, most of the rules change - you can trust
that a few of the rules will remain the same.

Take DNS for an example. There have been all sorts of cool tricks
done with DNS over the years. Dynamic DNS, Hesiod, all those weird
things active directory does, IP over DNS, etc, etc. The one constant
throughout the history of DNS is that everyone gets it wrong.

The expectation that every domain's DNS should be 100% correct is the
path of a long and painful net experience.


Rather than trying to add your own DNS records for every site on the
net that does not meet your expectations, you may want to reallocate
that time to investigating alternate paths.

Spam detection has become an advanced science. There is a significant
body of recent anti-spam literature available that is much more likely
to lead you to the spam-free nirvana than the crude methodology of
relying on correct PTR records.


-Eric

--
http://www.google.com/search?q=spam




From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Tue Sep 30 22:11:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Tue Sep 30 22:11:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What a mess...  No reverse record for this PCC site...
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0309302050120.28747-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0309302050120.28747-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <1064984913.2512.49.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> So Michael, you ever feel like you are tilting at windmills?

The purpose of DNS is to identify hosts and networks 
without having to know ip addresses.  If trusted responsible 
authorities took care of the PTR zones for all Internet 
sites, that would help.  Fortunately, it looks like I 
finally got Postfix's access table hooked up allowing 
me to punch addresses I know I shouldn't block through.  

I suppose I can do a program that filters email after 
receiving it, but I want to block the data rude people
want to send me.  Internet clients need 
reliable dns, face it that having to use the numbers 
would be absolutely ridiculous and highly error prone
especially considering that so many of the numbers are
in address pools.

The alternative is to throw away source as a filtering
criteria and accept connections from anywhere.  This 
approach cannot address denial of service from mail 
floods though.

Is there no way to encourage sites to set up DNS
correctly?  Is dns a hopelessly untested system?
It's seems ridiculous that people are giving up
on determining intent before allowing anyone to 
connect to their server and inject data or
programs into it.  Maybe a filter will keep
the inbox clean, but downloading a message and
the deleting it without any intention of 
reading it is downright inefficient.

I found this link on www.rpmfind.net and is a link to a relatively new 
version of SUSE (I think).

ftp://216.254.0.38/linux/SuSE-Linux/i386/8.2/suse/src/diald-1.0-187.src.rpm

This is a binary version also.

The interface it used was, IIRC, ethertap.  You could manage more that 
just ppp links.  And I liked the diald-ctl tool to monitor the link in 
real time.  Truely a shame it is not being developed anymore.




From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Tue Sep 30 23:13:02 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Tue Sep 30 23:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] What a mess...  No reverse record for this PCC site...
In-Reply-To: <1064984913.2512.49.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0309302218380.28747-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On 30 Sep 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

>> So Michael, you ever feel like you are tilting at windmills?
>
>The purpose of DNS is to identify hosts and networks 
>without having to know ip addresses.  If trusted responsible 
>authorities took care of the PTR zones for all Internet 
>sites, that would help.  Fortunately, it looks like I 
>finally got Postfix's access table hooked up allowing 
>me to punch addresses I know I shouldn't block through.  

PTR records point an IP address back to name. Your average
shmuck only cares about A & CNAME records, the mappings of
a name to the IP address. From time-to-time, you find someone
who knows what a MX record is.

Reverse lookups seem to be a fading fad.

>I suppose I can do a program that filters email after 
>receiving it, but I want to block the data rude people
>want to send me.  Internet clients need 
>reliable dns, face it that having to use the numbers 
>would be absolutely ridiculous and highly error prone
>especially considering that so many of the numbers are
>in address pools.

Converting a name to an IP is handled by A & CNAME
records. As we are all too-painfully-aware, the 
internet can indeed function without PTR records,
more often than not anyways.

>The alternative is to throw away source as a filtering
>criteria and accept connections from anywhere.  This 
>approach cannot address denial of service from mail 
>floods though.

Huh? What exactly is the correlation between spam,
PTR records, IP addresses, and DOS attacks?  If the
lack of PTR records leads to indefensible DOS attacks
we're all in trouble, since the bad-guys are in control
of the PTR records...

>Is there no way to encourage sites to set up DNS
>correctly?  Is dns a hopelessly untested system?

I see that you are starting to get the concept!

>It's seems ridiculous that people are giving up
>on determining intent before allowing anyone to 
>connect to their server and inject data or
>programs into it.  Maybe a filter will keep
>the inbox clean, but downloading a message and
>the deleting it without any intention of 
>reading it is downright inefficient.

I have read only a small portion of this on-going
thread, so I may have missed something important,
but from my statistical sampling all I've seen have
been comments about how 100% correct DNS is required
for proper spam filtering.

If my impression is correct, you need to sit down
awhile and think through the implications of spam
being sent from servers with correct DNS information.

The vast majority of spam I see, and that my users forward
to me, come from "xasd342sdf at hotmail.com", compromised servers
(correct DNS != patched/properly configured servers), and other
such attrocities that have nothing to do with DNS what-so-ever.

Michael, many of us here agree with you that the state of
DNS records tends to be dismal at best. It has been bad
for a long time, and is gradually getting worse. Fight it
if you wish, I wish you luck.

But before you go, re-read this sentence you wrote:

>It's seems ridiculous that people are giving up
>on determining intent before allowing anyone to
>connect to their server and inject data or
>programs into it. 

How much information can you glean from a syn bit?
Is it possible to determine intent before allowing
a connection to your mail exchanger?

Is it possible for the "bad guys" to forge every single
bit of information required to establish a connection?


My comments are not focused on "giving up", they are
intended to point out an approach to this problem that does
not work in most cases. The only thing that whining about
the sad state of DNS seems to accomplish is annoying the
sysadmins on the list who have to live with the sad state
of DNS...

-Eric

This is in the dmesg:
usb.c: registered new driver usbdevfs
usb.c: registered new driver hub
usb-uhci.c: $Revision: 1.251 $ time 20:53:29 Apr  8 2001
usb-uhci.c: High bandwidth mode enabled
PCI: Found IRQ 12 for device 00:04.2

usb-uhci.c: Detected 2 ports
usb.c: new USB bus registered, assigned bus number 1
hub.c: USB hub found
hub.c: 2 ports detected


I cannot find any package, man file or anything that has anything to do with 
these. It looks like I could remove all of the usb devices from /dev and the init 
script would not load it, but that seems crude.

Any other suggestions?

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Sep 30 23:36:01 2003
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue Sep 30 23:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how to remove usb
In-Reply-To: <0674JD62LF63GEVRJWVYV09A0FEJIN.3f7a7352@miked>

On Tue, 2003-09-30 at 23:25, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> RH 7.1, I want usb support out. This server will never need it.

Recompile your kernel without USB support, remove Hotplug if it's
installed, and then any USB utilities RH may have installed (although I
really don't know what those might be).

Then you'll be USB free.  :-)

Rob




From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Tue Sep 30 23:41:01 2003
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue Sep 30 23:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] latest RH kernel
Message-ID: <WRKFOI5Y74EB2WC8D0QHEKJUT5YUPE0.3f7a76c6@miked>

So, I've got this RH 7.1 system I admin about 70 minutes from my house, when 
there's no traffic. I'm a good sysadmin, so I keep it patched.

It goes down occasionaly, I think there's a very marginal glitch in the swap 
partition. While I'm convincing the customer to replace the server or upgrade it 
to use SCSI drives, it goes down today. On reboot, it has fits and runs a couple 
of hours and locks up. Starts spewing all kinds of IDE errors. I'm thinking that 
the drive is going catastrophically. The customer can't wait another 20 minutes 
for me to show up on site and tries another reboot. This time, it wants a system 
disk. Cr--, I'm thinking. It's dead. Customer had set the drive to none in the 
BIOS.

I take the errors that I got over the phone, and google them. Turns out that the 
newest kernel does not like the PII, PIIx based IDE controller. Rebooted with the 
last kernel, and, viola, no more IDE errors.

Hope this helps somebody. I know it's bad to leave unknowns un-rebooted, but it's 
so easy to do when it's not handy to watch it reboot.

Mike De La Mater
Small business networks and technology consulting
503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com
